Mr. Stanfield voted for Mr. Austin.

The CHAIRMAN. The whole number of votes cast here is 97. Jonathan W. Gordon having received 50 of these, which is a majority, I declare him to be duly elected Speaker of the present House of Representatives. The gentleman from Jefferson (Mr. Branham) and the gentleman from Vanderburgh (Mr. Blythe) will conduct the Speaker to the Chair.
This service being performed -

This service being performedThe SPEAKER returned his thanks appropriately for this renewed expression of the confidence of the House of Representatives; introducing again the argument for the permanency of the organization at the opening of the extra session. [The address is withheld for authentication and will be printed hereafter.]
On motion by Mr. HUNTER, the Speaker now received his official oath at the hand of Mr. Davis.
Mr. DEVOL submitted a resolution to declare the re-election of the Clerks and Police of the extra session, which, upon objection, he withdrew.
On motion by Mr. RITTER, the House proceeded to the election of a Principal Clerk.
Mr. SHIELDS nominated Richard J. Ryan.
Mr. PARRETT nominated John P. Dunn.
Mr. Ryan received 54 votes.
Mr. Dunn received 46 votes.
Mr. Ryan having received a majority of the hundred votes cast, was declared by the Speaker to be duly elected Principal Clerk of the House of Representatives.
The remainder of the officials of the extra session were then re-elected in the following order:
For First Assistant Clerk - George H. Chapman received 53 votes; Ellia E. Campbell received 45 votes.
For Door-keeper - For Door-keeper.Robert Jennings, of Floyd, received 53 votes; Henry Achey, of Marion, received 44 votes.
So George H. Chapman was declared to be duly elected First Assistant Clerk, and Robert Jennings Door-keeper; and the Clerks and Door-keeper received their oath of office at the hand of the Speaker
Mr. GIFFORD submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved, That the Senate be informed that the House of Representatives has organized, by electing Hon. Jonathan W. Gordon, Speaker; Richard J. Ryan, Principal Clerk; George H. Chapman, Assistant Clerk; Robert Jennings, Door-keeper; and that they are ready to proceed to legislative business.

A message from the Senate, by Mr. Vawter, their Secretary, now announced the organization and election of officers of that body, and their readiness to proceed to business; and also the appointment of a committee to act with a similar committee on the part of the House of Representatives to wait on his Excellency, the Governor, and inquire when it will be convenient for him to deliver his biennial message
On motion by Mr. RITTER, the resolution creating these committees was concurred in; and the Speaker appointed Messrs. Ritter, Davis and Blythe, on the part of the House of Representatives.
The House then, at 3:38 o'clock, adjourned.

div.head: MESSAGE FROM THE HOUSE.
div.p: A message from the House of Representatives announced the organization of that body by the election of Jonathan W. Gordon, Speaker; R. J. Ryan, Clerk; G. H. Chapman, Assistant; and Robert Jennings, Door-keeper.
Also, that the House has appointed Messrs. Ritter, Davis and Blythe, a committee on the part of that body to act with the committee appointed by the Senate to wait upon the Governor.
The PRESIDENT pro tempore laid before the Senate the order of business, (being the same as was adopted at the last session.)
Mr. HEFFREN asked and obtained leave to make a report as follows:

MR. PRESIDENT : The select committee appointed by the Senate to act with a like committee on the part of the House to wait upon His Excellency, the Governor, and see at what time it would be convenient for him to deliver his message to this General Assembly, have performed that duty, and report that it will suit his convenience to attend to that duty in the Hall of the House to-day, at 2 o'clock, P. M.

div.head: NEWSPAPERS AND REPORTING.
div.p: Mr. GREEN offered the following:

Resolved,That the Door-keeper be directed to contract for and place upon the desks of the members and officers of the Senate, three copies each of the Daily Journal and Daily Sentinel, also, three of the Weekly American, Volksblatt and Fres Press; two of the aforesaid to be wrapped and stamped ready for mailing.
Mr. CONNER. A select committee was appointed on yesterday to inquire into the cost of employing an official Reporter, and I think it improper to act upon this resolution until that committee report.

Mr. GREEN. Yesterday there was a resolution adopted to inquire into the expediency of having a regular Reporter for this body; and this resolution brings before us directly the question of expediency, which plan we will adopt take the papers as heretofore, or employ a Reporter. Every man in the State wants to know, and feels an interest in how his representative acts and votes upon certain questions; and the report of our proceedings is what I want to send to the country. I put in the weekly American because the reports in that paper have been more full than in any paper that has a reporter on this floor.

Mr. HEFFREN. The calculations made by the committee on employing a Reporter, show that for the sixty-one days of this session the cost will not amount to half as much as was spent in the thirty-six days of the last session of the Senate, for newspapers alone. I move to refer this resolution to the select committee appointed yesterday, with reference to the employment of a Reporter.
Mr. BOBBS. I would inquire, if the Senate procure a Reporter, whether the daily papers will publish the proceedings?
Mr. HEFFREN. The proceedings will be published in the form of the Legislative Sentinel of the last session. The Reporter does it himself. No public printer, or anything else about it
Mr. BOBBS. That paper came out in sheets some week or two after the proceedings had transpired, and until I have some knowledge that the papers will publish our reports, I am not prepared to vote.

Mr. CONNER. The discussion of this resolution is premature, and inasmuch as a motion has been made to refer this resolution to a committee, I move to amend the motion so that it shall require that committee to inquire into the expediency of taking those papers.
Mr. MURRAY thought the papers would publish the reports if the Senate would furnish them. But the trouble was the heavy expense attending the employment of a Stenographer.
Mr. BOBBS offered the following amendment to the resolution:

p.hi: " That the committee be directed to ascertain upon what terms the daily papers will publish the daily proceedings of the Senate upon the Senate furnishing such report."

div.p: The amndment was adopted by consent.
Mr. GREEN moved to amend the motion to refer so as to give the resolution into the hands of a select committee of three.
Mr. WEIR and Mr. TARKINGTON favored the amendment to the motion to refer.
Mr. GOODING moved to amend the resolution by including three copies of the Daily Citizen.
Mr. MURRAY thought it best to refer this matter to a select committee.

Mr. JOHNSTON. The committee on the reporter have not reported. Now, sir, I propose to wait until that report comes in before we take any action in this matter. I there
fore move that the resolution and pending amendment be laid on the table.
The motion was agreed to upon a division of the Senate - 24 to 20.

div.head: QUALIFICATIONS OF MEMBERS.
div.p: Mr. HEFFREN offered the following preamble and resolution:

WHEREAS, Under section 16 of Article 7 of the Constitution of the State of Indiana declares that "no person elected to any judicial office shall, during the term for which he shall have been elected, be eligible to any office of trust and profit under the State other than a judicial officer: and whereas, it is believed that Hon. Hugh Miller, Hon. Walter March, and Hon. D. S. Gooding, were each holding the office of Judge of the Court of Common Pleas in their respective Common Pleas Districts, and which term of office as said Judge of said Court extended and continued until the first day of January next, after the electien held in October, 1856, at which time it was pretended that said persons were elected as Senators: and whereas, it being desirable that a proper construction of the said section should be had upon this point: Therefore,

Resolved, That a select committee of five be appointed by the Chairman to inquire and examine into and report whether the persons named in the preamble are entitled to their seats in this body, in accordance with said section 16 of the Constitution
Mr. HEFFREN. This is merely a resolution of inquiry. I have not yet examined the matter sufficiently to state what my opinion would be.
Mr. MARCH denied that the Supreme Court or any other body has the right to go behind the decisions of the Senate upon the qualifications of its own members.
Mr. JOHNSTON held the same doctrine to be true, and that when the Senate has once settled the question, it cannot be changed.
Mr. TARKINGTON. It is clear that the Senate has a right to look into and examine the facts as to the legal election of its members at any time it sees fit to do so.
Mr. McLEAN. I think this resolution is ill-timed. The proper time to investigate this matter was in 1857

Mr. GOODING. I would scorn to hold a seat in this body in defiance of the Constitution of my State, or the will of the people I represent. I investigated this matter fully before I became a candidate for this place. This question shall be for the Senate to decide, without any interference on my part.
Mr. BOBBS was opposed, to raising this question at this time.
Mr. JOHNSTON denied the right of the Senate to reconsider a vote, or reverse a decision made two years ago.
Mr. COBB. When a member of the Senate comes here and is sworn in, he is prima facia entitled to his seat.
Mr. MURRAY held that the Senate had the right to examine into the rights of its members to hold their seats at any time.
The resolution was adopted - yeas 21, nays 20.
The PRESIDENT, pro tem., makes the committee to consist of Senators Heffren, Murray, Conner, Bennett and Authony.

On motion of Mr. MARCH, the message from the House of Representatives inviting the Senate to meet in the Hall of the House this afternoon at 2 o'clock to receive the Governor's communication, was taken up and concurred in nemine contradicente.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Mr. CONNER. Mr. President, the hour of two has arrived. I move that the Senate how proceed to the Hall of the House of Representatives to hear the Governor's message.
The motion was agreed to, and the Senate, preceded by the PRESIDENT, pro tem., vacated the Chamber.
When the Senate returned -
Mr. WALLACE offered the following:
Resolved,That when the Senate adjourns it stands adjourned till Monday at 2 o'clock P. M.
The resolution was adopted by consent.
The Senate adjourned.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
div.p: Mr. TURPIE submitted the following, which was adopted:
Resolved,for the last regular session, be adopted as the Rules of this House until further ordered.>
Mr. AUSTIN submitted a resolution for a committee of three, to prepare and report rules for the government of this House, which was adopted.
Mr. MURRAY submitted the following, which was adopted:
Resolved, That newspaper reporters be allowed seats inside the bar, for the purpose of reporting the proceedings of this House.

div.head: REPORTER TO THE HOUSE - NEWSPAPERS.

div.p: Resolved,That a committee of five be appointed to inquire into the expediency of employing a reporter for this House, whose duty it shall be to make full reports of the proceedings, and cause the same to be published in the form of The Legislative Sentinel; and that said committee make inquiry into the cost of furnishing each member of the House with four copies of the same.

Mr. SCOTT. You are aware, sir, that the cost of furnishing papers as heretofore provided, is a very expensive item. If something of this kind could be devised, which would cost much less, and yet afford us the means of keeping our constituents informed of our proceedings here, would it not be well to adopt a resolution of this kind, to inquire into it ? That is all I wish. I do not know what would be the expense. The committee could ascertain that.

Mr. MURRAY. I am opposed to that resolution. I do not think it could operate well in any way. It is true, if we should employ a reporter to take our proceedings in full and publish them in full, it would be a very nice thing to look at and get bound into a book; but it could subserve no other purpose whatever. Now we take a certain number of papers, who employ their own reporters, and they give to the public all that is necessary of
our entire proceedings. If we have a reporter report the proceedings in full, there is not a paper in the city that could get the entire report into their columns. Then we should have to hire not only a reporter to report our proceedings, but also to publish them; and if this were done, we could not then afford to purchase a sufficient number of copies of that paper to send to our constituents. They would have to remain here and be bound up simply our accommodation. There is no practicality in the resolution, and it ought to be voted down.

Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone. I had prepared a resolution on the same subject, differing in details from this, and perhaps obviating the objections of the gentleman from Elkhart. At the last session our newspapers cost some twelve or thirteen hundred dollars. This is proposed as a substitute for the old practice. But four copies of one paper are to be taken. Last session we took three copies of five papers. I undertake to say we can have a reporter at one-fourth part of the expense of papers, from whom all the papers can have their reports free of charge. The proposition does not interfere with the right accorded to reporters to sit here, but it obviates the necessity of taking three or four copies of each of the city papers. My friend from Elkhart seems to go upon the presumption that we must take the city papers in addition. I am opposed to that, and in my resolution I have provided that these authorized reports shall be taken in lieu of the newspapers.
Mr. SCOTT. That is the object of my resolution.

Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren. Whatever we do, we should do promptly. Whether we had paid too much for newspapers, he knew not, but thought still that the money was well expended. He objected to all waste of words upon this proposition, as far more expensive than the newspapers.
Mr. MURRAY proposed to amend by striking out and inserting

That the Door-keeper contract with the publishers of the Indiana State Journal, the Indiana State Sentinel, the Indiana American, and the two German papers printed in Indianapolis, for three copies of each of their papers for the use of the members of this House, two copies of each to be enveloped and stamped.

Mr. SCOTT. My resolution was to prevent that. It was that the reporter furnish four copies of the proceedings of the day previous; so that we may not have newspapers lying uselessly about the Capitol. It -was to reduce the expenses of the Legislature in this respect. The member from Elkhart, at the last session, was among the foremost for economy, and it is my object to carry out the gentleman's principle-so that the House shall not expend $2,000 for newspapers this session. I have no other object whatever in view.
Mr. CAVINS proposed to amend the amendment by adding three copies of the Daily Citizen.
The proposition was rejected.
Mr. WATERMAN submitted the following:
"Amend so as to allow each member to designate what papers he will takethe amount not to exceed that of the number in the resolution."
The amendment to the amendment was adopted.
Mr. MURRAY now moved to lay the resolution and amendments on the table - demanding the yeas and nays, which being ordered and taken, resulted - yeas 30, nays 62 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Boyd, Cavins, Clayton, Comstock, Cotton, Davidson, Davis, Dougherty, Devol, Hall of Rush, Hamilton of Boone, Hamilton of Wayne, Harney, Harrison, Hartley, Hunter, Johnston, Knowlton, Murray, Martin, Ritter, Robinson, Row, Rynerson, Shields, Shockley, Stanfield, Thompson of Elkhart, Whetzel, and Mr. Speaker-30.

NAYS Messrs. Austin, Baird, Black, Blythe, Bowman, Boxley, Brotherton, Carr, Clark, Claypool, Clements, Colgrove, Collier, Dobbins, Durham, Early, Eastham, Edwards, Firestone, Gifford, Gregory, Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hancock, Jeffries, Jones, Jordan, Kelley, Kempf, Lawhead, Lewis, McLain, Mansfield, Massey, Mellett, Merrifield, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Nelson, Newton, Parks, Parrett, Power, Prosser, Scott, Sherman, Shall, Smith of Miami, Snyder, Stanley, Stiles, Sullivan, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of Madison, Treadway, Turpie, Usrey, Waterman, Wheeler, Whiteman and Wood - 62
So the House refused to lay on the table, and the question recurred on the adoption of the amendment as amended.

Mr. HUNTER. I hope the original resolution will prevail. At the commencement of the last session I offered a similar resolution to employ a reporter. This is merely to inquire into the expense. It is not binding on the House or the committee. Gentlemen think the proposition expensive. What is the fact? Instead of one, we now employ five or six reporters, and take their papers beside. Gentlemen may say we do not pay the reporters; but we add enough to the cost of the papers to pay them, and so we do substantially pay the reporters. Gentlemen may say we need these papers for the purpose of informing our constituents of our proceedings here. But I say there was not a paper went out from this city during the last session, from the reading of which alone a person could gain a full knowledge of the proceedings of this House. They are political papers, and, as a matter of course, they give a coloring to their reports. I do not say the Journal is more fair than the Sentinel. I think one about as fair as the other. Take the Journal, for example. One gentleman has his speech reported in full, and another has a mere description - a little paragraph. There is neither a full nor a fair report. And if we take up the Sentinelthere is the same partiality and want of fullness. So when gentlemen say we want these papers to inform our constituents of our proceedings, it is not the fact. I go then for employing reporters, as a matter of economy, and to secure fairness and completeness in, the reports, &c.
Mr. DEVOL submitted the following by way of substitute:

Resolved, That in the opinion of this House, it is inexpedient for the House to subscribe for any newspaper to be paid for out of the funds of the State, or to pay anything for reporting the proceedings of this House.
On the motion of Mr. KEEFER, this proposition was laid on the table, by yeas 67, nays 27; and the question again recurred on the adoption of Mr. Murray's amendment, as amended.
Mr. FIRESTONE demanded the previous question.
Mr. RITTER. I desire, in this connection, to enquire what has become of the Legislative Sentinel?
The SPEAKER. The Chair is informed that it is printed and ready to be laid on the desks of members.
Mr. RITTER. In binding?
The SPEAKER. The Chair is not informed as to that.
Mr. RITTER. At the proper time we will attend to that Legislative Sentinel.

Mr. HARNEY. (By leave.) It looks to me that this proposition is wholly impracticable and absurd. It is expected that the proceedings of the House are to be published in full; that will involve the publication of the debates and a double publication of the journals, and that would be an improvident waste of the public money. It is infinitely better to have our proceedings reported by men outside of the influence of this Hall, than to make them creatures of the Legislature. It is to me a plan got up to enable gentlemen to obtain reports of their speeches at the public expense, or in some way more congenial to their feelings than they would be likely to get at the hand of outsiders. The scheme is new, untried and1 impracticable, and would make us ridiculous-in the eyes of our constituents and the world.
The previous question being now seconded, the yeas and nays on the main question re-resulted - yeas 33, nays 58 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Clark, Clements, Dobbins, Early, Firestone, Gifford, Hancock, Harney, Jones, Jordan, Keefer, Kempf, Knowlton, Lawhead, McLain, Massey, Merrifield, Nebeker of Warren, Nelson Shields, Shull, Smith of Perry, Snyder, Stanley, Stiles, Sullivan, Summers, Turpie, Waterman, Wheeler, Wildman, Wood. Mr. Speaker - 33.

NAYS-Messrs. Austin, Baird, Black, Blythe, Bowman, Boyd, Boxley, Brotherton, Carr, Cavins, Claypool, Clayton, Colgrove, Collier, Comstock, Cotton, Davidson, Davis, Dougherty, Durham, Devol, Edwards, Gregory, Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hall of Rush, Hamilton of Boone, Hamilton of Wayne, Harrison, Hartley, Hunter, Jeffries, Johnston, Kelly, Lewis, Mansfield, Mellett, Miller, Murray, Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion, Newton, Parks, Prosser, Ritter, Robinson, Row, Scott, Sherman, Shockley, Smith of Miami,Stanfield, Tebbs, Thompson of Elkhart, Thompson of Madison, Treadway, Usrey, Whetzel. Whiteman - 58
So the amendments were lost, and the question recurred on the adoption of the original resolution.
Mr. MURRAY moved to lay the resolution an the table, demanding the yeas and nays, which resulted - yeas 67, nays 28 - as follows:

YEAS.Messrs. Blythe, Bowman, Boyd, Brotherton, Carr, Cavins, Clark, Claypool, Clayton, Clements, Colgrove. Collier, Davis, Dobbins, Doueherty, Devol, Early, Firestone, Gifford, Griffin, Hancock, Harney. Harrison, Hartley, Jones, Jordan, Keefer, Kelly, Kempf, Knowlton, Lawhead, Lewis, McLain, Major, Mansfield. Massey, Merrifield, Miller, Murray, Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Nelson, Parrett, Prosser, Ritter, Row, Rynearson, Shields, Shockley, Shull, Smith of Miami, Smith of Perry, Snyder, Stanley, Stanfield, Stiles, Sullivan, Summers, Thompson of Elkhart, Thompson of Madison, Turpie, Waterman, Wheeler, Whetzel, Wildman, and Wood - 67.

NAYS. Messrs. Austin. Black, Boxley, Comstock, Cotton, Davidson, Durham, Edwards, Gregory, Hall of Grant, Hall of Rush, Hamilton of Boone, Hamilton of Wayne, Hunter, Jeffries, Johnston, Mellet,Newton, Parks, Power, Robinson, Scott, Sherman, Tebbs, Treadway, Usrey, and Mr. Speaker. - 28
So the House refused to lay on the table, and the question again recurred.
Mr. NEBEKER, of Vermillion, proposed the following by way of substitute:

Resolved, That the Door-keeper be instructed to subscribe for three copies of the daily State Sentinel, three copies of the daily State Journal, three copies of the weekly American, and three copies of the two German papers published in the city of Indianapolis, for the use of members of the House of Representatives.
Mr. SCOTT proposed to add: "and all the rest of the papers of the State;" which was rejected.
Mr. RYNEARSON, proposed to add: "Provided their publishers shall afford the same at their ordinary club rates."
Mr. NEBEKER accepted the latter.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, proposed to add: "The weekly Expositor and Boone County Pioneer;" which was rejected.
Mr. KNOWLTON proposed to substitute the amendment and the resolution by the following:

Resolved, That the Door-keeper contract for three copies each of the daily State Sentinel and the daily State Journaltwo copies to be enveloped and stampedand place the same on the desks of the members of this House.
Mr. MURRAY moved ineffectually to lay this amendment on the table, and then it was adopted, and the question recurred on the adoption of the resolution as amended by Mr. Knowlton.
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, demanded the previous question, and under its operation, the vote on the main question stood - yeas 54, nays 35, as follows:

YEAS Messrs. Bowman, Boyd, Brotherton, Clark, Clayton. Clements, Colgrove, Collier, Cotton, Davidson, Dobbins, Early, Edwards, Firestone, Gifford, Gregory, Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hall of Rush, Hamilton of Wayne, Hancock, Harney, Hartley, Jeffries, Johnston, Jones, Jordan, Keefer, Kelly, Kempf, Knowlton, Lawhead, Lewis, Merrifield. Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Nelson, Parrett, Power, Prosser, Shull, Stanley, Stanfield, Sullivan, Summers, Thompson, of Elkhart, Thompson of Madison, Turpie, Waterman, Wheeler, Whiteman, and Wood - 54.

NAYS-Messrs. Austin, Baird, Black, Boxley. Carr, Comstock, Davis, Dougherty, Durham, Devol, Hamilton of Boone, Harrison. Hunter, McLain, Mansfield, Mellett. Miller, Murray. Newton, Parks, Ritter, Robinson, Row, Rynearson, Scott, Sherman, Shields, Shockley, Smith of Miami, Stiles, Tebbs, Treadway, Whetzel, and Mr. Speaker- 35.
So the resolution was adopted.

div.head: REV. MR. CUNNINGHAM.
div.p: Mr. MURRAY submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved, 'That a committee of three be appointed to wait on the Rev. Mr. Cuanmgham, of this city, and request him to open the present session of the General Assembly with prayer, in joint convention of the two Houses, immediately preceding the delivery of the message of his Excellency, the Governor.

div.head: CONVENTION TO HEAR THE GOVERNOR'S MESSAGE.
div.p: Mr. DOBBINS submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved, That the Senate be invited to attend in the Hall of the House of Representatives this day at two o'clock P. M., to receive the biennial communication of His Excellency the Governor, and that seats be prepared therefor by the Door.keeper on the right of the Speaker's Chair, and that the Senate be forthwith informed of the adoption of this resolution

div.head: POSTAGE STAMPS.
div.p: Mr. PROSSER submitted the following:
Resolved,That the Door-keeper be authorized to purchase three dollars worth of postage stamps for each member of this Housetwo dollars of the same to be in one cent stamps.
Mr. KNOWLTON demanded the previous question, and pending the force thereof -
Mr. COLGROVE (by leave) said he would vote against the resolution because there was not money enough in it. He would vote for five dollars' worth to each member.
Mr. PROSSER would accept, with the consent of the House. ("No consent.")
he vote on the mam question was - yeas 47, nays 42.
So the resolution Was adopted.

div.head: PAGES.
div.p: Mr. GIFFORD submitted, the following, which was adopted by consent.
Resolved,That the Door-keeper be authorized to appoint two boys to act as Pages to this House, during the present session.

div.head: NEWSPAPERS FOR CLERKS OF THE HOUSE.
div.p: Mr. DURHAM submitted the following:
Resolved, That the Clerks of this House be each allowed a copy of the Daily Sentinel and Daily Journal.
Mr. KEEFER proposed to include the Doorkeepers and Pages.
Which was rejected.
Mr. THOMPSON, of Madison, made an ineffectual motion to lay the resolution on the table, and then it was rejected.

div.head: STATIONARY FOR THE HOUSE.
div.p: Mr. HUNTER. Mr. Speaker, I offer the following resolution for a Committee on Stationery. I would just state that at the last Session a similar committee was appointed, and under the rules reported by them and adopted here, the stationery account did not exceed $150, against $2,000. I believe, at the last regular session.

Resolved, That a committee of three be appointed to act as a Standing Committee on Stationery, and that said committee be instructed to make the same rules and regulations with regard to the purchase and distribution thereof, as at the last session.
Mr. DAVIS. I would like to know whether there is any way of getting better paper? The paper I have got is not worth much
Mr. CLEMENTS moved ineffectually to lay the resolution on the table.

Mr. DOUGHERTY. I believe that contemplates a return to the rule of the last session, by which we obtained our paper. I am certainly in favor of economical and just restrictions to prevent waste of stationery, and would vote for such a measure. But it seems to be rather degrading to require members to go to the Doorkeeper to beg a little paper, and then to require the amount obtained to be entered in a book. It seems to me rather degrading to make the Door-keeper the guardian of the stationery, and the member as the ward. It is making our servant our guardian; and then it throws no restriction around the Door-keepers.
Mr. HUNTER. Yes, they account to the committee.
Mr. DOUGHERTY. For my part. I do without stationery to some extent, rather than go to the Door-keepers and ask for it, and then have it charged against me.

Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, did not beg. His stationery was charged, and he supposed the items were examined. He asked for and obtained and used what he got. He knew of no better way than to call for what a man wants.

Mr. HUNTER replied to Mr. Dougherty. Two years ago thousands of dollars were charged to the State for stationery for the Legislature; and the object was to restrict waste and save money. There was nothing objectionable in the proposition.
The resolution was adopted.
The SPEAKER appointed the Committee on Rules, under Mr. Austin's resolution, namely: Messrs. Austin, Edwards, and Scott, and
The Committee on Prayer, under Mr. Murray's resolution, namely: Messrs. Murray, Blythe, and Gregory.
Mr. KNOWLTON asked and obtained leave of absence until Monday.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: On motion by Mr. BLYTHE, the Committee on Prayer had leave to vary their report from the instructions in the resolution, so as to substitute the name of the Rev. Mr. Tyndall for that of Rev. Mr. Cunninghamthe latter gentleman having been called out of the city; and reported that Mr. Tyndall had consented to pray before the General Assembly at two o'clock this day.

div.head: CLERK OF THE STATIONARY ROOM.
div.p: Mr. TURPIE submitted the following, which was adopted by consent:

Resolved, That the Stationery Clerk render to the Secretary of State an account of his disbursements of the
same during the late special session, and that he account to the said Secretary for the remainder in his hands at the close of the session; and that he take the same action and render the same account at the close of the present regular session.

div.head: OPENING BY JOINT CONVENTION
div.p: The members and officers of the Senate now appeared and took seats in accordance with the order adopted this morning in joint convention with the House of Representatives.
The convention was called to order by the PRESIDENT pro tempore of the Senate.
Prayers having been offered by the Rev. Mr. Tyndall, of the 2nd Presbytsrian Church of this city.
The PRESIDENT, pro tem., of the Senate anuonnced the order of delivery of the

div.head: GOVERNOR'S BIENNIAL MESSAGE.
div.p: His Excellency the GOVERNOR, standing on the right of the forum, then read to tin convention his biennial message,
The PRESIDENT, pro tem., of the Senate, The business of the Convention of the two Houses, being concluded, Senators will now repair to their Chamber.
The Senate retired, and the SPEAKER laid before the House, the Governor's Biennial Message.
On motion by Mr. DOBBINS, the consideration of the message was postponed and made the special order for Monday next, at two o'clock.
Mr. BOYD submitted the following:

Resolved,That there be printed for the use of the House of Representatives five thousand copies of the Governor's Biennial Message, one thousand of which shall be under the direction of the Governor and for his use.
Mr. DOUGHERTY proposed to add: "One thousand of the five, to be printed in the German language."
Mr. BOYD accepted; and so the resoultion was adopted.
The House then, at three o"clock, adjourned
The Senate did not sit to-day.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
div.p: Mr. LAWHEAD. Mr. Speaker, I move to dispense with the readng of the journal, to enable me to make another motion. I do not want to work to-day
The motion was agreed to.
Mr. LAWHEAD. I now move that the House adjourn.
["NO," ""no" - and laughter.]
This Mr. Speaker, is the 8th of January - the far-famed anniversary of General Jackson's victory at New Orleons, and I want to celebrate it, because I am old fashioned Democrat. [Cheers.]

div.head: THE VOLKSBLAT AND THE FRIE PRESS.
div.p: Mr. MURRAY. If the gentleman will withhold his motion to enable me to offer a resolution, I will go with him.
Mr. LAWHEAD. I withdraw for the gentleman.
Mr. MURRAY. I submit the following resolution:

Resolved, That the Door-keeper be instructed to contract with the publishers of the Volksblat and Frie Press of this city, for three copies of their respective papers, to be enveloped and stamped, for the use of members of this House.
After debate the resolution was adopted, and then -
The House adjourned till Monday morning, 9 o'clock.

div.head: IN SENATE
div.p: Senators Line and Studabaker appeared in their places.
Mr. HARGROVE, by consent, offered the following, which was adopted:

Resolved, That five thousand copies of the late message of his Excellency, Governor Ashbel IJ. Willard, be printed for the use of the Senate, two thousand copies of which to be in the German language, and the same be made the special order of business for to-morrow, at two o'clock, P.M.

div.head: STATIONERY.
div.p: Mr. GREEN offered the following:

Resolved, That a committee of three be appointed to act | as a committee on stationery, and that the said committee be instructed to make the same rules and regulations, with regard to the purchase and distribution thereof, as at the I last session, except said committee may substitute the [ Door-keeper in place of the principal Secretary.
Mr. HEFFREN said there was a similar I committee appointed at the last session, but he had seen no report from them yet.
Mr. HAMILTON proposed the following as an amendment to the resolution:
ResolvedResolved, That the Secretary be requested to deliver to the desk of each Senator a quantity of stationary, not exceeding in value three dollars worth, at actual cost.
Mr. MARCH. Last session the Secretary of the Senate was required to report to the Committee on Finance. He hoped some such system would be again adopted.
Mr. GOODING. It seems to me we will economize by not devoting much time to the matter. I am satisfied with the plan of the last session.
Mr. HEFFREN regarded the resolution as throwing a suspicion upon the integrity of Senators, and those whom we have employed
Mr. CARNAHAN said the bills for stationery at the last session were delivered to the Finance Committee. He was willing to let ,he matter go by the board, and continue as before.
Mr. CONNER offered the following as an amendment to the amendment:

Strike out from the resolving clause, and insert: "That the Door-keeper of the Senate be instructed to appoint a suitable person to take the exclusive care and charge of the stationrey, in the stationery room, which may be furnished, under the order of the Senate, and that such person, so appointed, supply Senators, Secretaries and others entitled to be supplied with stationery, with the same upon application, and that such persan keep an account of the stationery so furnished."
Mr. WEIR was opposed to hiring a clerk to take charge of the stationery, for his per diem would amount to more than the cost of all the stationery used by every Senator.

Mr. TARKINGTON thought it degrading to honorable Senators to employ a clerk at $3 a day, to charge them with so much paper and so many pencils. It was supremely ridiculous. He wanted no such plan. He read a resolution which he desired to offer.
Mr. GREEN withdrew his resolution.
Mr. TARKINGTON then offered his resolution, which was read by tne Secretary as follows:

Resolved, Resolved, That the Secretary of State be requested to purchase in the most economical manner, all the stationery necessary for the Senate, and that the principal Secretary of the Senate apply for the same, when needed, and place in charge of the Door-keeper, who shall take charge of the same by self or assistant during the session and deliver to Senators when needed and all such stationery as may not be used on adjournment be returned to the Secretary of State.

Mr. HEFFREN moved to strike out the words, "and place in charge of the Doorkeeper." He contended that the resolution as introduced contained an implicit censure of-the Secretary. He was opposed to the resolution in toto, and would go to a stationery house and buy his stationery, before he would go to the Senate stationery room and ask an employee of any officer for a half dozen sheets of paper or a lead pencil.
Mr. MURRAY thought the resolution did not contain a censure of the Secretary.
Mr. MILLER was opposed to the resolution, but was in favor of the proposition submitted a while ago by the Senator from Allen [Mr. Hamilton.]
Mr. Heffren's motion was lost.
Mr. MILLER proposed as a substitute, that each Senator be allowed $3 50 worth of stationery.
Mr. SLACK thought three dollars worth was more than any one Senator could use. He was in favor of the resolution.
Mr. HEFFREN moved to lay the resolution on the table.
The motion was rejected.
On motion by Mr. GREEN, the substitute was laid on the table.
Mr. MARCH offered the following amendment:
All officers of the Senate,their assistants and employees, are prohibited from making any account, for any thing for the use of the Senate, except upon the
Mr. HAMILTON moved to amend by striking out the word "Door-keeper," and inserting in lieu thereof the words: "Secretary of the Senate."
Mr. MARCH accepted of the amendment.
The amendment was agreed to, and the resolution, as amended, was adopted.
Mr. MARCH accepted of the amendment.
The amendment was agreed to, and the resolution, as amended, was adopted.

The remainder of the session this day was occupied with the propositions to elect a reporter, and subscribe for newspapers for Senators, resulting in the recommitment of the Select Committee's report recommending the election of a reporter, and constituting said committee a Joint Committee, and in the adoption of an order, directing the Door-keeper, (for the present,) to procure and place on the desk of each Senator one copy of the Daily Sentinel and one copy of the Daily Journal.
Mr. MURRAY, submitted, for adoption, a list of the Standing Committees of the Senate; pending which -
The Senate adjourned.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: The Journal of Saturday was read.

div.head: NEWSPAPERS.
div.p: The SPEAKER laid before the House a statement of the Door-keeper to the effect, that the proprietors of the Daily State Journal and the Daily State Sentinel refuse to furnish the House of Representatives with their said papers at any rate less than that of their bill presented at the last session - that is 15 cents per three copies per day, two of them being enveloped and stamped: and the Door-keeper thereupon asked for further instructions from the House.
Mr. HUNTER. The bill at the last session was 5 cents per copy. If we have to pay that I move that the House take no papers: (consent,) or, I suppose a motion should be made to reconsider.
Mr. DAVIS. I move to reconsider the vote of Friday adopting the resolution.
The motion was agreed to. The vote was reconsidered, and the question recurred again on the adoption of the resolution.

Mr. MURRAY. I would like to see that resolution amended, so as to require these papers to be furnished at the prices paid at the last session; and if the printers refuse them at those rates, with the gentleman from Monroe, I shall be in favor of taking no papers this session. I propose to amend the resolution by adding the following:
"Provided that these papers be furnished at the same rates as at the special session."
The amendment was rejected.
Mr. DOBBINS submitted the following by way of a substitute:

Resolved, That the Door-keeper contract at the usual legislative price, for three copies each of the Daily Sentinel and Daily Journal two copies of each paper to be enveloped and stampedfor the use of members.
The substitute was rejected; and then the question recurring again on the adoption of the original resolution, it was also rejected.

The SPEAKER laid before the House a peti-
tion, signed by E. Buchanan and others, ladies of Martinsville, praying for a liquor law similar to that of 1855, and reasoning at length on the subject; which was read and referred to the Committee on Temperance.

The SPEAKER also laid before the House the petition of Henry Craft and others, citizens of Pulaski county, memorializing the Legislature against the administration of the Swamp Land Commissioner for said county, and asking that his late sales be annulled, &c; which was read, and on motion by Mr. BOYD, it was referred to the Committee on Swamp Lands.

Mr. SCOTT presented the petition of sundry citizens of Laporte county, memorializing the Legislature against seining and shooting fish in the inland lakes at certain seasons; which was read, and on the motion of Mr. WHETZEL it was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.

Mr. WILDMAN submitted the petition of sundry citizens of Lagrange county, asking for the passage of the Senate bill No. 8, to restrain the sale of intoxicating liquors; which on the motion of Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, was referred to the Committee on Temperance.

On the motion of Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, it was ordered that when the House adjourns [takes the first recess] for this day, it shall be till 1 1/2 o'clock. This was to give the Speaker opportunity to prepare for the announcement of the Standing Committees.

div.head: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION.
div.p: Mr. DAVIS asked and obtained leave to introduce a bill (No. 1) to provide for taking the sense of the qualified voters of the State on calling a convention to alter, amend, or revise the State Constitution.

div.head: SALARIES OF PUBLIC OFFICERS.
div.p: Mr. STANFIELD asked and obtained leave to introduce a bill (No. 2) relative to the salaries of public officers, and providing for the payment of the same; and to repeal so much of an act, entitled an act relative to the salaries of public officers, and providing for the manner of the payment of the same, approved June 14, 1852, as is inconsistent with this act.

div.head: TESTIMONY.
div.p: Mr. STANFIELD also had leave to introduce a bill (No. 3) to amend section 302 of the Law Reform act, approved June 18, 1852, so as to authorize plaintiffs and co-defendants to testify in certain cases; also, to allow defendants to testify in certain actions brought by assignees where the assignor testifies.

div.head: SOLDIERS OF THE WAR OF 1812.
div.p: Mr. DURHAM asked and obtained leave to introduce a joint resolution (No. 1), as follows:

WHEREASThere yet remains some of the valiant men who served in the war of 1812, and also indigent widows of the soldiers of ssid war, who have never received a pension from the government of the United States, therefore -

Be it resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the State of Indiana That our Senators Congress be instructed, and our Represtatives requested to use their best efforts to obtain for such soldiers and their widows a pension during their natural lives.

div.head: EXEMPTIONS.
div.p: Mr. PROSSER obtained leave to introduce a bill (No. 4) to exempt property from execution in certain cases therein named, providing who may claim, and the manner of appraisement of property claimed, ars exempt under the provisions thereof, and repealing an act entitled an act to exempt property from sale in certain cases, approved Feb. 17, 1852.

div.head: SCHOOL TOWNSHIPS.
div.p: Mr. STANFIELD had leave to introduce a bill (No. 5) incorporating school townships defining their powers, requiring the title of school lots to be vested in the corporate name of the township, town or city in which the same is situate, and authorizing public school houses to be occupied for private schools, also for other meetings and to authorize the common council, the aldermen or trustees of any incorporated town to levy all taxes for school purposes, andthe building and repairing of school houses, and to repeal all laws inconsistent with this act.

div.head: COUNTY BOUNDARIES.
div.p: Mr.NEBEKER, of Warren, asked and obtained leave to introduce a bill (No. 6) to amend the second section of the act approved March 7, 1857, entitled an act to authorize the formation of new counties. and to change county boundaries.

div.head: A CONVENTIONAL INTEREST.
div.p: Mr. SHULL obtained leave to introduce a bill (No. 7), supplemental to an act concerning interest on money, approved Feb. 22, 1852, and providing for a conventional rate of interest [not exceeding- ten per cent.]

div.head: PUBLIC BUILDINGS.
div.p: Mr. RITTER obtained leave to introduce a bill (No. 8) to preserve public buildings, and to punish persons for un lawfully occupying the same.

div.head: INDEPENDENT TREASURY.
div.p: Mr. Jones obtained leave to introduce a bill (No. 9) to establish an independent treasury of the State of Indiana, to provide for the safekeeping and disbursement of the public money of the State and of the several counties thereof, creating the office of Comptroller of the Treasury, end prescribing the manner of his election, defining Ms duties and fixing his compensation; defining the duties of Treasurer of State, Auditor of State and other State officers, and the duties of County Auditors and Treasurers and other county officers : for the examination of the State and county treasuries, and providing for the punishment of the crime of embezzlement of public moneys, and fixing other penalties for violations of the provisions of this act.
Which bills were severally read throughout, and passed the first reading.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The SPEAKER announced the following landing and Joint Standing Committees of he House of Representatives, viz.

list.item: On Elections.- Messrs. Hamilton, of Boone, Harrison, Power, Dobbins, Merrifield and Jordan.
On the Judiciary. - Messrs. Colgrove, Baird, Stanfield, Davis, Blythe, Mellett and Turpie.
On Ways and Means. - - Messrs. Branham, Hunter, Smith, of Perry, Shields, Major, Harvey and Wildman.
On Banks. - Messrs. Mellett, Bowman, Scott, McClain, Robinson, Smith, of Miami, and Firestone.
On Education. - Messrs. Mansfield, Boyd, Stiles, Hamilton, of Wayne, Dougherty, Major and Robinson.

On the Organization of Courts of Justice. -
On the Organization of Courts of Justice. Messrs. Stanfield, Baird, Stiles, Merrifield, Davis, Dobbins and Bro. therton.
On the Affairs of the State Prison. - Messrs. Hunter, Carr, Murray, Shields, Comstock, Prosser and Fordyce.
On Swamp Lands. - Messrs. Hamilton, of Boone, Jeffries, Comstock, Colgrove, Martin, Cavins and Harney.
On Claims. - Messrs. Wildman, Martin, Cavins, Boxey, Collier and Hartley.
On Trust Funds. - Messrs. Jeffries, Rynearson, Martin, Stanley, Kempf, Whitzel and Gilford.
On Military Affairs. - Messrs. Power, Prosser, Miller, Hall, of Grant, Claypool, Eastham and Thompson, of Elkhart.
On Fees and Salaries. - Messrs. Scott, Robinson. Stiles, Turpie, Dougherty, Griffin and Dobbins.
On Sinking Fund. - Messrs. Robinson, Branham, Colgrove, Black, Early, Martin and Jones.
On the Rights and Privileges of the Inhabitants of this State. - Messrs. Parks, Brotherton, Nebeker, of Warren, Griffin, Nelson, Merrifield and Massey.
On Roads - Messrs. Comstock, Devol, Durham, Nebeker, of Vermillion, Early and Hall, of Grant.
On Manufactures and Commerce. - Messrs. Smith, of Perry, Gregory, Duvoll, Thompson, of Elkhart, Waterman, Murray and Durham.
On County and Township Business. - Messrs. Harrison, Whitzel, Mellett, Martin, Jones, Harvey and Snyder.
On Agriculture - Messrs. Rynesrson, Treadway, Whitzel, Wheeler, Kelly, Tebbs and Boxley.
On Benevolent Institutions. - Messrs. Edwards, Boyd, Branham, Hucter, Rynearson, Smith, of Perry, and Collier.
On Temperance. - Messrs. Austin, Nebeker, of Warren, Shockley, Thompson, of Madison, Davidson, Johnson and Lawhead.
On the Affairs of the Town of Indianapolis . - Messrs. Cotton, Hall, of Rush, Johnston, Summers, Keefer and Claypool.
On Mileage. - Messrs. Nebeker, of Warren, Hall, of Grant, Wildman, Cavins, Carr, Sullivan and Shockley.
On Enrolled Bills.- Messrs. Brotherton, Gregory, Shull, Griffin, Newton, Cotton and Usrey.
On Engrossed Bills. - Messrs. Griffin, Hall, of Rush, Nelson, Gifford, Nebeker, of Warren, Claypool and Parks.
On Canals.- Messrs. Miller, Comstock, Stinson, Fordyce, Duvoll, Newton and Knowlton.
On Public Expenditure. Messrs. Ritter, Fordyce, Duvoll, Hall, of Rush, Gifford, Lewis and Newton.
On Corporations. - Messrs. Stiles, Cavins, Martin, Brotherton, Stinson, Hartley and Lawhead.

div.head: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEES.

item.orgName: On Public Buildings. - Messrs. Duvoll, Austin and Lawhead.
On State Library. - Messrs. Cavins, Smith, of Perry, and Boyd.
On Canal Fund. - Messrs. Sherman, Comstock and Stinson.

div.p: The SPEAKER announced that the order of business would be the same as in the special session.

div.head: BOARD OF SINKING FUND COMMISSIONERS.
div.p: Mr. SMITH, of Perry, asked and obtained leave, to introduce a bill (No. 10) to establish a Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners, providing for the election and appointment of the officers thereof, and prescribing the powers and duties of said Board; which was passed the first reading.

Mr. SMITH. Inasmuch as there is a question whether there is at this time any officer of the Sinking Fund, it ia expedient that this bill should be taken up and considered at as early a period as possible, I would ask the House to suspend the rules, that it may be read a second time now. I would remark that it is the same bill as that reported at the last session, with the exception of the exceptionable portionthe llth and 12th sections. It does not even propose to legislate the Board into office.
The SPEAKER directed the call of the yeas and nays under the constitutional provision, which resulted, yeas 74, nays 5.
So two-thirds voting in the affirmative, the rules were suspended and the bill was read the second time by its titleso passing to the question of engrossment.
On motion by Mr. DOUGHERTY, the bill was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means

div.head: LIST OF STANDING COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. MILLER (by unanimous consent) submitted the following:
Resovled, That 300 copies of the list of the Standing Committees of the House of Representatives be printed for the use of the House.
Mr. GIFFORD proposed 200 copies:
Which was adopted by consent.
Mr. THOMPSON, of Madison, proposed 100.
Which was rejected.
And then the resolution was adopted.

div.head: STATIONARY REPORT.
div.p: Mr. DOUGHERTY obtained leave to submit the following, which was adopted by unanimous consent:

Resolved, That the Committee on Stationery be instructed to report to this House, at their earliest convenience, the amount and several kinds of stationery placed in the stationery room at the late Special Session for the use of this House; what amount remained on hand at the close of the session, and the specific amount of each kind obtained therefrom by each member; and that a like report be made by said committee at the close of the present session.

div.head: THE LEGISLATIVE SENTINEL.
div.p: The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from the Assistant Clerk (Mr. Chapman) stating, that, in obedience to a resolution adopted by the House of Representatives near the close of the extra session, he had contracted with Bingham & Doughty for the binding of 100 copies of the Legislative Sentinel at 12 1/2 cents per copy; which was ordered to go upon the Journal.

div.head: COUNTY BONDS.
div.p:
Mr. CAVINS asked and obtained leave to introduce a bill (No. 11) to amend the 21st section of an act entitled An act providing for the organization of County Boards, and pre-
scribing some of their powers and duties, approved June 17, 1852.

div.head: UNAUTHORIZED PAPER CURRENCY.
div.p: Mr. MARTIN (by unanimous consent) introduced a bill (No. 12) to prevent the issuing and circulation of unauthorized paper currency, and prescribing penalties for the issuance and failure to redeem any such currency.

div.head: QUALIFICATION OF ELECTORS.
div.p: Mr. GREGORY (by unanimous consent) introduced a bill (No. 13) to amend the section of article two of the State Constitution, denning the qualifications of electors so that every white male citizen who has resided in the State six months shall be entitled to vote in the township where he resides:
Which bills were severally passed the first reading.

div.head: GOVERNOR'S MESSAGE.
div.p: The SPEAKER now announced the special order, viz.: the consideration of the Governor's Biennial Message, and stated that it was usual to consider the Message in Committee of the whole House.
The House then resolved itself into Committee of the Whole - Mr. Edwards in the Chair and took up the Governor's Biennial Message.
On motion by Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, the reading of the Message was dispensed with.
On motion by Mr. BOYD, it was
Resolved, That so much of the Governor's Message as relates to the State's Prison, be referred to the Committee on the State's Prison.
On motion by Mr. FORDYCE, it was
Resolved, That that part of the Governor's Message relating to the Wabash and Erie Canal be referred to the Committee on Canals and Internal Improvements.

Mr. Speaker GORDON submitted a resolution referring to a select committee of five, that part of the Message which relates to the failure of the General Assembly of 1857 to make appropriations for the Benevolent Institutions, and to the course pursued by the Treasurer and other State Officers in the premises, with instructions to inquire -

list.item: How the General Assembly failed to make such appropriations?
Whether the Treasurer vioalated his duty in refusing to pay out the money in the Treasury for such purpose?
Whether the resolution of the Officers of State transcended their constitutional and legal authority, advising the Treasurer to use the money of the State to sustain these Institutions?
What authority existed for such resolution, and the action of the Treasurer thereunder? and if none
What was the constitutional means of providing for sustaining said Institutions, and what officer or officers of State had exclusive control thereof, and how did he or they employ the same?

div.p: Mr. DOUGHERTY. I would say, in regard to that portion, it does seem to me that an inquiry of that kind would be useless. What will the gentleman from Marion gain by instituting an inquiry into the cause of the failure of the last State Senate to pass certain laws? What new facts will be elicited? I presume the history of the acts of the last Senate is before the people; it is made up; has gone out; it has been read by the people It has grown into a political question. The people have all formed their opinions upon and taken sides; and any investigation by committee, at this day, would not affect the views one way or another. A report in the matter would simply raise a political question, and do no good. But if the gentleman wishes to examine into the conduct of the State Officers concerning these Institutions- if he wishes to take a tilt at themI have objection. Let him go ahead. I propose amend the resolution by striking out that petition which relates to the failure of the Senate to pass the appraisement and money bills in the session of 1857.
The amendment was agreed to, and so the resolution was adopted.
On motion by Mr. AUSTIN, it was
Resolved,That so much of the Governor's Message relates to the Governor's salary and that of the Judges the Courts, be referred to the Committee on Fees and Salaries.
On motion by Mr. MURRAY, it was

Resolved, That so much of the Governor's Message relates to the repeal of the law to organize companies the apprehension of horse thieves and other felons be referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
On motion by Mr. HANCOCK, it was
Resolved, That so much of the Governor's Message relates to election frauds be referred to the Committee on Elections.
On motion by Mr. BOYD, it was
Resolved,That that part of the Governor's Message which relates to the surrender of fugitives from justice be referred to a select committee of one from each Of Congressional District.
On motion by Mr. STILES, it was
Resolved, That so much of the Governor's Message,refers to the increase of salaries be referred to the Committee on Fees and Salaries.
On motion by Mr. HUNTER, it was

Resolved, That the Chairman appoint a committee seven, which shall be denominated a Committee on Agriculture, Science, Manufactures, and the Mechanic Arts, which shall be referred so much of the Governor's Message as relates to the establishment of an Agricultural Bureau, to the establishment of a Professorship of Agriculture in the Indiana University, and to a Geological Survey of the State.

Mr. GREGORY submitted a resolution referring to the Committee on Ways and Means that portion of the Message which relates to the tax-levy failure of the year 1857, its consequence, and the borrowing of $330,000 by the Officers of State, with instructions to inquire -

list.item: Where and of whom, and on what rate of interest and on what time was the $165,006 borrowed in June?
Under what authority of law was such loan made?
Of whom, on what securities direct or collateral, at what rate of interest, and on what time was the $165,000 borrowed in December, 1858?
Under what authority was said last sum borrowed? was it in pursuance or in violation of the direction of the General Assembly? If in violation -
Could the money have been obtained in pursuance of said Legislature?And that said committee have authority to send for persons and papers.

div.p: The resolution was agreed to.
On motion by Mr. DOUGHERTY, it was -
Resolved, That that portion of the Governor's Message relating to an Independent State Treasury be referred to a select committee of five, of which Mr. Jones, of Spencer, shall be Chairman
On motion by Mr. Martin, it was -
Resolved,That so much of the Governor's message as relates to the subject of Temperance be referred to theCommittee on Temperance.
On motion by Mr. GIFFORD, it was -
Resolved, That so much of the Governor's message as refers to the Sinking Fund, be referred to the Committee on the Sinking Fund.
On motion by Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, it was -
Resolved, That so much of the Governor's message as relates to Temperance but not noticed in said message be referred to the Committee on Temperance.
On motion by Mr. WATERMAN, it was -
Resolved, That so much of the message as refers to the matter of the preservation of the Public Buildings, be referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.

On motion by Mr. ROBINSON, the Committee rose, and the CHAIRMAN reported the foregoing resolutions, recommending their adoption, and that the Committee of the Whole be discharged from the further consideration of the subject.
The report was concurred in, and the resolutions were adopted as a whole.
Mr. MURRAY (by consent) submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved,That the State Printer be requested to furnish this House with a statement, showing the number of bills printed by the order of this House, and the aggregate amount charged for the same, during the late special session thereof; and, also, the number of bills printed by order of the Senate during the same period, and the aggregate amount charged therefor.
Mr. KEMPF (by consent) submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved,That the Committee on the Judiciary inquire into the constitutionality of "Section six, of an act entitled an act regulating the fees of officers; page 291:" when compared with "Section twenty-one, article one, of the constitution ofthe State of Indiana; page 44, of the Statutes:" and report by bill or otherwise.
Mr. ROBINSON (by consent) submitted the following:
Resolved,That the members of this House proceed in-stanter to select their seats by lot.
On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, it was laid on the table.
Mr. RITTER (by consent) submitted the following, which was adopted:
Resolved,Resolved, That the Committee on the organization of Courts of Justice be directed to inquire into the expediency of abolishing the office of Attorney General, and report to this House,
Mr. SUMMERS (by consent) submitted the following, which was adopted by consent:
Resolved,That the duties usually performed by a Sergeant-at-Arms be performed by the Door-keeper of this House without additional charge.

div.head: NEW PROPOSITIONS.
div.p: Mr. MARTIN (by consent) introduced a bill (No. 14) to amend section 14 of the Act providing for the election of Justices of the Peace, and defining their jurisdiction, powers and duties in civil cases, approved June 19, 1852.

Mr. WATERMAN (by consent) introduced a joint resolution (No. 2) instructing our Senators, and requesting our Representatives in Congress, to use their influence to procure the passage of an act granting lands for Agricultural Colleges.
Which bill and joint resolution were passed the first reading.
Mr. GREGORY (by consent) submitted the following, which was adopted:
Resolved, That the Door-keeper be instructed to ascertain whether the State Printer has completed the printing of the report of the Special Committee on the State Printing.

Mr. RITTER (by consent) introduced a bill (No. 15) to amend the first and sixth sections of the Act to exempt property from sale in certain cases, approved Feb. 17, 1852; which was passed the first reading.

div.head: NEWSPAPERS - REPORTING.
div.p: Mr. SHULL (by unanimous consent) submitted the following:

Resolved,That a Committee of three be appointed to subscribe for three copies of the following papers of this city, to wit: the Daily State Sentinel, Daily State Journal and Weekly Indiana American two copies of each respectively to be enveloped and stamped, and that the Door-keeper procure the same to be laid upon the desk of each member of this House.

Mr. HUNTER. I have had a conversation with the reporter for the Sentinel in the Senate, and he says he is a printer, and that this House may employ a reporter to report all the proceedings, and that his report can be published daily, and twelve copies laid on the desk of each member every morning - the report to embrace all the bills offered the preceding day, and everything done in the House the day before - that this can be done much
cheaper than the cost of the newspapers, as subscribed for by the House at the last session. I therefore move that the resolution be laid on the table, or referred to a Committee to be appointed, to inquire into and report as soon as possible, what will be the cost of employing a reporter, and proceeding upon that plan. I move to refer the resolution to a Select Committee of three, with instructions to inquire into the cost of employing a reporter and having the proceedings of the House published, together with the bills as they are introduced, and have twelve copies thereof furnished to each member.
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren. Are we not already bound by contract to take the two papers ?
Mr. BOYD. I shall vote for the proposition to refer, with a view of moving to re-consider the order for taking the two German papers.
Mr. Hunter's motion was then agreed to, and the resolution was referred to a Select Committee, which the SPEAKER makes to consist of Messrs Hunter, Shull and Martin.
Mr. MURRAY (by consent) submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved,That so much of the Constitution of the State of Indiana which says: " No person elected to any judicial office shall, during the term for which he shall have been elected, be eligible to any office of trust or profit under the State, other than a judicial office," be referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions to inquire whether said clause precludes Justices of the Peace from holding any office other than a judicial one during the term for which he may be elected, in the township where he may reside, in the county, or in the State; and if there be exceptions, what are they? and report their decision to this House.
Mr. HARRISON (by consent) submitted the following, which was adopted, and referred to the foregoing committee on reporting:

Resolved,That the Door-keeper be instructed to contract for and cause to be laid on the table of each member, one copy each of the State Sentinel and the State Journal, and six copies each of the Weekly Sentinel and the Weekly Journal - the copies of the weekly to be enveloped and stamped.

Mr. PROSSER (for Mr. Boyd) moved to reconsider the vote by which the subscription for three copies of each of the two German papers was ordered.Messrs. Baird and Keefer demanded the yeas and nays, and they were ordered.
Messrs. Baird and Keefer demanded the yeas and nays, and they were ordered.

Mr. MURRAY hoped the vote would not be reconsidered, for we had a pretty hard scratch to get it. He was willing to allow the gentleman from Monroe to have his chance for inquiring into the cost of hireing a reporter, but he still believed the plan would be a failure, and these newspaper resolutions would have to be adopted again.
Mr. PROSSER had moved the reconsideration, becauge he wanted equality in this matter of taking newspapers.
Mr. BAIRD. We take newspapers for the benefit of our constituents, not for the benefit of printers.

Mr. KEEFER, from his reading of those German papers, stated that one of them, the Frie Presse, scarcely made any legislative reports at all, and neither were Democratic papers. Whilst he voted for them, he thought it proper to make these statements to the House.
So the vote was reconsidered; and the question recurring on the adoption of the resolution,
Mr. DOUGHERTY proposed to amend by adding: "Provided the publishers of said papers agree to publish liberal abstracts of the Legislative proceedings."
On motion by Mr. BOYD, the resolution and pending amendment were referred to the select committee on Reporting.

div.head: NEW NATIONAL ARMORY.
div.p: Mr. HUNTER (by unanimous consent) introduced a joint resolution (No. 3) instructing and requesting our Senators and Representatives in Congress to use their influence to procure the location of the National Armory for the Western States at the Falls of the Ohio on the Indiana side; which was passed the first reading.
Mr. MURRAY inquired with reference to the disposition of the bills pending at the close of the special session.
The SPEAKER. The Chair believes they are placed on file with the State Librarian.
On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, the credentials of members af the House of Representatives, still on file with the Clerk, were ordered to be referred to theCommittee on Elections.

Mr. HARNEY (by leave) introduced a bill (No. 16) to amend the 3d section of an act, defining misdemeanors and prescribing punishments therefor, approved June 14, 1852 approved March 7, 1857; which was passed the first reading.
The House then (at 3:15 o'clock) adjourned.

div.head: STANDING COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. STUDABAKER offered a resolution embracing an entire list of Standing Committees.
Mr. JONES Moved its reference to a select committee of one from each Congressional District.
Mr. WALLACE contended that the President of the Senate should appoint the Standing Committees in accordance with time-honored usage.
Mr. MURRAY insisted that it was the province of the Senate to arrange its own committees.

Mr. HEFFREN said that the Republican party was responsible for legislation in this body, and consequently he was willing they should shape the committees of the Senate. He moved to lay the motion of the Senator from Bartholomew [Mr. Jones] on the table.
The motion was rejected by yeas 18 nays,30.

The original motion was agreed to and the resolution was referred to a special committee of one from each Congressional District, which the PRESIDENT pro tempore subsequently made to consist of Senators Jones, Hargrove, Anthony, Stevens, Bennett, Jennings, McLean, Wagner, Miller, Hamilton and Murray.

div.head: SENATORS GOODING, MARSH AND MILLER.
div.p: Mr. HEFFREN offered the following:

Resolved,That the Secretary of State be requested to furnish the Senate the dates of the respective commissions as Common Pleas Judges in the year 1852, of Hon. Hugh Miller, Hon. Wa ter March and Hon. David S. Gooding, and at what time the commissions of their successors were dated in 1856, or if any of them resigned, the date of the resignation of the same.
Mr. HEFFREN stated that the resolution was simply for the purpose of putting facts before the select committee appointed to investigate these several cases.
The resolution was adopted.
Mr. HEFFREN, presented the petition of George Leachman, claiming that he was elected a Senator from the counties of Shelby and Hancock in October, 1857, to the place of Mr. Gooding.
Mr. HAMILTON moved to refer the paper to the above committee of one from each Congressional District.
Mr. GOODING made a statement of the case offering to resign, if the Senate would accept of Esquire Leachman as the legal Senator from Hancock and Shelby.
Mr. MARCH said that this paper was not made out in a legal manner, and he had no doubt it was intended as a hoax.
Mr. MURRAY also regarded this paper as a sham, because it did not show from what district the person claimed to be elected.
On motion by Mr. WALLACE, the paper was laid on the table.
On motion by Mr. ANTHONY, the vote adopting the resolution was reconsidered. The resolution was then laid on the table - yeas 34, nays 11.

div.head: INTEREST ON MONEY.
div.p: Mr. MILLER offered the following:

Resolved, That it is the sense of this Senate that the law regulating the interest on the use of money should be so amended as to allow the taking of ten per cent, where a contract to that effect has been entered into. But without such contract, six per cent, to be the legal rate of interest.
Mr. MILLER said he would like to have a test vote upon this question by yeas and nays.
Mr. HAMILTON, by leave, submitted a petition, embracing the same idea, from citizens of Allen county, and moved that it be referred to a committee of five.
Mr. LINE desired to see the rates of interest in Indiana equal to that in the adjoining States. He should vote for the resolution offered by the Senator from Fulton.
Mr. McLEAN thought this was one of the most important questions likely to come before the Legislature. He moved it be madethe special order for Tuesday next at 2 o'clock P.M.
Mr. ANTHONY was in favor of removing the present restrictions upon money-lenders; but any new measure must be carefully guarded.
Mr. GOODING saw no impropriety in the consideration of the resolution, but he would not indicate his opinion on the subject at this time.
Mr. RICE said this question should not be passed without due consideration. It would be improper, perhaps, for the Senate to commit itself to the proposition now.

Mr. MARCH saw no necessity for taking the sense of the Senate now. He was opposed to a law authorizing any interest higher than six per cent, because he did not believe the masses of the people demanded it.

Mr. WEIR hoped the Senate would come to a direct vote upon the question. He was in favor of abolishing the usury laws. He moved to lay the motion of the Senator from Vigo (Mr. McLean) on the table; but withdrew for -

Mr. WAGNER, who said he was the representative of money-borrowers, that he thought ten per centum was the usual rate of interest, and that money was worth ten per cent. He thought it best to send the matter to a special committee.
Mr. STEELE remarked that as this was one of the questions upon which he was elected he desired to be heard upon it at the proper time.
Mr. WEIR renewed his motion to lay on the table the motion to postpone.
This motion was agreed to, and the question recurring upon the reference of the resolution to a committee of five -
Mr. MARCH moved to amend as follows:
Add to the resolution the following: "But in actions upon contracts for a rate of interest exceeding six and not exacting ten per cent. the plaintiff shall recover judgment for only six per cent."
Mr. TARKINGTON moved to further amend as follows.

p.hi: "That all judgments rendered on notes and contracts drawing ten per cent, interest shall also draw the same rate of interest."

div.p: Mr. STUDABAKER moved to refer the resolution and amendments to tht special committee proposed.
Mr. TARKINGTON moved to make the subject the special order for to-morrow 2 o'clock P.M.
The motion was rejected.
Mr. BOBBS was opposed to the resolution and petition.
Mr. HEFFREN moved to lay the motion of the Senator from Adams (Mr. Studabaker) on the table.
The motion was rejected.
On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the whole subject was laid on the table.

div.head: ISSUES IN VACATION.
div.p: Mr. WEIR offered the following:

Resolved, That a select committee of three be appointed for the purpose of inquiring into the expediency of so amending the practice in Courts as to provide for making up issues of law in vacation, and that they report by bill or otherwise
Mr. GOODING moved to amend by striking out the word "three" and inserting "five."
Mr. WEIR accepted.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The resolution of the Senator from Laporte (Mr. Weir) pending when the Senate took a recess, was adopted, and the PRESIDENT pro tempore makes the committee to consist of Senators Weir, Heffren, Wallace, Gooding and Anthony.

div.head: POSTAGE STAMPS.
div.p: Mr. WEIR offered the following:
Resolved,That the Door-keeper furnish each Senator and officer of the Senate $3 worth of stamps to enable them to distribute necessary documents.
