div.head: JOINT COMMITTEES.

list.item: On Public Buildings Messrs. Culver, Studabaker and Robinson.
On State Library Messrs. Wilson, Craven, Tarkington and Murray.

div.p: A proposition was again made to subscribe for the newspapers which gave legislative reports, which after a lengthy discussion was referred to a select committee of three.

A message was received from the House, announcing the final passage by that body of a bill establishing a Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners, providing for the election of officers thereof and prescribing the duties of said Board.
Mr. WALLACE offered a resolution to bring on the election of State officers on Friday next at two o'clock, which after various amendments being proposed was laid upon the table yeas 26, nays 21.
On motion of Mr. CONNER, 300 copies of the standing committees were ordered to be printed for the use of the Senate.
On motion, Senators Weir, Bennet and Heffren, were appointed to inquire if there is any law now in force in this State providing the punishment of the crime of embezzlement.

Mr. JOHNSTON offered a resolution providing for letting the State Printing to the lowest responsible bidder, to furnish all materials and give bond for faithful performance work, which was laid upon the tableyeas 23, nays 21.

Mr. STEVENS offered a resolution, which was adopted, directing the Committee on Road to inquire into the expediency of giving to County Commissioners the power to taxes for the making of gravel and turnpike roads, and report by bill or otherwise.

div.head: FELONY.
div.p: Mr. McLEAN offered the following:

Resolved,That the Judiciary Committee be requested to inquire into the expediency of so amending the act defining felonies and prescribing punishment therefor, as to make breach of trust a felony, punishable by the same penalty as grand and petit larceny, and that they report by bill or otherwise.
The resolution was adopted.

div.head: COUNTY COMMISSIONERS.
div.p: Mr. BROWN offered the following, which was adopted:

Resolved,That the Committee on County and Township Businessbe instructed to inquire into the expediency of amending the law in relation to County Commissioners, that there shall be but one commissioner to each county and report by bill or otherwise.

div.head: ALLEN MAY, M. G. BRIGHT AND J. P. DRAKE.
div.p: Mr. WEIR offered a joint resolution (No. 2) with regard to the claims of the State against Colonel Alien May, Michael G. Bright and James P. Drake, Esqr's., directing the Attorney General to proceed to the collection o said loans by due process of law, and further providing that if the Attorney General should fail to begin suit within 30 days after the passing of this resolution, that the Treasurer of State be authorized to employ other counsel to do the same.
Mr. WALLACE said no blame should be attached to the Attorney General for not bringing on this suit, because he had no authority so to do.

Mr. STEELE thought it was somebody's duty.
Mr. WEIR stated, that the resolution was not intended to reflect upon the Attorney General.
Mr. FISK moved to amend by inserting the words "unless properly secured to the satisfaction of the Treasurer of State."

Mr. CARNAHAN stated that there was suf-ficent property mortgaged and held by Messrs. Bright and Drake, Colonel May's sureties, to secure the full payment of the debt, and all they wanted was time to dispose of the mortgaged property.
Mr. JOHNSTON thought this resolution was an entering wedge to the relief of the former Treasurer of State from the payment of certain moneys. He moved -

p.hi: "To refer the resolution to the Committee on the Judiciary, and that said committee be requested to report to this Senate, whether the bringing of such suit will not discharge the treasurer from an obligation that he is now under to the State on his bond."

div.p: Mr. HEFFREN stated that Mr. Bright has a proposition pending before the House of Representatives for the settlement of this whole matter.
Mr. SLACK made an ineffectual motion to lay the whole matter on the table.
Mr. WALLACE offered the following as additional instructions:

p.hi: "And enquire, whether it will not be accessary to amend the act of 1855, relative to the duties of Attorney General."

div.p: Mr. BENNETT moved to further instruct the committee to inquire into the expediency of abolishing the office of Attorney General.
Mr. WALLACE protested against that.
Mr. MARCH did not believe there was any need for that office.
Mr. HAMILTON made an ineffectual motion to lay instructions on the table.
The whole subject was then referred to the Judiciary Committee.

div.head: JOURNAL OF THE LAST SESSION.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tempore laid before the Senate a communication from the Secretary of the Senate, showing that the public printer had made a formal demand upon him for the Senate journal of the last session, for the purpose of printing the same; and delivering the said journal back into the custody of the Senate.
Mr. SLACK offered the following:
Resolved, That the Secretary of the Senate be requested to furnish the State Printer the journal of the last session of the Senate.
Pending which, the Senate took a recess till 2 o'clock.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: On motion by Mr. CONLEY, the committee on township business were requested to inquire into the expediency of changing the method of doing said business so as to have but one trustee, and abolish the offices of treasurer and clerk.

div.head: OLD STATE BANKS.
div.p: Mr. WIER offered a joint resolution (No. 3) with regard to moneys due the State from the old State Bank, and authorizing the appointment of a joint select committee to investigate the matter.
Mr. STEELE said it seemed like another bank fraud matter, to institute this investigation.
Mr. WIER said the resolution was not offered to cast any reflection upon any officer.
Mr. WALLACE moved to postpone the resolution one week from to-day, and if the report from the bank officers was not in by that time, he would move a further postponement.
Mr. STEELE moved to lay the resolution on the table.
The motion was agreed to - yeas 32, nays 16.

div.head: SINKING FUND COMMISSIONERS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. STUDABAKER, the bill (H. R. 10) establishing a Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners, providing for the election thereof, and prescribing the duties of the Board, was taken up, and passed the first and second reading.

Mr. WALLACE moved its reference to the Judiciary Committee with instructions to inquire into the expediency of reducing the Board to a President and two commissioners, to prescribe their duties, and to fix the salary of the President and each commissioner.

Mr. JOHNSTON moved that the committee be instructed to inquire into the expediency of requiring the payment of the bonds as soon as possible, so as to apply the money coming thereby to the use of common schools.

Mr. SLACK moved to further instruct, as to inquire into the expediency of so amending section 9, that the salary of the president of the Board shall not exceed $1,000 per year, and the salary of the clerk of the Board shall not exceed $800 per year. And strike out all that part of section 7 which authorizes the employment of as many assistants as may be deemed necessary.
Which propositions to instructive Committee were severally agreed to, and so the bill was referred.

div.head: UNITED STATES SENATORS.
div.p: Mr. PRESIDENT,pro tem., CRAVENS, (Mr. Wagner in the Chair,) desired to present a memorial which he assured gentlemen would not be objectionable to any Senator upon this floor.

No objection being made, Mr. Cravens read, from the Secretary's stand, a very long document in relation to the seats of Messrs. Bright and Fitch, in the Senate of the United States, setting forth that it is the wish and desire of the people of the State of Indiana, that H. S. Lane and W. M. McCarty be admitted to the places of Senators Bright and Fitch, that Lane and McCarty were constitutionally elected to said places, &c., &c.
On motion by Mr. WALLACE a call of the Senate was had, and the Secretary reported every Senator as present.

Mr. WALLACE. I understand this memorial states as a fact that which I can not and do not believe. It is this: That the State of Indiana is not now represented by Senators in the Senate of the United States.
Mr. CRAVENS. I asserted that fact in the memorial, because the Legislature has passed a resolution stating that such is the case.
Mr. WALLACE then made some remarks, calling into question several matters set forth in this paper.
Mr, CRAVENS replied, in defense of his memorial.

Mr. HEFFREN moved to amend by striking out the words " Vice President of the United States." Two years ago the Republican party did not seek to make the Vice President the sewer through which they were to put this thing through the United States Senate - they designated Mr. Trumbull.
On Mr. WEIR'S motion the amendment was laid on the table by yeas 28, nays 20.The question being upon the passage -
The yeas and nays were demanded, and being ordered and taken, resulted - yeas 26, nays 6, refusing to vote 18 - as follows:

YEAS. - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson, Bennet, Blair, Bobbs, Brown, Conner, Cooper, Cravens, Craven, Culver, Green, Hendry. Hill, Jones, Kinley, March, Murray, Rice, Robinson, Steele, Stevens, Thompson, Turner, Wagner and Weir - 26.
NAYS. - Messrs. Hamilton, McLeaa, Odell, Shoemaker, Studabaker and Williams6.
REFUSING TO VOTE. - Messrs. Carnahan, Cobb, Conley, Fisk, Gooding, Hargrove, Heffren Jennings, Johnston, Line, Lomax, McClure, Miller, O'Brien, Slack, Tarkington, Wallace and Wilson -18.

Mr. CARNAHAN, when his name was called said: Believing it to be the case that a majority of the Indiana Legislature elected Messrs. Bright and Fitch, I look upon all this as a farce, and therefore refuse to vote.
Mr. HEFFREN, when his name was called, said: In the language of the Senator from Union, (Mr. Bennett) the other day, "It reads very fine, but I don't believe a word of it." I refuse to vote.
Mr. JOHNSTON, when his name was called, said: I refuse to vote for the same reason.
Mr. McLEAN, when his name was called, said: With the hope that this will be the last grand act in this drama, I shall participate in it by voting "No."
Mr. STEVENS, when his name was called, said: The reason that I vote is because I am present, and can not see but one sensible way of voting. I vote "Aye."
Mr. WALLACE, when his name was called, asked the Senate to excuse him. The Senate refused to excuse him, and he peremptorily refused to vote.
Mr. WILSON, when his name was called, also asked to be excused from voting. The Senate refused, and he said : I wish to I law-abiding man, but I utterly refuse to vote. So the memorial was adopted.
And the Senate adjourned.

div.head: DEAF AND DUMB AND BLIND.
div.p: Mr. BOYD (by unanimous consent) submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved, That the Superintendents of the Asylums for the education of the Deaf and Dumb and Blind, are respectfully invited to give exhibitions of the progress of the pupils under their care, before the members of this General Assembly ; that the Clerk inform the said Superintendent of the adoption of this resolution, and report the time when it will be convenient for the proposed exhibit to be given.

div.head: BOARD OF SINKING FUND COMMISSIONERS.
div.p: Mr. HUNTER, from the Committee on Ways and Means, reported back Mr. Smith's of Perry, bill (H. R. 10) establishing a Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners, &c., without amendment, recommending its passage, The report was concurred in.

Mr. DOUGHERTY. As that is a very important bill, and as it is doubtful whether the Sinking Fund has now any legal custodian, I move that the bill be considered as engrossed and read the third time now.
Mr. DAVIS. The fund is all safe enough.
The motion was agreed to, and the bill being again read through by the Clerk, the vote on the question: Shall the bill pass? resulted yeas 87, nays 1.
So the bill passed the third and last reading in the House of Representatives.
Mr. STANFIELD submitted the following:
Resolved,That no Committee of this House shall employ a clerk at the expense of the State without being previously authorized by a resolution of the House.
Mr. BOYD. What will be done with those already employed?
The resolution was adopted by consent.
Mr. JONES submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved,That the Judiciary Committee be instructored to inquire into the expediency of enacting a law prohibiting Deputy Auditors from acting as Deputy Treasarers and Deputy Treasurers form acting as Deputy Auditors, and report by bill or otherwise.
Mr. FIRESTONE submitted the following:

Resolved,That the Committee on Roads inquire into the expediency of levying one and one-fourth cent on each acre of taxable land in this State for the use of public roads, and report by bill or otherwise.

Mr. PROSSER. I hope this resolution willnot be adopted. We are in for taxation on the ad valorem system. There are lands not worth twenty-five cents an acre, that would pay just as much tax as land worth $150 an acre. The resolution was rejected.
Mr. HARTLEY submitted the following which was adopted:
Resolved,That the Committee on Ways and Means inquire into the expediency of so changing the assessment law that the tax-payer may deduct money on hand from his tax account or personal property.
Mr.GORDON submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved,That the Committee on County and Township Business be requested to take into consideration the propriety of reducing the number of township officers to three trustees - one to act as treasurer, one as clerk and done as president of the Board.

Mr. MURRAY submitted the following resolution - remarking that it was one of series he had offered at the extra session. He was informed that the greater portion of resolutions we then offered instructing committees, had never been sent to the committees - the principal clerk having neglected his duties in that case.

Resolved, Resolved, That so much of the Auditor's report which refers to the present insufficiency of the Insurance laws, where companies are doing business in the State, regardless of its provisions, be referred to the Committee on the Judiciary,with instructions to inquire what further legislation upon that subject is necessary, and report by bill or otherwise.
The resolution was adopted.
Mr. TREADWAY submitted the following,which was adopted:
Resolution,That the Committee on Agriculture be instructed to inquire into the expediency of ordering a thorough geological survey of the State of Indiana.

Mr. DURHAM introduced a bill (No. 51) to y amend the 3d section of the act containing several provisions, regarding landlords and tenants,lessors and lessees, approved May 1852, which was passed the first reading.
Mr. COLLIER, (by unanimous consent,) introduced the following resolution, (No. 4) which was passed the first reading.
WHEREAS, It is the duty of the Legislature at the present session to elect a State Printer: Therefore,

Resolved by the General Assembly of the State of Indiana, That notice be given, upon the passage of this joint resolution, that proposals will be received till the day of January inst., and that the two Houses will proceed on said day, in joint convention, to elect the loweset responsible bidder to said office of State Printer, and that he be required to furnish the paper and all other matters necessary in the discharge of his duties as State Printer, at his own expense, and that he be required to give bond and approved security for the faithful performance of said work in a good, substantial and workmanlike manner.

div.head: NEW PROPOSITIONS
div.p: Mr. WATERMAN introduced a bill (No. 52) to provide for the election and qualification of assessors, and prescribing a part of their duties.

Mr. HALL, of Rush, introduced a bill (No. 53) to amend the 14th section of the act providing for the electon or appointment of Supervisors of highways, and ascertain the duties of county and township officers in relation thereto, approved June 18, 1852. [The bill provides that no person shall be required to work more than two days in each year.]

Mr. STANLEY introduced a bill (No. 54) to prohibit clerks and deputy clerks in the Supreme and Circuit Courts, and in the Courts of Common Pleas from prosecuting as attorneys counselers at law, and prescribing penalties against such clerks for refusing to issue writs and summonses.

Mr. COLGROVE introduced a bill (No. 55) giving to the clerks of the several Circuit Courts in this State probate jurisdiction, defining their powers and duties there; fixing their compensation therefor, and to prohibit clerks and their deputies from practicing law, and providing penalties therefor; and repealing all laws in conflict with this act.

Mr. COLGROVE introduced a bill (No. 56) to repeal the acts establishing Courts of Common Pleas, and defining the jurisdiction and duties of, and providing compensation for, the Judges thereof, approved May 14, 1852.
Mr. HARNEY introduced a bill (No. 57) to amend the 74th section of the act defining misdemeanors and prescribing punishments therefor, approved June 17, 1852.
Mr. MARTIN introduced a bill (No. 58) to require the Governor to make requisition for the apprehension and delivering up of fugitives from justice.

Mr. HARRISON introduced a bill (No. 59) to extend to borrowers from the Sinking Fund, the Surplus Revenue Fund, the College Fund, the Saline Fund, the Congressional School Fund, and other trust funds, time for payment of their loans, and prescribing the duties of officers in relation thereto.
Which bills were severally passed the first reading.

div.head: THE CALENDAR.
div.p: Mr. Stanfield's bill (5) to authorize school townships, coming up, it was referred to the Committee on Corporations.
Mr. Nebeker, of Warren's, bill (6) in relation to county lines, coming up, it was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. Shull's bill (7) providing for a conventional interest coming up, it was referred to the same committee.
Mr. Ritter's bill (8) to preserve public buildings, coming up, it was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. Jones' bill (9) to establish an independent treasury, coming up -
On motion of Mr. TREADWAY, the rule was suspendedyeas 63, nays 23 and the bill was read the second time by title
Mr. JONES moved its reference to a select committee of seven.
Mr. DOUGHERTY suggested the committee to which the independent treasury portion of the Governor's message had been referred.
The SPEAKER. The committee has not been appointed.
Mr. JONES acquiesced, and it was so referred.
Mr. Cavin's bill (11) to amend section 21 of the act for the organization of County Boards, coming up -
Mr, CAVINS said, it authorized the Commissioners to levy, in their discretion, any amount of tax for payment of county bonds, instead of 25 cents on the $100.
The bill was ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. Martin's bill (12) to prevent the circulation of unauthorized bank paper, coming up -

Mr. BAIRD proposed to amend by "striking out all that part making it a misdemeanor to issue the paper therein described - leaving it a misdemeanor to fail or refuse to redeem the same on demand." Why should the mere issuing of such paper be a crime? Who is injured by it if the paper is redeemed? Is there any harm done? There are many of these in my district - one has existed for twenty years, and always redeemed. Why should that man be subject to the penalties of this bill?
Mr. KEEFER replied - proposing to compel Mr. Watson to bank according to law.
Mr. MARTIN and Mr. MURRAY demanded the yeas and nays on the amendment, which being taken, resulted yeas 3, nays 88. So the amendment was lost.
Mr. KNOWLTON proposed to amend by adding a clause to the effect, "that all penalties herein prescribed for failing to redeem, shall apply to banks and bankers. ("Consent.")
Mr. MARTIN hoped no amendment would be adopted to kill the bill.
Mr. DAVIS moved to refer the bill and pending amendment to the Committee on the Judiciary.
The motion was agreed to.
Mr. Gregory's bill (13) to amend the Constitution so as to confine the voter's qualification to six months' residence, &c., coming up -
On motion by Mr. AUSTIN, it was referred to a select committee of five, which the SPEAKER makes to consist of Messrs. Austin, Gregory, Kempf, Mansfield and Blythe.
Mr. Martin's bill (14) to amend the 14th section of the act for the election of Justices of the Peace, coming up -
On motion by Mr. KNOWLTON it was referred to a select committee of three, which the SPEAKER makes to consist of Messrs Knowlton, Martin and Cavens.
Mr. Ritter's bill (15) to amend the first and sixth sections of the exemption law, coming up - it was referred to the committee on Rights and Privileges.

Mr. HALL, of Grant, (by leave) introduced a bill (No. 60) to authorize the County Commissioners of Grant county, to open a settlement with Samuel L. Woolman and grant any relief to the said Woolman, which passed the first reading.
On motion by Mr. HALL, (the rules being suspended for the purpose - yeas 66, nays 19,) the bill was read the second time and ordered to be engrossed.

Mr. BOYD (by consent) introduced a bill, (No. 61,) to regulate the retailing of intoxicating liquors, to suppress the evils arising therefrom, fixing penalties for the violation of the law, and declaring certain contracts void which was passed the first reading.
Mr. DURHAM'S joint resolution, (1) memorializing Congress for an old soldier's pension, coming up -
Mr. DOUGHERTY proposed to amend inserting appropriately the word "indigent,"" so as to read "such indigent soldiers," &c.
On motion by Mr. EDWARD'S, the resolution and proposed amendment were referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.
Mr. Waterman's joint resolution (2) in relation to agricultural colleges, coming up, was referred to the Committee on Agriculture.
Mr. Hunter's joint resolution, relative to the United States Armory at the falls of the Ohio, coming up.
Mr. DOBBIN'S suggested a committee to inquire into who were the United States Senators addressed in the resolution.
On motion by Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, it was referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Mr. Hamilton, of Boone's, bill (17) to so amend the misdemeanor act of June 14, 1852, as better to protect the bodies of the dead, coming up on the second reading -
On motion by Mr. RITTER, it was referred, to a select committee of five, which the Speaker makes to consist of Messrs. Ritter, Hamilton, of Boone, Firestone, Sullivan and Gifford.
Mr. TURPIE'S bill (18) to repeal the Game Law, coming up -
Mr. PARRETT moved to refer it to a select committee of five.
Mr. TURPIE objected to the reference of so plain a proposition.
Mr. DAVIS understood there was a diversity as to the time when game may be killed, and hoped the bill would not now be put upon its passage. The law had certainly operated to protect quails, &c.

Mr. MELLETT had been entrusted with a petition for some modification of the game law, which at the proper time he hoped would be referred to the same committee, who should consider the bill. He also objected to the re-seal of the law.
Mr. TURPIE insisted that no modification of the law could be made without destroying ts principle - the most odious - principleof jiving half the fine to the informer.
Mr. DAVIS. Why not strike out the objectionable feature?
Mr. TURPIE. Because that could not be lone without invalidating the act. I move to ay the amendment on the table, and demand he yeas and nays.
Mr. DAVIS. And the bill also.

Mr. DOBBINS demanded a division of the question.
The first question being on laying the bill on the table, was determined by yeas 38, nays 5 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Black, Bowman, Boxley, Brotherton, Carr, Claypool, Clayton. Cotton, Davis, Dougherty, Edwards, Firestone, Fordyce, Gifford, Gregory, Hancock,Jeffries, Johnston, Keefer, Lawhead, Major, Mansfield, Mellett, Miller, Murray, Nebeker, of Vermillion, Nebeker, of Warren. Scott, Sherman, Snyder. Stanfield, Stiles, Thompson, of Elkhart, Thompson, of Madison,Treadway,Waterman, and Mr. Speaker 38.

NAYS Messrs. Austin, Blythe, Boyd, Cavins. Clark, Clements, Colgrove, Collier, Comstock, Davidson, Dobbins, Durham. Devol, Early, Griffin, Hall, of Grant, Hall, of Rush, Hamilton, of Boone, Hamilton, of Wayne, Harney, Hartley, Hunter, Jones, Jordan, Kelly, Kempf, Knowlton, Lewis, McLain, Massey, Martin, Nelson, Newton, Parks, Parrett, Power, Prosser, Ritter, Robinson, Row, Rynerson, Shields, Shockley, Shull, Smith, of Miami, Stanley, Sullivan, Summers, Tebbs, Turpie, Usrey, Wheeler, Whetzel, Wildman and Wood-55.
So the House refused to lay the bill on thetable; and the question recurring on laying e motion to commit on the table, was decided by yeas 58, nays 36; so that motion was laid on the table.

Mr. MURRAY proposed to commit to the Conmittee on the Judiciary, with instructions "to inquire into the expediency of repealing at part which relates to giving compensation to the informer." He hoped our game law is not going to be repealed. He objected tounrestrained onslaught on the wild game.

Mr. TURPIE felt satisfied that a majority of the House were in favor of the repeal of this law. The present law invited the onslaught deprecated by the gentleman. It was a law also to invite an onslaught by the fancy of the metropolitan saloons upon theme fattened at the expense of the farmer all the game regions of the State. He moved again to lay the motion to commit and the instructions on the table, and again demanded the yeas and nays, which being seconded and and ordered, resulted - yeas 52, nays 41; so the House again refused to commit.

Mr. MILLER moyed to recommit to the Judiciary Committee, with instructions "to end the game law so as to prolong the time ed which prairie chickens may be killed till first of February, also to repeal that part a which gives compensation to the informers."
Mr. STILES spoke to this motion, and in be reply to Mr. Turpie.

Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, proposed to addto the instructions "that the committee change the law so as to permit farmers to kill game on at all times on their own farms," speaking at length against the repeal of the law.
Mr. DOBBINS. Perhaps every man in his county was opposed to this law. He wanted a direct vote.

Mr. TURPIE spoke again in reply, and proceed to state that the law was not so objectionable to him as to the mass of the farmers who demanded this repeal. The principle of a game law was as old as feudalism, and could have little applicability to our country, though one might go for one framed on proper principles. He demanded the previous question, and there being a second, the main question was ordered, viz.: The adoption of Mr. Nebeker's amendment to the instructions, the vote resulting yeas 54, nays 36.
So the amendment to the instructions was adopted, and the question recurred on commitment with the instructions as amended, the vote resulting - yeas 54, nays 39.
So the bill was referred to the Judiciary Committee.

Mr. MELLETT (by leave) presented a petition of T. M. Scott and others, for amendment of the game law so as to extend the time for taking quails till February, which was referred to the same committee.

The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from the Superintendent of the Asylum for the Insane, responding to Mr. Smith, of Perry's resolution of the extra session, in regard to expense of patients, &c.
On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, it was ordered to lie on the table, and that 500 copies thereof be printed for the use of the House of Representatives.
Mr. Mellett's bill (19) to prohibit false entries by trustees, declaring the same a felony, &c., coming up on the second reading, it was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. Hamilton, of Boone's bill (20) to prevent the carrying of concealed weapons, coming up, it was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. Scott's bill (21) to provide for voluntary assignments for the benefit of creditors, coming up -
Mr. DAVIS proposed to refer to the Committee on the Judiciary, but did not press the motion.
Mr. PARRETT preferred a select committee of five, which prevailed, and it was referred to a committee, which the Speaker makes to consist of Messrs. Parrett, Mellett, Scott, Colgrove and Griffin.
Mr. Nebeker, of Warren's bill (22) for a conventional interest, coming up, it was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
The House then (at 4 o'clock) adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tempore laid before the Senate a communication from M. G. Bright and J. P. Drake, Esq's., offering to liquidate by transfer of real estate, the claim of the State against Colonel Allen May, whose securities they were.
Mr. SLACK moved its reference to the Committee on Finance.

Mr. WEIR said this subject has been before the Committee on Finance and afterwards it had been referred to the Judiciary Committee ; he therefore moved to amend the motion by referring it to a select committee of three.

Mr. HEFFREN thought we had nothing to
do with Messrs. May, Bright and Drake; we should hold Dr. Noffsinger responsible, because he, as the financial officer of the State, loaned this money unlawfully.
Mr. STEELE said that the Senator from Washington, [Mr. Heffren,] takes strange views of this matter; and therefore proceeded to defend Dr. Noffsinger from any imputations that may be cast upon him.
Mr. TARKINGTON could not see why the Legislature should proceed against these sureties, but thought it proper that the Treasurer himself should be held responsible for the amount.

Mr. LINE moved to amend the amendment by adding the following: "with instructions to investigate all the facts in the case, and present to this Senate a detailed statement of such facts at as early a day as practicable."
Mr. WEIR accepted the amendment.
Mr. TARKINGTON moved to lay the whole matter upon the table.The motion was rejected by yeas 18, nays 31.
The motion of the Senator from Huntington, [Mr. Slack,] was lost, upon a division, by the vote of the PRESIDENT pro tem.
Mr. CONNER offered an amendment to the motion to refer, as follows:

Resolved,That the Committee on the Judiciary, to whom was referred the resolution and instructions in reference to the protested drafts of Messrs. Bright and May, be further instructed to inquire into the legality and expediency of not only instituting suit against the said Bright and May, and others, their securites, but also against William R. Noffsinger, late Treasurer of State, and his securities, in order that the State may recover the amount due on account of that transaction as speedily as possible.
Mr. WIER moved to lay on the table.
The motion was lost.
Mr. HEFFREN moved the following as additional instructions to the amendment:

Instruct committee to report a joint resolution directing the Attorney General to bring suit upon the official bond of William R. Noffsinger, for the amount of the bills of exchange endorsed by Bright and Drake.
Mr. SLACK moved the following as further instructions:
Add to the amendment the following:
And that they examine into any other amounts for which he may be liable as a former Treasurer of State; and also, inquire as to the liability and defalcation of any other former Treasurer of State.
Mr. HEFFREN accepted the amendment.
Mr. TARKINGTON offered additional instructions as follows:

That the committee report a bill (if necessary) making it the duty of the Attorney General to commence suit against all persons from whom money is due to the Treasury of State, as officers or otherwise.
Mr. ANTHONY moved to lay on the table all instructions subsequent to those offered by the Senator from Wabash, [Mr. Conner.]
Mr. TARKINGTON called for a division of the question.
Mr. ANTHONY withdrew his motion.
The question being upon the adoption of the amendment proposed by the Senator from Wabash [Mr. Conner] with the pending instructions,Mr. TARKINGTON demanded a division of the question.
The question being upon the reference the matter to the Judiciary Committee, it was so referred.
The instructions proposed by the Senate from Washington [Mr. Heffren] coming up,
Mr. WAGNER moved that they be laid on the table.
The motion was agreed to, by yeas 28, nays 22.
The instructions proposed by the Senator from Brown [Mr. Tarkington] were adopted.
The PRESIDENT pro tempore laid before the Senate the biennial report of the State Bank, of Indiana.
Mr. SLACK moved that it lay on the table and 500 copies be printed.
The motion was agreed to

div.head: NEWSPAPERS AND REPORTING.
div.p: Mr. TARKINGTON obtained leave to make a report from the select committee appointed to ascertain on what terms a report of the proceedings of the Senate could be published in the same manner and as fully as they were published in the Legislative Sentinel of the last session.
The committee reported several propositions, and recommended the adoption of the following:
Resolved,That the Door-keeper procure three copies each of the Daily Sentinel and Daily Journal, two enveloped and stamped, and one copy of each loose, as per agreement.
Mr. WALLACE said he had authority to say that the Citizen office would print the reports, as they may be furnished by an official Reporter, for about one-half those rates.
Mr. GREEN submitted a supplemental report, recommending a subscription to the Weekly American, Volksblatt and Free Presse, three copies eachtwo of the American and all of the German papers stamped.
Mr. GOODING saw no reason why the Citizen should not have the job, if it would do it for half price.

Mr. WILLIAMS moved to recommit, with instructions to contract with the proprietors of the daily papers of this city for four hundred copies of their daily papers, to be taken daily by the Senate, provided they will publish as full proceedings as the Daily State Sentinel did at the extra session, provided the same can be had at the same rates they furnished them at the extra session.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Mr. WILLIAMS said he was opposed to taking papers unless we had the proceedings of this body published something near as full as we had last session in the Legislative Sentinel, and in order to enable the printers to keep a competent reporter upon this floor, he had submitted his proposition to take eight copies of the daily paper publishing full reports.

Mr. WALLACE said that he had been handed a proposition from the Citizen office, but he saw nothing to be gained by their proposal. He was satisfied that each Senator is so desirous of having the Legislative Sentinel that they would pay for it out of their own pockets, should the Senate refuse to subscribe for it.
Mr. HEFFREN moved to lay the whole matter on the table, to enable a resolution to be introduced covering the whole matter, and settling the question at once.
The resolution was agreed to.
Mr. HAMILTON obtained leave to introduce the following resolution, which was adopted:

Resolved, That the Committee on Printing inquire into the expediency of reducing the price paid for the printing of the Journals of the Legislature, the Laws of the State, and such other printing as is necessary for the State of Indiana, for which the State pays, of every kind, and to report by bill or otherwise.

Mr. GREEN, from the Select Committee to which was referred his bill (S. 3) enlarging the Seventh Judicial Circuit, by adding to the same the counties of Hancock, Madison, Hamilton, Tipton and Howard, and fixing the time of holding Circuit Courts therein, reported the same back with sundry amendments.
The report was concurred in, and the bill read the second time by its title.
On motion of Mr. MURRAY, the bill was considered as engrossed, read through the third time and finally passed the Senateyeas 47, nays 2.
The PRESIDENT, pro tempore, laid before the Senate the annual report from the Trustees of the Wabash and Erie Canal.
Mr. HEFFREN moved that it be laid on the table, and 200 copies printed.
The motion was rejected, after two votes, by yeas and nays - the second resulting - yeas 19, nays 30.
The report was then read.
Mr. WALLACE moved its reference to the Committee on Canals and Internal Improvements, and that 500 copies be printed.
The motion was agreed to.
On motion by Mr. WALLACE, Senators Hamilton, Conner, Carnahan and McLain were added to the Committee on Canals and Internal Improvements.
On Mr. WEIR'S motion, Mr. Murray was also added to the same committee.

Mr. TURNER offered a resolution that the Senate subscribe for three copies each of the Daily Journal, Sentinel,Citizen, weekly American, Volksblatt and Frie Presse, two of the English and all the German papers to be enveloped and stamped.
Mr. JOHNSTON moved to strike out all papers except the Sentinel and Journal.
Mr. MARCH offered the following as an amendment.
Providing that each daily paper publish full reports of the proceedings of this body.
Mr. TURNER accepted the amendment, and moved the previous question.

There being a second, under its operation the amendment of the Senator from Putnam [Mr. Johnston] was rejected - yeas 23, nays 26and the original resolution, as amended by the Senator from Delaware [Mr. March] was adopted by yeas 27, nays 23.
Mr. GOODING offered the following:

ResolvedThat the Senate will, the House of Representatives concurring therein, proceed, in the Hall of the House ot Representatives, at 10 o'clock, A. M.,on to-morrow, to elect by joint viva voce vote, a State Agent, a Canal Trustee, a State Librarian, and Trustees for the Insane, Blind, and Deaf and Dumb Asylums, according to law.
Upon Mr. TARKINGTON'S motion the resolution was laid on the table by yeas 32, nays 17.

A message was received from the House of Representatives announcing the passage by that body of a joint resolution (H. R. 5) instructing our legally elected Senators and requesting our Representatives to vote for a law giving to each settler on the public lands 160 acres.
Also, a joint resolution (H. R. 6) authorizing a number of German books to be delivered to township libraries where the number of German voters justify it.
Mr. HEFFREN offered the following resolution, which was adopted by consent:

Resolved That the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to inquire into and report to the Senate whether under the provisions of the Constitution a Senator elected to fill a vacancy occasioned by resignation, or otherwise, shall hold his office for the unexpired term, or for the full term of four years.

Mr. BEESON offered a preamble and resolution that on the 19th inst., the Senate repair to the Hall of the House of Representatives, to receive and hear petitions from women of the State, praying for legislation in their behalf. He sustained his resolution in a few remarks.
The resolution was adopted.
And then the Senate adjourned.

div.head: HIGH PRESSURE, CONFISCATION AND DESTRUCTION.
div.p: The SPEAKER laid before the House the petition of sundry citizens of the counties of Marion and Hancock, praying for a liquor law on the "high pressure, confiscation and destruction principle," which was being read, when -
Mr. KNOWLTON moved that the further reading be dispensed with -
Mr. FIRESTONE moved to refer to the Committee on Military Affairs.
Mr. SCOTT moved that it be tabled, as its terms were disrespectful to the House of Representatives.
Mr. PROSSER proposed to amend by substituting a motion to reject.

Mr. Speaker GORDON said he had had no time to read the petition having received it from one of the most intelligent citizens of the State, who assured him it was from the people of Hancock and Marion. They may have used indecorous language, but certainly no insult could have been intended. I know them - many of them - to be as good men as there are in the State. It might not appear so offensive if it were read well, instead of the slow and faulty manner in which it was begun. I ask that it may take the usual course. I ask it on the part of the signers of the paper whom I know.

A lengthy debate here ensued upon the reference of the petition which occupied nearly the entire morning session. The discussion involved the right of petition, prohibitory laws, the license system, &c., &c.
The SPEAKER decided the motion to reject to be out of order.

Mr. KNOWLTON demanded a division of the questionthe first question being: Shall the petition be received; was decided by yeas 80, nays 16 - Messrs. Keefer, Merrifield, Sullivan and others voting in the negative, because the paper was considered unfit to be read. Pending the next question: Shall the petition be referred to the Committee on Temperance ?
Mr. DOUGHERTY moved to lay the motion and the petition on the table, and the vote resultedyeas 36, nays 62, so the latter motion was rejected.

Mr. BAIRD made an ineffectual motion to refer to a select committee of three.The petition was then referred to the Committee on Temperance.Mr. DAVIS presented the petition of Jared O. Jocelyn, praying for compensation for services, which was referred to the Committee on Fees and Salaries .

div.head: THE EDWARDS AND FIRESTONE CONTEST.
div.p: Mr. STANFIELD, in conformity with an order of the House, at the extra session, submitted the following report:

MR. SPEAKER :In obedience to the resolution of this House at its special session, I proceeded to Huntington to take the deposition of witnesses in the case mentioned in second resolution. Finding that a full investigation had been had of all the facts in controversy arising in said election in a contest of the seat of a County Commissioner elected at that election, which had been reduced to writing, and eould, by an agreement between the parties, be made applicable as evidence in this cause, I procured such an agreement to be made; and I herewith lay befere the House the evidence taken in pursuance of it, and also the poll books and tally papers of said election in Huntington township, which may be valuable in showing the truth of the fact in controversy. All of which is respectfully submitted.
THOS. S. STANFIELD.
The report was received and referred to the Committee on Elections.
Mr. DURHAM (by consent) presented the petition of Thomas Johnson, which was referred to the Committee on Claims.

Mr. KNOWLTON, from a majority of the select committee to which was referred Mr. Martin's bill (H. R. 14) to amend the 14th section of the Justices act, reported the same back, with an amendment, inserting appropriately, "or where a defendant or defendants has or have promised in writing to discharge any debt or contract in a township, suit may be commenced either in the township where said defendant promised to discharge the same, or where either of the defendants reside;" and so amended they recommend the passage of the bill.
Mr. MARTIN opposed the adoption of the amendment.
Mr. KNOWLTON explained it.
Mr. LAWHEAD opposed it from the fact that three-fourths of the promissory notes were made at the county seat.

Mr. CAVINS. The bill provides that the assignors of the note shall not be made parties to it. We propose to make an additional amendment: that where a man has promised to pay a note at a particular place, it shall be collectable there, or where he resides.

Mr. MURRAY. The effect of the amendment would be to compel their creditors to sign notes collectable at the county seats. It would break up the business of the Justices of the Peace in rural townships. The proposed change would increase costs in the mileage of constables. Should not we legislate for the benefit of the people at large, rather than those petty office-holders?
Mr. LAWHEAD. The adoption of this amendment would create a necessity for drawing notes, waiving its force.
Mr. HALL, of Rush, also approved the amendment.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The SPEAKER laid before the House a report from the Trustees of the Wabash and Erie Canal.
On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, it was laid on the table, and 500 copies thereof be printed for the use of the House of Representatives.

div.head: CONGRESSIONAL HOMESTEAD.
div.p: Mr. STILES asked and obtained leave to introduce a joint resolution (No. 5) viz.:

Resolved,That our legally elected Senators and Representatives in Congress be requested to take such action as may be necessary to give to each of the actual settlers on public lands a homestead of one hundred and sixty acres.
Whereupon -
The SPEAKER, ruling that a joint resolution is not a law and does not require three readings, ordered the yeas and nays, which being taken, resulted - yeas 77, nays 1.
So the joint resolution was adopted on the part of the House of Representatives.

div.head: GERMAN BOOKS.
div.p: Mr. KEMPF, (by unanimous consent,) submitted a joint resolution (No. 6) authorizing the addition of a number of books to any township library, where the number of German voters in such township will justify so doing [in the opinion of the State Board of Education.]
The yeas and nays being taken thereon, under the constitutional provision, the result was yeas 77, nays 8.

Mr. KNOWLTON, (by leave,) explained. He understood the resolution to include a distribution of all the books by law required to be distributed. He could go for distributing in the German language books on Government, Agriculture, Commerce and the Mechanic Arts, but no farther.
Mr. KEMPF. The terms of the resolution were so restricted.
So the joint resolution was adopted.

Mr. SHULL asked and obtained leave to submit a joint resolution (No. 7) expressive of the sense of the General Assembly with reference to the distribution of the Common School Fund, [that said distribution among the counties be in proportion to the number of children entitled thereto.]
Mr. DOUGHERTY moved to refer to the Committee on Education.
Mr. BOYD preferred a vote of the House on this resolution. In this way, the Committee on Education would be guided in their action.
Mr. PARKS spoke against the constitutionality of the Senate bill on this subject.
Mr. MANSFIELD. This subject has been before the Committee on Education. If the matter was to be decided By this vote, he would be in favor of sending it first to some committee.
Mr. KEEFER should vote to lay the resolution on the table. He was in favor of each county collecting and appropriating its own school tax.

Mr. SHULL. There was diversity of opinion as to the distribution of this fund. He was satisfied that the northern portion of the State would be loser by any change of the present law of distribution. He desired an expression on the subject by both Houses of the General Assembly.
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, moved to lay the motion and joint resolution on the table.
The motion was agreed to.

The SPEAKER announced the following additional members of the Committee on Judiciary: Messrs. Parrett, Scott and Stiles.The House now resumed the consideration of the committee's amendment to Mr. Martin's bill. (H. R. 14.)
On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the amendment was laid on the table.
The bill was again read through.
Mr. CLEMENTS proposed to amend by adding a section.

p.hi: "SEC. - Nothing herein contained shall prevent the collection of debts in townships where the same shall have been contracted."

div.p: Mr. MURRAY moved to lay the amendment on the table.
Which was agreed to - affirmative 44, negative 20.
Mr. BROTHERTON moved to refer the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, moved to instruct the committee to strike out the exception in the proviso.
Mr. MARTIN explained the abuse which had grown up under the present law.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, said it was wrong to impose upon one a responsibility that belongs alike to all the parties defendant.The House refused to recommit, and the question recurred on engrossment.
On motion by Mr. MURRAY, it was referred to the Judiciary Committee without alterations.

div.head: RESOLUTIONS.
div.p: Mr. HARNEY submitted the following, which was adopted:
Resolved,That this Hall be tendered for the use of the State Temperance Convention, on Monday evening, the l7th, and on Tuesday the 18th inst., to transact their business and hold their meetings.
Mr. DOBBINS submitted the following:

Resolved, That the Committee on Rights and Privileges to whom was referred the bill (No. 7) providing for ten per cent, interest on contract be instructed to report an amendment thereto prohibiting all banks from a greater rate of interest on notes, bills of exchange, &c., per annum, than that which is allowed in said bill to individuals on moneys loaned, with proper penalties and restrictions.
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, moved to make it a resolution of inquiry.
Which was agreed to, and, as thus amended, the resolution was adopted.
Mr. MURRAY submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved, That the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to inquire into the power and expediency of providing, by law, for setting apart a sufficient portion of the funds arising from the State's interest in the State Bank, and distributing the residue immediately among the several counties of the State, in just proportions, to be loaned upon mortgaged security for the benefit of common schools.
Mr. SUMMERS submitted the following:

Resolved,That the Committee on County and Township Business be requested to inquire into the expediency of so amending section 18 of the Act of May 6, 1852. that the Trustees shall annually, on the third Monday in March of each year, settle and audit the accounts of the Treasurers and Supervisors of roads in their respective townships, instead of February, as now provided by law.
Other resolutions were submitted as follows:
By Mr. SULLIVAN, referring that portion of the Governor's Message which refers to banks and bank laws, to a committee of one from each Congressional District.
By Mr. COLLIER, excusing Mr. Dougherty and appointing Mr. Parks a member of the Committee on Education.

By Mr. SNYDER, instructing the Committee on Fees and Salaries, to inquire into the propriety of so amending the law as to attain uniformity in fees and allowances made to County Auditors; to provide a fee for transferring the lands described in each deed instead of as now giving a fee for each description contained in a deed; to provide for a cross index to be made by the County Recorder, and making it a part of the Recorder's duty to continue and keep up the same without charge of allowances.
By Mr. DOBBINS, that Mr. Eastham be excused and Mr. Firestone appointed as a member of the Committee on Military Affairs.
By Mr. JORDON, instructing the Judiciary Committee to inquire whether the circulation of bank bills of a less denomination than five dollars issued by banks in this State can be prohibited by law.

By Mr. WATERMAN, instructing the Fees and Salaries Committee to inquire into the propriety of so amending the law regulating fees and salaries as to allow County officers stated annual salaries, with authority given to Boards doing County Business to allow said officers for clerk hire in counties where justice requires it.

By Mr. JOHNSON, directing the Judiciary Committee to inquire into the expediency of abolishing the present mode of selecting jurors of the Circuit and Common Pleas Courts and providing a cheaper system.
By Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, referring so much of the Auditor's report as relates to the insurance laws to the Committee on Corporations.
By Mr. WILDMAN, instructing the Judiciary Committee to inquire into the expediency of so amending the law as to allow parties to swear to their book accounts.

div.head: JOINT RESOLUTIONS.
div.p: By Mr. SMITH, of Perry, accompanying a memorial from the State Board of Agriculture, on the subject of a geological survey of the State. The memorial was referred to the Committee on Agriculture, and it was ordered to be subsequently returned and referrred to a select committee of sixteen - nine on the part of the House and seven on the part of the Senate - one to be selected from each Agricultural District of the State.
By Mr. SHERMAN, on the subject of an appropriation by the Federal Government for the improvement of the harbor at Michigan City.
By Mr. MURRAY, on the subject of the admission of Oregon and Kansas into the Union.

div.head: BILLS INTRODUCED.
div.p: By Mr. BOYD, amendatory of the act providing for the election and prescribing certain of the duties of Recorders, approved May 31. 1852.
By Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, to regulate and restrain the sale of spirituous and intoxicating liquors to prevent and punish drunkenness and crime.
By Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, to prevent the killing or destruction of wild game repealing laws conflicting therewith.
By Mr. STANFIELD, to amend section 4 of the act concerning interest on money, approved May 27, 1852, so as to allow the recovery of principal and interest.

By Mr. EDWARDS, to regulate the business of Insurance Companies, incorporated by the State of Indianato punish violations of its provisions and to repeal former enactments in regard to such companies.
Which were severally passed the first reading.
The House adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tempore laid before the Senate a communication from the Superintendent of the Indiana Hospital for the Insane, in compliance with a resolution of the Senate, respecting the pay in mileage and per diem of each Trustee for the years 1854, 1855, 1856, 1857 and 1858, &c.

Mr. CULVER presented the petition of a large number of voters of the county of Tippecanoe, praying for the passage of a law raising the rate of interest to 10 per centum, which was referred to the Committee on Finance. Also, a petition from the same county, asking for a law making railroad companies liable for stock killed where said roads can not be fenced, which was referred to the Committee on Corporations.
Mr. HARGROVE presented a petition from sundry citizens of the county of Gibson on the subject of temperance, which was referred to the Committee on Temperance.
Mr. ODELL presented the petition of Henry M. Wright, praying an allowance for pursuing and arresting a murderer, which was referred to the Committee on Claims.
Mr. MARCH, from the Judiciary Committee, to whom was referred the bill (II. R. 10) establishing a Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners, recommending its adoption with the following amendments:
Strike out the provision relating to the employment of assistants, and add that the salary of the President shall not exceed $1,500, and the Clerk $ 1,000.
Mr. SLACK made a minority report from the same committee, recommending -
That all that part of the bill giving to the Board the power of fixing the salary of President, be stricken out, and that the amount be fixed at $500 per annum.
On Mr. MURRAY'S motion, the minority report was tabled - yeas 37, nays 11.
Mr. HARGROVE moved to concur and amend by striking out $1,500 and inserting $1,000.
Mr. SLACK moved that it be $800.
On Mr. STUDABAKER'S motion, the amendments were laid on the table - yeas 34, nays 14.
Mr. SLACK moved to strike out $1,500 and insert $900.
Mr. MURRAY moved the previous question, and there being a second, under its operation the amendment was lost - yeas 11, nays 88 - and the report was concurred in, by yeas 35, hays 14.
On motion by Mr. STUDABAKER, the bill was considered as engrossed and read a third time.
Mr. LINE moved to recommit to a select committee of five, with instructions to strike out $1,500 and insert $1,250.
On motion by Mr. STUDABAKER, this motion was tabled - yeas 31, nays 17.
Mr. SLACK moved to recommit to a committee of five, with instructions to limit the salary of President to $1,100.
Mr. HEFEREN demanded the previous question.
There being a second, under its operation, the motion to recommit was rejectedyeas 15, nays 31and the bill finally passed the Senate, by yeas 36, nays 12.
Mr. SLACK made a motion to take up his resolution, giving the journal of the last session of the Senate into the hands of the State Printer, which was rejected by yeas 21, nays 25.
Mr. WALLACE submitted a resolution to the same effect, which -
On Mr. MURRAY'S motion, was laid on the table - yeas 27, nays 22.

Mr. WAGNER offered a resolution that the Senate will, the House concurring therein, proceed to the Hall of the House this day at half-past two o'clock, for the purpose of electing three Directors of the State Prison, Librarian, Trustee of the Wabash and Erie Canal, State Printer and Agent of State, in the order as above stated.
Mr. STUDABAKER made an ineffectual motion to lay it on the table - yeas 19, nays 30.
Mr. MURRAY moved the previous question; there being a second, under its operation the main question was ordered - yeas 26, nays 24 and the resolution was not adopted - yeas 25, nays 25.

Mr. CONLEY offered a resolution which was adopted, that the Committee on Organization of the Courts inquire into the expediency of abolishing the Court of Common Pleas and establishing a surrogate system for the settlement of estates of decedants, and report a bill to that effect.

Mr. HAMILTON offered a resolution, which was adopted, that the Committee on Finance inquire into the expediency of prohibiting all officers of the State holding public moneys from loaning the same, and also providing by law where the public funds shall be deposited.

On motion by Mr. GREEN a concurrent resolution was adopted, appointing a joint committee of two in the Senate and three in the House, to inquire into and make a full investigation of the alleged swamp land frauds.

Mr. COOPER offered a resolution, which was adopted, that the Committee on the State Prison inquire into the expediency of erecting a House of Refuge as contemplated by the Constitution, section 2, article 9.
Mr. JONES offered a resolution, the same as Mr. Wagner's, which is recited above.
Mr. TARKINGTON made an ineffectual motion to lay it on the tableyeas 23, nays 27.
Mr. WAGNER moved the previous question.
There being a second, under its operation the resolution was passed - yeas 27, nays 22.

div.head: BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS
div.p: Mr. BENNETT offerered the following:

Resolved, That the Door keeper be directed to contrat with A. E.Drapier & Son, for six hundred copies of the "Brevier Legislative Reports," of the proceedings and debates of the present General Assembly, after the style [?] their reports in the "Legislative Sentinel"said reports [?] be made up from the columns of some daily newspapers printed in the town of Indianapolis and laid upon the desks of members as fast as they shall complete sixteen pages in double newspaper column; provided the cost I the same shall not exceed one dollar per copythe House adopting a similar resolution.
The yeas and nays were demanded, and being ordered and taken, resulted - yeas 29, nays 19 - as follows:

YEAS- Messrs. Anthony, Bennet, Brown, Cobb, Connelly, Cravens of Jefferson, Fisk, Gooding, Hamilton, Heffren, Line, Lomax, McClure, McLean, March, Miller, Murray, O'Brien, Rice, Shoemaker, Slack, Steele, Stevens, Studabaker, Tarkington, Turner, Wallace, Weir,Williams - 29.
NAYS - Messrs.Beeson, Blair, Bobbs, Carnahan, Conn[?], Cooper, Craven of Madison, Culver, Green, Hargro[?], Hendry, Hill, Johnston, Jones, Kinley, Odell, Robins, Thompson, Wilson - 19.
So the resolution was adopted.,
[A message from the House of Represenatives announced the concurrence of that bo in the memorial to the Senate of the United States in relation to the seats of Mess[?] Lane and McCarty.,
Also, the concurrance of the House in Senate amendments to the bill (H. R. 10), establishing a Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners.]

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p:
On Mr. WEIR'S motion, the special order being the consideration of the Governor's
Message was postponed until Monday two o'clock, P. M.

On motion by Mr. CONNELLY, the Committee on Banks were directed to inquire into the expediency of so amending the Bank, law as to prohibit the circulation of bills of the Banks of other States of a less denomination than $5.

Mr. WEIR offered a resolution directing the Committee on Agriculture to inquire into the expediency of authorizing County Commissioners to purchase and held lands for the use of county agricultural societies.
Mr. BROWN moved, as an amendment, that the Committee on County and Township Business, inquire into the expediency of allowing County Commissioners to purchase sufficient grounds for county fairs.
On motion by Mr. WALLACE, they were preferred to the Committee on Agriculture.
On motion of Mr. WALLACE, it was -
Resolved,That a special committee of three be appointed to prepare and submit to the Senate a bill denning he duties of the Commissioners and President of the Sinking Fund.
Mr. WILSON introduced a resolution that in the opinion of the Senate, any law restricting and regulating the sale of spirituous and intoxicating liquors ought to contain a [?]ay license clause.
Mr. GOODING was in favor of the resolution.
Mr. SLACK wanted to put every thing upon tie same level. If liquor is to be sold let it put upon the same terms as any thing else hat is sold.

Mr. HENDRY opposed the resolution because if it passed it would fail of the object [?] view - it would not be an expression of the opinion of the Senate, because the amount of money for the license is not fixed.
Mr. CARNAHAN was in favor of a pay liscense system, and did not believe a law uponany other plan would effect any thing.
Mr. HAMILTON moved to amend by issuing licenses for not less than $25 nor more than $200, at the option of the County Commissioners.
Mr. WEIR was opposed to their being any money attached to the license system, but if their must be, he was in favor of some low figure [?]th good freehold sureties.
Mr. GREEN moved that it be not less than [?]0 nor more than $5000.
Mr. HAMILTON accepted.
Mr. HEFFREN moved to amend by adding:
"Also, to prohibit all but pure liquors from being sold making it a misdemeanor to sell any impure, drugged mixed liquors."
Mr. WAGNER, could vote for no law that [?] not license for $50.

[?] message from the House of Representatives announced the concurrence of that body the Senate's resolution to go into the election of State officers, and inviting the Senate to the Hall for that purpose.
Mr. WAGNER having the floor, moved that the Senate repair to the Hall of the House instanter, but withdrew it for
Mr. WALLACE, who demanded a call of the Senate.
The call was had and every Senator reported as present.
Mr. WAGNER renewed his motion, which was agreed to, and Senators preceded by the PRESIDENT pro tempore, vacated the Chamber.
When Senators returned -
The Senate adjourned.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
div.p: The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from the Auditor of State, responding to Mr. Davis' resolution, of the llth inst., embracing statements of the amount due from Hiram E. Talbott, at the time of his retirement from the Auditor's office, and the amount which has been collected of him; also, the amount which has been received by the Auditor of State from all sources during the present term, the amount by him paid out, the balance on hand, and where deposited, which was read, and on the motion of Mr. Davis referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.

On motion of Mr. HUNTER, the Senate amendments to Mr. Smith's, of Perry, bill (H. R. 10) were taken up, viz: Strike out from section 7, all that relates to the employment of assistants, and adding to the 9th section, "nor shall the salary of the President exceed $1,500 a year, and the Clerk $1,000 a year; and amending the title accordingly;" and they were concurred in as a whole, without a division.
Mr. FIRESTONE presented the petition of C. W. Hughes and others, for a law to regulate the exhibition of stallions, which was referred to the Committee on Agriculture.

div.head: THE LANE AND M'CARTY MEMORIAL.
div.p: On motion of Mr. MURRAY, this memorial, communicated from the Senate as having been adopted by that body in the name of the people of the State of Indiana, rehearsing at length the history and the Republican view of the election of Senators Bright and Fitch, and memorializing the Senate of the United States against the legality of the seats of Messrs. Bright and Fitch, and in favor of the alleged election and claim preferred to their places by Messrs. Henry S. Lane and William M. M'Carty, and entrusted by resolution to the Vice President of the United States, was taken up, and the same having been read through by the Clerk -

Mr. DAVIS said: Mr. Speaker, I do not propose to discuss this question now, or to reply to or review the memorial. I had the privilege and the honor, when this question of the election, or the pretended election, of United States Senators was pending in ; the extra session, of presenting in brief, the views I then entertained; and I wish now merely to say, in addition to the remarks I then sub-
submitted, that I have the gratification of knowing that the view then taken of this question, by the gentleman from Vanderburg and Posey, and myself, has been sustained by the voice of at least one of the greatest men of the ageone who, like the gentleman from Vanderburg and I, is himself " a fossil " of the great Whig party - I mean the Honorable John J. Crittenden, of Kentucky. He looks upon this question as a settled judicial question - a question that is judicially closed, and cannot be opened by any action of ours; a question that can not now be placed in a position in which the memorial seeks to place it. Further I am gratified to learn that the venerable Joseph Gales, editor of the National Intelligencer - a paper standing in the same relation to other papers that the Bible sustains to other books sustains the same view. I am also further advised that William Pitt Fessenden, a Senator from the State of Maine, entertains the same viewand no one questions his Republicanism. I am further advised - and you, Mr. Speaker, know the fact - that Senator Collamer, of Vermont, a sound lawyer and statesman, entertains precisely the same view which has been declared on this floor by the gentleman from Vanderburg and Posey, and myself. Again, sir, I am advised that the great wheel-horse of Republicanism in the State of Ohio, Mr. Wade, looks upon this as a settled question. I have been told also, that Senator Bell, of Tennessee, a sound lawyer, and one of the most accomplished statesmen of the day, entertains the same view.

It may be that the gentleman from Vanderburg and myself are wrong, but certain it is, if we are wrong, we are in very good company. And is it not strange, Mr. Speaker, that when, in the conscientious discharge of a sworn duty here a duty we have been compelled to discharge under the obligation of a solemn oath we have taken herethat because we have not shrunk from our duty, we are to be traduced by little scribblers all over the State, in every little eight-by-ten, dog-fennel gazette merely because we have discharged our honest duty according to our best understanding in the case.

As I have said before, Mr. Speaker, so I say yet, that I deeply regret that we have no power to go now into an election of United States Senators; for if I had the power to elect United States Senators by my vote, certain it is, that by my vote, Jesse D. Bright and Graham N. Fitch would not be in the Senate of the United States for the State of Indiana. Having stated, when called upon on a former occasion in this place, that I believed it was not in our power to go into that electionthat the question had been settled and closed up against us. And being called upon again by those who have a right to know my views, I say now, that I still see no reason to change the views I then expressed.

What, sir, would be my proper position,should I feel disposed to change my views ? I was a candidate before the people and was elected to this seat here upon a full and free exposition of the views I have expressed on this question. Would it not have been acting unfaithfully to my people had I attempted here to disobey their voice, or to act in deliberate contravention of their expressed will? Most assuredly. No, Mr. Speaker, had I changed my views, I would at once have resigned my seat, in order that the people of the county of Floyd might have found another man to carry out their views. But, sir, 1 say here in my place, that I do not believe there are ten men in the county of Floyd, who do not entertain the views I have here endeavored to represent upon this question.

I have said this, sir, in order that, at some future time, and in my own way I might put tegether what I have now said, and the declarations which I made upon this subject in the extra session; for, although I may have but little reputation abroad in the State, still I desire to be placed right before my constituents upon this question, and especially those of them who take a deep interest in the matter. I desire also to avoid misrepresentation, and, therefore, for my constituents, as well as for myself, I propose that what I say now, and what I have heretofore said on this question, shall be prepared and published in the shape of a speech.
I will not further occupy the time of the House, because I know the friends of this paper desire to have the vote this morning.
And then under the force of the previous question demanded by Mr. Murray, the memorial and resolution were adopted and concurred in by yeas 51, nays 49, as follows :

YEAS. -Messrs. Austin, Baird, Boyd, Boxley, Branham, Brotherton, Cavins, Clark, Colgrove, Collier, Comstock, Cotton, Davidson, Duvoll, Edwards, Pordyce, Gregory, Griffin, Hall of Grant. Hall of Rush, Hamilton of Boone. Hamilton of Wayne, Harrison, Hunter, Jeflfries, Johnston, Jones, Mansfield. Mellet, Miller, Murray, Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Parks, Power. Bitter. Robinson, Rynerson, Scott, Sherman, Shields, Smith of Miami, Stanfield, Stiles, Thompson of Elkhart, Tread-way, Whetzel, Whiteman, Wildman, Mr. Speaker. - 51.

NAYS. - Messrs. Black, Blythe, Bowman, Carr, Claypool, Clayton, Clements, Davis, Dobbins, Dougherty, Durham, Early, Eastham, Firestone, Gifford, Hancock, Harney, Hartley, Jordan, Reefer, Kelly, Kempf, Knowlton, Law-head, Lewis, McLain, Major, Massey, Merrifield, Nelson, Newton, Parrett, Prosser,Row, Shockley, Shull, Smith of Perry, Snyder, Stanley, Stinson, Sullivan, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of Madison, Turpie, Usrey, Waterman, Wheeler, Wood. - 49.

div.head: ALLEN MAY AND SECURITIES.
div.p: Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, submitted a resolution requiring the Attorney General to proceed immediately to institute suit against Colonel Allen May, and his securities, on the $40,000 due from said May to the State, and that any judgment thereon be pressed as speedily as possible, without any unnecessary delay.

Mr. DAVIS raised the question, whether those notes were not the paper of the State Treasurer, and preferred to defer action. He
did not recognize the right of the Treasurer to loan out money and take such notes. If we were to pursue this against May, it would relieve the Treasurer.

On the motion of Mr. EDWARDS, the resolution was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions "to inquire whether the resolution proposes the proper course to be pursued, and if not, what should be done in the premises?"

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: After sundry calls of the House, the Senate concurrent resolutions for the two houses in joint convention, at 2 1/2 o'clock, in the Hall of the House of Representatives to proceed to the election of three Directors of the State Prison, a State Librarian, a Trustee of the Wabash and Erie Canal, a State Printer, and an Agent of State, in the order herein stated, was taken up and concurred in by yeas 58, nays 39.

div.head: IN THE JOINT CONVENTION.
div.p: The Convention of the two Houses was organized according to order - the PRESIDENT pro tem, of the Senate in the Chair - and on the first vote for Directors of the State Prison -
Mr. TURPIE nominated Grafton F. Cookerly, of Vigo county, and Mr. EDWARDS nominated Cullum H. Baily, of Vigo county.

item.p: So Mr. Cookerly was declared elected.
Senator MURRAY nominated Mr. Earlywine, of Shelby county.
Mr. TURPIE nominated Thomas M. Brown, of Floyd county.
Mr. TURPIE nominated Samuel H. Buskirk, of Monroe county.
Senator GREEN nominated J. D. Kelso, of Floyd county.

div.head: STATE LIBRARIAN.
div.p: Under the order for the election of State Librarian -
Mr. TURPIE nominated James R. Bryant, of Marion county.
Senator MURRAY nominated N. Wilson, of Tippecanoe county.
Under the order for the election of Canal Trustee (which was by ballot according to the statutory provision, older than the Constitution.) -
Mr. TURPIE nominated Richard Raleigh, of Vanderburg county.,
Senator WEIR nominated Dudley G. Coffin, of Parke county.
On the first ballot -
Here the Convention took a recess till half-past seven o'clock.

div.head: NIGHT SESSION.
div.p: A call of the Convention proceeded and brought in the absentees:

Mr. Austin and Mr. Newton, Mr. Griffin and Mr. Sullivan, Mr. Black and Mr. Hamilton, of Boone, Mr. Smith, of Perry, and Mr. Branham, Mr. Clements and Mr. Miller, having paired off respectively - the vote on the sixth ballot for Canal Trustee proceeded.
Mr. Raleigh was declared elected.
Mr. TURPIE moved the order of the election of State Printer, and nominated Colonel, John C. Walker, of Laporte county.
Mr. Senator MURRAY nominated Berry R. Sulgrove, of Marion county.
The PRESIDING OFFICER of the Senate directed a viva voce vote in this election, under the constitutional provision.
Mr. Anthony failing to answer, a call of the House on the part of the Senate was demanded, and proceeded without result, until it was dispensed with, when the vote was taken.
For Walker, 73 votes were cast.
For Sulgrove, 68 votes were cast.
Mr. Walker having received a majority of the votes cast, was declared elected.
In the order for the election of State Agent -
Mr. TURPIE nominated Aquilla Jones, of Marion county.
Mr. Senator JONES said he had been requested to withdraw the name of Mr. Jones, and he nominated James A. Cravens, of Washington county.
Mr. Senator MURRAY nominated John D. Defrees, of Marion county.
Mr. Senator SLACK nominated D. C. Stover, of Montgomery county.
Mr. Senator HEFFREN nominated Samuel H. Owen, of Floyd county.
Mr. Senator HEFFREN withdrew the name of Mr. Owen.
On the second ballot -
Mr. HARNEY now withdrew the name of Mr. Stover.
On the fourth ballot -
Mr. Cravens was declared elected.
The Presiding Officer then adjourned the Joint Convention.
The House then (at forty minutes past 9 o'clock) adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tempore laid before the Senate the annual report of the Superintendent of the Hospital for the Insane; which was referred to the Committee on Benevolent Institutions.

div.head: HEATING THE SENATE CHAMBER.
div.p: Mr. BOBBS submitted the bill of cost for the,' heating apparatus furnished for the Senate Chamber, amounting to $940 00; which was referred to the Committee on Finance without reading.

div.head: "INDIANA SCHOOL JOURNAL."
div.p: Mr. CONLEY, by leave, offered a resolution which was adopted, directing the Committee on Education to report a bill providing for placing a bound copy of the Indiana State Journal in all the school libraries in the State.

div.head: STATE LIBRARY.
div.p: Mr. WALLACE had leave to offer a resolution, which was adopted, directing the Librarian to prepare a complete catalogue of books in the State Library, for the use of those having the privilege of the same.
And then the Senate adjourned till Monday two o'clock P. M.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: Leave of absence till Monday was accorded to Messrs. Carr, Parks, Kempf, Robinson, Whetzel and Hall, of Rush; and to Mr. Knowlton till Wednesday, on account of sickness in his family.

div.head: ADJOURNMENT TILL MONDAY.
div.p: Mr. SNYDER submitted a resolution making it a standing rule to adjourn from Saturday at 11 A. M. to Monday, 2 P. M.
The SPEAKER. It can not be considered now because it proposes a new rule.

Mr. SNYDER withdrew the resolution, and moved to suspend the order of business to enable him to make a motion to take up Mr. Park's resolution, submitted last Thursday, which proposes a standing rule for Saturday's adjournment, to the same effect.

Mr. POWER should vote for the resolution,out of consideration for those members standing here in opposition to the Republican party,who had been to a weding and infair last night and needed rest. [Laughter.]
The rules were suspended and the resolution was taken up.
Mr. HALL, of Rush.The adoption of this rule would not retard business.

Mr. MURRAY preferred that gentlemen gohome on leave, and leave a sufficient number disposed to work, at least to read the journal and submit their reports, and asked the House to vote the resolution down.

Mr. RITTER was willing to adopt the rule provided the House would act upon another rule - not to excuse the aboence of any gentleman, except for sickness in his family. The fact was, we sit here too long. It was a clog to legislation to sit here when we ought to be at work in the committees.

div.head: BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS.
div.p: A message from the Senate by Mr. Vawter,their Secretary, announced the adoption in that body of the following resolution:

Resolved, That the Door-keeper be directed to contract A. E. Drapier & Son for six hundred copies of "Brevier Legislative Reports" of the Proceedings and Debates the present General Assembly, after the style of their reports of the proceedings of the late extra session in the"Legislative Sentinel" - said reports to be made up from columns of some daily newspaper printed in the town of Indianapolis, and laid upon the desks of members as fast as they shall complete sixteen pages in double newspaper column: provided the cost of the same shall not exceed one dollar per copy, the House adopting a similar resolution.
[A message from the Governor, by Mr. Osburn, Executive Messenger, announced that his Excellency had approved and signed the Fund Commissioners bill (18. 12.10.) introduced by Mr. Smith, of Perry.]
The rule for adjourning over from 11 till Monday 2 o'clock was adopted, by yeas 25, nays 29.

div.head: WOMAN'S RIGHTS.
div.p: Mr. WHITEMAN moved further to suspend the rules to enable him to make a motion to take up the consideration of the Senate's concurrent resolution; inviting certain ladies to present a petition in their own persons, in the Hall of the House of Representatives, on Wednesday next, the 19th instant, at 2 o'clock P. M.
The motion was agreed to and the resolution was taken up.
On the motion of Mr. DOUGHERTY, the blank was filled with "two."
Mr. MERRIFIELD, and Mr. THOMPSON, of Madison, demanded the yeas and nays on the question of concurrence.

Mr. BRANHAM hoped the House would not concur. He was in favor of the right of petition, but did not think it right to waste the time of the House with such an exhibition as was proposed. It was unnecessary for these petitioners to come into this presence. If they wish to petition for a redress of grievance, let them proceed as in other cases of petition to the Legislature. He considered it due to the reputation of our wives and mothers to refuse to concur in this resolution.
Mr. LAWHED spoke in favor of the adoption of the resolution.
Mr. STILES should vote against the resolution out of consideration for the sex.
Mr. DEVOL, understanding that the petition was to be presented by the ladies in person, was very anxious that the resolution should be concurred in.
Mr. CLAYTON thought this was carrying the joke a little too far in the way of petition. Such an exhibition he believed had never before been proposed in a deliberative body.
