Mr. MURRAY was willing to concur in the resolution, with the following amendment:

p.hi: "That the House will not organize till said petition is presented, and the parties presenting the same shall retire from this Hall."

div.p: If he understood the reading of the resolution, it was that this petition should be presented in person by the ladies at 2 o'clock next Wednesday. He was in favor of giving the ladies the use of the Hall for the presentation of their petition. They desired to present it to the Legislature to read it themselves. He supposed it was to be read. It was directed to the Legislature of the State of Indiana, and all the ladies claimed was the right to read it to us as the Legislature of the State. With the gentleman from Jefferson, (Mr. Branham,) he held that it would be setting a bad example to give the right to these ladies to come in here and occupy our time; for if we allow it to them, we ought not to with old the same right to the humblest petitioner in the State. But what right had the Senate to set apart this Hall for this purpose? Why did they not permit the ladies to come into their chamber?
Mr. POWER should vote for the resolution, because his mother was a woman, and because he loved the ladies generally.
The SPEAKER. On reflection, the Chair decides the amendment out of order.

Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, did not under stand the programme; but if the petition was to be presented by the ladies in person - read by themselves, and acted on here under their influence and dictation, he could not but be apprehensive for the result of such legislation. Still he could not refuse the exercise of the right of petition, and would vote for the resolution with the proposed modification.
Mr. COLGROVE interupting. Is the gentleman from Boone a married man?
Mr. HAMILTON. I am, sir, and have three little babies.
Mr. COLGROVE. Then it was not to be supposed that the gentleman was in danger of coming too much under the influence of these ladies. [Laughter.]

Mr. Speaker GORDON (Mr. Blythe in the Chair) was never averse to doing an act of
kindness - and least of all doing an act of kindness to the gentler sex. He did not think we could consume more time in the hearing of the proposed petition, than we have occupied this morning in discussing this resolution. Many ladies (he continued) not only in our own State, but in every State of the Union, deem themselves neglected, and their God-given rights withheld by our legislation. This may be true. I am not going to discuss that. But I will say that they certainly have the right of petition. There can be no discussion about the right - the only question is as to the manner of petitioning. Here the ladies ask to be heard - to present their petition in their own proper persons - to present their grievances in their own way. And as for the influence of their presence here, there was need for it this moment to repress the discourteous language of gentlemen, for who could believe that in the presence of ladies, any gentleman could indulge in expressions of contempt for their proposition? Gentlemen have made themselves merry over it - have made this proposition a subject of burlesque and ridicule. It is not right that ladies should be treated in that way. If we look at the history of the right of petition, and the manner in which it has been exercised in connection with legislation - all we have of this is derived from the parliamentary history of Great Britain - we shall find it as old as the right of representation in that Island, that men and women entered the parliament of Great Britain, submitting their grievances in their own proper persons. We find laws enacted to limit the number that shall present a petition, and to restrain petitioners from coming into the parliament with arms upon their persons, so that the lives and liberties of members might not be endangered. But here, sir, there is no danger from these ladies. True, some of us may be conquered by them, but if so, of course it will be in a way that we can not regret. I hope, indeed, that we may be conquerred so far as to do justice, and to be courteous in all cases where the rights of ladies are in the question - that, we shall have the manhood to give to the ladies that position in civil society which shall enable them to press the demand for all their right to the utmost extent - to the very furthest verge. This is due to them. Let us remember that the ladies constitute half the people of the State, and, as we all say, the better half.
Mr. MURRAY interrupting. Does the gentleman know the object of the proposed petition?

Mr. GORDON. I do not. I know some of the ladies concerned in it. I have the honor to be acquainted with Mrs. Thomas and Mrs. Birdsall, who have both written to me upon the subject, and I will here say, that more worthy or intelligent ladies do not live in the State of Indiana. They are ornaments to the State and to their sex. * * * *I am just now informed of their object. Part of it I should vote against and part of it I should be willing to concede. The first is to give them an equal right with men to property. The second is to give them the right of sufrage. They reason that the right of taxation follows the right of property, and that taxation and representation should go together. There is force in this. It was upon this very ground that our fathers went to war in 1776.
Mr. GIFFORD, Mr. MERRIFIELD and Mr. MANSFIELD each spoke against concurra and the resolution was further supported Messrs. SCOTT, HALL, of Rush, and Mr. LAWHEAD.
Mr. RITTER demanded the previous question, and under its force the House concurred by yeas 44, nays 37 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Austin, Bowman, Boyd, Boxley, Brotherton, Clark, Colgrove, Collier, Comstock, Cotton, Davidson, Dougherty, Devol, Early, Firestone, Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hall of Eush, Hamilton of Wayne, Harney, Jeffries, Johnston, Jordan. Keefer, Kelley, Lawhead, McLain, Miller, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Parks, Power, Scott, Shockley, Smith of Miami, Snyder, Stanley, Thompson of Elkhart, Treadway, Usrey, Waterman, Whiteman, Wildman and Mr. Speaker - 44.

NAYS - Messrs. Baird, Blythe. Branham, Cavins, Claypool, Clayton, Dobbins, Durham, Edwards, Fordyce, Gifford, Gregory, Hamilton of Boone, Hartley, Jones, Lewis, Major, Mansfield, Massey, Merrifield, Murray, Martin, Nelson, Parrett, Prosser, Ritter, Row, Shields, Shull, Smith of Perry, Stiles, Stinson, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of Madison, Turpie and Wood37.

div.head: BANK OF THE STATE OF INDIANA.
div.p: The SPEAKER laid before the House the reports from the officers of the Bank of the State of Indiana and its several Branches.
On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, they were referred, without reading, to the Committee on Banks.

div.head: ASYLUM FOR THE DEAF AND DUMB.
div.p: The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from Thomas McIntyre, Superintendent of the Hospital for the Deaf and Dumb, appointing next Wednesday even: for the time, and Masonic Hall the place, for an exhibition of the proficiency of the pupils under his care - no tickets to be given out but to members, who are invited to occupy reserved seats.
It was referred to the Committee on Benevolent Institutions.

div.head: HOSPITAL FOR THE INSANE.
div.p: The SPEAKER laid before the House the annual report of Dr. James S. Athon, Superintendent of the Indiana Hospital for the Insane for the year ending October 31, 1858.
On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, it was ordered that it lie on the table - the order for printing to be made on Monday.

div.head: FOREIGN WILLS.
div.p:
Mr. STILES asked and obtained leave to introduce a bill (No. 67) in regard to the contest of foreign wills and testaments, [parties interested in foreign wills admitted to probate
may contest under the legal provisions for contests in cases of the probate of domestic wills,] which was passed the first reading.
Mr. STILES asked that the rules be suspended to enable him to move the second reading of the bill.
Mr. DOUGHERTY would ask whether the bill is not intended to apply to a special casethe will of the late Hon. H. L. Ellsworth.

Mr. STILES. Only in part. The law now provides only for the contest of domestic wills. If a person dies out of the State, and his will be brought into the State, there is no provision for contest, but in compliance with the provisions of the law of the State where the testator died. If the rules were suspended, I should move to refer the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary.
The rules were suspended by yeas 69, nays 63; and then without further action.
The House (at 11 o'clock,) adjourned till Monday 2 o'clock, P. M.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The hour having arrived for the special order, it being the consideration of the Governor's Message -
On motion by Mr. McLEAN, the Senate went into Committee of the Whole.
The PRESIDENT pro tem, called Mr. Mc-Lean to the Chair.
After some time spent therein -
The committee rose, and the Chairman reported the adoption of sundry resolutions, referring various portions and recommendations in the message to appropriate committees, which were concurred in.

div.head: BILLS ON THE SECOND READING.
div.p: Mr. Cravens' (S. 1) to amend the law granting divorces. Read and referred to the Judiciary Committee.
Mr. Wallace's (S. 2) regulating the election of United States Senators. Read and referred to a select committee of five.

Mr. Studabaker's (S. 4) to amend an act for the valuation and appraisement of real property and the collection of taxes, the election of township assessors, &c. Read a second time and ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. Bennett's (S. 5) to amend an act to regulate the interest on money. Read and referred to the Committee on Finance.
Mr. Slack's (S. 6) to provide for the safe keeping of the public moneys of the State, and prescribing the duty of the State Treasurer in relation thereto, was read the second time, and,
On motion by Mr. WALLACE, 200 copies were ordered to be printed.
Mr. Tarkington's (S. 7) to prohibit the issue of unauthorized Bank notes, &c.r was read the second time, and referred to the Committee on Banks.
Mr. Hamilton's (S. 9) for the creation of townships, election of trustees, &c., was read twice, and referred to the Committee on Township Business.
Mr. Fisk's (S. 10) to regulate and restrain the sale of spirituous liquors, &c., was read the second time, which was referred to a select committee of one from each Congressional District.

Mr. CONNER wished the bill to go to the Committee on Temperance, that they could examine the different bills on the same subject, and report a bill embracing the best provisions contained in the different bills.

Mr. STEELE hoped the gentleman from Wabash would withdraw his motion to refer his bill to the Temperance Committee, as this bill's author [Mr. Fisk] was in favor of a license law. He [Mr. Steele] was in favor of that kind of law, provided we could not pass something better in the shape of Senator Hill's bill. He earnestly hoped that this bill might go to a select committee. Let them perfect a bill of that kind, and then let the genuine temperance men from their committee perfect their's, and if we can not pass one, I do hope we may make the other a law before we adjourn.
Mr. CONNER withdrew his motion, and Mr. Fisk's motion prevailing -
The PRESIDENT pro tempore made the committee to consist of Messrs. Carnahan, Heffren, Crane, Fisk, Kinley, Blair, Steele, Wallace, Weir, Hamilton and Murray.

Mr. LINE submitted instructions to the Committee on County and Township Business, to which was referred bill (S. 9) to strike out one trustee wherever it occurs, and insert three; and also that they may hold four meetings in the year.
The debate on Mr. Line's instructions was resumed and was participated in by Messrs. Tarkington, Line, Studabaker, Wagner, Williams, Anthony and Murray.

Mr. TARKINGTON offered an amendment to the instructions, that a committee report a bill giving the Board of County Commissioners jurisdiction of the locating, opening, re-opening of roads; the appointment of supervisors when not elected the appointment of one trustee for each township, who shall discharge the duties that the inspectors of election, overseers of the poor, and fence viewers did under the revised laws of 1843.
Mr. JOHNSTON offered an amendment to the amendment, to the effect that the committee be instructed to confer with the Committee on Education, and that the committees report separate bills.
The amendments were accepted by Mr. LINE, and the instructions were adopted.
On motion by Mr. MARCH, the order of business was suspended, and messages from the House were taken up.

A Joint Resolution that a committee of two
on the part of the Senate, be appointed to act with three on the part of the House, to examine the books, vouchers, &c., of the Agent of State and Trustees of the State Prison was taken up and concurred in by consent.
Mr. Bobbs' bill (S. 11) was read and laid on the table; the House having proposed a bill similar in its provisions.
Mr. Jeffries' bill, (S 12,) making the taking of unlawful interest a misdemeanor, and prescribing punishment therefor, was passed the second reading, and referred to the Committee on Finance.
Mr. Turner's bill, (S. 13) to amend certain provisions of the law in relation to swamp lands, coming up on the second reading -
On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the rules were suspended, by a vote of yeas 36, nays 1; the bill read the second time by its title, and referred to the Committee on Swamp Lands.
Mr. BENNETT offered a resolution, that the Door-keeper be directed to distribute documents equally among members, which was adopted.
Mr. WAGNER introduced a bill, (No. 59,) supplemental to an act to provide for a general system of common schools, &c., which was passed the first reading.
The Senate adjourned.

div.head: INSANE ASYLUM.
div.p: Mr. EDWARDS stated that the Superintendent of the Insane Asylum had advised him that more copies of his report was demanded of him than he was usually supplied with, and that he asked now for 3,000 copies. He therefore moved that 5,000 copies be printed for the use of the Superintendent, in addition to the 3,000 copies required by law.
The motion was agreed to.
Mr. Stinson and Mr. Hancock had leave of absence on account of ill health.

Mr. SCOTT presented the petitions of many citizens of Laporte county recommending such amendment of the law in relation to landlord and tenant as shall make the landlord's claim for rent a lein on all the personal property of the tenant, without relief from valuation and appraisement laws; which being read, he moved that it be referred to the Committee on Judiciary, but -
On the motion of Mr. GIFFORD, it was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.

Mr. HALL, of Grant, presented tho petition of sundry citizens of Grant county, praying for the enactment of a law to rid community of the evils of intemperance, which was read and referred to the Committee on Temperance.

Mr. BRANHAM presented the petition of J. P. Drake and M. G. Bright, praying relief as the securities of Alien May, from his alleged liabilities; which was read and referred the Committee on the Judiciary.

div.head: DEPUTY AUDITORS AND TREASURERS.
div.p: Mr. BAIRD, from the Committee on the Judiciary, returned the resolution instructing them to inquire into the propriety of enacting a law prohibiting deputy auditors from acting as deputy treasurers, and deputy treasurers from acting as deputy auditors, with the expression of opinion that legislation on the subject is inexpedient.
The report was concurred in.

Mr. SCOTT, from the Committee on Judiciary, returned the resolution, directing them to enquire into constitutionality of the forms and precedents found in the Statutes of 1852 both civil and criminal, and reported a motion for the indefinite postponement of the resolution.
The report was concurred in.

div.head: PUBLIC BUILDINGS.
div.p: Mr. SCOTT, from the same Committee, returned Mr. Ritter's bill (8) to preserve public buildings and prescribing penalties for unlawfully occupying the same, reported the same back, recommending that it be indefinitely postponed.

Mr. RTTTER said he had introduced that bill at the request of many citizens of the State. The law now punishes for injuries to public buildings as for trespass and damages, This bill would make such an act a misdemeanor and punish it accordingly. He considered a law could hardly be passed of so little importance that would please the people more than this.

Mr. COLGROVE. The offenses in the bill amounted to nothing more than trespasses, and the committee thought the laws on that subject were ample, if executed; and if not executed, it was perhaps useless to have any law on the subject.
The report was concurred in.

div.head: HORSE THIEF DETECTING SOCIETIES.
div.p: Mr. COLGROVE, from the Judiciary Committee, to which was referred the resolution referring so much of the Governor's Message as relates to companies formed for the purpose of detecting horse theives and other felons, reported that said committee have had the same under consideration, directed him to report a bill and recommend its passage and accordingly -

The Judiciary Committee's bill (No 68) to repeal the act authorizing the formation of companies for the apprehension of horse theives and other felons and defining their powers, approved March 9, 1852, was reported and passed the first reading.

div.head: UNAUTHORIZED BANK PAPER.
div.p:
Mr. COLGROVE, from the fame committee, returned Mr. Martin's bill (12) to prevent the issuance and circulation of unauthorized paper currency, and to prescribe penalties for
issuance and failure to redeem all such currency, without amendment, and with a recommendation that the same do pass.
The bill was, accordingly, ordered to be engrossed, and then -
On the motion of Mr. MARTIN, it was considered as engrossed, read and passed the third and last reading in the House of Representatives, by yeas 76, nays 0.

div.head: DIVORCE LAW.
div.p: On motion of Mr. JOHNSON, it was

Resolved,That the Committee on the Judiciary inquire into the expediency of so amending the divorce law as to require both parties to have residence in the Slate at least twelve months previous to the time of application for divorce, and report by bill or otherwise.

div.head: T.C. GILPIN.
div.p: Mr. HALL, of Rush, submitted the following, which was adopted:

WHEREAS, A certificate from the Clerk of the Circuit Court of Rush County shows that an allowance was made by Judge Logan to T. C. Gilpin for certain ser. vices as prosecuting attorney in said Court; and WHEREAS, said certificate has been presented here and referred to the Committee on Ways and Means, as recorded on page 102 of the Legislative Sentinel; therefore,
Resolved, That said committee be instructed to inquire into the expediency of making said allowance to the said T. C. Gilpin for such services.

div.head: COUNTY TREASURERS.
div.p: Mr. MURRAY submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved,That the Judiciary Committee be instructed to report a bill repealing so much of the law for the collection of the public revenue as requires the County Treasurer to visit the various election precincts for that purpose.

Mr. COLLIER submitted a preamble and resolution, which was adopted, directing the Committee on Rights and Privileges to inquire and report the most efficient means of suppressing theatrical entertainments, horse-racing, gaming, &c.

div.head: A NEW PENITENTIARY.
div.p: Mr. SNYDER submitted the following, which was rejected - that subject being now before the Penitentiary Committee.

Resolved, 1st, That the Auditor of State be requested to report to this House, at his earliest convenience, the amount of fees and mileage paid since the year 1848, for each year up to the present time, and the aggregate of said items of expense, during said time, for transporting convicts from the counties of this State lying north of the National Road to the State's Prison at Jeffersonville.
2d. What would have been the saving to the State in the last ten years in said item of fees, &c., if convicts had been sent from said counties to a Penitentiary located at Logansport?
3d. What are the facilities for the erection of a Penitentiary at Logansport, and for the profitable employment of hands at that point.

div.head: INSANE HOSPITAL.
div.p: Mr. AUSTIN submitted a resolution, which was adopted, directing the joint committee on public buildings to inquire into the expediency of sinking an Artesian well for the better protection of the Insane Hospital from fire.

div.head: TOWNSHIP BUSINESS.
div.p: Mr. LAWHEAD submitted a resolution, which was adopted, directing an inquiry into the expediency of abolishing the present township system, and transferring, as far as practicable, all township business to the County Commissioners.

div.head: ACCOUNTS AND ASSETS OF PUBLIC OFFICERS.
div.p: Mr. SMITH, of Perry, submitted a concurrent resolution, which was adopted, to the effect that a special committee of five - three on the part of the House, and two on the part of the Senate, be appointed to examine and report on the vouchers, accounts, and assets connected with the offices of Agent of State and the Trustees of the State's Prison, prior to the transfer of such vouchers, accounts, and assets from the present incumbents of these offices to their successors.

Mr. KEMPF submitted a resolution, which was adopted, directing the Superintendents of the Benevolent Institutions to report on the parentage of those entrusted to their care, upon the assumption that the condition of those unfortunates may be traced to consanguine intermarriages as the cause.

div.head: COMMON SCHOOLS.
div.p: Mr. WATERMAN submitted the following, which was adopted

Resolved, That the Committee on Education be instructed to inquire into the expediency of amending the law, so as to give to the inhabitants of the districts; all the power compatible with the efficiency of the general system of common schools.
Mr. HARTLEY submitted a resolution, which was adopted, expressing the opinion, that it is better to be taxed for the education of the boys than for the ignorance of the men. [Consent.]

Mr. DURHAM submitted a resolution, which was adopted, directing the Committee on Education to inquire into the expediency and constitutionality of so changing the school law that each county shall retain and appropriate that portion of the school fund collected therein.

div.head: SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION.
div.p: Mr. CLAYPOOL submitted a resolution, directing the Judiciary Committee, to inquire into the constitutional authority of the Legislature to abolish the office of Superintendent of Public Instruction.
After debate by Messrs. Murray, Scott, Clements, Hamilton, of Boone, and Nebeker, of Warren, alleging that this was a constitutional officer, &c,, the resolution was adopted.

div.head: ADJOURNMENT TILL WEDNESDAY.
div.p: Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren the use of the Hall being tendered for the temperance convention to-morrow submitted a resolution to adjourn over till Wednesday, which was adopted.

div.head: NEW BILLS.
div.p: In the order for the introduction of bills, propositions were introduced as follows:

By Mr. EDWARDS, (No. 69 ) to repeal all general laws incorporating bridge companies,
and providing for the incorporation of companies for the erection of bridges, for the erection of causeways across low bottoms, for the collection of tolls, and regulating other matters properly connected therewith:

By Mr. GRIFFIN, (No. 70) to make certain appropriations for the purpose of digging and constructing what is known as the Grand Calumet Canal Ditch, in Lake county, and denning the duties of the Swamp Land Commissioner of said county in relation thereto[proposing to appropriate $8,000 of the Swamp Land Fund:]
By Mr. HALL, of Rush, (No. 71) denning the residence of electors emigrating from one county to another in this State:

By Mr. EARLY, (No. 72) to amend the first and second sections of the act allowing compensation to the owners of animals killed or injured by the cars or railroad carriages of any railroad company in this State, approved March 1, 1852:
By Mr. JOHNSON, (No. 73) to enable industrious, indigent persons, who are unable to give security, to rent lands:
By Mr. JONES, (No. 74) to prohibit the circulation of bank bills of a less denomination than $5, in this State, and fixing penalties therefor:
By Mr. BLACK, (No. 75) to regulate interest on money:
By Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, (No. 76) to amend the act regulating the granting of divorces, nullification of marriages and the decrees and orders of Courts incident thereto, approved May 13, 1852:
By Mr. MASSEY, (No. 77) providing for the election or appointment of Supervisors of Highways, their duties, and certain of the duties of county officers in relation thereto:
Which bills were severally passed the first reading.

div.head: FOREIGN WILLS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, the order of business was suspended to enable him to move the consideration of bills on the second reading; and Mr. Stiles' bill (67) in regard to the contest of foreign wills, pending at the hour of adjournment yesterday, was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

A message from the Senate announced the concurrence of that body in the joint resolution of this day, by Mr. Smith, of Perry, and that Messrs. Bobbs and Tarkington were appointed said committee on the part of the Senate; and thereupon the SPEAKER appointed Messrs. Smith, of Perry, Branham and Hunter, on the part of the House of Representatives.

The SPEAKER now announced the following select committees on that part of the Governor's Message in relation to the failure of the General Assembly of 1857, to provide for the Benevolent Institutions of the State, viz.: Messrs. Cavins, Hunter, Jeffries, Parrett and Turpie - one from each congressional district.
The SPEAKER appointed Mr. Usrey to the place of Mr. Keefer in the Committee on the Town of Indianapolis; and Mr. Davidson to the place of Mr. Sherman in the Committee on the Canal Fund.

The SPEAKER announced the following select committees, (under Mr. Sullivan's resolution,) to consider that part of the Governor's Message which relates to Banks, viz.: Messrs. Sullivan, Clements, Prosser, Huntly, Melle Whetzel, Martin, Nebeker, of Warren, Sherman, Wheeler and Comstock.

The SPEAKER announced the following select committee, (under Mr. Boyd's resolution) to consider that part of the Governor's Message which relates to the surrender of fugitives from justice, viz.: Messrs. Boyd, Davis Blythe, Robinson, Colgrove, Dougherty, Martin, Stiles, Turpie, Stanly and Harrison-one from each Congressional District.

div.head: WORK FOR COMMITTEES.
div.p: The House now pursued the calender of business, and the following bills were considered and referred on the second reading:
Mr. Early's (23). Engrossed.

Mr. Robinson's (24), and Mr. Mansfield's (29), regulating the sale of intoxicating liquors, prescribing penalties, &c.,on motion by Mr. Mansfield, were referred to a select committee of nine, which the SPEAKER makes to consist of Messrs. Mansfield, Stanfield, Blythe, Davis, Harrison, Turpie, Jones, Scott and Murray.
Mr. HARNEY gave notice of his intention to make a motion to go into Committee of the Whole on the Temperance question, next Tuesday.
Mr. Griffin's (25), Mr. Powers' (30), and Mr, Merrifield's (36), were referred to the Committee on the Organization of Courts.
Mr. Treadway's (26), Mr. Jeffries' (27), and Mr. Griffin's (32), were referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. Blythe's (28), Mr. Scott's (31), Mr. Nelson's (33), Mr. Blythe's (34), and Mr. Prosser's (37), were referred to the Judiciary Committee.
Mr, Turpie's (38), relative to Township Trustees and repealing section 11 of the act of April 6, 1852. County and Township Business.
Mr. Dobbins' (42), to amend section 21 of he Misdemeanor Act of June 14, 1852, comiug up -
On motion by Mr. DOUGHERTY, it was amended by striking out "man" and inserting "husband," and then it was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. Austin's (43), and Mr. Durham's (35), to regulate the sale of spirituous liquors, were referred to the Committee on Temperance.
Mr. Kempf's (44), to amend section 2 of Article 2 of the State Constitution, was referred to the select committee on Mr. Gregory'1 bill, No. 13.
Adjourned till Wednesday.

div.head: WORK FOR COMMITTEES.
div.p: On motion by Mr. WEIR, the order of business as dispensed with, and bills of the Senate were considered on the second reading, as follows, viz:

The bill (14) to amend the Acts of March 1,1853, and May 6, 1852, providing for a more uniform mode of doing township business, was considered and referred to the Committee on County and Township Business.
The bill (15) to amend the 103d section of the Criminal Practice Act of June 17,1852, was considered and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

[Mr. SLACK asked and obtained leave to introduce a bill (No. 60) to fix the times of holding the Circuit Court in the several counties in the Eleventh Judicial Circuit, which, under suspension of the rules, was passed the first and second readings, and ordered to be engrossed.]

The bill (16) to amend the Acts of Jane 21, 1852, and March 7, 1857, concerning license for public shows, &c., and for the encouragement of Agriculture, was considered and referred to Committee on Rights and Privileges.

The bill (17) to provide for the partition of real estate, and for laying off the same in lots and out lots, streets and alleys, and for the sale thereof; also to provide when the same shall take effect, was considered and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

The bill (18) authorizing any corporation under the general laws of the State to borrow money and secure the repayment thereof by mortgage, was considered and referred to the Committee on Corporations.

The bill (19) to provide for the enumeration of all white male inhabitants in the State over 21 years of age in the year 1860, and every five years thereafter, was considered and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

The bill (20) providing for and regulating the payment of costs in the trial of persons charged with felony and punished with imprisonment in the State Prison, was considered and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

The bill (21) to prevent the issuing and circulation of unauthorized paper currency, and prescribing a penalty for the issuance and failure to redeem any such currency, was considered and referred to the Committee on Banks.
The bill (22) to prevent the intermarriage of first cousins, was considered and referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.

The bill (23) to fix the time of holding the terms of the Court of Common Pleas in the counties of Adams and Allen, and to repeal all laws in conflict therewith, was considered and ordered to be engrossed.
The bill (24) to incorporate the International University, was considered and ordered to be engrossed.

The bill (25) to provide for the redemption or purchase of Bank bonds, Indiana and other State Stocks, and United States Stocks, and defining the duties of certain officers in connection there with, was considered and referred to the Committee on Education.
The bill (26) to amend the 9th section of the act to exempt property from sale under execution, approved June 17, 1852, was considered and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
The bill (27) to amend section 63, of the act denning misdemeanors, and prescribing punishment therefor, approved June 14, 1852, was considered and ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. SLACK here made an ineffectual motion to adjourn.

The bill (28) to provide for the safe keeping, transfer and disbursement of public moneys, &c., entrusted to the safe keeping of certain officers, was considered and referred to the Committee on Banks.

The bill (29) to exempt personal and real property from forced sale under execution, establishing the amount, and prescribing the duties of officers therein mentioned, was considered and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

The bill (30) to provide for the transfer of certificates of stock of the State of Indiana, providing for the registry of the same, and providing against fraudulent practice therein, and providing punishment for the violation of the provisions of this act, was considered and referred to the Committee on Finance.
The bill (31) to suppress the publication of lotteries and defining punishment therefor, was considered and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
The bill (32) for the better protection of growing cranberries, &c., was considered and referred to the Committe on Agriculture.
The bill (33) [?]o tax dogs, and to indemnify the owners of sheep killed or injured by dogs or wolves, was considered and referred to the Committee on Agriculture.

The bill (34) making certain acts therein named misdemeanors, and providing for the punishment thereof, [assignees of State Bank assets,]
was considered and referred to the Committee on Banks.
The bill (35) to amend section 433 ot the practice act of June 18,1852, was considered and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
The bill (36) to amend the 6th section of the appraisement act, so as to exempt certain property therein named from taxation, was considered and ordered to be engrossed.
The bill (37) to amend the fourth section of the act to provide compensation for animals killed by railroads, approved March, 1853, was considered and referred to the Committee on Corporations.
The bill (38) to enable industrious indigent persons, who are unable to give security to rent land, was considered and referred to the Committee on Agriculture.
The bill (39) to amend the act providing for the election of Circuit Court Clerks and prescribing some of their duties, was considered and referred to the Committee on Education.
The bill (40) to amend the section 151 of the assessment act of June 21, 1852 - chapter 6 of the Revised Statutes - was considered and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
The bill (41) to separate the law books of the State Library, and to constitute the same the Law Library of the State of Indiana, was considered and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
The bill (42) to repeal the act to establish a bank with branches was considered.

Debate ensued on the question of reference Mr. Gooding preferring a select committee of five - Mr. Hamilton and others preferring the Bank Committee - the debate embracing the question ot the power of the Legislature to repeal said charter, as well as the policy of the proposition, in which Mr. Steele, Mr. Hamilton and others spoke in opposition, and Mr. Weir, Mr. Gooding, Mr. March and others in favor of the bill.
Mr. McLEAN proposed to amend the motion so as "to refer the bill to the Judiciary Committee, with instructions to inquire whether the Legislature can constitutionally repeal said bank charter."
Mr. WAGNER spoke at length against the bill, as the bantling of politicians and money speculators, and not demanded by the people.
Mr. HENDRY and Mr. BOBBS preferred the reference to a select committee, and maintained the right to repeal this charter, upon the principle that no legislation nor Court decision can sanctify fraud.
Mr. ANTHONY concurred in the apprehension that there was fraud in the case, though a conservative man, he preferred that the bill go to a committee of its friends.
Mr. WALLACE moved adjournment, but withheld the motion for -

Mr. CONNER, who, by unanimous consent, submitted a resolution, that considering the Temperance and Editorial conventions, now in session in the Hall of the House of Representatives and College Hall, the Senate, when it adjourns, shall adjourn till to-morrow morning, nine o'clock; and the yeas and nays being demanded, and taken thereon, resulted - yeas 22, nays 19.
So the resolution was adopted.

Mr. WIER submitted a concurrent resolution to meet the House of Representatives in joint convention, on Thursday, at ten o'clock, for the purpose of the election of a President and four Commissioners of the Sinking Fund, and the officers of the different Asylums.
Mr. JOHNSON proposed Friday.
Mr. WAGNER moved to lay the resolution and amendment on the table - he never wished to go into joint convention in that Hall again.
The motion was rejected, by yeas 20, nays 20.
Mr. GOODING proposed to amend the resolution by striking out all after "Commissioners," and inserting "Trustees of the Deaf and Dumb Asylum and of the Blind Asylum, according to law"
The PRESIDING OFFICER. The law requiring that in the case of the officers of the Deaf and Dumb Asylum, the Governor shall nominate for the confirmation of the Senate.
Before any further question was taken -
The Senate, at 12:20 o'clock, adjourned till to-morrow 9 o'clock.
The House of Representatives did not sit to-day

div.head: PETITIONS.
div.p: By Mr. WILLIAMS: A petition from certain citizens of Knox county and the Knox County Agricultural Society, in favor of a geological survey of the State. Referred to the Committee on Agriculture.

div.head: RESOLUTIONS.
div.p: By Mr. ANTHONY: That the Auditor of State inform the Senate what amount of money has been expended on the State Prison, up to the time the same was leased to Samuel H. Patter-son; what was received by the State from said lessee during his time; the amount of the increase of property received from said lessee at the expiration of his lease, and also the estimated value of the permanent improvements since the Prison has been opened under the present system.

By Mr. JOHNSTON: Requiring that the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to inquire into the legal right of the State, under the charter of the State Bank of Indiana, to redeem at any time after the expiration of twenty years, the bonds of the State known as the bank bonds, and report the result of such inquiry.

By Mr. CONLEY: That the Committee on the Organization of Courts be requested to inquire into the expediency of abolishing the present mode of selecting jurors, and instituting some method less expensive, and that they report by bill or otherwise. Adopted.
By Mr. MARCH: That the Secretary be requested to furnish the amount of stationery furnished the members and officers of this body at the last session. Adopted.

By Mr: TARKINGTON. Requiring the Committee on the Organization of Courts to report a bill repealing Common Pleas Courts and embodying the principle of the Surrogate system, by giving the Clerks of the Circuit Courts juris-
diction of all probate business not litigated, in vacation, &c.
Mr. GOODING asked if the resolution was one of inquiry, or if it was imperative.
Mr. TARKINGTON answered that it was the intention to make the resolution imperative.
Mr. GOODING would not now discuss, the question. It would be time to do that when a bill was reported giving details. He would ask the sense of the House on the passage of this resolution?
Mr. ANTHONY was not prepared to vote for abolishing the Common Pleas Court, but supporting this resolution did not bind Senators to vote for a bill that might be reported.
Mr. LINE opposed the resolution. He considered himself instructed to oppose the abolishing of the Common Pleas Court, and he should vote against any effort in that direction.
Mr. MURRAY said the Senate was hardly full enough to take a vote - but if it was taken, he wished it to be considered a test vote.
Mr. ANTHONY did not consider a vote on this resolution a test. He was not prepared. He would probably vote against a bill abolishing Common Pleas Courts.
Mr. CONNER was opposed to these attacks on Common Pleas Courts, and spoke at length against this desire for change.
Mr. STEELE agreed with the Senator from Wabash, and moved to amend the resolution by striking out so much as requires the repeal of the Common Pleas system.
[A message from the House announced the passage, by that body, of a concurrent resolution:

That the House of Representatives will, the Senate concurring therein, meet the Senate, in the Hall of the House of Representatives, in joint convention, on this day, at the hour of 10 o'clock A. M., for the purpose of electing, by joint viva voce vote, a President of the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners, and four Commissioners of said Board, in which the concurrence of the Senate is respectfully requested.]

Mr. TARKINGTON spoke at length in favor of his resolution, contending that the Common Fleas system was expensive. Reform was necessary. The people were tired of supporting an expensive routine of business, that could be simplified. Let the Circuit Courts take charge of misdemeanors - charge estates with the expense of settlement. He had no faith that these expensive systems would be abolished, but he would require Senators to pnt themselves on the record.
Mr. WALLACE moved to pass informally on the pending question, and take up messages from the House.
Mr. TARKINGTON moved to lay the resolution on the table. The yeas and nays being ordered, resulted - yeas 20, nays 24.
So the motion to lay on the table did not prevail.
Mr. CONLEY moved a call of the Senate. The yeas and nays were demanded, and resulted yeas 20, nays 23.
So the call was not ordered.M
Mr. SLACK moved the Senate adjourn.
The Senate refused to adjourn.
Mr. TARKINGTON moved that the further consideration of the question be deferred until Friday, at ten o'clock. The yeas and nays being demanded, resulted - yeas 17, nays 27.
So the motion to postpone did not prevail.
Mr. TARKINGTON moved the Senate adjourn. The yeas and nays were called, and resulted - yeas 11, nays 33.
The previous question was demanded, and being seconded -
Mr. SLACK moved an adjournment.
Which the PRESIDENT pro tem., decided out of order, as no business had intervened since a similar motion had been entertained.
Mr. SLACK appealed from the decision of the Chair.

[A message from the House was here received, informing the Senate of the passage of bill (H. R. 12) to prevent the issuing and circulation of unauthorized paper currency, and prescribing penalties for the issuing or failure to redeem such currency.]
The PRESIDENT pro tempore directed the Senator to reduce his appeal to writing.
Mr. WALLACE moved to lay the appeal on the table, which resulted - yeas 22, nays 10 - so the appeal was laid on the table.
The question then was, shall the main question be now put, resulting - yeas 27, nays 19.
The question then being on the motion of Mr. Wallace to take up the message from the House, and the yeas and nays being demanded,resulted yeas 28, nays 18.
So the motion prevailed.
The message from the House in regard to going into the election of certain officers, was read.
Mr. WALLACE moved the previous question which, being seconded -
Mr. TARKINGTON rose to a point of order.
There was no question before the Senate.
The PRESIDENT pro tempore decided that the question of concurrence in the message was before the House.
Mr. TARKINGTON moved to adjourn, and the yeas and nayes being taken, resulted - yeas 11, nays 25.
So the Senate refused to adjourn.
Mr. JOHNSTON moved a call of the Senate, which was not agreed to, by yeas 12, nays 32.
Mr. SLACK moved to adjourn, which not being entertained, Mr Slack appealed from the decision.

Mr. MURRAY moved to lay the appeal on the table, which was done by a vote of yeas 43, nays 12.The main question being on the motion by Mr. Wallace to concur in the message from the House, being put, resulted - yeas 30, nays 16.So the Senate concurred.
Mr. WALLACE moved that the Senate now proceed to the Hall of the House.
Mr. CONLEY moved to lay the motion on the table.
[A message from the House, inviting the Senate to proceed instanter to the Hall of the House, was received.
The Senate then repaired to the Hall of the House of Representatives.
On the return of the Senate to their chamber, at ten minutes past 12, they took a recess until 2 o'clock.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The Senate was called to order by the PRESIDENT pro tempore, at 2 o'clock.
The Chair stated the question pending at adjournment, to be on the amendment of Mr Steele to the resolution of Mr. Tarkington.

Mr. LINE offered the following: Amend by instructing the Committee to inquire into the expediency of abolishing said court - and if they should deem it necessary that justice should be administered freely and without purchase - completely, and without denial - speedily and without delay - that said court should be abolished then to report a bill that will assign to the proper court or person the duties discharged by said court.

[A message from the House inviting the Senate instanter to attend in the Hall of the House of Representatives to hear the petitions of the women, pursuant to a concurrent resolution of both houses of the General Assembly, heretofore adopted.]
The Senate then vacated the Chamber, and repaired to the Hall of the House.
The Senate returned to their Chamber and was called to order at ten minutes past three.
The question pending was the amendment to the amendment on Mr. Tarkington's resolution.
Mr. GOODING moved to postpone the consideration of the question until next Tuesday at two o'clock, which was agreed to.

div.head: RESOLUTIONS.
div.p: By Mr. LINE: That the Committee on Finance inquire into the expediency of having the laws of this Legislature published in one newspaper of each county of this State, (if there be one) and report by bill or otherwise.

By Mr. JOHNSTON: That the Committee on Temperance be instructed to report a bill to the Senate upon the subject of retailing liquors, embracing the following provisions, to wit: 1st. That it shall not be lawful for any person to sell or give away any adulturated liquors. 2nd. Nor to any intoxicated person. 3d. Nor to any minor without the consent of the parent or guardian. 4th. And that it shall not be lawful for any person to keep a disorderly house to the annoyance of the neighborhood, with such penalties as may be consistent with the offenses, and that no license be required.
Mr. GOODING moved to strike out the words "and that there be no license required:
Mr. TARKINGTON offered an amendment to the amendment, as follows:

That the Committee on Temperance be instructed to report a bill making it the duty of the Common Pleas and Circuit Court to declare all places where spirituous liquors are sold in less quantity than one gallon, a nuisance, and that it be made the duty of the prosecuting attorneys to prosecute in every instance, under a penalty of $100 for every failure.
Mr. STEELE moved to lay the resolution and pending amendments on the table. The yeas and nays being demanded, resulted - yeas 28, nays 11.

div.head: JOINT RESOLUTIONS.
div.p: By Mr. Bobbs (S. No. 4), a joint resolution to provide for the recovery of moneys paid out of the Township Library funds.
Mr. BOBBS moved its reference to the Committee on Judiciary.
Mr. TARINGTON wished the name of W. Noffsinger to be inserted in the joint resolution in the proper place.
Mr. WEIR moved to lay the amendment on the table.
Mr. TARKINGTON withdrew the amendment.
Mr. SLACK moved to amend by adding, in the proper place the name of Hiram E. Talbott and all other defaulters.
Mr. BOBBS moved to lay the amendment on the table. The yeas and nays being taken, resulted, yeas 18, nays 20 ; so the amendment was not tabled.
The vote on the amendment being taken by yeas and nays, resulted, yeas 28, nays 8 ; so the amendment was adopted, and the joint resolution was referred to the Judiciary Committee by consent.

Mr. STUDABAKER submitted instructions: the Committee to report a bill making it the duty of the Attorney General to commence suit in all cases of defalcation. Additional instructions by Mr. BOBBS : adopted.

By Mr. FISK'S joint resolution for the purpose of taking the sense of the Legislature upon the subject ot distributing such school funds as may accrue by the acts of the Legislature or otherwise, coming up
On motion by Mr. STUDABAKER, referred to Committee on Education.

Mr. LINE'S joint resolution, instructing our Senators, and requesting our Representatives to vote for a law by Congress, fixing the time, placeand manner of electing Senators in the different States, comiug up -
Mr. LINE moved to make it the special order of the day for next Monday, at 2 o'clock, which was agreed to, and then the Senate adjourned.

div.head: CALUMET DAMN.
div.p: Mr. GRIFFIN presented the petition of sundry residents of Lake county, praying for an appropriation out of the Swamp Land Fund sufficient to connect the Calumet River with the Grand Calumet, which was read and referred to the Committee on Swamp Lands.

div.head: OUR "COLORED FELLOW-CITIZENS."
div.p: The SPEAKER laid before the House the memorial of certain colored persons, convened at Indianapolis on the 4th day of January, 1859, asking for the right to testify in courts of justice, &c., which, on motion of Mr. TREADWAY, was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.

The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from the Secretary of the State Temperance Convention, held in this hall yesterday, inclosing a resolution of the thanks of that body for the use of the hall of the House of Representatives for said Convention.

div.head: JUDICIAL OFFICERS.
div.p: Mr. TURPIE, from the Committee on the Judiciary, returned the resolution of inquiry whether persons elected to judicial office, and especially Justices of the Peace, are eligible to official positions other than judicial offices, with a motion that the same be laid on the table.
The report was concurred in.
Mr. MURRAY gave notice of a motion to take up the resolution at some future day of the session.
On the motion of Mr. MANSFIELD, Mr. Harney was added to the Committee on Education.

div.head: FUND COMMISSIONERS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. HUNTER, it was

Resolved, That the House will (the Senate concurring) meet the Senate, in the hall of the House of Representatives, in joint convention, on this day at 10 o'clock A. M , for the purpose of electing a President and Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners.
Mr. TURPIE moved a call of the House, which proceeded, until it was dispensed with.
Mr. MURRAY declared that he would vote for no Democrat to serve on that Board.
Mr. BOYD would vote cordially for the old Board.
Mr, SCOTT would vote for Ebenezer Dumont, under all circumstances.
Mr. DOUGHERTY would vote for the resolution, to prevent out-side juggling.
The resolution was adopted.

div.head: ACTIONS.
div.p: Mr. ROW submitted the following, which was rejected:

Resolved,That the Judiciary Committee be requested to inquire into the expediency of enacting a law to provide that no suit shall be brought against the maker or assignee of any written instrument, whether with or without endorsement, out of the township in which the maker resides, before Justices of the Peace.

div.head: NATIVE WINES.
div.p: Mr. SULLIVAN submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved, That the Committee on Temperance be instructed to inquire into the expediency of refraining from further legislation on the subject of the manufacture and sale of native wine and cider, and fixing a penalty for mixing or adulterating liquors, and report by bill or otherwise.

div.head: CLAIMS.
div.p: Mr. TURPIE summitted the following, which was adopted:
Resolved,That the Judiciary Committee inquire into the expediency of so amending the law as to have the clerks dispense with carrying up the claims for trial, except at the instance of the claimant.

div.head: SCHOOL FUND.
div.p: Mr. HANCOCK submitted the following, which was rejected.

Resolved,That the Committee on Education be instructed to inquire into the expediency of so amending the law relative to the distribution of school funds, as to give to each school district in a township an equal amount of money.

div.head: PENITENTIARY.
div.p: Mr. LAWHEAD submitted the following, which was adopted.
Resolved, That the Auditor of State report to this House the amount of the cost of taking convicts to the State Prison during the last four years, from county seats north of the National road.

div.head: TOWNSHIP LIBRARIES.
div.p: Mr. SHULL submitted the following, which was rejected.

Resolved, That the Commitee on Education be instructed to inquire into the expediency of abolishing the Township Library system, and recommend the tax levied for the support of said system to be added to the common school tax, which would increase the present school fund raised upon the tax duplicate one-fourth more, which would materially and in the payment of teachers for which the people find so much difficulty in providing.

div.head: CLERKS FOR COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. BOYD submitted a resolution, which was adopted, authorizing the Committee on Education to employ a Clerk; and
Mr TURPIE, that the Judiciary Committee employ a Clerk.

div.head: CANADA THISTLE.
div.p: Mr. MURRAY submitted the following, which was adopted:
Resolved, That the Committee on Agriculture inquire into and report whether any law is necessary to check the spread of the Canada Thistle in this State, and if so, report a law for that purpose.
Mr. Speaker GORDON (Mr. Stanfield in the Chair) submitted the following.

div.head: SWAMP LAND LAW.

div.p: Resolved,That the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to inquire into the constitutionality of chapter 59 of the Acts of the Generally Assembly for the year 1857, and that they report the result of such examination and inquiry to this House without delay.

Mr. GORDON. The resolution contemplates inquiry into the constitutionality of the Swamp Land bill of 1857. A great deal of land has been disposed of under that act, and if it be not constitutional, it is proper we should know it, because further action on the part of the Legislature may be necessary, either to arrest the sales, or to place the purchasers in a proper situation, where they have purchased in good faith. Some of these purchases have been made on contract for ditching, and no ditching done. I am satisfied that unwarrantable, speculations have been made on sales of such fraudulent purchases. I have papers in my hands that satisfy me of this fact. It is important, then, that we should know whether this act is constitutional. My own impression is that it is not.
The resolution was adopted.
Mr. GORDON also submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved, That the Committee on Public Expenditures be instructed to inquire how much money was expended on behalf of the State for services now devolved on the Attorney General, for the four years next preceding the creation of that office, and how much has been paid out for such service in addition to the salary of that officer, since the creation of said office.

div.head: SEPULTURE.
div.p: Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, submitted the following, which was adopted:
Resolved,That the select committee to which was referred the bill (.No. 17) to prevent the illegal removal of dead bodies from burial grounds, be requested to report said bill to the House.

div.head: SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION.
div.p: Mr. MURRAY submitted ihe following, which was adopted:

Resolved,That the Committee on Education inquire into the expediency of reducing the amount of compensation of the State Superintendent of Public Instruction, so that it shall not exceed $500 annually.

div.head: JUDGE MORRISON.
div.p:
The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from Judge Morrison, embracing his claim for defending a suit brought against the Blind Asylum Trustees, which was referred with-
out reading to the Committee on Ways and Means.

div.head: SCHOOL FUND.
div.p: Mr. WATERMAN submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved,That the Committee on the Sinking Fund be instructed to inquire whether any pledge would be violated, by appropriating the interest on the bonds of the Sinking Fund to common schools, after paying the interest on the bank bonds and other expenses of the fund, and if so, that they report a bill accordingly, &c.

div.head: SINKING FUND COMMISSIONERS.
div.p: Mr. HUNTER submitted a resolution inviting Senators to the joint convention proposed for this day for election of Sinking Fund Commissioners.

div.head: NEW PROPOSITIONS.
div.p: By Mr. EDWARDS, (No. 78) to regulate the business of insurance companies not incorporated by the State of Indiana ; to punish violations of this act, and to repeal former acts in regard to such companies.
By Mr. STANFIELD, (No. 79) requiring the county from which a change of venue in criminal cases has been taken, to pay the expenses of such trial to the county where such trial has been had.
By Mr. DOBBINS, (No. 80) to provide cites and places for houses of refuge for the correction of juvenile offenders, creating a Board of Commissioners for the same.

By Mr. HUNTER, (No. 81) to prevent the retailing of spirituous, intoxicating and malt liquors; to provide for the punishment thereof; also, to provide for the duties and compensation of certain officers in relation thereto, and to repeal all former laws on the subject.
By Mr. MELLETT, (No. 82) to regulate the practice in certain cases appealed to the Supreme Court.
By Mr. SHULL, (No. 83) to amend section 7 of the act to authorize the construction of levees and drains, approved June 12, 1852.
By. Mr. HARTLEY, (No. 84) to amend sections 10 and 13 of the act for the election, qualification, &c., of Justices of the Peace, (in civil cases,) approved June 9,1852.
By Mr. CAVINS, (No. 85) for the relIEf of Peter Shultz, of Greene county, and releasing to him the interest which the State holds in certain lands.
By Mr. PARRETT, (No. 86) for the relief of Jane Walker.
By Mr JOHNSTON, (No. 87) to amend sections 5, 6, 11 and 18, and repeal section 8 of the act for the more uniform mode of doing township business, approved May 6, 1852.
By Mr. STILES, (No. 88) to amend section 531 of the practice act of June 18, 1852.
By Mr. SMITH, (No. 89) to amend section 3 of the act to incorporate the town of Peru, ap proved February 14, 1848.

By Mr. PARKS, (No. 90) to provide for the election of county prosecuting attorneys, prescribing their duties,defining their compensation, and repealing all laws for the election of prosecuting attorneys.
By Mr. BROTHERTON, (No. 91) to provide for the transfer from justices of the peace to the Circuit Court or the Court of Common Pleas, of certain cases therin named:

[Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, now had leave to submit a resolution,which was adopted, tendering the use of this Hall, this evening and tomorrow evening; to General S. F. Carey, of Ohio, for the purposes of public lecture on the subject of Temperance.]
By Mr. HANCOCK, (No, 92) to amend the 8th section of chapter 11, of the first vol. of the Revised Statutes of 1852, for the more uniform mode of doing township business, approved May 6, 1852.
By Mr. COLGROVE, (No. 93) to amend the 6th section and second clause of the 7th section of the Divorce act of May 13,1852:
Which bills were severally passed the first reading.

div.head: WORK FOR COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. Brotherton's bill, (39) to amend the 37th section, chapter 6, vol. 3, Revised Statutes, 1852the misdemeanor act oi June 14, 1852, was considered on the second reading and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. Murray's bill, (40) requiring the State Auditor to pay over money to the free banks, was considered and referred to the Committee on Banks.
Mr. Shull's bill, (41) to amend the 9th section of the Circuit Court Clerk's Act of June 14, 1852, was considered and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

div.head: ELECTION OF SINKING FUND COMMISSIONERS.
div.p: A message from the Senate, by Mr. Vawter, their Secretary, now announced the concurrence of that body in Mr. HUNTER'S resolution for the joint convention this day at ten o'clock, for the election of a President and Board of Commissioners of the Sinking Fund.
On motion by Mr. MELLETT, Mr. Hunter's resolution of inuitation was taken up and adopted:
And thereupon, immediately, the Senators appeared and the joint convention was called to order by the presiding officer of the Senate.
The election proceeded in the constitutional forms, with the following results:

The PRESIDING OFFICER of the Senate announced the election of Messrs. Dumont, Parks, Carr, McClelland and Bemusdaffer (being the re-election of the President and former Board)to serve for the term prescribed in the act passed at the present session of the General
Assembly, and then the PRESIDENT dissolved the convention, and Senators returned to their chamber.
The House then took a recess till 2 o'clock.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
WOMAN'S RIGHTS.
div.p: Mr. PROSSER submitted a resolution inviting Senators, instanter, into joint convention to been informed that ladies from my county have hear the petition of women, pursuant to a concurrent resolution, for that purpose, adopted last Friday, and that seats be prepared for them on the right of the Speaker's Chair.
A VOICE. That's impossible.[The inner tiers of seats were already occupied by ladies.]
Mr. KEEFER. I propose to amend, so as to provide seats in the galleries
The SPEAKER. The amendment is out of order.
The resolution was adopted.
A call of the House was demanded, but objection being made, the House refused to order a call.
Mr. TURPIE. Mr. Speaker, I move that theHouse resolve into Committee of the Whole to hear this petition.
The SPEAKER. The motion of the gentleman can not be entertained. The order is that the petition shall be heard in joint convention of the two Houses.
Mr. DAVIS. Will this appear on the Journal?
The SPEAKER. The Convention for hearing the petition will appear on the Journal.
The Senators now appeared in the Hall, and the President called the Convention to order.

The PRESIDING OFFICER. Gentlemen of the Senate and House of Representatives : In pursuance of a resolution adopted by both Houses, you are now convened for the purpose of hearing a portion of the Ladies of Indiana on behalf of themselves and their rights.

Mr. DAVIS. This is a very grave and important matter, and it seems to me that we ought to have positions favorable to hearing and understanding everything upon which we are called to act. A number of Senators and others here are in a position that we can neither see nor hear.
Mr. Senator BENNETT. There is a great deal of wisdom in that body (of the Senate,) and it ought to be provided for
.Mr. DAVIS. I have to request that room be made especially for the Senator from Vigo as the only bachelor in that body. [Laughter.]
Mr. EDWARDS. I object to that, on the part of my Senator.
The PRESIDING OFFICER. The hour having arrived, appointed for the purpose of hearing the petition on behalf of the ladies, if those entrusted with the matter are present, they will now proceed.
Mr. Senator SLACK. (Standing forward in the front aisle with Mr. Senator McLean.) The Senator from Vigo is present. [Cheers and laughter.]
Mr. McLEAN. Mr. President, I am overwhelmed. [Cheers and laughter continued.]
Mr. CLEMENTS. I move that we proceed. I understand that this memorial is to be read by the ladies themselves.
The PRESIDING OFFICER. That is the order If the ladies are present, a place will be made for them at this table.
A VOICE. The gentleman from Wayne can tell who is to read.

Mr. AUSTIN. I am not able to inform the Convention. I have had no interview with any of the ladies expected to appear here. I have arrived in the city, who are expected to present that petition, but I presume they are not now in the House.
Mr. EDWARDS. I suggested the Senator from Wayne, who introduced the resolution calling this joint convention. [Consent.]
Mr. AUSTIN. If my recollection serves me, half-past 2 was the hour appointed for the presentation of the petition.
The PRESIDING OFFICER. The Chair is informed that that is the hour.
Mr. DOUGHERTY. 2 o'clock is the time. It was fixed on my motion. [Sensation.]
Mr. COLGROVE. I understand that the ladies who are to present this petition will be present in a few minutes.
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren. During this interval, it has been suggested that the best looking bachelor address the assembly. [Vociferous cheers and cries for "Nebeker""Nebeker, of Warren."
Mr. NEBKKER. Gentlemen cannot be well informed. I am not a bachelor. I had reference particularly to the gentleman from Vigo. [Cheers and cries for "Edwards."]

Mr. EDWARDS. I waive my pretentions for the gentleman from Warren to give him an opportunity to exhibit his personal beauty, [Laughter and cries again for "Nebeker," which subsided under the hammer from the Chair.]
Mrs. Thomas, Mrs. Birdsall and Mrs. Cook, ladies of Wayne county, now came forward and took seats at the Speaker's table.
The PRESIDING OFFICER introduced Mrs. Thomas to the Convention.

Mrs. THOMAS said: Permit me, friends, to say a word before reading our petition. Brothers and sisters, we have not come here to exhibit ourselves as a show to our brothers of the General Assembly. We have come here feeling deeply the need of that which we petition of you; and I beg of you to receive us as becomes our cause and your position in this place. Gentlemen, we now read to you our petition, as representatives of the women of the State of Indiana.

The petition was read in a few plain words - asking the General Assembly to advance the women of the State to the same rights of property now enjoyed by men; and for such an amendment of the Constitution as shall confer the right or suffrage upon women.

An address in writing was then read to the Convention by Mrs. Thomas - reasoning at length upon the subjects of the petition, and stating, amongst others things, that the petition was signed by nearly a thousand residents of the State, and that the number would have been tens of thousands, but for the lack of effort to circulate it. It was, properly, the petition of the ladies of Wayne county. When Mrs. T. had concluded -
The PRESIDING OFFICER introduced to the Convention -
Mrs. BIRDSALL, who read a very clear and logical plea in behalf of the right of suffrage in womanand its exercise in this Stateif it should be her pleasure.

Mrs. COOK followed in an extemporaneous address on the subject of Temperance - making allusion to the unchivalric remark of one of the orators of the State Temperance Convention yesterday, to this effect: "We will hold the ladies' bonnets whilst they shall fight the doggeries." Nevertheless, the lady was willing to strive in the good work, but it was hinted how much more effectual would be the work of the enfranchised woman in the cause of Temperance.
Mr. Senator STEELE submitted a resolution, which was adopted, to the effect that the foregoing addresses of Mrs. Thomas and Mrs. Bird-sail be spread upon the journals of the two houses.
Mr. DAVIS. if we are to have resolutions here, it were as well to introduce bills and pass them.
Mr. Senator TURNER submitted the following:

Resolved, That the publishers of the papers of this city, and all other papers friendly to the cause of Woman's Rights, be respectfully requested to publish these proceedings, together with the addresses.

The PRESIDING OFFICER. Gentlemen of the Convention, you have now given your attention to the petition which has been read on behalf of the women of the State. You can go no further now, though there may be material matter in this petition for your future deliberation. The Senators will, therefore, now retire to their chamber.
So the joint convention was dissolved.
The SPEAKER called the House to order.
Mr. DAVIS and Mr. LAWHEAD moved adjournment.
The SPEAKER, still calling to order, did not entertain the motion.
Mr. MURRAY moved a call of the House, which was refused.
The SPEAKER. The Door keeper will clear the aisles and lobbies.
A VOICE. They never will clear as long as the ladies remain.

On the motion of Mr. MURRAY, the House resolved itself into a Committee of the Whole- Mr.MURRAY in the Chairand took up the consideration of the woman's rights petition; and after three minutes spent therein, the committee rose, and the Chairman reported a motion, that the further consideration of the subject be postponed, and that it be made the special order for Friday, two o'clock. P. M., and that the Committee of the Whole be discharged.
The report was concurred in.
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, moved a recess of half an hour; but -
On motion of Mr. DOBBINS, at half past three o'clock -
The House adjourned.

div.head: WOMAN'S RIGHTS.
div.p: Mr. JOHNSTON moved to expunge from the journal the resolution adopted by the joint convention, of yesterday, ordering the recording of the addresses of Mrs. Thomas and Mrs. Birdsall. On motion by Mr. BEESON, this motion was tabled - yeas 26, nays 15.

div.head: PETITIONS.
div.p: By Mr. STUDABAKER, from Wells county, on the improvement of stock, which was referred to the Committee on Agriculture.
By Mr. JENNINGS, from Johnson county, on temperance, which was referred to the Temperance Committee.

div.head: ATTORNEY GENERAL.
div.p: Mr. WEIR offered the following resolution, which was adopted:

Resolved, the Attorney General be requested to inform the Senate the reasons why the suit in Floyd Circuit Court, in favor of the State vs. Newland, was dismissed, and why the same was not attended to by him.
Mr. MARCH offered the following, which was adopted

Resolved,That the Attorney General be requested to report to the Senate the number and name of the cases in which he has been employed, or in which he has given a written opinion in the discharge of his official duties, during the last and present term of his office.

div.head: TEMPERANCE.
div.p: MR. STEVENS offered the following, which was adopted:

Resolved, That the Committee on Temperance be requested to inquire into the expediency of incorporating into any bill they may report, a provision that all liquors sold by any person, under the provisions of such bill, shall not be drank in or about the house where sold.

div.head: CONSTABLES.
div.p: Mr. THOMPSON offered the following, which was adopted.

Resolved, That the Committee on County and Township Business be directed to inquire into the expediency of requiring Constables to file their official bonds with the Treasurer of the township in which they are elected, respectively.

div.head: ABANDONED ROADS.
div.p: Mr. ODELL offered the following, which was adopted:

WHEREAS, There are a number of plank, turnpike, gravel and M'Adamized roads in this State, that have been suffered to get and remain out of repair for an unreasonable length of time: And Whereas, there are many of such roads that have been partially abandoned: Therefore, be it -

Resolved, That the Judiciary Committee be requested to inquire into the expediency of introducing a bill to provide the mode and manner by which the rights of the owners of such roads may be declared forfeited; and that they report by bill or otherwise.

div.head: ROAD LAW.
div.p: Mr. SHOEMAKER offered the following, which was adopted:

Resolved,That the Committee on Roads be requested to inquire into the expediency of revising the road law and of printing and binding in pamphlet form, ten thousand copies thereof, for the use of Supervisors, and report by bill or otherwise.

div.head: BANK TAX.
div.p: Mr. WEIR offered the following:
Resolved,That it is the sense of this Senate, that the law should be so amended as to require the Bank of the State of Indiana to pay corporation taxes.
Mr. HAMILTON moved ics reference to the Committee on Banks. He said he would prefer that it be made a resolution of inquiry, but he should favor such a proposition.

Mr. GOODING wished to bring the Senate to a direct vote upon the simple question, ought banks to be exempt from corporation taxes? He presumed every honorable Senator was ready and willing to take grounds upon this question. Let us settle it this morning without referring it to a committee.

Mr. BENNETT was willing to vote for a law of the kind contemplated in the resolution, providing a committee report that it is expedient, but he was not prepared to vote for the resolution, as imperative as it is.

Mr. McLEAN would vote for a resolution of inquiry upon the subject, but he held the Batik charter to be a contract made by the Legislature as agent of the people of the State; the people were the principal, and the principal is bound by the acts of the agent.
Mr. WEIR sustained his resolution in a few remarks. He thought the Legislature unquestionably had the power to amend this act so as to make the banks pay corporation taxes.
Mr. HEFFREN thought the passage of this resolution would have no effect, unless the law proposed to be enacted should be consented to by a majority of the President and Directors of each branch.
Mr. WEIR made an ineffectual motion to lay the reference motion on the tableyeas 20, nays 23.
Mr. STUDABAKER moved to amend the motion to refer by substituting the Judiciary Committee instead of the Committee on Banks.
Mr. HAMILTON accepted the amendment.
Mr. STEELE would say, as a member of the Committee on Banks, that he was distinctly in favor of the proposition, and has always been.

Mr. MARCH thought it was not very material to which committee the resolution was referred. He trusted there would be no hasty action in the passage of the resolution, although he was in favor of the proposition. He was opposed to taking any action at this time which would recognize the validity of this bank charter.
Mr. WAGNER said this was a resolution of expediency, and he thought it should go to the Committee on Banks. He moved to amend the the motion to refer so that it shall go to the Committee on Banks.

Mr. GOODING wanted to say one thing, in order that the anti-bank men of the Legislature may not be caught napping. He had no doubt these bank men would be glad to make a compromise with us to bring in a bill amending the charter, and thus making us acknowledge the legality of that institution. He was in favor of cutting it up by the roots and throwing it out into outer darkness. This bank charter is nothing more nor less than a law which any Legislature may repeal.
Mr. STEELE thought that this last declaration of the Senator from Hancock, [Mr. Gooding] was a montrosity.
Mr. BOBBS thought the charter was good, and that it was managed fairly.
On motion by Mr. STUDABAKER, the resolution and pending amendments were laid on the table.

div.head: EMPLOYEES OF THE SENATE.
div.p: Mr. WILLIAMS offered the following, which was adopted:

Resolved,Resolved, That in the opinion of the Senate, the Secretaries and Door keepers should be required to report the number and names of their assistants, as required in a former resolution adopted by the Senate.

div.head: ORDER OF BUSINESS.
div.p: Mr. ANTHONY offered a resolution rearranging the order of business, which lies over one day under the rules.

div.head: SWAMP LANDS.
div.p: Mr. MILLER offered a resolution, which was adopted, that the Swamp Land Committee inquire into the expediency of transferring the Swamp Land business to the care and control of the Auditor and Treasurer of State, now performed in the several counties, for the purpose of the speedy settlement and winding up of the same, and authorizing the purchase of swamp lands at the offices of the Auditor and Treasurer of State.

div.head: EMPLOYEES OF THE SENATE.
div.p: Mr. RICE, from the Committee on Finance, to whom was referred a resolution of the Senate, in relation to the allowance of claims in the specific appropriotion bill, &c., reported the following resolution, and asked its adoption by the Senate, viz:

Resolved,That the officers of the Senate report to the Finance Committee all purchases and items of account, made by them, at least once a week; also the numbers and names of all appointees and for what service appointed; and that all claims whatsoever, held by any person, be presented to said committee at least ten days before the adjournment of the Legislature, except such as may accrue within the list ten days of the session, and that no account presented by an employee shall be allowed, unless the person employing him certify the number of days the claimant served, the kind of service he did, and that he was necessarily employed.
The resolution was adopted by consent.

div.head: COMMON PLEAS JURORS.
div.p: Mr. McLEAN offered a resolution, which was adopted by consent, directing the Committee on the Organization of Courts to inquire into the expediency of abolishing the regular panel of jurors for the Court of Common Pleas, and that they draft and report a bill to that effect if it be deemed expedient.

div.head: DEAF AND DUMB ASYLUM.
div.p: Mr. LINE submitted the following, which was adopted by consent:

WHEREAS,The Superintendent of the Institution of the Deaf and Dumb did give a public exhibition of the progress of the pupils placed in said institution, for the accommodation of the members of the General Assembly; and WHEREAS, Many of the members of the General Assembly did attend said exhibtion, in which they did witness with a degree of State pride, the progress in intellectual improvement which the pupils were making in said institution; therefore,

Resolved, That we do, with full confidence, recommend to the tax-payers of Indiana, the capability of accomplishing the highest anticipations of the public, in the education of our unfortunate mutes, and that we do, with an abiding confidence, recommend to all parents in the State, who may have mute children, their duty to place said muteg in said institution, for the purpose of obtaining such intellectual training as shall qualify them for usefulness in after life.

div.head: NEW PROPOSITIONS.
div.p: The following bills were introduced and passed the first reading:
By Mr. HILL (No. 61) to amend sec. 3 of an act to provide for the government and discipline of the State Prison, and to repeal an act providing for the regulation of the State Prison.

By Mr. TARKINGTON (No. 62) for the relief of the Indiana University, to increase and extend its boundaries, and providing for the sale of lands donated by the United States for the benefit of the University.
By Mr. WILSON (No. 63) to amend sec. 5 of an act to provide for equalizing the assessment of real property approved May 28, 1852.
By Mr. JONES (No. 64) to render public officers competent to testify as witnesses in cases brought on their relation to the State.
By Mr. HENDRY (No. 65) defining the crime of embezzlement.

By Mr. BENNETT (No. 66) authorizing the Auditor of State to declare and pay the final dividends of banking associations organized under an act to organize and regulate business of general banking, approved May 28, 1852.
By Mr. TURNER (No. 67) requiring the Superintendent of the several State Asylums to report the number of patients who are offspring of parents married within the degrees of consan guinity.
By Mr. McLEAN (No. 68) to amend sec. 9, of an act to provide for the election of Clerks of Circuit Courts, and prescribing their duties, ap proved June 7, 1852.
And then the Senate took a recess till 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The following bills were introduced and were severally passed the first reading:
By Mr. STEELE, (No. 69) to prevent the circulation of the withdrawn currency of the old State Bank, and to punish persons violating the provisions of this act.
By Mr. HEFFREN, (No. 70) supplemental to an act concerning county prisons, approved May 27, 1852, and to provide for the erection of work-houses.,
By Mr. Carnahan, (No. 71) to incorporate the Indiana School of Practical Sciences.
