By Mr. O'BRIEN, (No, 73) to provide for the collection of taxes assessed against lands and lots mortgaged and secured to public and trust funds, and to repeal section 8 of chapter 6 of the revised statutes of 1852.
By Mr. KINLEY, (No. 74) declaring certain places where intoxicating liquors are sold to be nuisances.
By Mr. JOHNSTON, (No. 75) to amend sections 9 and 20 of an act regulating fees of officers approved March 2, 1855.

By Mr. STUDABAKER, (No. 76) for the distribution and investment of the Sinking Fund asset apart and constituted by an act establishing a State Bank, approved January 28,1834, and to provide for the purchase of bonds.
By Mr. McCLURE, (No. 77) to amend section 18 of an act concerning real property and the alienation thereof.
By Mr. BEESON, (No. 78) fixing the time of recording deeds and other instruments of writing herein named, and to amend the 16th section of an act concerning real property and the alienation thereof.
By Mr. LOMAX, (No. 79) to extend the time of payment to purchasers of saline and school lands.
By Mr. FISK, (No. 60) to amend section 2 of an act to authorize Commissioners of Sinking Fund to receive mortgages, &c., approved January 28, 1857.
By Mr. HARGROVE, (No. 81) fixing the compensation of executors and administrators, and to repeal section 148 of the revised statutes of l852.
By Mr. ANTHONY, (No. 82) to amend section 196 of a law reformed act, approved June 18, 1852.
By Mr. BOBBS, (No. 83) to provide and secure the rights of married women in real property.
By Mr. SLACK, (No. 84) fixing the time of holding the Courts of Common Pleas in the Counties of Huntington and Wells.
By Mr. WAGNER, (No. 85) to provide for a general system of Common Schools, to establish township libraries, and for the regulation thereof.
By Mr. CARNAHAN, (No. 86) to amend section 1 of an act regulating marriages, approved March 5, 1852.
By Mr. BROWN, (No. 87) to organize the Militia, providing for the appointment and prescribing the duties of certain officers.
By Mr. HILL, (No. 88) to amend sections 3 and 4 of an act providing for the protection of wild game, approved February 26,1857, and also adding a section supplementary to said act.
By Mr. CULVER, (No. 89) to amend section 1, and repeal section 7 of an act concerning interest on money, approved May 27, 1852.
By Mr. SHOEMAKER, (No. 90) to provide for the collection, safe-keeping and disbursement of the public money, and fixing the salary of Treasurer of State.
By Mr. JONES, (No. 91) to provide compensation to persons who may bring to justice fugitives from the same.
By Mr. SHOEMAKER, (No. 92; to provide for a more uniform mode of doing township business.
By Mr. HARGROVE, (No. 93) to amend section 15 of an act to establish a Bank with branches, passed May 3, 1855.

div.head: ORDERS OF THE DAY.
div.p: The PRESIDENT pro tempore announced the order of the day - being the consideration of Mr. Conley's bill (S. 42) providing for the repeal of the charter of the Bank of Indiana. A motion was made to refer it to a select committee (of five); an amendment was proposed referring it to the Committee on Banks, aud a further amendment that it be referred to the Judiciary Committee- the question being upon the latter motion -
On motion by Mr. TARKINGTON, it was laid on the table.

On motion by Mr. GOODING, the amendment was also laid on the table.
Mr. TARKINGTON made an ineffectual motion to lay the bill and pending motion on the tableyeas 13, nays 26.
And then the motion was agreed to and the bill accordingly referred to a select committee of five.

div.head: BILLS ON THE SECOND READING
div.p: Mr. William's bill (S. 43) to amend section 33 of an act providing for the valuation and assessment of real and personal property, approved June 21, 1852, coming up, it was, on his motion, referred to the Committee on Finance.
Mr. Wagner's bill (S. 44) to change the time for the election of members of Congress, and providing for their election, was, on his motion, referred to the Committee on Elections.

Mr. Craven's bill (S. 45) to provide compensation to owners of animals killed or injured by the cars, locomotives or carriages of any railroad company in this State, was referred to the Committee on Corporations.

Mr. Wallace's bill, (S. 46) to amend section 4 of an act providing for the election, fixing the compensation, and prescribing the duties of the Attorney General of the State of Indiana, was referred to the Judiciary Committee.
Mr. Cobb's bill (S. 47) to repeal an act providing for the protection of wild game, approved February 26, 1859, coming up -
On Mr. MURRAY'S motion, it was indefinitely postponed - yeas 22, nays 15.

div.head: UNCURRENT MONEY.
div.p: On Mr. HEFFREN'S motion, the bill (No. 12) from the House of Representatives, was taken up, and passed the first reading.

div.head: GEOLOGICAL SURVEY.
div.p: On Mr. WAGNER'S motion, the joint resolution (No. 8) from the House of Representatives, creating a joint committee, to which shall be referred petitions on Agriculture and a Geological Survey of the State, was taken up and read through.
And then the Senate adjourned.

div.head: PETITIONS.
div.p: Mr. EDWARDS presented the petition of Captain Mark Payne, and other citizens of Vigo county, praying for the enactment of a drain law, which was referred to the Committee on Swamp Lands.

Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, presented a temperance petition of a public meeting in Warren county, in favor of Mr. Goodwin's bill introduced into the Senate of the last session, which was referred to the Committee on Temperance.

Mr. JEFFRIES presented a petition of sundry citizens of Wayne county, praying for more stringent game laws for the protection of quails and other birds, which was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. MURRAY presented the petition of P. F. Davis, of Elkhart county, on the same subject, which took the same reference.

Mr. GRIFFIN presented the petition of E. 0. Dibblo, of Lake county, asking for an appropriation of $500 on account of the outlet of Lake George, and $1,100 damages, which was referred to the Committee on Swamp Lands.

Mr. MURRAY presented the petition of Charles W. Seely, late Sheriff of the county of Elkhart, asking for compensation for the capture of Abe Morehead and John Potts, escaped from thejail of said county, January 1, 1856total amount of claim, $107, which was referred to the Committee on Claims.
He also presented the memorial of Joel Ellis, a long printed paper setting forth his claims,which, on the motion of Mr. Edwards, was referred, without reading, to the Committee on Claims.
Mr. CLEMENTS presented the memorial of Charles E.Smith, of Lagrange county, embracing a claim for the recapture of a fugitive from justice, which was referred to the Committee on Claims.

div.head: WORK FOR COMMITTEES.
div.p: On the motion of Mr. BOYD, the order of business was suspended, and the House took up the consideration of the bills on the second reading, namely:
Mr. Brotherton's bill (39) to amend the 32d section of chap. 6, vol. 2, of the Revised Statutes of 1852misdemeanor act of June 14, 1852, was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.

Mr. Colgrove's bill (47) to reorganize the Circuit Courts, &c., was referred to the Committee on the Organization of Courts of Justice, with instructions moved by Mr. Hamilton, of Boone, "to amend so as to establish terms or days at the beginning of each term for making up issues on which no jury shall be called."
Mr. Fordyce's bill (45) for perpetuating records of survey of lands, was referred to the Committee on the Organization of Courts.

Mr. Hamilton of Boone's bill (46) to repeal the Attorney General's act of February 21, 1855, was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.Mr. Hamilton of Wayne's bill (48) to amend the 6th section of the County Board act of June 17, 1852, was referred to the Committee on County and Township Business.
Mr. Robinson's bill (49) for reducing the width of the Michigan Road, was referred to the Committee on Roads.
Mr. Treadway'sbill (50) to amend the section 31 of the Supervisor's act of June 18, 1852, was referred to the Committee on Roads.
Mr. Durham's bill (51) to amend the act of May 20, 1852, concerning landlord and tenant, was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. Waterman's bill (52) providing for the election and qualification cf assessors, was referred to the Committee on County and Township Business.
Mr. Hall of Rush's bill (53) to amend the section 14 of the Supervisor's act of June 14, 1852, was referred to the Committee on Roads.
Mr. Stanley's bill (54) prohibiting clerks from practicing lawprescribing penalty for refusal to issue summons, writs, &c., was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. Colgrove's bill (55) giving Circuit Court Clerks probate jurisdiction, prohibiting them from practicing law, &c., was referred to the Committee on the Organization of Courts.

Mr. Colgrove's bill (56) repealing the act establishing the Court of Common Pleas, was referred to the Committee on the organization of Courts.Mr. Harney'sbill (57) amendatory of section 74 of the act of June 17,1852, so as to suppress gambling establishments, was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. Martin's bill (58) requiring the Governor to make his requisition lor fugitives from justice, was referred to the select committee on that portion of the Governor's message
Mr. Harrison's bill (59) to extend time to borrowers of the trust funds, was referred to the Committee of Trust Funds.
Mr. Boyd's bill (61) to regulate the retailing of intoxicating liquors - suppress the evils arising therefrom - was referred to the select committee of nine on that subject.
Mr. Boyd's bill (62) amendatory of the section 3 of the Recorder's Act, approved May 31,1852, was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. Nebeker of Warren's bill (63) to regulate and restrain the sale of spirituous and intoxicating liquors - punish drunkenness, &c., was referred to the Committee on Temperance.
Mr. Hamilton of Boone's bill (64) to amend the game law, coming up -
Mr. MERRIFIELD proposed to amend by changing the first of January to the first of March in reltion to the time of killing prairie hens, which was agreed to.
The bill was then referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, now moved, ineffectually, to resume the regular order of business.

Mr. Stanfield's bill (65) to amend the section 4, of the usury act, so as to allow the recovery of principal and interest on contract for more than legal interest, was referred to the Committtee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. Edwards' bill (66) to regulate insurance companies incorporated by the State of Indiana, &c, was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

The Judiciary Committee's bill (68) to repeal the Horse-thief Detecting Society's Act of March 9, 1852, was referred to a select committee of five, which the SPEAKER makes to consist of Messrs. Wildman, Waterman, Wheeler, Murray and Firestone.
Mr. Edwards' bill (69) revising the Bridge laws, was referred to the Committee on Corporations.
On motion by Mr. HARTLEY, the House then took a recess till 2 o'clock.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Griffin's bill (70) appropriating $8,000 to the Swamp Land Fund to complete the Calumet Ditch, was referred to the Committee on Swamp Lands.
Mr. Hall of Rush's bill (71) defining residence of electors removing from one county to another in this State, was referred to the Commmittee on Elections.
Mr. Earley's bill (72) to amend sections 1 and 2 of the act of March 1, 1853, allowing compensations for animals killed by railroad cars, was referred to the Committee on Corporations.

Mr. Johnson's bill (73) to enable indigent persons to rent land, was referred to a select committee of five, which the Speaker makes to consist of Messrs. Johnston, Harney of Boone, Harney, Fordyce and Robinson.
Mr. Jones' bill (74) to prohibit the circulation of a less denomination than five dollars(a fine of ten dollars)was referred to ihe Comittee on Banks.
Mr. Black's bill (75) to regulate interest on money, was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. DOUGHERTY moved to reconsider the vote just taken, on the reference of Mr. Jones' bill to prohibit small notes, to enable him to move that it be referred to a committee of its friends.
Mr. Hamilton of Boone, would insist that the bill should go before the Standing Committee.
Mr. PARRETT would exclude small bills of other States - reciprocate the action of the States of Ohio and Kentucky in this respect.
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, considered the bill ought not to have any friends. The Illinois law for this purpose was disregarded.
Mr. TEBBS alleged that the small bills law was disregarded in the State of Ohio.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, had himself: passed Indiana small bills in the State of Ohio: &c., but had no objection to the bill going to a select committee.
Mr. JONES. This bill was not after the Ohio and Illinois laws. It was a law which had worked well in Missouri, Louisiana, Mississippi and Virginia.
Mr. CLEMENTS desired to reconsider.
The reference of the bill was recommended, and Mr. Hamilton, of Boone, had leave to with draw his motion.

Mr. CLEMENTS made an ineffectual motion to refer to the Judiciary Committee; and then the bill was referred to a select committee, which the Speaker makes to consist of Messrs. Jones, Dougherty, Turpie, Blythe and Hunter.
Mr. Hamilton, of Boone's, bill (76) to amend the Divorce law, was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

Mr. Massey's bill (77) to revise the Supervisor's act, was referred to the Committee on Roads, with instruction (by Mr. Dougherty) "to amend the first resolution, so that supervisors shall receive for compensation a credit for working the roads one year." Also (by Mr. Hamilton, of Boone) so that "each voter shall vote only for the supervisor in the Road District where he resides."
Mr. Edward's bill (78) to regulate Insurance Companies not incorporated by the State of Indiana, was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. Stanfield's bill (79) requiring the county from which a charge of venue is taken to pay expenses of such trial, was considered and ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. Dobbins' bill (80) to provide sites for houses of refuge and a Board of Commissioners, was referred to the Committee on Benevolent Institutions.
Mr. Hunter's bill (81) to prevent the retail of spirituous and intoxicating and malt liquors, was referred to the Committee on Temperance .
Mr. Mellett's bill (82) to regulate practice in certain cases appealed to the Supreme Court, was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

Mr Shields' bill (83) to amend the 7th section ol the act to authorize levees and drains, approved June 7, 1852, was referred to a select committee of five, which the Speaker makes to consist of Messrs. Shull, Clements, Blythe, Mellet and Griffin.
Mr. Hartley's bill (84) to amend section 10 and 13 of the Justices' act of June 9, 1852, was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. Cavin's bill (85) for the relief of Peter Shultz, was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. Parrett's bill, (86) for the relief of Jane Walker, was referred to a select committee of five, which the Speaker makes to consist of Messrs. Parrett, Sullivan, Stinson, Martin and Cavins.
Mr. Johnston's bill (89) to amend the act of May 6, 1852, for a more uniform mode of doing township business, was referred to the committee on County and Township Business.
Mr. Stile's bill (88) to amend the section 531 of the Practice act of June 18, 1852, was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr, Smith of Miami's bill, (89) to amend the 3d section of the charter of the town of Peru, was referred to the Committee on Corporations.

Mr. Parks' bill (90) for the election of county prosecuting attorneys, and prescribing compensation, was referred to the Committee on the Organization of Courts, with instruction to "amend by striking out all that relates to prosecutors in the Circuit Courts."
Mr. Brotherton's bill (91) to provide for the transfer of certain cases from the Common Pleas and Justice Courts, was referred to the Committee on the organization of Courts of Justice.
Mr. Hancock's bill, (92) to amend the section 18 of the act of May 6, 1852, for the more uniform mode of doing township business, was referred to the Committee on County and Township Business.
Mr. Colgrove'sbill (93) to amend the sections 6 and 7 of the Divorce act of May 13, 1852, was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. Firestone made an ineffectual attempt to adjourn.
The House, then, (at 4 o'clock) reconsidered, and adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The journal of yesterday was read.

The PRESIDENT pro tempore announced Senators Wagner, Wallace, Steele, Murray, March, Carnahan and Line as the committee on the joint resolution (H. R. 8) on the subject, of agriculture and a geological survey of the State

The PRESIDENT pro tempore, also, makes Senators Conley, March, Weir, Wagner and Heffren, the committee authorized to be appointed yesterday afternoon, and to which was referred Mr. Conley's bill (S. 42) providing for the repeal of the charter of the Bank of the State of Indiana.

div.head: PETITIONS AND MEMORIALS.
div.p: Mr. HILL presented a memorial from the yearly meeting of the Society of Friends residing in parts of Indiana, Ohio and Iowa, held at Richmond, praying for the repeal of that portion of our laws which denies to colored persons the right to testify as witnesses in any cause in which a white person is a party in interest.
Mr. SLACK moved that it lie upon the table, but withdrew the motion at the instance of several Senators.

Mr. MARCH was surprised at the motion of the Senator. He thought it would be well to let negroes testify, and that there was no danger in allowing juries to determine as to the credibility of their testimony.

Mr. SLACK was willing to extend courtesy to any reasonable extent, but he thought the people of Indiana were almost as a unit upon the subject of that petition, and that it would be a waste of time to consider the matter. He therefore renewed his motion to lay upon the table.
This motion was rejected - yeas 10, nays 27.
On Mr. HILL'S motion the paper was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.

Mr. HAMILTON presented a petition from H. P. Ayres, praying for the erection of an Asylum for idiotic and imbecile persons, accompanying a resolution directing the Committee on Benevolent Institutions to inquire into the expediency of erecting such an Asylum.
The resolution was adopted by consent, and the petition referred to the same committee.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. CONNER, reported from the Judiciary Committee his bill, (S. 17) providing for the partition of real estate, and for laying the same out into lots and out-lots, and recommended its passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill ordered to be engrossed for the third reading.
Mr. McLEAN, from the same committee, reported back Mr. Brown's bill, (S. 29) to exempt personal property from sale on execution, recommending its indefinite postponement.
The report was concurred in.

Mr. MARCH, from the same committee, reported back Mr. Conner's bill, (S. 1) to amend the 6th, 7th, 12th, 19th and 20th sections of the Divorce law, approved May 13, 1852, and providing for opening decrees in the cases therein specified, with an amendment, and recommended its passage.

Mr. HAMILTON moved to concur with an amendment that no divorced party shall be permitted to marry for two years after the granting of a divorce had by publication. He was opposed to fill divorces except in cases of adultery.
Mr. BENNETT and Mr. CONNER opposed the amendment.
On Mr. HEFFREN'S motion, the amendment was laid on the table.

Mr. STUDABAKER said the law ought not to permit a recision of the marriage contract to be opened up. He proposed to concur with an amendment so that the question of alimony may be opened up but not the question of recision of matrimony.
On Mr. HAMILTON'S motion, this amendment was laid on the table.

Mr. MURRAY contended that we had no right to pass a law opening up decrees that have been heretofore granted. He moved to strike out so much of the original bill as refers to cases pending, and insert an amendment to the effect that cases pending and commenced by bona fide residents, shall not be affected by this act.
On motion by Mr. WEIR this motion was laid on the table.
The amendment proposed by the committee was adopted.
Mr. MURRAY moved to strike out from the 6th section the words "heretofore or." He was standing up against his own individual interest as a lawyer, when he advocated an amendment of the divorce law
Mr. MARCH offered the amendment because frauds heretofore enacted under the present Divorce law could not be remedied.
The amendment was adopted.
Mr. BLAIR and Mr.WALLACE made ineffectual efforts to amend, and then -
The bill was ordered to be engrossed, for a third reading.

Mr. WILLIAMS, from the Committee on Agriculture, reported a bill (No. 94) amending section 6 of an act for the encouragement of Agriculture, approved February 17, 1852, which was passed to the second reading.
[This bill changes the time of annual meetings of the State Board, and allows to district societies a delegate-]
Mr. HILL, from the same committee, to which was referred a resolution in relation to young bulls, bucks and boars running at large, reported that further legislation on the subject is unnecessary.
The report was concurred in.

Mr. BEESON, from the same committee, to whom was referred resolutions concerning the holding of fair grounds by agricultual societies, reported that the said committee deem further legislation upon this subject as unnecessary.
The report was concurred in.
And the Senate took a recess till 2 o'clock.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR [Hon. A. A. Hammond] appeared in the Chair for the first time during the present session.

div.head: UNITED STATES SENATORS.
div.p: Mr. WALLACE, from a majority of the select committee of five, to which was referred his bill (S. 2) regulating the choosing of United States Senators by the General Assembly, specifying time, place and mode of such choosing, providing for the designation of such Senators by the people, reported the same back with a recommendation that it pass.
Mr. MURRAY and Mr. STUDABAKER opposed the provisions of the bill.
Mr. ANTHONY moved to postpone the further consideration of the bill till Wednesday next, 2 o'clock P. M.
Mr. WALLACE spoke in favor of the changes proposed in his bill.
Mr. HEFFREN made an ineffectual motion to indefinitely postpone - yeas 21, nays 26.
And then Mr. Anthony's motion was agreed to.

div.head: THANKS.
div.p: Mr. WILSON offered a resolution of thanks to the Hon. J. R. Cravens for the able and impartial manner in which he presided over the Senate during the absence of the Hon. A. A. Hammond.
The resolution was adopted by consent.

div.head: DOCUMENTS.
div.p: Mr. HARGROVE offered a resolution, which was adopted, directing the Door-keeper to procure and distribute certain documents in the hands of the printer.

div.head: BANKS.
div.p: Mr. HEFFREN offered a resolution, which was adopted, directing the Committee on Banks to inquire into the expediency of amending the present assessment law, so as to require banks to be assessed upon the amount of bonds deposited in the Auditor's office, and upon their circulation, also upon the entire amount of currency, gold and silver on hand, on the 1st day of January of each year.

div.head: ADJOURNING OVER.
div.p: Mr. WIER offered a resolution, which was rejected, that when the Senate adjourn, it adjourn to meet on Monday, at 2 o'clock, P. M.

div.head: ORDERS OF THE DAY.
div.p: Mr. ANTHONY'S resolution of yesterday, with reference to the order of business, was now adopted. It is as follows:

Rosolved, That the 53d rule of the Senate be so changed as to read as follows: The daily order of transacting business, shall be as follows, viz: 1st. Reading and correcting the journal of the preceding day. 2d. Introduction of petitions, memorials, and remonstrances. 3d. Reports from Standing Committees. 4th. Reports from Select Committees. 5th. Bills. 6th. Orders of the day. 7th. Resolutions of the Senate. 8th. Joint resolutions.
On motion by Mr. MURRAY, 100 copies were ordered to be printed.

div.head: TRUSTEES OF ASYLUMS.
div.p: Mr. STEVENS offered a resolution, which was adopted, requesting the Committee on Benevolent Institutions to inquire into the expediency of limiting the meetings of Trustees of State Asylums to one every three months, unless by special call of Superintendent.

div.head: PUBLIC PRINTING.
div.p: Mr. ANTHONY offered a preamble and resolution, stating that the present law by which the public printing is done is unnecessarily high, and directing the Committee on Printing to report a bill amending the laws reducing the prices.
The resolution was adopted.

div.head: TAXES ON NEGROES.
div.p: Mr. KINLEY offered a resolution, which was adopted, instructing the Committee on Education to inquire into the expediency of providing by law for the assessment of taxes for school pur poses on people of color, and applying the funds to the education of the colored persons of the State in separate schools.

div.head: JUSTICES OF THE PEACE.
div.p:
Mr. McCLURE offered a resolution, which was adopted, directing the Committee on Education to inquire into the expediency of so amending an act approved March 1, 1855, entitled an
act to amend the 21st section of an act prescribing the duties of Justices of the Peace in State prosecutions, approved May 29, 1852, as not to require said Justice of the Peace on the first Monday in January and July, to make returns to the Treasurer of his county of fines and fees unclaimed when they have no such moneys, and when the amount on hand will not justify the expense of making such returns.

div.head: KANSAS AND OREGON.
div.p: Mr. TURNER offered a joint resolution (No. 7) directing our Senators and Representatives in Congress to vote for the admission of Kansas and Oregon into the Union at as early a day as possible.
Mr. WALLACE was in favor of the resolution, but it did not go far enough. He moved to lay it on the table for the present.
The motion was agreed to.

div.head: PRINTING OF THE JOURNALS.
div.p: Mr. HEFFREN offered a resolution, which was rejected, directing the Secretary of the Senate to deliver the journal of the extra session to the proper officer, according to law.

div.head: TEMPERANCE
div.p: Mr. GOODING introduced a bill (S. 95) to regulate and restrain the sale of spiritous and intoxicating liquors, which was passed the first reading.
On motion by Mr. GOODING the rules were suspended and the bill read a second time - yeas 35, nays 7and referred to the Committee on Temperance.

div.head: FROM THE HOUSE.
div.p: A message was received from the House of Representatives, announcing the adoption by that body of the following resolution:

Resolved, That the Door-keeper be directed to contract with A. E. Drapier & Son for five hundred copies of ''Brevier Legislative Reports" of the Proceedings and Debates of the present General Assembly, after the style of their reports of the proceedings of the late extra session in the "Legislative Sentinel"said reports to be made up from the columns of some daily newspaper printed in the town of Indianapolis, and laid upon the desks of members as fast as they shall complete sixteen pages in double newspaper column; provided the cost of the same shall not exceed one dollar per copy, the Senate adopting a similar resolution.

div.head: TEMPERANCE.
div.p: Mr. HEFFREN introduced a bill (S. 96) to regulate and restrain the retailing of spiritous liquors and for the suppression of evils arising therefrom, which was passed the second reading.
On motion by Mr. HEFFREN the rules were suspendedyeas 42, nays 2the bill read the second time by title and referred to the Committee on Temperance.
Mr. TARKINGTON introduced a bill (No. 97) to prevent the retailing of spiritous and intoxicating liquors, &c., which was read through the first time.
On motion by Mr. GOODING [Mr. Tarkington in the chair,] the bill was read the second time by title - yeas 41, nays 1.
On motion by Mr. TURNER it was referred to the Committee on Temperance.
Mr. ROBINSON introduced a bill (No. 98) to regulate and restrain the sale of spiritous and intoxicating liquors, which was read through.
The rules were suspended - yeas 37, nays 1 the bill read the second time by title and referred to the Temperance Committee.

div.head: WILD GAME.
div.p: Mr. CONLEY introduced a bill (No. 99) to provide for the protection of wild game, which s passed to the second reading.

div.head: TOWNSHIP BUSINESS.
div.p: Mr. WALLACE introduced a bill (No. 100) providing for a more uniform mode of doing township business, which was read through and passed to the second reading.

div.head: ASSESSMENT OF PROPERTY.
div.p: Mr. JOHNSTON introduced a bill (No. 101) to authorize County Treasurers to assess property which may be omitted by assessors, and to legalize assessments heretofore made by treasurers, which was passed the first reading.
Mr. WILSON introduced a bill (No. 102) to amend the 3d section of an act to establish Courts of Common Pleas, which was passed to the second reading.
And then the Senate adjourned.

div.head: PETITIONS.
div.p: Mr. COTTON presented the petition of sundry citizens, on the subject of Temperance.
Mr. DAVIDSON presented a petition of citizens of Kosciusko county, for a conventional interest law.
Mr. WHETZEL presented a petition embracing the claim of William Tanzy.
Mr. SCOTT - the claim of William Whitehead.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. Nelson's bill (39) was returned, and indefinitely postponed.
Mr. Mellett's bill (19) was returned and ordered to be engrossed.

Mr. BLYTHE reported that it was inexpedient to legislate further so as to allow parties to swear to book accounts; also, that the bill (No. 14) be laid on the table: also, that the bill (No. 34) be amended and passed, and the report was concurred in.
Mr. STANFIELD reported favorably on his bill, (No. 3) so as to allow complainants and co-defendants to testify in certain cases, and it was ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. STANFIELD returned his bill (No. 65) to amend the usury laws, and it was made the special order for Wednesday.
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, returned the bill to prohibit concealed weapons, and it was ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. Harney's bill (No. 57) was ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. Brotherton's bill (No. 39) was ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. Shull's conventional interest bill was laid on the table.

Mr. BAIRD reported a substitute for the bill (No. 15) entitled a bill (No. 94) supplemental to an act entitled an act to exempt property from sale in certain cases, approved February 17,
(before any person shall be entitled to the benefit of this act he shall make out an inventory of his effects under oath, and deliver to the officer)which was passed the first reading
Mr. KEMPF returned the bills (Nos. 13 and 44) recommending the passage of the former so amending the Constitution as to require foreign voters to reside five years.
After debate the report was laid on the table by yeas 51, nays 42, as follows:

YEAS- Messrs. Black, Bowman, Carr, Claypool, Clayton, Clements, Collier, Dobbins, Dougherty, Durham, Early, Eastham, Firestone, Gifford, Griffin, Hancock, Harrison, Hartley, Jones, Jordan, Kelly, Lawhead, Lewis, McLain, Major, Massey, Merrifield, Murray, Nelson, Newton, Parks, Parrett, Prosser, Row, Scott, Shields, Shockley, Shull, Snyder, Stanley, Stanfield, Sullivan, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of Elkhart, Thompson of Madison, Turpie, Usrey, Waterman, Wheeler and Wood. - 51.

NAYS - Messrs. Austin, Baird, Blythe, Boyd, Boxley, Branham, Brotherton, Cavins, Clark, Comstock, Cotton, Davidson, Davis, Edwards, Fordyce, Gregory, Hall of Grant, Hall of Rush, Hamilton of Boone, Hamilton of Wayne, Hunter, Jeffries, Johnston, Kempf, Mansfield, Mellett, Miller, Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Ritter, Robinson, Rynerson, Sherman, Smith of Miami, Smith of Perry, Stiles, Treadway, Whetzel, Whiteman, Wildman and Mr. Speaker, - 42.
Mr. PARRETT, from the select committee on that subject, returned the bill (8) for the relief of Jane Walker, and recommended its passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill was ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. HUNTER (by consent) submitted the report of the Clerk of the stationery room, embracing the items drawn by members and officers, which remains on the Clerk's files, without action.

div.head: BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS.
div.p: Mr. STANFIELD offered the following resolution:

Resolved,That the Door-keeper be directed to contract with A. E. Drapier & Son for six hundred copies of ''Brevier Legislative Reports" of the Proceedings and Debates of the present General Assemby, after the style of their reports of the proceedings of the late extra session in the "Legislative Sentinel"said reports to be made up from the columns of some daily newpaper printed in the town of Indianapolis, and laid upon the desks of members as fast as they shall complete sixteen pages in double newspaper column; provided the cost of the same shall not exceed one dollar per copy.
Which was withdrawn on Mr. EDWARDS' motion to take up a similar concurrent resolution from the Senate.
After debate, the resolution was rejected, by yeas 37, nays 55, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Baird, Blythe, Bowmon, Clements, Carr, Davis, Tobbins,Early, Eastham, Edwards, Firestone, Gifford, Griffin, Hancock, Harney, Jeffries, Jordan, Kempf, Lawhead, Massey, Merrifield, Murray, Newton, Parrett, Scott, Shockley, Smith of Perry, Snyder, Stanfield, Sullivan, Tebbs, Thompson of Madison, Treadway, Turpie, Wheeler, Whiteman, and Mr. Speaker - 37.

NAYS. - Messrs. Austin, Boxley, Branham, Brothertor, Cavins, Clark, Claypool,Clayton, Collier, Comstock, Cotton, Davidson, Dougherty, Durham, Eordyce, Gregory, Hall of Grant, Hall of Rush, Hamilton of Boone, Hamilton of Wayne, Harrison, Hartley, Hunter, Johnston, Jones, Kelly, Lewis, McLain, Major, Mansfield, Mellett, Miller, Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Nelson, Parks, Prosser, Ritter, Robinson, Row, Rynerson, Sherman, Shelds, Shull, Smith of Miami, Stanley, Stiles, Summers, Thompson of Elkhart, Usrey, Waterman, Whetzel, Wildman and Wood55.
Mr. STANFIELD submitted a resolution, which was adopted, authorizing a select committee of five to investigate the Sinking fund.
Mr. STILES submitted a resolution, which was rejected, looking to an amendment of the Appraisement laws, so as to extend the time for making appraisements and to provide for a Board of Equalization.

Mr. Speaker GORDON [Mr. Davis in the Chair] submitted a resolution, which was adopted, requiring the Committee on Education to consider the propriety of erecting a female department of the Indiana University, on University square, in the town of Indianapolis.
Mr. EDWARDS - a resolution, which was adopted - requesting the Superintendent of Public Instruction to report the names of the Trustees of the Indiana University.
The House then took a recess till 2 o'clock.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Mr. STILES AFTERNOON SESSION.The SPEAKER announced the following members (on the part of the House of Representatives) of the joint select committee on the subject of geological survey, viz: Messrs. Smith, of Perry; Treadway, Stanfield, Dobbins, Davis, Harrison, Dougherty, Branham, Wildman.

Mr. SHULL moved to reconsider the vote of this morning rejecting the Senate's resolution to authorize 600 copies of Drapier's Legislative Reports of the proceedings and debates of the present session,
Which motion was laid on the table, on a division - affirmative 38, negative 27.

div.head: RESOLUTIONS.
div.p: By Mr. TURPIE. Inquiring into the pro-priety of requiring Railroads to be fenced.
By Mr. GRIFFIN. Inquiring into the amount of the Swamp Land Fund on hand and chargeable to Lake county.
By Mr. HAMILTON, of Wayne. Claims for the specific appropriation bill to behanded in ten days before the adjournment of the session.
By Mr. MERRIFIELD. Directing the principal clerk to deliver the journals of the House to the Secretary of State. Rejected - yeas 44, nays 44.
By Mr. HARNEY. To consider the Temperance bills next Tuesday at 2 o'clock, in Committee of the Whole.
By Mr. MURRAY. Inquiring into the expediency of selling the Governor's Circle, in the town of Indianapolis.
By Mr. GIFFORD. Inquiring whether supervisors should include persons of color (who are residents of the State and not otherwise exempt) amongst the number of those who are to work on the highways.
By Mr. BOWMAN. Inquiring into the expediency of amending the 34th section of the act for opening and vacating high ways,approved June 17,1852.
[The SPEAKER here named the select committee on Mr. Stanfield's motion of this day, viz: Messrs. Stanfield, Davis, Blythe, Smith, of Perry.
By Mr. ROBINSON. Inquiring into the least amount of bail which should be required of persons charged with felony. Rejected.
By Mr. Speaker GORDON. Directing inquiry into the amount of money audited in favor of . Henry Coburn, and the present incumbent of the office of Clerk of the Supreme Court - set
forth by items. Also, into the amounts of money audited in favor of Governor Wright and Governor Willard.
By Mr. RITTER. Authorizing a clerk for the Committee on Public Expenditures. Rejected.
By Mr. PARKS. Directions to the Committee on Roads, in regard to the pay of Supervisors.

div.head: BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS.
div.p: By Mr. CLEMENTS. Authorizing the Doorkeeper to subscribe for 500 copies of Drapier's Brevier Legislative Reportsthe Senate adopting a similar resolution.
Mr. STILES moved to lay this resolution on the table.
Mr. CLEMENTS demanded the yeas and nays, and the vote resulting - yeas 36, nays 55the question recurred on the adoption of the resolution.

Mr. RITTER complained that his proposition to allow the Committee on Public Expenditure a Clerk, which would only cost the State some $60, for the purpose of finding out how some ten thousand dollars have been taken from the Treasury, had been just voted down by gentlemen who were now proposing to expend a thousand dollars for taking reports perfectly useless to our constituents; and they were determined to persist in this, and wear out the patience of the House until they should obtain it; an I when we stand up and oppose their resolution, they tell us we spend more money by the consumption of time than would authorize these reports. He made the point that the resolution was out of order. Define the House had neglected a similar resolution.
The SPEAKER decided the resolution in order.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, proposed to amend, by adding a provision, "That each member pay for the number of copies he may wish, out of his own private funds.
The SPEAKER. That is incompatible with the object of the resolution, and out of order.

Mr. CLEMENTS demanded the previous question, and there being a second, and the main question being ordered by consent, the vote on the adoption of the resolution, resulted - yeas 45, nays 43, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Black, Blythe, Bowman, Carr, Clayton, Clements, Collier, Davia, Dobbins, Durham, Early, Eastham, Edwards, Firestone, Gifford, Gregory, Griffin, Hancock, Hartley, Jordan, Kelly, Kempf, Lawhead, Lewis, McLain, Massey, Merrifield, Murray, Nelson, Newton, Parks, Parrett. Prosser, Scott, Shockley, Shull, Snyder,Stanley, Sullivan, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of Madison, Turpie, Usrey, Wheeler - 45.

NAYS - Messrs. Austin, Boyd, Boxley, Branham, Brotherton, Cavins, Clark, Colgrove, Com.stock, Cotton. Davidson, Dougherty, Fordyce, Hall of Grant, Hall of Rush, Hamilton ot Boone, Hamilton of Wayne, Harrison. Hunter, Jeffries, Johnston, Jones, Major, Mansfield, Mellett, Miller, Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Ritter, Robinson, Row, Rynerson, Sherman, Shields, Smith of Miami, Stiles, Thompson of Elkhart, Whetzel, Whiteman, Willman, Wood, and Mr. Speaker43.
So the resolution was adopted.
On motion by Mr. CAVINS the vote on Mr, Ritter's proposition for a Clerk to the Committee on Public Expenditures was reconsidered, and the Clerk was allowed.
On motion by Mr. AUSTIN, it was resolved that the Auditor of State be requested to send in his report for the year 1858.

div.head: KANSAS.
div.p: Mr. SHIELDS submitted a resolution to the effect, "that that part of the English bill known as the population clause, discriminating as it does in favor of a Constitution conceived in fraud, born in perjury, and baptized by a wholesale violation of principle, should be repealed, and that we respectfully request all persons in Congress from the State of Indiana to vote for its repeal."
Mr. DAVIS. If the gentleman will make it a joint resolution and strike out the toploftical language, I will vote for it.
Mr. SHIELDS acquiesced.

Mr. DOUGHERTY proposed to amend by striking out the repealing portion, and inserting words to the effect that the Territory of Kansas be admitted as a State, without regard to population, whenever she applies with a Republican Constitution.
Mr. GIFFORD. We have heretofore passed a resolution to nearly the same effect.
Mr. MERRIFIELD moved to lay the resolution and amendment on the table.
Mr. MURRAY. Which is the Democratic side of this question. [Laughter.]The House refused to lay on the table, by yeas 34, nays 51and the question recurred on Mr. Dougherty's amendment modified.
Mr . SHIELDS. I accept the amendment as additional matter.
Mr.DOUGHERTY explained his views at length, and his position on this question before his constituents. His modification was by way of substitute.
Mr. GIFFORD also defined his position to this question - insisting that there was no urgency for action.
Mr. MELLETT moved to lay the amendment on the table.
The motion was agreed to - yeas 49, nays 40.The previous question was demanded and ordered on the adoption of the original resolution, and pending its force -
Mr. RITTER desired to amend the phraseology.
Mr. DAVIS and others objected, insisting that the phraseology ought to remain, because the House had refused to amend.
The vote resulted - yeas 49, nays 29, as follows:

NAYS - Messrs. Austin, Boxley, Branham, Brotherton, Cavins, Clark, Colgrove, Collier,Comstock, Cotton, Davidson, Edwards, Fordyce, Gregory, Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hall of Hush, Hamilton of Boone, Hamilton of Wayne, Harney, Harrison, Hunter, Jeffries, Johnston, Jones, Mansfield, Mellett, Miller, Murray, Martin, Nebeker of Vermilllon, Nebeker of Warren, Parks, Ritter, Robinson, Row, Rynerson, Scott, Sherman, Shields, Smith of Miami, Stiles. Thompson of Elkhart, Treadway, Waterman, Whetzel, Whiteman, Wildman, and Mr. Speaker - 49.

YEAS - Messrs. Bowman,Carr, Claypool, Clayton, Clements, Dobbins, Early, Eastham, Firestone, Gifford, Hancock, Hartley, Jordan, Kelly, Kempf, Lewis, McLain, Merrifieid, Nelson, Parrett, Prosser,Shockley, Shull, Snyder, Stanley, Sullivan, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of Madison, Usrey and Wood - 29.
Messrs. Black, Blythe, Boyd, Davis, Dougherty, Durham, Major, Massey, Newton, Turpie, Wheeler and perhaps others, being present, and refusing to vote.
So the resolution was rejected for want of a constitutional majority.
Mr. COLGROVE. Is the resolution subject to be called up again?
The SPEAKER. Yes, by a majority.
Mr. DAVIS submitted a joint resolution to the following effect:

Resolved,&c. That our Senators in Congress be instructed, and our Representatives be requested to vote for the admission of Kansas into the Union as a State, without regard to the population, as soon as the people thereof shall desire to come in under a republican constitution, adopted by a majority of the voters of said Territory.
Resolved further,That the Governor be requested to forward a copy of the foregoing joint resolution to each of our Senators and Representatives in Congress.
Mr. JORDON proposed to amend, by adding to the first resolution these words:

p.hi: "Believing that she now has, or will have, before the people can form a constitution and apply for admission, a population sufficient to entitle her to admission under the English bill."

div.p: Mr. DAVIS moved to lay the amendment on the table.
Mr. MELLETT-the bill and the amendment.
Mr. DAVIS and Mr. JORDON demanded the yeas and nays, which resultedyeas 47, nays 41, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Austin, Bowman, Boxley, Brotherton, Clayton, Clements, Colgrove, Comstock, Cotton, Davidson, Early, Eastham,Edwards, Fordyce, Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hall of Rush. Hamilton of Boone, Hamilton of Wayne, Harney, Jeffries, Kempf, McLain, Major, Mansfield, Miller, Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren,-Parks, Prosser, Ritter, Robinson, Rynerson, Scott, Sherman, Smith of Miami, Snyder, Stiles, Sullivan, Thompson of Elkhart, Treadway, Turpie, Whetzel, Whiteman, and Wildman - 47.

NAYS - Messrs. Blythe, Boyd, Branham, Carr, Cavins, Clark,Claypool, Collier. Davis, Dobbins, Dougherty, Durham, Firestone, Gifford, Gregory, Hartley, Johnston, Jones, Jordan, Kelley, Lawhead, Lewis, Massey,Mellett, Merrifield, Murray, Nelson, Newton, Parrett, Row, Shockley, Stanley, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of Malison, Usrey, Waterman, Wheeler, Wood and Mr. Speaker - 41.
So the resolution and amendment were laid on the table.
Mr. DOUGHERTY submitted a joint resolution to the following effect:

Resolved,&cThat our Senators in Congress be Instructed, and our Representatives requested to vote for the admission of Kansas into the Union, either as a Free or Slave State, as her people may determine, with a constitution approved by her people, and without regard to population; and that the Governor be requested to transmit a copy of this resolution, to each of our Senators and Representatives in Congress.
Mr. MURRAY proposed to amend, by striking out and inserting these words:
Resolved,That the victorious and harmonious Democracy be permitted to hold a caucus to-night, at early candle lighting, for the purpose of re-organizing their forces [Laughter.]
The SPEAKER: That is out of order.
Mr. CLEMENTS demanded the previous question, and, there being a second, the main question was ordered.
Mr. COLGROVE demanded a call of the House.
The SPEAKER: We are under the previous question.
On motion by Mr. AUSTIN, and on a division of affirmative 40, negative 37 -
The House adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: The journal of yesterday was read.

div.head: PETITIONS AND MEMORIALS.
div.p: Mr. WILLIAMS presented a petition from sundry printers of the City of Vincennes, praying against reducing the prices now paid for public printing, and asking that all bids for doing said printing at a lower rate, be treated as such designing schemes deserve; which was read and referred to the Committee on Printing.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. HENDRY from the Judiciary Committee, returned Mr. Murray's bill (S. 15) to amend the 103d section of a law reform act approved June 17,1852, and recommended its indefinite postponement.
Mr. BENNETT desired to make a minority report in a day or two, and for that purpose moved to lay the bill on the table.
The motion was agreed to.

Mr. MARCH, from the same committee returned Mr. Green's bill (S. 19) providing for an enumeration to be made of white inhabitants over 21 years of age, in 1860, and every five years thereafter; and recommended its passage.
The report was concurred in by consent, and the bill passed the second reading.

Mr. HEFFREN, from the same committee, returned a resolution having reference to abandoned plank and other roads,recommending that it lie on the table, as a bill had already been introduced covering the entire ground contemplated in the resolution.
The report was concurred in.

Mr. SLACK, from the same committee, returned Mr. Wallace's bill (S. 20) providing for and regulating the payment of costs occasioned by the prosecution and conviction of persons charged with felony, and recommended its indefinite postponement.

Mr. WALLACE hoped the report would not be concurred in. Innocent men have been compelled to attend upon trials of persona accused of felory, and their trouble and expense have all amounted to nothing to them - they have never had compensation therefor.
Mr. WEIR hoped this bill would not be postponed indefinitely. He believed it just as much the duty of the State to pay those fees as to pay any debt she owes.
Mr. JOHNSTON was opposed to the bill. He thought the tendency of the bill would be to make witnesses swear hard in order to get their fees.

Mr. GOODING desired that the bill should not be indefinitely postponed The bill ought to be amended so as to provide that where the convict has an estate liable to execution, the costs should be collected by execution, but failing in that, the costs should be paid out of the labor of the convict in the State Prison.
Mr. ANTHONY defended the report of the committee, and urged concurrence therein.
Mr. HEFFREN was opposed to the provisions contemplated in the bill, and hoped the bill would be indefinitely postponed.

Mr. CONNER contended that the bill was not perfect, but insisted that some law upon this subject should be passed by the Legislature. He moved to recommit, with instructions to so amend as to prevent the transfer or assignment of costs, that the defendant's property shall first be reported to for the payment of such costs, and to inquire into the expediency of providing for the payment of costs under proper restrictions, in state cases where the defendant is acquitted.
The PRESIDENT [Mr. Slack in the chair] decided the amendment out of order.
Mr. WALLACE appealed from the decision of the Chair.
The PRESIDENT. Send up your appeal in writing.
On motion by Mr. BLAIR, the appeal was laid on the table before the appellant had time to reduce it to writing.
Mr. WALLACE objected to such summary proceeding, come from whom it may.
Mr. JOHNSTON saw no necessity for any had feeling. He thought the decision of the Chair was correct.
The report was then concurred in.
Mr. BENNETT, from the same committee, returned his bill (S. 35) to amend section 433 of a law reform act, approved June 18, 1852, and recommended its passage.

Mr. BENNETT desired to have the present law so amended as that sheriffs shall be compelled to levy on all property alike, whether the party against whom the execntion is issued, be the officer's political friend or foe. He declared his willingness to vote for an increase of the homestead law from $300 to $500, or any other reasonable amount.
Mr. STEVENS moved to concur in the report with an amendment, giving the sheriff nine months to make the money and return executions for the years 1859 and 1860, and thereafter six months.
On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, the amendment was laid on the table - yeas 21, nays 19.
Mr. MARCH had heard no complaint of the law as it exists, and thought it bad policy to change the law in relation to debtor and, creditor at a time when there is no demand for it.
On motion, the bill was laid on the table.
Mr. ANTHONY, from the same committee, returned his bill (S. 20) to amend section 9 of an act to exempt property from sale in certain cases, approved February 17, 1852, and recommended its passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill passed the second reading.

Mr. WALLACE, from the same committee, returned his bill (S. 46) to amend sec. 4 of an act providing for the election, fixing the compensation and prescribing the duties of the Attorney General of the State of Indiana, and recommended its passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill ordered to be engrossed.

Mr. WAGNER, from the Committee on Education, returned Mr. Bobbs' bill (S. 25) to provide for the redemption or purchase of bank bonds of Indiana, State stocks, &c.. with an amendment and recommended its passage.
On motion by Mr. STUDABAKER it was made the special order for Tuesday next at 10 o'clock A. M.
[A message from the House announced the passage by that body of a joint resolution (H. R, 13) relative to the construction of a canal at the Falls of the Ohio river.]

Mr. WAGNER, from the Committee on Agriculture, returned Mr. Brown's bill (S. 32) for. the better protection of growing cranberries and to prohibit the sale or purchase thereof in the time therein specified, and recommended its passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill ordered to be engrossed.

Mr. TURNER, from the Swamp Land Committee, returned his bill (S. 13) to amend sections 20, 28, 32, 35 and 51 of an act regulating the sale of swamp lands, approved May 29,1852, and recommended its passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill ordered to be engrossed.

div.head: NEW PROPOSITIONS.
div.p: The following bills were introduced and severally passed the first reading:
By Mr. ODELL, (No. 103) authorizing County Boards to hear and determine complaints against plank, gravel, turnpike or McAdamized roads.
By Mr. MILLER, (No. 104) in relation to abandoned plank, McAdamized or chartered roads.
By Mr. WAGNER, (No. 105) prescribing the forms to be used in criminal cases.

By Mr. HEFFREN, (No. 106) providing for the relief of purchasers of real estate at Sheriff's sales under executions issued on judgments
against services on recognizances, where such had been taken after the Revised Statutes of 1852 took effect.
By Mr. STUDABAKER, (No 107) to authorize assessors of real property to administer all oaths required to be administered in the discharge of their duties.

By Mr. RICE (No. 108) to amend sections 4, 5, 18, 20, 28 and 32 of the law regulating general elections; approved June 7, 1852; to repeal sections 29 and 30 of said act, and adding a provision supplementary thereto.
[Mr. WAGNER, by leave, submitted a report from the Committee on Education, embracing a history of the sinking fund, which was laid on the table without reading, and 200 copies ordered to be printed.]

By Mr. JOHNSTON, (No. 109) to amend sections 1 and 2 of an act to provide compensation to owners of animals killed or injured by any car, locomotive or carriage of any railroad company in this State, approved March 1, 1853.

div.head: BANK OF THE STATE OF INDIANA.
div.p: Mr. CONLEY, by leave, offered the following:

Resolved,Mr. CONLEY, by leave, offered the following: Resolved, That the special committee to whom was referred Senate bill (No. 42) are hereby directed to inquire into the management of the Bank of the State of Indiana, and the conduct and transactions of its officers during and since its organization, and that said committee is hearby empowered to send for persons and papers if deemed necessary by a majority of said committee.

Mr. CONLEY said there were indications that this concern has not been properly conducted, and in the event of the discovery of misconduct, this resolution is offered in order that we may have the proper sources of development. If there has boon no mismanagement it world increase the credit of the institution with the people; and these ultra bank men should be the last to oppose the adoption of the resolution.
On a motion to lay the resolution on the table, the yeas and nays were demanded, and bring ordered and taken, resulted - yeas, 18, nays 17 - as follows:
YEAS - Messrs. Anthony, Bennett, Blair, Bobbs, Cobbt Conner, Cooper, Cravens, Craven, Green, Hamilton, Heffren, Hill, Johnston, Odell, Stevens, Turner and Wagner-18.
NAYS. - Messrs. Conley, Fisk, Qoodinjr, Hargrove, Hendry, Jennings, Kinley, Line, Lomax, McClure, March, Miller, Rice, Shoemaker, Slack, Thompson and Wallace-17.
Mr. CRAVENS, when his name was called, said he thought the proposition was intended to injure the currency of the country.

Mr. GOODING, when his name was called, said the repeal of this bank charter might effect the currency somewhat, but currency or no currency, he should vote for the repeal, and let consequences take care of themselves. It were better to have war, pestilence and famine, than to sustain such an institution. The honor of Indi an a requires the repeal of that charter.

Mr. LINE, when his name was called, said he was not here to cast his vote with a view to make war upon any institution of our State, but when the question comes up here to investigate this matter, it seemed out of place to refuse.

Mr. WAGNER, when his name was called, said that, by his vote, he did not express an opinion in favor of covering up any mismanagement on the part of any bank. He took the ground that the Senate had no right to presume matters were going wrong, unless there were charges made.

Mr. WALLACE, when his name was called, said it was contended, as a reason why we can not repeal this charter, that it is a contract; if it is, who are the parties to it? The State of Indiana and certain citizens? If it is a contract, and the State is a party to it, we unquestionably have the right to make this examination. He was in favor of an examination, whenever we can do it lawfully.
So the resolution lies upon the table.

div.head: DOG LAW.
div.p: DOG LAW. Mr. LINE, (by leave) from the Committee on Agriculture, returned Mr. Fisk's bill (S. 33) to tax dogs, and indemnify owners of sheep, killed or injured by dogs or wolves, with amendments, and recommended its passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill ordered to be engrossed.

div.head: PUBLIC PRINTING.
div.p: Mr. WAGNER, (by leave) presented a petition similar to the first one offered this day, praying against the reduction of the prices paid for public printing, and signed by several printers of Williamsport, which was also referred to the Committee on Printing.
And then the Senate adjourned.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: Messrs. Knowlton, Stanfield and Sullivan had leave of absence till Tuesday.

div.head: OHIO FALLS CANAL.
div.p: Mr. CARR asked and obtained leave to submit a joint resolution (No. 13) relative to the construction of a new canal at the Falls of the Ohio river, on the Indiana side.
The joint resolution was adopted - yeas 73, nays 0.

div.head: TESTIMONY
div.p: Mr. DAVIS (by unanimous consent) returned from the Judiciary Committee Mr. Blythe'a bill (28) providing the use of evidence in perpetuating testimony, &c., recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in aad the bill ordered to be engrossed.

div.head: DIVORCE.
div.p: Mr. DAVIS, from the same committee, returned the resolution of inquiry into the expediency of requiring both parties to an action in divorce, to have a residence of one year, with the expression of opinion that further legislation in this direction is inexpedient.
The report was concurred in.

div.head: HIGHWAYS.
div.p: Mr. PROSSER (under a suspension of the order of business) introduced a bill (No. 95) to legalize the location, vacation and change of public highways, which was passed the first reading.

Mr. P. said: I have introduced that for the purpose of curing defects in the location of our highways. Owing to the manner in which roads have been located, there is scarcely any road that is legal, and the roads are shut up and obstructed. If the supervisor is indicted, the indictment can not be maintained, and consequently our roads are generally in bad order. I know of no better way of coming at the remedy than by legalizing the roads that have been located. You are aware, sir, that unless the width of the road is specified in the order for location, it is not a lawful road, under the decisions of the Courts, and there are very few roads having the width so specified. I move a suspension of the rules to allow the bill to be read the second time now.
The motion was agreed to, and the bill referred to the Committee on Roads.
On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, the orders were suspended generally for the

By Mr. PARKS, (No. 108) for the protection of wild cranberries growing on public, State, and non-resident lands in this State, and providing penalty for violation of this act.

By Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, (No. 110) to amend the 76th section of the misdemeanor act of June 14, 1852.

div.head: ADMISSION OF KANSAS
div.p: The SPEAKER announced the order of unfinished business, viz: the question on the adoption of Mr. Dougherty's joint resolution (12) in relation to the admission of Kansas - the previous question having been demanded and seconded, and the main question ordered thereon.

Mr. DOUGHERTY asked the unanimous consent of the House to pass the subject over inform
ally, and make this and and Mr. Shield's joint resolution (10) the special order for Friday next. ["Consent," "consent''"No consent"]
Mr. MURRAY. I hope the House will consent.
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren. Will it not still be under the previous question?
The SPEAKER. It will.
Mr. NEBEKER, Then I move to reconsider the order for the main question.
Mr. DOUGHERTY and Mr. FIRESTONE demanded the yeas and nays, which being ordered and taken, resulted - yeas 18, nays 44 - no quorum voting.

Mr. AUSTIN moved a call of the House, but - The SPEAKER now decided, no motion in order, nor anything but the vote, under the force of the previous question. The vote was taken and resulted - yeas 28, nays 28 - as follows:

YAES - Messrs. Black, Boyd, Carr, Cavins, Claypool, Comstock, Dougherty, Firestone, Gifford, Jones, Kelley, Lawhead, Lewis, Major, Massey, Merrifield, Nelson. Newton, Prosser, Row, Sherman, Shockley, Shull, Snyder, Stanley, Waterman, Wheeler and Wood2 - 8.

NAYS -Messrs. Austin. Boxley, Branham, Brotherton, Clark, Colgrove, Davidson, Fordyce, Hamilton of Boone, Hamilton of Wayne, Harrison, Hartley, Jeffries, Johnston, Mansfield, Murray, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Ritter, Robinson, Scott, Smith of Miami, Thompson of Elkhart, Treadway,Usrey, Weetzel, Wildman and Mr. Speaker - 28.
No quorum voting
Mr. PARKS desired to record his vote, but -
The hour of 11 o'clock having arrived, the Speaker declared there was no result on the queston, and under the standing rule, adjourned the House till Monday, 2 o'clock P. M.

div.head: UNITED STATES SENATORS.
div.p: The LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR announced the special order for this hour, [2 o'clock]being Mr. Line's joint resolution, (No. 6) instructing our Senators and requesting our Representatives in Congress to vote for a law fixing the time, place and manner of electing United States Senators in the different States.
Mr. ODELL moved that the resolution be referred to the Committee on Federal Relations.
The motion was agreed to by consent.

div.head: PETITION.
div.p: Mr. STUDABAKER. presented a petition from sundry citizens of Adams county, against reducing prices paid for the public printing which, on his motion, was referred to the Committee on Printing without reading.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. HEFFREN,from the Finance Committee, returned his bill (S. 30) to provide for the transfer of certificates of State stocks, &c., and to prevent the fraudulent issue thereof, and recommending its passage. He moved that it be considered as engrossed and read the third time now.
The motion was agreed to, the bill read the third time, and finally passed by yeas 37, nays 5.

Mr. BEESON, from the Committee on Agriculture, returned Mr. Carnahan's bill (S. 38) to enable industrious, indigent persons, who are unable to give security, to rent land, and recommended its passage.
The bill was read the second time by title and ordered to be engrossed.

div.head: CHANGING THE TIME OF HOLDING COURTS.
div.p: Mr. SLACK moved to suspend the order of business and take up his bill (S. 60) fixing the time of holding Circuit Courts in the 11th Judiciary Circuit.
The motion was agreed to, and the bill being on the third reading was finally passed the Senate, yeas 44, nays 0.
Mr. BOBBS moved to further suspend the order of business and take up his bill (S. 49) fixing the time of holding courts in the 5th Judicial Circuit.
The motion was agreed to, and the bill was referred to a special committee of five, which the LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR makes to consist of Senators Bobbs, Jennings, Gooding, Blair and Murray.

div.p: The following bills were introduced and severally passed the first reading:
By Mr. GREEN, (No. 115) to amend section 327, art. 18, chap. 1, Revised Statutes of 1852.

By Mr.HEFFREN, (No. 116) fixing the times of holding Courts in the Second Judicial Circuit.On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, the rules were suspendedyeas 41, nays 0the bill read a second time by its title, and referred to a select committee of three, which the LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR makes to consist of Senators Heffren, Lomax and Cobb.
