div.p: In the absence of the Lieutenant Governor, on motion by Mr. GREEN, the Senator from Jefferson (Mr. Cravens) took the Chair and called the Senate to order.

div.head: PETITIONS, MEMORIALS, AND REMONSTRANCES.
div.p: Mr. CRAVENS presented a petition from sundry citizens of Madison, Indiana, praying for the repeal of the 9th section of an act to reduce the law incorporating the city of Madison, approved January 15, 1849, which was referred to a select committee of three.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p:
Mr. RICE, from the Committee on Finance,
returned Mr. Cooper's bill (S. 110) to prohibit Clerks of Circuit and Common Pleas Courts, and their deputies, from practicing as attorneys at law in the courts in which they are deputies; recommending indefinite postponement.
Mr. GOODING objected to concurrence in the report, and desired to know the reason why the commitee recommended an indefinite postponement of the bill.
Mr. RICE replied, that after considering article 7, section 21, of the State Constitution, the committee were of opinion such an act as contemplated in the bill would be unconstitutional.
Mr. GOODING thought you might just as well say that judges might practice in their own courts, as to allow clerks and deputy clerks to do so. He moved to recommit the bill to the Judiciary Committee.

Mr. MURRAY thought the Committee on Finance did not view this matter right. In his opinion the Legislature had no power to pass a law that any individual of good moral character should not practice law in any court; but we have the power to say that an officer shall not, while he is such officer, or acting as such officer.The motion was agreed to, and the bill recommitted to the Judiciary Committee.

Mr. CARNAHAN, from the same commitee, returned his bill (S. 53) authorizing County Commissioners to award compensation to persons who may bring to justice fugitives from the same, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. JONES, from the same committee, returned his bill (S. 19) to provide compensation to persons who may bring to justice fugitives from the same, recommending that it lay on the table.
The report was concurred in.

Mr. TARKINGTON, from a select committee, returned his bill (S. 62) for the relief of the Indiana University, and to increase and extend its benefits by providing for the sale of the University lands, &c., (19,000 acres) under the direction of its Board of Trustees, after appraisement, on a credit of ten years, recommending its passage.

Mr. GOODING thought this was the worst time that could be chosen to dispose of these lands. He would not say he was opposed to the bill, but simply wished to be assured that it was all right, and for that purpose moved its reference to the Committee on Education.

Mr. WAGNER said that the University must have some iunds, but he did not wish to authorize the sale of more land than was necessary, be cause it was a bad time to sell now. He knew of land belonging to the University which a railroad would run through in five years, when the land would be worth twice as much as it is now.
Mr. TARKINGTON saw no objection to this bill as it is, and he had no objection to the reference, except that it would retard the passage of the bill.

Mr. RICE understood that the University was in need of funds. $10,000 of debt is hanging over them, and as they ask to be relieved from that embarrassment, he hoped this bill for their relief would not be retarded in its progress.
Mr. McLEAN thought there was no need of referring this bill to the Committee on Education, and apprehended that the Senate was fully prepared to vote upon the bill now.
Mr. CARNAHAN was in favor of the bill going to the Committee on Education, and be scrutinized closely. He looked upon this college as being one of the best endowed in the world.

Mr. HENDRY would be under the necessity of voting against this bill were the vote taken now, because he had been unable to inform himself of the condition of the financial affairs of the University. He did not see the use of bringing all these lands into market, when there was need of the sale of but one-half of them.

Mr. MARCH was disposed to vote for this bill upon the information he had obtained from those in whom he had confidence, but he had no objection to its going to the Committee on Education, as proposed.
Mr. TARKINGTON spoke in explanation of the condition of the affairs of the University, in which he showed, among other things, that it was at this time in a very flourishing condition.
The motion was agreed to, and the bill recommitted to the Committee on Education.

Mr. STEELE, from the Committee on Banks, returned Mr. Conley's resolution in relation to suppressing the circulation of foreign bank bills of a less denomination than $10; recommending that it is inexpedient to legislate upon the subject.

Mr. MARCH expressed his dessent from the report. If there ever was a favorable time for restricting the issue of small notes, now is the time We have now a greater supply of specie currency than ever before. There has been produced from the mines of Australia and California within the past few years more gold than was in existence before. He then indulged in a few remarks having particular reference to the Bank of the State of Indiana.
Mr. HAMILTON objected to the Senator's reflections upon the Bank of the State of Indiana.
Mr. WALLACE desired to have a law on this subject that should apply to the banks of our own State.

Mr. STEELE had declared here time and again that he had not one dollar's interest in the Bank of the State either directly or indirectly, but he regretted that no question relating to the trade of the country can come up here without having Senators talk about the iron heel of banks. The committee were induced to make this report from comparing the experience of other States upon this subject. In Illinois they have a law prohibiting the circulation of foreign bank bills of a small denomination, but the law is not carried out; it is a dead letter on the Statute Book. In Iowa they have a similar law, and yet small notes constitute almost the entire circulation of that State.
Mr. WALLACE. Suppose this Bank of the State were stricken down, how long would it take the free banks to issue a circulation sufficient to supply the demand for a home currency in this State?

Mr. STEELE thought it would take some time. The entire circulation of all the free banks of the State amounts to about $900,000.
They can not issue a dollar unless by permission of the officers of State and upon the deposit of stocks to the amount of $10 for every $100 issued. It is now with difficulty that these banks keep up their securities there. The Bank of the State will be the only bank in operation in the State in a few years.
Mr. HEFFREN was opposed to the report. He moved to lay the report on the table.
The motion was agreed to.

div.head: REDEMPTION OF BONDS, STOCKS, &C.
div.p: The special order for 10 o'clock, Mr. Bobbs' bill, (S. 25) to provide for the redemption or purchase of Bank bonds, State stocks, United States stocks, &c., the question being on concurring in the report with the amendments proposed by the committee to which it was referred - coming up -
Mr. STUDABAKER moved to amend by striking out from the enacting clause and inserting an entire new bill.
On motion by Mr. CONNER, the consideration of this subject was further postponed till tomorrow 10 o'clock.

div.head: SHINPLASTERS.
div.p: Mr. HEFFREN, from the Bank Committee, by leave, returned the bill (H. R. 12) to prevent the issue of unauthorized paper currency, with amendments, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in.
On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, the bill was considered as engrossed.
Mr. GOODING. May not a third person maliciously put in circulation bills and thus make it almost impossible to prove a negative?
Mr. HEFFREN. It is in that the signature to the note or bill is prima facie evidence that the person whose name is put there executed it aid is responsible for the issue.
Mr. TARKINGTON. The courts have decided that we have no right to make a retrospective law, affecting bills in circulation at the time of the passage of the law
Mr. HEFFREN. The bill provides that a failure or refusal to redeem their issues shall be deemed a misdemeanor.
Mr. STUDABAKER thought the bill unconstitutional.
Mr. BOBBS was in favor of legislation of the most stringent character.
Mr. BENNETT thought there ought to be a diflerence between banks unauthorized and banks authorized; and this bill refers not to regular banks, but to unauthorized banks, as he understands it

Mr. MURRAY proposed to amend by adding to the first section the words: "Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as giving the right to any free bank of this State or the Bank of the State of Indiana, to issue or put in circulation any other paper than that authorized by the laws under which they were created."

Mr. GOODING. That amendment commits this Senate and the State to the existence of the Bank of the State as an institution. He would vote for no bill that acknowledges the existence of that institution. He moved to strike out the words "free banks of this State or the Bank of the State of Indiana," and insert in lieu thereof the words "banks created under the laws of this State."
Mr. MURRAY accepted of the amendment.
Mr. ANTHONY expressed himself as satisfied with the amendment proposed by the Senator from Howard, [Mr. Murray.]

Mr. TARKINGTON moved to recommit the bill to the Committee on Banks, with instructions to strike out all after the enacting clause and insert an entire new bill - which was read at the Secretary's desk.

Mr. WALLACE preferred the substitute proposed. The House bill made the offense punishable as a misdemeanor, and the substitute made the punishment as for felony, and will effectually crush out all unauthorized currency. There is nothing we should consider so carefully as a criminal statute. The proposition in the House bill making this prima facie evidence of guilt, is in violation of the oldest rule in the criminal evidence books, viz: that every presumption shall be in favor of a man's innocence. This House bill proposes that rule shall be pulled up by the roots.

Mr. CONNER thought the controversy on every bill of this kind which had been before the Senate, was with reference to the phraseology Senators do not seem to differ so much about the principles which should be carried out.

Mr. MURRAY. The difference is almost like that between tweedle-dum and tweedle-dee. Every Senator must not insist upon having every bill just exactly as he wants it. If we are not prepared to give and take we can not get anything done. The bill reported by the committee is as much as he could ask upon this subject. The adoption of the substitute would be the cause of difficulty with the House of Representatives. The best policy will be to take the House bill, amend it to suit our views, pass it, and it will then only require simple concurrence on their part. He moved to lay the motion to recommit, with instructions to adopt the substitute proposed, on the table.
The motion was agreed to.
Mr. CRAVEN moved to recommit with instructions to strike out that provision of the bill which provides that notes shall be prima facie evidence of guilt.
On motion by Mr. HARGROVE, this motion was laid on the table - yeas 33, nays 11.
Mr. TARKINGTON moved to amend by adding to the fourth section the words "unless its execution be denied under oath by the defendant."The motion was agreed to by unanimous consent.

Mr. WALLACE moved to amend by making the offense a felony instead of a misdemeanor. Under our present law misdemeanors are never punished; but felonies are in the jurisdiction of the grand jury, and they are bound to find bills. In order to make this offense punishable, it has got to be removed from the list of misdemeanors and made a felony.
The motion not being received by unanimous consent - the bill having been read the third time and upon its passage - the amendment proposed, was ruled out of order.
Mr. MURRAY demanded the previous question.
There being a second, and the main question ordered, under its operation the bill was finally passed the Senate yeas 43, nays 1.
On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, the title was amended by adding these words: "And to punish the putting away of broken bank notes or the notes of banks which have suspended specie payment.
Mr. MURRAY offered a resolution, which was adopted, that when the Senate adjourn it adjourn till 9 o'clock to-morrow.
And then the Senate adjourned.

div.head: PETITIONS AND MEMORIALS.
div.p: Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, presented the resolution of a late public meeting at West Lebanon, praying for the passage of Mr. Good-win's Temperance bill(the Senate bill similar to that of Mr. Nebeker)which was referred to the Committee on Temperance.

M. MURRAY presented the petition of Jacob and John Soffer, asking for indemnification for their ouster from title to a quarter section of land in Kosciusko county, which was referred to the Committee on Claims.

Mr. CARR presented the petition of sundry citizens, asking for John F. Wyly & Son further time to complete their Charleston and Jeffersonville road, which, on the motion of Mr. Davis, was referred to a select committee, which the Speaker makes to consist of Messrs. Carr, Davis, Bowman, Comstock and Sullivan.

Mr. COTTON presented the petition of Samuel W. Ritchey and others, for the establishment of an Agricultural College within five miles of the city of Indianapolis, which was referred to the Committee on Agriculture.

Mr. COLLIER presented the petition of Henry Winter, Alonzo Hubbard and others, printers of the State of Indiana, asking that "the various schemes, strategems and low bids, looking to a reduction in the price of the public printing," be "treated with merited contempt," and he moved that it be referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. RITTER. There were quite a number of these petitions, and he thought, perhaps, it would be best to pile them up with the Committee on Rights and Privileges; which was agreed to.
Mr. SULLIVAN and Mr. SHULL presented similar petitions, which took the same direction.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, presented the petition of Levi Raymond - for relief - which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions to inquire, &c.
Mr. MELLETT presented the petition of Caleb White and others, for a more stringent law against sheep killing and other dogs, which was referred to the Committee on Agriculture.
Mr. Hall, of Grant, presented two temperance petitions, which were referred to the Temperance Committee.

div.head: BREVIER LEGISLATIVE REPORTS.
div.p: Mr. SCOTT. Mr. Speaker, I have been justinformed that the Senate insists on taking 600 copies of the Legislative Sentinel for that body alone, and that the Door keeper under our resolution is to take five hundred copies for the House of Representatives. That was not my understand ng when I voted for that resolution, and I move to suspend the order of business to enable me to move to reconsider the vote adopting that resolution.

Mr. DAVIS. This matter has been up two or three times, and there can be no room for misunderstanding as to its being a concurrent resolution. It was a resolution of this House. We can not, at this time prudently talk about acting again on these resolutions of the two Houses, passed more than a week since. We perfectly understood what we were doing.

Mr. SCOTT. That was not my understanding. The friends of the resolution understood that two hundred copies of the paper were to be taken by the Senate, and three hundred by the House. With that understating I voted for it. I never understood that the order of the Houses was to extend to $1,100.
Mr. RITTER. They worried us into the passage of this resolution, and it is nothing but right that we should now worry them a little in turn.

Mr. STANFIELD I suppose this question is settled - and that the House will be unwilling to sustain this motion. I am not resposible for the understanding of gentlemen, but I will say this: that unless the number of copies provided for in these resolutions are taken, the Reporters will be unable to make the reports the Legislature seem to desire. I am satisfied that it will be much better for the country and for us to have a clear, succinct and reliable statement published of what transpires in these halls something that will give the position taken by members upon the propositions and bills to come before the Legislature, and we have had an illustration of what these reports will be. We have taken the various newspapers as heretofore, and I think their publishers have not treated us fairly. I have no doubt that it was the clear understanding of the House and the publishers themselves, that those papers should employ reporters, and furnish reports of the proceedings of this session, similar to those of the Legislative Sentinel, but so soon as the contracts are made, we are bound by them, end the publishers refuse or neglect to make the reports we expected. Now, sir, how are we to obviate this difficulty? The Reporter [Mr. Drapier] is willing if this mode of compensation is provided for him, to make the reports we desire and publish them in this paper. The only compensation he gets for making and publishing these reports, is what he gets under this order, after paying for the printing in the newspaper and in the book form and I am assured by him that he will be entirely unable to furnish these reports in the manner proposed, unless the entire number subscribed for in both resolutions shall be taken. He says, and I rely upon him as a gentleman of intelligence and integrity, that the order for a less number will not be a sufficient compensation ? or his work. I hope, therefore, that the House will not suspend the rules, or if they do, that
the resolution, when taken up, will not be reconsidered.

Mr. GIFFORD. If this question is pressed, 1 shall insist upon a call of the House. I am satisfied that every member of this body who voted for this resolution, understood that five copies were to be taken by each member of this House. I have consulted with my colleague in the Senate, and he understands that the Senate are to take 600 copies, and we have agreed together that the whole number will be sufficient to supply every library in our county with a copy. I see my friend from Adams here, and several other members on this side of the House are absent, and I must insist on a call if gentlemen press this matter.

Mr. BOYD. In the discussion of this question of taking papers, as upon other questions, the country suffers more from too much than too little legislation. Had we understood ourselves at the start we should not have been put to so much trouble. In the beginning the proposition was to take two papers - the Journal and Sentinel. I voted for that. After that there were two others added. Then we got up the project of employing a Reporter and concluded to take none of the papers. Finally we concluded to take the papers upon the condition that the publishers should furnish Reporters for themselves. After that, when we came to consider the project of the Legislative Sentinel, I was favorable to taking that by individual members - not by the State. But the House decided otherwise; and I can not see how any one could misunderstand that resolution. The Reporter stated, by his friends here and elsewhere, that he could not get up the reports unless he had a thousand copies authorized. If gentlemen could not understand that, he is not to blame. I voted against that - being willing at the same time to take the work and pay for it out of my own pocket. But now, Mr. Speaker, since the order is passed, I see no necessity of consuming time in discussing that question, and so spending a larger amount of money than the reports would cost. I am opposed to reconsideration.

Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, spoke at length against the resolution, giving his construction the same with that of Mr. Scott and the Doorkeeper, and proceeding to point out several inaccuracies in the proceedings of the extra session as they are reported in the Legislative Sentinel.
After further discussion by Mr. Gifford, Mr. Harney, Mr. Hunter, Mr. Mellett and Mr. Murray,
Mr. DOBBINS demanded the previous question, which was sustained, and under its force the question on suspending the order of business was taken and resulted - yeas 42, nays 48, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Austin,Black, Boxley, Branham,Brotherton, Clark, Claypool,Collier, Comstock, Cotton,Davidson, Duvall, Fordyce, Hall of Grant, Hall of Rush, Hamilton, of Boone, Harrison, Hunter, Jeffries, Johnston, Jones, Kelly, Major, Mansfield, Mellett, Miller, Martin,Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Parks, Power, Ritter, Robinson, Rynerson, Scott, Sherman, Shields, Smith of Miami, Tebbs, Thompson of Elkhart, Whetzel, and Wild man - 42.

NAYS - Messrs. Blythe, Bowman, Carr, Cavins,Clayton, Clements, Davis, Dobbins, Dougherty, Durham, Early, Eastham, Edwards, Firestone, Gifford, Gregory, Griffin,Hancock, Harney, Hartley, Jordan, Kempf, Lawheaed, McLain, Massey, Merrifield, Murray, Nelson, Parrett, Prosser, Row, Shockley, Shull, Smith of Perry, Snyder, Stanley, Stanfield, Stiles, Sullivan, Thompson of Madison, Turpie, Usrey, Waterman, Wheeler, Whiteman, Wood and Mr. Speaker - 48.
So the order of business was not suspended.

Mr. PARKS presented the petition of H. B. Walbridge and others, on the subject of a more adequate remuneration for the services of "small officers in State cases;" which was referred to the Committee on County and Township Business.

Mr. MANSFIELD presented the petition"Of the Trustees of the town of Carlisle, asking that their acts in connection with the matter of the assessment of taxes for the erection of a school, house in said town may be legalized, which was referred to the Committee on Education.

Mr. EDWARDS presented the memorial of D. P. Hutchinson, relative to the protection and improvement of the breed of horned cattle which, after a discussion of its merits by Messrs. Comstock, Edwards and Murray, was referred to the Committee on Agriculture.

Mr. McLEAN presented a memorial in reference to the jurisdiction of Justices of the Peace, asking that the same be extended to one hundred dollars in civil cases, and to all cases of small offenses, where the penalty does not exceed fifty dollars, so that there can be no appeal taken therefrom; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

Mr. THOMPSON, of Madison. What has become of the Senate bill which proposes to transfer the County of Madison to the 7th Judicial Circuit. I wish it to be brought forward as soon as possible, for our court comes on the fourth Monday in next month.
The SPEAKER. It has been referred to a select committee, of which Mr. Brotherton is chairman.

div.head: THE EDWARDS AND FIRESTONE CASE.
div.p: Mr. STANFIELD, from the Committee on Elections, read a unanimous report on the contested election case for the seat ot the Hon. James B. Firestone, a Representative for the counties of Huntington and Whitley, made by Isaac B. Barker, for Caleb W. Edwards, concluding with the expression of the opinion of the committee that James B. Firestone is the legally elected Representative for said counties, in this body.
The report was concurred in unanimously, and it was ordered to be placed on the files of the Clerk.

Mr. STILES, from the Judiciary Committee, returned his bill (57) relative to contests of foreign wills and testaments, with a recommendation that the same do pass, and proposing an amendment of the title, so as to read: An act supplemental to an act entitled an act prescribing who may make a will, what shall be devised, and regulating contests thereof, approved may 31, 1852
.The SPEAKER. The Chair having reconsidered the matter, will hold that neither a member nor a committee can propose the amendment of a title, till the bill has passed the third reading.

The report of the committee (with this exception) was now concurred in, and the bill was con-
considered as engrossed, and passed the third reading by yeas-80, nays 0.
On motion by Mr. STILES, the title was then amended to read as above. So the bill passed the House of Representatives.

Mr. MELLETT, from the Judiciary Committee, returned the bill (76) to prohibit Clerks and Deputy Clerks from practicing law, &c., and declaring it a misdemeanor to refuse to issue writs, &c., with an amendment by way of substitute for the 2nd section, to-wit:
SEC. 2. Judges of all the Courts of Record in this State, are hereby prohibited from practicing law in this State.'
SEC. 3. Repealing conflicting laws.

Mr. DOUGHERTY hoped the report, would not be concurred in. He was opposed to prohibiting Common Pleas Judges from practicing, because $800 a year was not an adequate salary. He was opposed that provision of the bill which prohibits Deputy Clerks from practicing law. It was particularly calculated to operate against young lawyers.

Mr. MELLETT. The duties of a judge and lawyer were not consistent with each other The Common Pleas Judge frequently had a partner, and such an arrangement could not be satisfactory to the people. The bill provides that a Deputy Clerk shall not practice in the Court in which he is an officer. The bill was eminently just in every particular.

Mr. PARRETT. The Judges of Common Pleas in his part of the State could not maintain themselves upon $800. But he would seek the remedy in a reorganization of that Court, which should give the judges an adequate salary. He moved to refer the bill to the Committee on the Organization of Courts.
Mr. DOBBINS concurred with Mr. Dougherty. He considered the bill conflicted with the constitutional provision authorizing every citizen of the State of good moral character to practice law.
Mr. PARRETT'S motion was agreed to.

Mr. MELLETT, from the same committee, also reported a bill, declaring it a misdemeanor for any Clerk of the Circuit or Common Pleas Courts to refuse to issue writs and summonses, defining penalty therefor, which was passed the first reading.

div.head: REMOVAL OF DEAD BODIES.
div.p: Mr. SCOTT, from the same committee, returned Mr. Hamilton, of Boone's, bill (17) to prevent the illegal removal of dead bodies, recommending indefinite postponement.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, called for the reading of the bill. It was merely changing the offense from a misdemeanor to a felony. He hoped the House would not concur in the report.

Mr. GIFFORD. It was only necessary to enforce existing laws on this subject, to accomplish all that could be desired on this subject. A thousand dollars fine was an ample sanction for the law against this offense. What right could the Coroner have to give permission to enter the Potter's field? He preferred the existing law.
Mr. BAIRD thought the bill prescribed a punishment too severe to be executed. It were better policy to maintain a law that could be enforced.

Mr. RITTER. There was inequality against the medical profession, in that the State Library contained no work in medicine, whilst it is full of law books; yet the physician was vigorously prosecuted for malpractice in surgery, and surgery could not be understood without dissection - an act for which this bill proposes to send a man to the peniteniiary - to disfranchise him, &c. The present law was sufficiently stringent. There was a morbid sensibility and public feeling on this subject in many places.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, was heard again in reply, and in defense of the bill.
Mr. KEMPF. The foundation of medical knowledge was Anatomy, and from Anatomy came surgery, a most important branch of the profession. No physician should be allowed to practice without a diploma. &c.
The report was concurred in, and the bill indefinitely postponed.

div.head: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
div.p: Mr. DAVIS, from the Committee on the Judiciary, returned his bill (No. 1) for a Constitutional Convention, with amendments by way of substitute - prescribing that the question of calling said Convention, shall be submitted to the people on the day of April next; that if the expression be in the affirmative, the Governor shall issue his proclamation for the election of Delegates, (one from each Senatorial District) at the general election in October next - the said Convention to meet and be held in the Hall of the House of Representatives, on the day of November, 1859the Constitutional amendments of said Convention to be submitted for the confirmation of the people, by the next General Assembly.

Mr. DAVIS stated the general provisions of the bill. The whole was embraced in one question: Are we willing to submit this question to the people? It was just devolving power upon the people, where reposes all power in a Government like ours. It might be objected, that the Constitution provides for its amendment. If Constitutional provisions for its own amendment were binding, then we come still under the first Constitution. If the bill pass, there would not be cast in the county of Floyd 300 votes against the proposition.
The report was concurred in, and the amendment adopted.
Mr. CLEMENTS moved to lay the bill on the table and print 300 copies.
The motion was lost.

Mr. HUNTER proposed to amend, by striking out the words, "one from each Senatoriol District," and inserting these words: "one from each Congressional District, and two from the State at large;" and he spoke to this amendment - admitting the popular demand for a new Constitution - defending the amendment on the ground of economy, &c.
Mr. SHULL proposed to amend further, by striking out the words, "one for each Congressional District," and Inserting, "one from each Representative District."

Mr. DAVIS advocated the number, fifty. The former Convention was too large150. The bill does not provide for a reporter of speeches, as in
the former convention. The argument for the amendment of the gentleman from Monroe went too far and destroyed itself. It was approximating the one-man power. He was willing the people should act upon any question concerning their rights, and he was assured that a majority of the people of Indiana desired to get rid of the rickety Constitution under which we now live.
Mr. DOBBINS. Is the gentleman in favor of amending the present Constitution?
Mr. DAVIS. I am. I would strike the whole thing out if I could get a whack at it.
Mr. AUSTIN spoke against the proposed amendments.
[Mr. McLean, Mr. Colgrove, Mr. Collier, Mr. Wildman, Mr. Merrifield and Mr. Stanley had leave of absence till Monday.]
On motion by Mr. DAVIS the futher consideration of the bill and amendments was made the special order for to morrow, two o'clock.
On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, Mr. Blythe was added to the Select Committe on Colonization.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The SPEAKER announced the special order, viz: the consideration of the several bills to regulate the traffic in intoxicating liquors; and the order was that the House be resolved into Committee of the Whole for this purpose.

div.head: NEW PROPOSITIONS.
div.p: Mr. BAIRD (the order being suspended) introduced a bill (No. 134) to amend the first section of the act concerning real property and the alienation thereof, approved May 6, 1852:

Mr. EDWARDS introduced a bill (No. 135) dispensing with giving of bonds by any executor or executrix as a condition to granting letters testamentary in any case where the testator has declared the same may be done without the execution of bond:
Mr. BOYD introduced a bill (No. 136) for the protection of side-walks in towns ond villages, and for the preservation of shade-trees planting along the same:

Mr. COTTON introduced a bill (137) to amend the 24th section of the act concerning real property, and providing for the alienation thereof, and adding a section legalizing conveyance made by married women under twenty-one years:

Mr. BLYTHE (the House still under a suspession of the special order) introduced a bill (No. 138) declaratory of the meaning of the first section of the act describing who may make a will, the effect thereof; what may be devised, regulating their revocation; admission to probate and contest thereof, approved May 31, 1852, and to legalize all wills made by married women in pursuance of said act since the taking effect thereof:
Which bills were severally passed the first reading.
Mr. STILES and Mr. DAVIS desiring to introduce bills, the House refused further to suspend the special order.

div.head: THE LIQUOR TRAFFIC.
div.p: Mr. MANSFIELD, from the Select Committee on Temperance, returned his bill (29) to license, regulate and restrain the sale of spiritous, vinous, malt and intoxicating liquors, to punish drunkenness, prohibit the adulteration of liquors, &c., with an amendment by way of substitute, which was read, the report concurred and the amendment adopted.

On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, the bill amended was referred to the Committee of the Whole ; and thereupon the House resolved into Committee of the Whole - Mr. Edwards in the Chair - and the Chairman announced the consideration of the various temperance bills which had been referred to this committee.
Mr. DAVIS moved to report Mr. Mansfield's bill as amended and recommended its passage.
The CHAIRMAN then directed the reading of Mr. Harney's resolution of last week, making the order for the present consideration of "all bills on the subject of temperance before the House."
Mr. HUNTER proposed to amend Mr. Mansfield's amended bill, by substituting his bill (H R. 81) to prevent the retailing of intoxicating or malt liquors, &c.

Mr. MANSFIELD. The object of the amendment seemed to be to avoid giving license. An injudicious law might extend the evils we wish to suppress. The habit of strong drink was commensurate with history. Legislation could not abate it any more than it could change the nature of man. He distinguished between the moral and civil law; and considered the reasons for a licence law - a law, which he favored. The principal thing was to guard the rising generation against tippling. The increase of intemperance was attributable to an increase of population. There were other sources of danger under this head - he referred to opium eating.
Mr. COLLIER. Would the gentleman license opium-eating?
Mr. MANSFIELD. Yes, if it could not be suppressed otherwise.

Mr. HUNTER could never consent to license an evil. He believed efficient checks could be thrown around the liquor traffic. He admitted, however, under the decisions of the Supreme Court, and the present Constitution, that this might be nearly impossible. He then described his bill - providing that the liquor shall not be drank on the premises. First, this made the evil to rest with the drinker and his family - and his wife would interpose a most wholesome restraint. It also makes the public appearance of an intoxicated man a misdemeanor. There was never a well behaved drunkard, nor a decent, well kept grocery. His bill proceeded on the admission that liquor was a benefit. The fourth section of the bill provides that where two or more persons shall file an affidavit that such a person is in the habit of drinking to excess and it jury, and serve notice thereof upon the trafficker - any trafficker selling to such person - the intoxicated person shall be a witness against his drencher, and the prosecuting attorney shall proceed against the liquor seller in such a case. These provisions, he considered, would effectually dry up the abuse of intoxicating liquors; and he showed that his bill was otherwise free from objection.

Mr. AUSTIN sustained the amendment of Mr. Hunter. It had been decided by the Supreme Court that this traffic is a legitimate business.
But it was conceded that we had the right to restrain the unlawful use of intoxicating liquors to say it shall not be used to destroy the happiness of society, it had been abundantly demonstrated, that intemperance induced lunacy; and then we were called upon to expend the public money to erect and maintain asylums to treat the lunacy and wretchedness thus induced. This was certainly a very unwise line of policy for a State to pursue. This traffic had cursed the fairest prospects of his own early life, in its mournful effects on the character of his own father. This bill would close up all its dens of iniquity, and be asked for its passage as a protection for his , own children. The bill was not all he could desire, but perhaps the best he could get.

Mr. GIFFORD could say that he was as anxious for the remedy of this evil as the gentleman from Wayne. But what was the remedy? Even the Temperance men in State Convention here a few days ago, could not agree on the remedy. He lived "in a town where the restriction against the manufacture and sale of alcoholic liquors was a condition in every conveyance of a town lot, and even that was a failure. It as the intemperate use of intoxicating drinks that we should combat. But this (Hunter) bill proposed to go back and make it popular to take your gin home and drink with your friends - the very thing which had been years ago successfully combatted by the temperance movement. He was disposed to favor the committee's bill - prescribing notice of twenty days before application for license, so that objection may be made, and it will thus become the interest of all the neighborhood, in this way, to provide against disorderly houses. He gave examples of ineffectual attempts to avoid a license law, which had fallen under his immediate observation.

Mr. MURRAY considered the merits of these two bills. Coming here, he had made up his mind, that under the ruling of the Supreme Court, a license law was the best; but since that, he had come to the conclusion that a better system was practicable. He thought Hunter's bill the best of these two. He had investigated them both in committee. But still, a license law was better than no law at all. He should vote for the most stringent temperance law he could get. The principles of the prohibitory law of 1855 were odious - in advance of the public sentiment. It destroyed what some regarded the rights of property." We were acting now with the advantage of experience. The committee's bill was the best license law he ever saw. But he would amend, fixing the lowest license at $40. Both bills aimed at the same thing - the suppression of the use of intoxicating drinks - the suppression of doggeries - objects which would be sustained by the people of the State of Indiana. The reason of his first determination was, that he understood the Supreme Court would not sustain any other than a license law. But he had been since informed that the Court would sustain the Hunter bill to break down the doggeries. That bill left the traffic open. But the liquor shall not be drank on the premises where sold, because that makes the business a nuisance. That bill also punishes the drunkard, which accorded with his temperance principles. It also enabled wives or next friends to serve process, and prohibit sales to their drinking husbands; and many of these provisions he was glad to find, were in the bill of the Temperance Committee - the select committee of nine on this subject. The only difference between them was, that Hunter's avoids the principle of license makes the traffic a nuisance. It was the moral aspect of the license question that was to be dreaded, &c.
Mr. THOMPSON, of Madison, made an ineffectual motion that the committee rise, and have leave to set again next Tuesday week.
Mr. MURRAY made an ineffectual motion to recommend the Hunter bill.
On motion by Mr. Speaker GORDON, the bill was considered by sections.
Mr. GRIFFIN proposed to amend the first section by striking out "one gallon," and inserting "one barrel," which was rejected.
Mr. USREY proposed to strike out "one gallon" and insert "one quart," which was also rejected.
Mr. AUSTIN proposed ineffectually to strike out the word "white" from the second section.
Mr. RITTER proposed ineffectually to strike out the words "of good character" from the third section.

Mr. MURRAY proposed ineffectually to add to section 3, these words: "and the bond shall be a lein on the real and personal property of every signer of the same, from the moment the same is filed with the auditor of the county, and the obligors shall prove by affidavit that they are possessed of sufficient property to secure the payment of said bond.
Mr. TURPIE proposed to strikeout the words "this privilege," and insert in lieu thereof the words, "said license," which was agreed to.
Mr. SCOTT proposed ineffectually to make the range from $1,000 to $5,000.
So the third section was agreed to.
Mr. POWER proposed to amend the 4th sec. so that the minimum of license shall be $50 instead of $20.
Mr. MURRAY proposed to make it $100.

Mr. THOMPSON, of Elkhart. Why now should license shirk this responsibility ? Look at the profits made in this traffic. He would like to see an adequate license. One hundred dollars was not too much. He would rather say $500. The profits on a single barrel of whisky would pay a license of $20. Why then throw this responsibility upon the County Commissioners?

Mr. POWER agreed with the gentleman from Elkhart, and spoke at length against the moral incongruity of a license law. He was at a loss which bill to vote for. He could not go with Mr. Murray for punishing the unfortunate inebriate.
Mr. HALL, of Rush, deprecated haste, and moved ineffectually that the committee rise.
Mr. HAMILTON,of Boone, submitted a statement of figures to show the profits on a barrel of whisky at retail, by way of argument, for the highest minimum rate of license.
Mr. AUSTIN. Would not the ruling of the Supreme Court allow the trafficker to fall back upon his right to sell, notwithstanding this proposed restraint?
Mr. Speaker GORDON (in his seat.) Certainly not.
Mr. Murray's amendment was rejected, and Mr. Powers' was adopted.

Mr. MELLETT proposed to extend the maximum rate of license in the 4th section, from "$500" to "$1,000." He offered this as a compromise, and it gave to the County Commissioners a discretion not likely to be abused.

Mr. DAVIS doubted the propriety of the amendment already adopted to this resolution. There should be a latitude given - to accommo date the views and interests of large towns and the townships. But then you can not execute the law unless you bring the dealer under its operation. He had no fear about fixing the amount, but it was impracticable. The high figure of the gentleman from Henry, would render the law inoperative wherever it was attempted to be enforced.

Mr. Speaker GORDON. The Commissioners of the County would not fix the license at the maximum without good reason. He was in favor of allowing the people everywhere to fix their own institution in their own way. The argument of the gentleman was certainly as strong against him as for him.
Mr. DAVIS. Would the gentleman from Henry support the bill with his amendment.
Mr. MELLETT answered affirmatively. Then in his county they would be able to prohibit the traffic, and it would be as good a law as that of 1855.
The amendment was agreed to, and the Committee so recommended the adoption of section four.

Mr. Speaker GORDON proposed to amend section 7, by adding to the Sunday prohibition, clause, these words: "Nor upon the day of any State, county, township or municipal election in the town or city where the same shall be held," which was adopted.

Mr, LAWHEAD proposed to add to the 8th section, these words: "Every person who shall, by himself or agent, directly or indirectly, knowingly sell, barter or give away any intoxicating liquor to any person in the habit of being intoxicated, shall forfeit and pay a fine of not less than $5, nor more than $50."
Mr. MANSFIELD had considered that amendment and found it impracticable. How could the dealer know whether a man was in the habit of intoxication?
Mr. LAWHEAD. The liquor dealer knows frequenters of his house well enough to decide whether he is in the habit of being intoxicated or not.
The amendment was adopted.

Mr. GREGORY proposed to amend the 9th section by adding to the prohibition against sell ing less than a gallon, these words: "Shall be fined in any sum not less than $25, nor more than $100," which was adopted.
Under Mr. MURRAY'S motion to reconsider this vote -
Mr. STANFIELD regarded it as unjust and oppressive to exact so high a penalty for so small an offense.

Mr. Harney, Mr. Mellett and Mr. Stiles con curred with Mr. Stanfield. Five dollars was enough for selling a glass of liquor without license. It were better the execution of the law should be certain, than too severe.
The vote was reconsidered, and then the amendment was rejected.
Mr. GREGORY proposed to amend the provision against selling to minors, by fixing the penalty between $50 and $300, which was rejected.
Mr. Speaker GORDON made an ineffectual motion to strikeout that part of the 13th section, which gives the Circuit Court jurisdiction of these misdemeanors.

Mr. DOUGHERTY proposed to add to the 14th section these words: "Nothing contained in this act shall be so construed as to prohibit the sale, in any quantity, by the manufacturer of wines and cider, manufactured from fruits grown by the manufacturer in this State," which was adopted; and so the 14th section was recommended to the House.
Mr. SCOTT proposed an additional section to the following effect, which was agreed to:

Sec. 16. It shall be the duty of the District Attorney, being informed of the violation of any of the provisions of this act, immediately to prosecute the person against whom complaint is made and upon his failure to do so, any other attorney at law, or citizen, may prosecute the same to a final decision.
Mr. MELLETT proposed an additional section declaring that an emergency exists, and that this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its publication, which was also adopted.

On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the committee now arose, and the Chairman reported the bill as amended, recommending the adoption of the amendments, the passage of the bill, and that the committee be discharged from i s further consideration.
The report was concurred in, and the bill was ordered to be engrossed.
The House then, at 5:45 o'clock, adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE
div.p: The Lieutenant Governor being kept from his place in the Senate by severe sickness, the Senator from Jefferson (Mr. Cravens) took the Presidents' chair, and called the Senate to order. The journal of yesterday was then read.

div.head: ELECTION OF PRESIDENT PRO TEM.
div.p: Mr. WAGNER called up the question whether the President pro tem, elected at the commencement of the regular session, was authorized take the chair on every occasion during the session when the Lieutenant Governor would be absent. His opinion was that such is the case.
Mr. JOHNSTON coincided with the opinion expressed by the Senator.
Mr. HEFFREN, Mr. SLACK, and Mr. CRAVENS (in the Chair) thought differently.
Mr. HEFFREN offered the following:
Resolved,That, at 11 o'clock this forenoon, the Senate will elect a President pro tempore, to act as such whenever the Lieutenant Governor may be absent.

Mr. GOODING was of opinion that there was no necessity for the resolution. He understood that the President pro tem. elected at the begin
ning of the session should act as such whenever the President of the Senate is absent.
Mr. WALLACE thought there must necessarily be an election every time the Lieutenant Governor is absent.

Mr. STEELE stated, that in the session of 1842-43 the Lieutenant Governor was here only a part of the session, and a President pro tempore served during the whole time of the absence of the President proper.
Mr JONES, in order to settle this question, moved to strike out the words "11 o'clock," and insert the word "forthwith."
The motion was agreed to.
Mr. SLACK moved to further amend, by striking out all that part of the resolution which relates to the pro tempore officer presiding from time to time.
Mr. HEFFREN accepted the amendment.
The resolution, as amended, was then adopted.
Mr. WEIR nominated Hon. John R. Cravens, the Senator from Jefferson.
Mr. GOODING nominated the Hon. Lewis Wallace, the Senator from Montgomery.
Mr. HEFFREN nominated the Hon. Win. C. Tarkington, the Senator from Brown.
The names of Senators were called for their viva voce votes with the following result:

For Mr. Cravens - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson, Bennett, Blair, Bobbs, Brown, Conner, Cooper, Craven, Green, Hamilton, Hendry, Hill, Johnston, Jones, Kinley, March, Murray, Rice, Steele, Stevens. Thompson, Turner, Wagner, and Weir - 25.
For Mr. Wallace - Messrs. Cobb, Conley, Gooding, Line,Odell, Robinson, and Wilson - 7.
For Mr. Tarkington - Messrs. Carnahan, Hargrove, Heffren, Jennings, Lomax, McClure, O'Brien, Slack, and Williams - 9.
For Mr. Hamilton - Messrs. McLean and Tarkington - 2
For Mr. SlackMr. Studabaker - 1.
For Mr. Gooding - Mr. Wallace - 1.
Mr. Cravens having received a majority of all votes cast, was declared duly elected to serve during the temporary absence of the Lieutenant Governor.

[A message from the House announced the passage by that body of an act supplemental to an act entitled an act prescribing who may make a will, what shall be devised, and regulating contests thereof, approved May 21, 1852.]

div.head: SHINPLASTERS.
div.p: Mr. WALLACE, out of courtesy, and for the accomodation of the Senator from Laporte, [Mr. Weir] who was absent on yesterday at the time of the passage of the bill (H. R. 12) to present the issue of unauthorized paper currency, made a motion to reconsider the vote by which the said bill was passed.
Mr. HEFFREN made an ineffectual motion lay the motion to reconsider on the table yeas-21, nays 25.
The motion to reconsider was then agreed to bv yeas 25, nays 22.
The question being shall the bill pass? -

Mr. WEIR moved to recommit the bill to the Committee on Banks, with instructions to amend the bill so as to prevent the issuing hereafter by others of any such currency, under severe penalties, and provide by further amendments for the gradual and ultimate redemption of what is now in circulation. Also add a section to compel the redemption of what has been issued heretofore, under the same penalties as for that which is hereafter issued.
Mr. HENDRY regarded the passage of this law as a disgrace to the laws of the State of Indiana.
On motion by Mr. KINLEY, the motion to recommit with instructions was laid on the table.

Mr. HENDRY moved to recommit to the Judiciary Committee, with instructions to strikeout all that part of the bill in regard to the drawee, and all that which makes the circulation of notes prima facie evidence of guilt; also to inquire whether the Legislature has power to make the issuing of unauthorized paper currency a crime now, when it was not a crime at the time of issuing the same.
On motion by Mr. HAMILTON, this motion to recommit was laid on the table - yeas 30, nays 17.
Mr. LINE demanded the previous question, and there being a second, the main question was ordered, and under its operation the bill was finally passed the Senate by yeas 41, nays 4, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson, Bennett, Blair, Bobbs. Brown, Carnahan. Cobb, Conley, Conner, Cooper, Cravens, Hamilton, Hargrove, Heffren, Hendry, Hill, Jennings, Johnston, Jones, Kinley, Line, Lomax, McClure, McLain, March, Murray, O'Brien, Odell, Rice, Robinson, Shoemaker, Slack, Steele, Stevens, Tarkington, Turner, Wagner, Wallace, Williams and Wilson - 41.
NAYS - Messrs. Craven, Green, Thompson and Weir - 4.
Mr. Studabaker refused to vote.

Mr. ANTHONY, when his name was called, said: I must be permitted to say there are some things in this bill to which I seriously object; but as there seems to be a determination of the majority to take this bill in this way, I shall vote for it.
Mr. HENDRY, when his name was called, said: Mr. President: I shall vote "aye," under protest.

Mr. STUDABAKER, when his name was called said: While I am in favor of the object of the bill, I am opposed to some details of it - one in particular I deem unconstitutional. I should like to vote for the bill, yet I can not feel willing to do so on the ground of the objections that occur to me to be in the bill. For that reason I shall refuse to vote on the question.
Mr. WALLACE, when his name was called, said: I vote "aye," with infinite and inexpressible disgust.

Mr. WEIR, when his name was called, said: I approve of the general features of the bill, and believe that the people should be protected against such issues in future, but I am opposed to the detail of the bill, believing that it will result in large losses to the people, by what is now in circulation, there being no mode provided by which the circulation now out will be redeemed, I therefore, vote "no."
The title of the bill was then read and adopted.

div.head: CANAL AROUND THE FALLS OF THE OHIO.
div.p:
On motion by Mr. McCLURE, the special order, being Mr. Bobbs' bill (S. 25) for the redemption of bonds, stocks, &c., was informally passed over, and the joint resolution (H. R. 13) with relation to constructing a canal around the falls of
the Ohio, was read and passed the Senate by yeas 45, nays 0

div.head: BANK OF THE STATE OF INDIANA.
div.p: Mr. CONLEY, by leave, returned from a select committee his bill (S. 42) to repeal an act establishing a bank and branches, passed March 3, 1855, the Governor's objection to the contrary notwithstanding, and setting forth that the act was procured by fraud; recommending passage with an amendment in the shape of a preamble, as follows:

WHEREAS, It clearly appears from the evidence taken before the investigating committee appointed by the Senate, at the session of the General Assembly in 1857, and reported at the late extra session, that the passage of the above entitled act, and the original subscriptions of stock in the pretended organization under said act. were procured by the fraud of the subscribers and their confederates;

AND WHEREAS, It clearly appears that the precedent conditions by said act required to be performed in the organization of a bank with branches, have never been complied with; and, WHEREAS, The persons now claiming the franchises of said act were either parties or privies to all the fraud therein alleged, or had actual or presumptive notice thereof, and after non-performance of said precedent conditions, at the time they severally acquired the pretended rights; and, WHEREAS, Said franchises have never rested in any person or persons, whatsoever, and the existing organization called the Bank of the State of Indiana, is a usurpation acting without authority-of laws:

The other amendments proposed by the committtee constitute the present Directors, Receivers and Trustees a Board for winding up within three years, the business of the Bank, giving the Circuit Court power to enforce the trust, and to appoint other trustees on the failure of the directors to act as such.
Mr. WAGNER submitted a minority report, which recommended the indefinite postponement of the bill.
Senators Conley, Heffren and March desired that this subject should be made the special order for some day certain.

Mr. McLEAN apprehended that every speech to be made on this subject would be for effect outside of the Senate Chamber; and as he thought they would not change the views and sentiments of a single Senator upon this floor, he was willing that gentlemen should hand to the Reporter the speeches which they desire to deliver, let them be reported as delivered and thus save the Senate from a vast amount of infliction.
Senators Tarkington, Gooding and Bennett expressed themselves as in favor of making the subject the special order for some day next week.
On motion by Mr. WAGNER it was made the special order for Thursday next at 10 o'clock.

Mr. SLACK, by leave, returned from a select committee his bill (S. 84) fixing the times of holding Courts of Common Pleas in the counties of Huntington and Wells, with an entire substitute therefor, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in.
On Mr. SLACK'S motion the bill was considered as engrossed, read the third time and finally passed the Senateyeas 42, nays 0.
The PRESIDENT pro tem, laid before the Senate, the 15thAnnual Report of the Trustees and Superintendent of the Indiana Institute for Educating the Deaf and Dumb, which laid on the table.

The PRESIDENT pro tem, also laid the Senate a report from the Secretary of the Senate, setting forth how many steel pens, lead pencils, inkstands, sheets of paper and quills each Senator procured from the stationary room during the extra session of last November and December: which the Secretary proceeded to read in detail.

Mr. WAGNER [interupting the reading of the report] said he took this matter to be childish, a contemptible piece of business, and a perfect outrage. [Cries of "read on," "read on."] If gentlemen insisted on the reading of the report he would not sit by and hear it. He moved that the further reading of the report be dispensed with.
Mr. TARKINGTON was in favor of the motion. He thought the report should not be permitted to appear upon the journal of the Senate.
The motion was rejected.
Mr. HAMILTON offered the following:
Resolved, That there be no more stationery furnished Senators, but that each member pay for his own stationery.
A SENATOR suggested the propriety of post-poning the resolution for a day or two, until Senators could supply themselves from the stationery room. [Laughter.]
Objection being made the resolution was ruled out of order.
And then the Senate took a recess till 2 o'clock.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: On motion by Mr. WEIR, the pen, pencil and paper report, pending at the time of taking the recess, was referred to the Finance Committee.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. MARCH, from the Judiciary Committee, returned Mr. Hargrove's bill (S. 50) to amend section 16 of an act concerning the partition of lands, approved May 20, 1852, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill ordered to be engrossed.

Mr. McLEAN, from the same committee, returned his bill (S. 68) to amend section 9 of an act to provide for the election ot Clerks of the Circuit Courts, approved June 7, 1852, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill ordered to be engrossed.

Mr. GOODING, from the same committee, returned Mr. Jones' bill (S. 64) to render public officers competent to testify as witnesses incases brought on their relation to the State, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in, and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. MURRAY, from the same committee, returned Mr. Wagner's bill (S. 105) prescribing the forms to be used in criminal cases, reeommending indefinite postponement.
The report was concurred in.

Mr. CONNER., from the same committee, returned his bill (S. 55) to amend section 315 of
the law reform act, (making the publication 30 instead of 60 days) approved June 18, 1852, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill orded to be engrossed.
Mr. HENDRY, from the same committee, returned Mr. McClure's bill (S. 77) to amend sec. 18 of an act concerning real property and the alienation thereof, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill ordered to be engrossed.

Mr. HEFFREN, from the same committee returned his bill (S. 131) to amend sections 207 and 208 of the law reform act, approved June 18, 1852, so as to authorize the change of venue in certain cases, recommending its passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
On Mr. HEFFREN'S motion the bill was considered as engrossed, read the third time, and finally passed the Senate by yeas 43, nays 0.

div.head: DISPOSITION OF THE SINKING FUND.
div.p: On motion of Mr. BOBBS, the order of business was passed over, and his bill (S. 25) to provide for the redemption or purchase of the bank bonds and Indiana and other State Stock, and United States Stocks (by the money in the Sinking Fund vault) providing for the manner of doing the same, and defining the duty of certain officers in connection therewith, was taken up for consideration.
The question being on concurring in the report of the Committee - being a recommendation for the passage of the bill-
Mr. WAGNER moved that the report be concurred in.
The motion was agreed to.
Mr. HEFFREN moved to amend, by adding the following:

Sec. , That in cases where bonds or stocks are purchased in accordance with the provisions of this act, the State only shall allow such price as is paid for them in the market where purchased, by the duly authorized agent or agents of the State of Indiana.
Mr. WAGNER was in favor of the amendment.
Mr. TARKINGTON moved to further amend by adding "and that the proper officers shall report to each session of the Legislature what State bonds are purchased, and the price paid therefor."
Mr. HEFFREN accepted of the amendment.
Mr. STEELE had no particular objections to the amendments.
Mr. BOBBS proposed in his bill that there be no purchase at all of the bonds or stocks without public advertisement having been first made of the intention so to do.
Mr. WEIR moved to lay the bill, with the pending amendment, on the table.
Mr. BOBBS demanded a division of the question.
The,question being on laying the bill on the table, the motion was lost.
The question recurring on laying the amendment on the table, that motion was lost.
The amendment was then adopted.
Mr. STUDABAKER moved to strike out from the enacting clause and insert an entire substitute providing for distributing the Sinking Fund among the various counties.

Mr. WALLACE moved to amend the amendment by requiring the Sinking Fund Commissioners to give notice that it is the pleasure of the State of Indiana that her outstanding bank bonds shall be presented on or before a day to be specified for their redemption, and the interest shall be stopped on such bonds as are not by that time presented.
The amendment was declared out of order, and withdrawn.
Mr. JOHNSTON expressed himself in opposition to the original bill, but disposed to f vor the substitute proposed by the Senator from Adams, [Mr. Studabaker ]
Mr. LINE was also in favor of the substitute.

Mr. BOBBS spoke in favor of his bill, submitting facts and figures in argument, and claiming that it would be better for the fund itself to invest it in the manner proposed by his bill, than to distribute it in the manner proposed by the substitute.
Mr. STUDABAKER replied, sustaining the provisions of the substitute, and insisting upon its advantages over that of the original bill.

Mr. WALLACE, by leave, from a select committee, returned Mr. Wilson's bill (S. 102) to amend the third section of an act to establish Courts of Common Pleas ; recommending that it be indefinitely postponed, and substituting an entire new plan for a bill.
Mr. TARKINGTON made an ineffectual motion to lay the report on the table.
Mr. CONNER moved to make it the special order for Tuesday morning next at 10 o'clock.
The motion was agreed to.
Mr. TARKINGTON obtained the floorAnd then the Senate adjourned.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: Mr. MURRAY presented the petition of Joel Ellis, for relief, which was referred without reading to the Committee on Claims.
The SPEAKER laid before the House the petition of Andrew P. Jones, of Indianapolis, for damages on account of the construction of the canal, which was referred to the Committee on Claims.

The SPEAKER laid before the House a statement from the Auditor of State, responding to a resolution of the House, adopted on the 26th day of November, 1858, embracing an account of moneys audited to certain Clerks of the Supreme Court; also, a statement by the same officer, responding to a resolution of the House, of the same day, embracing an account of moneys audited to ex-Governor Wright and Governor Willard, which were read and referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.
Messrs. Stinson, Keefer, Hartley, Shields and Lawhead had leave of absence till Monday.

div.head: NEW PROPOSITIONS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. DAVIS, the previous order of business was suspended for the purpose of the introduction of bills, which were passed the first reading, as follows:

By Mr. DAVIS: (139) to amend the 9th sec
tion of the 5th article of chapter first, part third of the Revised Statutes of 1852(with reference to bailable offenses.)

By Mr. PARKS: (140) to amend part of section 2, and to amend section 4 of an act to repeal all laws in force for the incorporation of cities, and to provide for the incorporation of cities, prescribing their powers, and the manner in which they shall exercise the same, approved March 9, 1852, and repeal conflicting laws(require 500 inhabitants for an incorporated city.)
By Mr. EDWARDS: (141) to authorize the formation of limited partnersnip?, fixing the liabilities of the several partners, &c.

By Mr. DAVIS: (142) to authorize the Boards of Commissioners of the several counties to make such allowance out of the county treasuries of their respective counties, as will indemnify the owners of property for losses sustained by the taking, conveying or the destruction of such property by any officer, by virtue of the provisions of the act entitled an act to prohibit the manufacture and sale of intoxicating liquors,and to repeal former laws on this subject, approved February 18, 1855, and in cases where such property may have been used or carried away by such officers.

By Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone: (143) to legalize the appraisement and assessment of property for taxation in the cities of this State, incorporated under the act of March 9, 1857, and an act providing for the incorporation of cities, prescribing their duties, rights, &c.(shall be as valid as if made out before the first Mondays in May and August.)

By Mr. SNYDER: (144) to authorize railroad companies to use bonds, to fix the rate of interest thereon, and to authorize sale and conveyance of railroads and their franchises; and to vest the title thereto in the purchaser or purchasers; to provide for a new Board of Directors; to authorize railroad companies to consolidate their stock, to assume a new name, &c.
By Mr. SMITH, of Perry: (145) to provide additional security to the bondholders, and to the people of the State, in issuing certificates of stock for the original Bank of the State.
By Mr. BLYTHE: (146) to amend 22d section of the act for the incorporation of Insurance Companies defining their powers and prescribing their duties, approved June 17, 1852

By Mr. MANSFIELD: (147) to authorize the Board of Directors or any incorporated company to reduce the amount of their capital stock to the nominal value ,of shares thereof, and to issue certificates of stock therefor.
By Mr. BLACK: (148) to amend sections 18 and 19 of the act prescribing the powers and duties of Justices of the Peace, approved May 29, 1852.
By Mr. BLACK: (149) to amend the act concerning the partition of land, approved May 20, 1852the 11th and 18th sections thereof.

By Mr. STANFIELD: (150) to amend the practice act of June 18, 1852 - requiring answers to be drawn before a judgment or default against a non resident shall he set aside; authorizing property taken on execution to be held in certain cases; judges in vacation to appoint receivers; providing for the faithful discharge of their duties; to modify or reinstate orders of injunction granted in vacation; provisions in relation to the continuance of causes, and the sale of property on the foreclosure of mortgage.

Sherman, Davis, Mellett, Harney and Branham.
Mr. MURRAY, by consent, submitted a joint resolution, on the subject of the Wabash and Erie Canal.

Mr. BLYTHE. This was a very important subject. He apprehended that some of us at least, are not prepared to take definite action in regard to it at this time. He was informed by the papers and othewise, that there are now being held along the line of that canal, sundry public meetings upon the subject, and he preferred to await the expression of public sentiment. He was unwilling now to do anything which might be construed as estopping the General Assembly from future action in this matter. He desired to move to lay the resolution upon the table, because he regarded it as premature.

Mr. MURRAY. The resolution, he believed, embodied the opinion of nine-tenths of the people of the State. It was adopted by a meeting of citizens residing on the line of the Canal. That opinion had been heretofore expressed by
both political parties in terms that could not be misunderstood; and he desired now, in obedience to the wish of his people, to give that expression herethat we are opposed to taking back the Canal and standing responsible again for that Canal debt.

Mr. BLYTHE was just as determinedly hostile to taking back the Canal and reassuming those bonds as the gentleman. He was in no wise favorable to that course. But should we say now, we will not! The act of taking back was not all. He had heard of an accommodation - a mode of adjustment of the difficulty. If there was a necessity for it, he might be willing to vote for the resolution at the proper time; but not under a threat of the trustees, &c. It was manifestly the part of prudence to delay this action to wait for expressions of the views and opinions of the people at other points along that Canal Lafayette, Terre Haute, Evansville - the latter point being most interested, and having done most for that work. There had been a public meeting on this matter in Evansville, and a committee of consider ite men had been appointed to report upon it at another meeting, to be held next Tuesday.
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, concurred with Mr. Blythe. Masterly inactivity was our policy now in this matter.

Mr. EDWARDS also coincided with Mr. Blythe. He had heretofore introduced a resolution against the State taking back this Canal, and he should not change this declaration. But there were questions in connection with this interest which demanded deliberation, and he should vote to lay the resolution on the table.
Mr. DAVIS. Though these bond-holders have no claims on the State, yet he thought it best to delay, but would rather not vote to lay on the table. He would prefer a reference to a select committee.
Mr. DOUGHERTY. To lay on the table might place members in an equivocal position. He moved to postpone till the second Friday in February.
Mr. DAVIS would prefer to have the resolution in a little different language. He was willing to require the select committee to report it back on a certain day. He wanted to get rid of the preamble.
Mr. CLAYPOOL. His county was deeply interested in this matter. It was the desire of his people that we should not take hasty action. He moved to refer to a select committee of five.
Mr, MURRAY seconded this motion. He was willing - but there were interests in the State outside of this Canal.
Mr. DOUGHERTY'S motion was agreed to, and the resolution was postponed.

Mr. TURPIE submited a resolution, which was adopted, to the effect, that the Committee on Education inquire into the expediency of providing by law, that the voters of each school district shall have the employment of their teachers, and the management of their school houses, instead of leaving these to be controlled by the township trustees.
