By Mr. WATERMAN: a bill (228) to provide for the collection of the surplus revenue fund belonging to the counties of Dekalb, Lake and Wells, on loan in the State Treasury, and for the payment of said fund over to said counties.
By Mr. SNYDER: abill (229) to amend the 76th section of the act defining misdemeanors and prescribing punishment therefore, approved June 14, 1852.

By Mr. MAJOR: a bill (230) to amend section 143 of the assessment act of Jane 21.1852[so as to require the delinquent land tax list to be copied and posted on the court house door, and a copy of the delinquent list of each township in the county to be posted in the most public places in each township, instead of the same being printed three times in a newspaper.]
By Mr. KNOWLTON: a bill (231) prescribing the duties of parties commencing, prosecuting or defending suits or actions in the Circuit Court or in the Court of Common Pleas in this State.

By Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone: a bill (233) to amend the 10th section of the act to establish a Court of Conciliation, prescribing rules for proceeding therein, and the compensation of the judges thereof.
By same: a bill (233) to amend the 3d section of the act providing for the election and prescribing certain of the duties of county surveyors, approved June 17, 1852.
By Mr. WATERMAN: a bill (234) to provide for taking appeals from the decisions of township officers having charge of the Common School Funds, to the countv auditor.

By Mr. USREY: a bill [235] to amend section 6 of the act of May 31, 1852, in relation to county auditors, and adding a section thereto, authorizing county auditors to use the seal of their county in certain cases.

By Mr. SNYDER: abill [236] fixing the times of holding the Court of Common Pleas in the
counties of Warren, Benton, and Jasper, and regulating the terms thereof.
By Mr. MURRAY: a bill [237] to amend the act of May 14. 1852, establishing a Court of Common Please, &c.
By Mr. KEMPF: a bill (248) to authorize the erection of a house of refuge for penitent prostitutes.

By Mr. WATERMAN: a bill (239) requiring jury causes to be tried first in the courts of this State, and requiring the regular pannel to be discharged as soon as the jury causes shall be disposed of, and providing for calling a jury from amongst the by-standers:
By Mr. KNOWLTON: a bill (240) to amend the 13th section of the act providing for the election and qualification of justices of the peace, &c., defining their powers and duties in civil causes.
By Mr. MURRAY: a bill (241) to amend the97th section of the practice act, of June 18,1852:
These bills were severally passed the first reading.

div.head: POSTAGE STAMPS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. KNOWLTON, amended by Mr. COMSTOCK, it was -
Ordered, That the Doorkeeper buy three dollars worth of postage stamps to each member of the House of Representatives, and deliver the same at his desk.

The SPEAKER laid before the House the memorial of the Warren Township Horse-thief Detecting Company, against the repeal ot the law of their organization, which was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, from the select committee thereon, returned his bill (143) to legalize the appraisement of city property under the act of March 9, 1857, recommending passage.
The bill was ordered to be engrossed.

Mr. PROSSER, from the select committee thereon, returned his bill (203) to amend the 103d section of the Assessment Act; [changes the time of settlement from the first Monday in August to the 15th day of October;] recommending passage.
The bill was ordered to be engrossed.
On motion by Mr. HARNEY, the bills numbered 93, 94, 95, 96, reported by the Committee on Ways and Means, were made the special order for Thursday 10 o'clock.
The House, at 4:30 o'clock, adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: Mr. McLEAN said that he had received through the Post office a pamphlet, entitled "Prophecy Explained" directed to the Chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the State of Indiana He moved its reference to the Judiciary Committee without reading.
The PRESIDENT pro tempore entertained the motion, and it was so referred.

div.head: THE CALENDAR.
div.p: Mr. HEFFREN moved to dispense with the regular order of business and take up the orders of the day - being bills on their third reading.
The motion was agreed to.
Mr. Turner's bill (13) to amend the swamp land act approved May 29, 1852, [taking the power to appoint Swamp Land Commissioners from the Governor and giving it to the County Commissioners] was read.
Mr. WILLIAMS moved to strike out the emergency clause.
Mr. TURNER objected.

[A message from the Governor announced his approval and signature of Mr. Slack's bill (84) fixing the time of holding Common Pleas Courts in Huntington and Wells; also Mr. Beeson'a bill (144) to extend the time of holding Courts in the 13th Judicial Circuit.]

Mr. MILLER could not see the necessity of the passage of the bill under consideration. It does not change the law as to the management of the swamp land fund or interest. Now if the gentleman from Lake had introduced or will introduce a bill to put the swamp land interest of each county under the entire control of the respective county boards, I am with him. I will heartily vote for any measure that will give the county boards full control over the swamp lands of their respective counties. I would in fact be glad to see the swamp land matter wound up so far as the State is concerned, the State officers making immediate settlements with the swamp land officers of the several counties, and setting to the credit of the State its dues for expenses as provided by law, then transferring the control of the balance to the counties where it properly belongs. But why make this alteration, so long as the State remains a trustee for the safe keeping, and the State officers the financial agents for receiving and paying out all swamp land funds.

Mr. TURNER stated that frauds had been perpetrated under the appointing power of the Governor, which were a burning shame to the State, and he knew the Governor was known to the facts - it could not be otherwise.
Mr. ANTHONY and Mr. GOODING expressed themselves in favor of the passage of the bill.
Mr. CONNER said if the appointing power was to be used by the Governor to subserve private purposes - for the benefit of relatives - he was prepared to vote for a change of this appointing power.
The bill was then finally passed the Senate by yeas 40, nays 8.

Mr. Conner's bill (17) for the partition of real estate - allowing County Commissioners to lay off streets and alleys on lands adjoining towns, where any of the owners thereof may be minors was read and finally passed the Senate - yeas 48, nays 0.
Mr. Bobbs' bill (170) fixing the time of holding Courts of Common Pleas in Marion county, was read.
On motion by Mr. BOBBS, a substitute was adopted; the rules suspended - yeas 45, nays 0 and the bill passed the final reading by yeas 46, nays 0.

div.head: SPECIAL ORDER.
div.p:
The PRESIDENT pro tempore now announced the special order for this hourMr. Bobb's bill (25) providing for the redemption and purchase of Indiana and other State stocks and United States stocks [by the Sinking Fund moneys] the question being on Mr. Studabaker's substitute providing for the distribution of the Sinking Fund
common school purposes among the several counties of the State - excepting so much as may be necessary to pay the back bonds.
Mr. TARKINGTON spoke in favor of the substitute proposed, submitting figures clearly proving to his mind the advantages of the substitute over and above the investment proposed by the original bill.
Mr. HENDRY argued that a distribution of this fund as proposed by the substitute was far preferable to the investments proposed by the original bill.

Mr. MURRAY thought the investments proposed by the bill would be the means of increasing the school fund $1,000,000 within a few years. He thought the proposition was a fair one, and hoped the Senate would give it due consideration. We have got to keep up the Sinking Fund until 1866, or until these bank bonds are paid, and why not make the profitable investments proposed? He was opposed to the dividing up and frittering away of this fund among the several counties of the State, and was in favor of gradually investing this fund in the stocks of the State.
Mr. LOMAX expressed himself in favor of the substitute.

Mr. CRAVENS [Mr. Hendry in the Chair] was anxious, ready and willing to appropriate this fund in the way which would tend the most toward the advancement of the interests of the School Fund of the State. He would like to see the fund distributed, but as that was a proposition in his opinion which could not be entertained at this time, the investments proposed by the bill under consideration would certainly be the most secure. This fund can not be distributed until the last bond due on the subscription by the State to the bank shall have been re deemed, and therefore he could not support the substitute of the Senator from Adams, [Mr. Studabaker.]

Mr. WAGNER said he should vote for the bill of the Senator from Marion [Mr. Bobbs.] He thought the substitute proposed a continually wasting away of the fund, both principal and interest. He did not think the bill went far enough, yet it would answer for the next two years, when he hoped to be able to vote for a better one. He wanted the whole fund sunk in the debt of the State, the State being responsible for the principal and paying the interest. After 1861 he was in favor of putting every dollar that comes into this fund, above what is needed to pay bonds, directly in the treasury of the various counties of the State to be expended for common school purposes.

Mr. TARKINGTON could not see why gentlemen wanted to take this school fund from the Commissioners when it is paying 7 per cent, and invest it in bonds which would pay but 6 percent This Sinking Fund was paying far better under its present management than it would by the bill "under consideration; it is as safe as though it were invested in bonds; and if the substitute to the bill were not adopted, he was in favor of letting the law remain just as it stands.

Mr. ANTHONY thought it would be well to dispose of all Sinking Funds belonging to the State in order to clear the lobby of a set of men who were always there trying to get at these moneys. For this and other reasons which he submitted in a twelve minute speech, he favored the substitute of the Senator from Adams.
On motion by Mr. WAGNER, the Committee on Benevolent Institutions had leave of absence for the remainder of the day.
And then the Senate took a recess till two o'clock.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Mr. HILL, by unanimous consent, offered the following resolution, which was adopted, nemine contradicente:
Resolved,That the Door-keeper be directed to furnish each member and officer with three dollars in postage stamps to enable them to distribute public documents.

div.head: WABASH AND ERIE CANAL
div.p: Mr. LINE, by consent, offered the following preamble and resolution, which were adopted by consent:
WHEREAS, The Federal Government did donate to the State of Indiana, a large lot of land to aid said State in the prosecution of the Wabash and Erie Canal;

AND WHEREAS, The State of Indiana, owing to her financial embarrassment, did convey to her bond holders said Canal, and the lands which had been donated by the Federal Government, yet unsold, as a consideration in full of one-half of her State debt;

AND WHEREAS, It is uncertain to what extent the State of Indiana is involved or may become involved, or liable on account of said abandonment, either to individuals or to the State of Ohio, in case of said abandonment; therefore,

Resolved, That a committee of five be appointed, whose duty it shall be to investigate the whole affair as connected with the transfer of said Canal, and report the extent (if any) to which Indiana is liable, either to individuals as lessees of water power, or to the State of Ohio, and that they report to the Senate at as early a day as practicable; and be it further

Resolved, That for the purpose of aiding said committee in a full and free investigation of all the facts in the case that they have free access to all the public record of the State touching this matter.

div.head: DISPOSITION OF THE SINKING FUND
div.p: The Senate resumed the consideration of the subject pending at the time of the recess.

Mr. STEVENS was in favor of disposing of this fund so that each county may have the management of a share of it. He objected to the original bill because he did not believe the people would be satisfied with it, and that it was a blow against their very best interests. He did not believe the fund could be better secured than by loaning it to the counties of the State and taking mortgages upon real estate at one-half its valuation.

Mr. HEFFREN thought the substitute would be impracticable at this time. He objected to the distribution of this fund until the plighted faith of the State be redeemed by the taking up of our bank bonds. As between the original bill and the substitute, he was in favor of the bill. The best thing we can do is to pass a law for the redemption of these bonds; and after that, let some just disposition be made of this fund. He was in favor of that principle which will most conduce to the interests of the whole people of the State of Indiana.

Mr. COBB thought this fund should be distributed; and he believed it could be so disposed of,
with as much security as it is now managed. Indeed there can not be any loss, if the law is carried out providing that no money shall beloaned on a security of real estate unless it exceeds in value the amount of money loaned, by one half, and that no perishable improvements shall be taken into the account. If this money is vested as provided for in the original bill it can not subserve the interests of the people to such a degree as if disposed of as proposed int he substitute. Under the present law this fund is not equally distributed it seems to be given to those residing near here, to the exclusion of citizens residing at a distance from the capital.
This objection would be overcome by the adoption of the substitute proposed.

Mr. ROBINSON - between the two propositions submitted for the disposition of the Sinking Fund - could not see how Senators could object to he one which proposes the distribution. He was in favor of letting the people of Indiana have the use of this $3,000,000 that belonged to them.
[A message was received from the House announcing the adherence of that body to its amendment to the shinplaster bill (H. R. 12.)

Mr. HEFFREN, by leave, subsequently made a motion, which was agreed to, that a committee of conference be appointed on the part of the Senate, which is made to consist of Senators Heffren, Tarkington and Kinley.]
Mr. BOBBS was heard in a few remarks in reply to arguments urged by Senators in opposition to his bill.
Mr. STUDABAKER was also heard in answer to objections urged against his substitute for the bill.
The further consideration of this subject was informally passed over on account of the absence of several Senators who desired to be present when the vote should be taken.

Mr. WALLACE, by leave, from the Committee on Military Affairs, returned his bill (149) for the organization of the militia of the State, &c., recommending its passage. The report was concurred in, and the bill ordered to be engrossed.

On motion by Mr. WILSON, the bill (H. R. 23) legalizing the acts of a Justice of the Peace of Jackson county, to whom a commission was issued without the affixing of the signature of the Governor, was taken up, read the first, second and third time, and finally passed the Senate by yeas 37, nays 1.
Mr. ANTHONY, by leave, introduced a bill (182) to abolish the Court of Common Pleas, &c.
Mr. ANTHONY explained the provisions of the bill, as follows:

The bill proposes to change the judiciary system by depositing the power now vested in the Circuit Court and Court of Common Pleas, .in the Circuit Court and the clerk of that court, giving the Circuit Court jurisdiction over all manner of litigation, where the amount involved exceeds $100, and concurrent jurisdiction with justices, between $50 and $100.

It gives to the clerk of the court a limited power in the nature f the power vested in the surrogate in the State of New York-giving him power to make settlements with administrators, and to determine and settle claims in favor of and against the estates of deceased persons, requiring administrators, executors &c., to report to him in short, requiring him to settle the mere business transactions in which the intervention of a court is not necessary. Where claims and settlements are disputed by interested parties, it is the duty of the clerk to docket the case, and it goes to the Circuit Court for settlement there. It will, of course, require an increase in the number of circuits; the bill proposes 25, which would make an average of less than 4 counties to each circuit. It increases the salaries of judges to $1,500 per annum, and provides a tax upon litigants by way of a docket fee, to pay the expenses of the court. The object of the bill is to decrease litigation - to remove useless courts, and consequently useless expenses; to provide a salary sufficient to secure competent talent upon the Bench, and thereby secure to the intricate and important matters which often arise in the settlement of estates, as in civil and criminal litigation, a just, uniform and enlightened determination, and will prevent their important interests from being sacrificed to ignorance and dishonesty, as now too frequently the case; to save to the State [a large amount of money] and thus relieve the tax-payer of a part of the onerous burden they are compelled to carry under the present expensive system of administering the affairs of the State.

On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the rules were suspended - yeas 34, nays 4the bill read the first time by title only, instead of being read through by sections. It was also read the second time by title and referred to the Judiciary Committee.
Mr. SLACK, by leave, introduced a bill (183) in relation to the partition of real estate, which was passed the first reading.

On motion by Mr. MILLER, the bill (H. R. 36) fixing the time of holding courts in the 9th Judicial Circuit, was taken up, read the first, second and third time, and finally passed the Senate - yeas 38, nays 0.
Mr. JOHNSTON introduced a bill (184) to amend section 8 of an act in relation to County Treasurers, approved June 4, 1854, which was read the first time.

On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, the bill (H. R. 168) to amend section 1 of an act authorizing road companies to borrow money, and secure the repayment thereof by mortgage, was taken up; the rules suspended - yeas 39, nays 0-the bill read the second time by title and referred to a select committee of three, which is made to consist of Senators Heffren, Murray and Bobbs.

Mr. TARKINGTON introduced a bill (185) providing for the assessment and taxation of banks, brokers, stock jobbers, insurance companies, trust companies, and savings institutions; which was read by title only the first time, under a suspension of the rules - yeas 38, naye 0.
On motion by Mr. TARKINGTON, the bill was read the second time, laid on the table, and 100 copies ordered to be printed.
And then the Senate adjourned.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: Mr. Hancock had leave of absence till Monday.

Mr. MELLETT, from the Committee on Banks, returned Mr. Smith of Perry's bill [188] supplemental to the general banking law of March 3, 1855, providing for additional security, and for the delivery, surrender, exchange or sale of stocks or bonds deposited under said act, recommending passage.
The bill was ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. PARKS, from the Committee on Rights and Privileges, returned petitions for the protection of fish in the lakes - having heretofore reported a bill for that object.
The petitions were laid on the table.

Mr. MASSEY, from a majority of the same committee, returned Mr. Nebeker of Warren's bill (6) to amend the second section of the act of 7th March, 1857, to authorize new counties, and change county boundaries, recommending that it be laid on the table.
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, submitted a minority report, as follows:

Mr. SPEAKER - The undersigned, a member of the Committee on Rights and Privileges of the inhabitants of this State, would respectfully submit to the House of Representatives, his reasons for dissenting from the decision of the majority of said committee in relation to the report just made, on House bill No. 6, entitled "A bill to amend the second section of an act approved March 7, 1857, entitled an Act to authorize the formation of new counties and to change county boundaries."
The Constitution will not permit a county that has an area of over four hundred square miles, to be reduced below that quantity; nor a county with less than that quanty to be further reduced.

There are in the State thirty-nine counties that have an area of over four hundred square miles, then that number of counties can be effected by a reduction, and as all of these counties are surrounded by other counties to which they may be attached territory, it will be seen that all, or nearly all of the counties are interested in this question. We have not been curious enough to hunt out the exceptions, if there are any. We do not deem it proper that the lines of counties should be changed, without giving the interested parties notice by advertisement in a newspaper or otherwise. Yet the law as it now stands does not require notice of any kind. But your statutes sufficiently guard the rights of the people inroads, so as to require twenty days notice, and a petition to the next session of the board of commissioners; the appointment and view, and report to the next board thereafter; if any objection be made by any one, the board are required to appoint reviewers, whoso duty it is to assess damages and report to the next board. Not so with this.

The section of the law proposed to be amended, provides that a majority of the legal voters who shall reside in a territory whose jurisdiction it is proposed to change, may change the same by petition; without consulting the minority of said territory; without giving notice by advertisement; without providing for a view or review of the question, and without providing for the payment of damages. And all of this is to be done too, without giving any means by which the wish of the voters of the county to be effected thereby can be known.

An organized county is a corporation. The legal right to dissolve a corporation by a majority only of the disaffected who desire to go out of the corporation is doubted. We think the consent of a majority of the corporators is imperative. If this principle is wrong, why not extend the provisions of the law to States, and to townships? A county can receive territory that may contain one section of land and five votes, if three of said voters should petition for such change. This question does affect the whole county; to illustrate, take the county of Allen, she has a territory of 672 square miles and can be shorn of 272 square miles, which is over one third of her territory. The majority of the whole county voted a stock of $100,000 for railroad purposes. Now if it is legal, is it for one third of the county of Allen, after aiding by their votes to create this debt, to attach itself to one or more of the six counties that touch her borders, without first securing the consent of the remaining two thirds of the county that would yet remain to constitute the county of Allen, and to pay the whole debt, with only two-thirds of her acres upon which to levy a tax; the other one-third having avoid the liability by being attached to other counties?

By this law the jurisdiction of county officers may be reduced and their rights curtailed, and that may be done by consulting a majority only of the one third of the territory that to-day constitutes a part of the county of Allen, but to-morrow may be taking the first steps toward dissolution, To illustrate: the Recorder's jurisdiction would be reduced to two thirds of its former area. Territories now attached to counties, the area of which is over four hundred square miles, may avoid the taxes assessed for any purpose. For example, say building a court-house, by attaching itself to another county, by its own action, without the consent of the tax payers of the county interested in said assessment.
Therefore, the undersigned would recommend the passage of the bill.
R.M. NEBEKER
The House refused to concur in the report of the majority.
Mr. MURRAY moved to reconsider the vote.

Mr. HARRISON replied to the argument for the bill, submitted in the minority report. The bill proposed to amend the existing law so as to allow the whole county to vote on the question of the motion of the people residing on the excess of territory over 400 square miles to be set off, &c., instead of that portion only which maybe desirous of being so transferred, and which may be legally transferred to another county. He would like to hear more of the reasons tor this amendment of the law, which he believed was a mere question of taxation - of the exercise of arbitrary power. Were not local interests to be subserved by this bill?

Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, argued that a county is a corporation, and denied the right of a portion thereof to act in any matter affecting the whole, without the consent of the majority. If the principle were good in the case of counties, it would be good in the case of States. Would it be proper for Warren county to vote herself into the State of Illinois? The title of the statute of 1857 should have been, "An act for the purpose of getting people by the ears." He gave an example of the case of the County of Allen. Her people had voted $100,000 for railroad stock; and it was now manifestly unjust to allow one-third of her tax payers to attach themselves to another county, or other counties, and so shirk their part of this responsibility.
Mr. DOBBINS had voted against the act of 1857, and still dissented from its principle, which allows the minority thus to relieve themselves from tax responsibilities.
Mr. MURRAY It was manifestly the effect if not the object of the bill of the gentleman from Warren, to prevent the change of county boundaries. He replied to the argument of Mr. Nebeker.
Mr. FIRESTONE was glad of the opportunity to be able to vote with the gentleman from Warren, and he rehearsed the case of the county of Allen.

Mr. CLAYPOOL supported the principle of the bill and gave an example in the history of the desire to change the boundary between Fountain and Warren, to avoid taxation. He had no doubt there would be a change effected ultimately, but he wanted it to be done fairly.

Mr. RYNERSON spoke against the bill, and gave an example of the necessity of the application of the provisions of the present law to the desire of a portion of the people of Morgan county to be attached to Putnam.

Mr. DOUGHERTY. These speeches disclose the working of self interest. The gentleman from Howard desires a slice from Clinton;and the gentleman from Putnam, a portion of Morgan county. He did not like the present but as between that and the bill of Mr .Nebeker, he preferred the law as it is. He gave examples. He had no doubt that a majority of the county of Morgan, on proper application,would let off to Putnam the Eel river portion, &c.
Mr. WHETZEL concurred in the latter sentiment.
Mr. SNYDER thought the bill might infringe the Constitution, and for the purpose of reference, he hoped the vote would be reconsidered.
Mr. PROSSER moved to lay the motion to reconsider on the table, but withheld the motion for -

Mr. HARRISON, who spoke further in reply to Mr. Nebeker, and Mr. Dougherty. He was interested. A portion of the county of Clinton did desire to come into Howard county. But the gentleman from Warren had admitted his interest in the passage of his bills, &c. Democrats desire that States should shape their affairs in their own way, but here they trampled under foot their own principles, as applied to the people of a county. He gave examples sustaining his position and the justice and wisdom of the existing law. The only question involved, was as to the rights of the people within a given territory.
Mr. WHETZEL made an ineffectual demand for the previous question
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, replied to Mr. Harrison, discussing the local question as it affects the people of Fountain and Warren.

Mr. NEWTON. Like the gentleman from Howard, he was personally interested here. He wanted a portion of Clinton county, and the people of Clinton did not want to set off that portion. But a bare majority of the portion proposed to be set off were in favor of it, and every man in the county, outside of that portion, was opposed to it. He was a popular sovereignty man, but was not in favor of setting up every township as an independent sovereignty. He reasoned upon the injustice which would result from this detachment of the best portion of his county. He considered that Mr. Nebeker's bill ought to pass.
The motion to reconsider was then laid on the table, and Mr. Nebeker's bill was ordered to be engrossed.

Mr. PARRETT (by leave) presented the petition of sundry citizens of the counties of Perry and Spencer, for a new county to be formed out of the territory of said counties to be submitted to the voters of said counties at the general election of 1860.

Mr. PARRETT referred to the constitutional provision for the proposed new county, stating that he presented the paper (wholly disinterested) simply recognizing the right of petition; and on his motion it was referred to Messrs. Smith of Perry, Jones, Parrett, Davis and Blythe.

On motion of Mr. BAIRD, (the orders being dispensed with,) the vote concurring in the Judiciary Committee's report to postpone Mr. Prosser's bill No 37, was reconsidered, and the bill referred to Messrs. Baird and others.

div.head: SHINPLASTERS.
div.p: On motion by Mr. STANFIELD, Mr. Martin's bill (12) was taken up, and he explained the amendment he had submitted to the Senate's amendment to said bill, which is to the following effect:
Nothing in this act shall be so construed as to permit any person, corporation, &c., other than the Bank of the State and the Free Banks, to issue or put into circulation any such paper.

It was not the effect of the amendment to clothe the Bank of the State and the Free Banks with authority to circulate this unauthorized paper, &c. That error of construction came probably from the terms of the title of the bill. That construction might be given to the original bill, and his amendment was to counteract that. He hoped the House would adhere, and that a committee of free conference be had. He desired earnestly to stop these rag mills.
The House insisted on the amendment.

div.head: RECOGNIZANCE OF BONDS.
div.p: Mr. BROTHERTON moved a reconsideration of the vote of yesterday, rejecting Mr. Stiles' bill (No. 88) to make recognizances to bind the real estate of the securities as well as the principal, from the date thereof.
Mr. STILES reasoned on the propriety and necessity of the enactment proposed in the bill.

Mr. PARRETT admitted the plausibility of the reasoning, and replied, coming to an adverse conclusion. It would take away the power of giving a recognizance bond from too many persons, and it would fill up the county jails, &c.
Mr. STILES spoke again.
Mr. HALL, of Rush, supported the provisions of the bill.

Mr. PARRETT. The bill might as well go a step further and require the money, to the extent of the bond, to be deposited for the security of its payment. He reasoned at length to show that such a loan would operate oppressively and expensively. It was looking that way and would be a bad law.
Mr. PROSSER was for the bill. The man that violated the law should be punished, and if another stepped in to shield him enable him to avoid the sanction of the lawlet his property pay the forfeit.

Mr. DAVIS would not punish a man before he is tried. This incarceration for want of bail was no part of the punishment. The law presumes
the innocence of the accused. He had seen nothing of the ill-working of the present law of which Mr. Stiles had spoken. He looked at the practical operation of the bill, &c.

Mr. GRIFFIN was in favor of the bill and hoped the motion to reconsider would prevail. Under the present law the surety could convey away his property and avoid the bond after default is made. He gave a case of abuse of this law, which had just come to his knowledge, where property was disposed of before judgment was taken on the bond, &c.

Mr. MURRAY was opposed to the bill, because he would not encourage the common impression that a rich man can over-ride the law and baffle the authority of the courts of justice. It would enlarge the sphere of impunity of the man of property.
Mr. RITTER. It would be more inconvenient for the attorney to go bail for his client, it were made impossible for him to avoid the payment of the forfeited bond.
He thought th property of the bailor should be held from the date of the bond.
Mr. LAWHEAD demanded the previous question, and under its force the House refused to reconsider - yeas 25, nays 62, as follows:

AYES - Messrs. Brotherton, Carr, Clark, Cotton, Devol, Early, Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hall of Rush, Harrison, Jeffries, Miller, Martin, Parks, Prosser, Ritter, Robinson, Row, Rynerson, Shockley, Stanfield, Stiles, Treadway Waterman, Wildman - 25.

NAYS - Messrs. Austin, Baird, Black, Blythe, Boyd, Boxley, Branham, Cavins, Claypool, Clayton, Clements, Colgrove, Collier, Comstock, Davidson, Davis, Dobbins, Dougherty. Durham, Edwards, Fordyce, Gifford, Gregory, Hamilton of Boone, Harney, Hartley, Johnston, Jones, Jordon, Kelley, Kempf, Knowlton, Lawhead, Lewis, McLean, Major, Mansfield, Massey, Merrifield, Murray, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Parrett, Power, Scoit, Shermwn, Shields, Smith of Miami, Smith of Perry, Snyder, Stanley, Sullivan, Tebbs, Thompson of Elkhart, Thompson of Madison, Turpie, Usrey, Wheeler. Whetzel, Whiteman, Wood, Mr. Speaker - 62.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: The bill from the Senate (S. 181) was passed the first reading.
Mr. GRIFFIN, (by leave) from the select committee thereon, returned Mr. Hunter's bill (190) to amend the 11th section of the Common Pleas Act of May 14,1852, recommending passage.
The bill was referred to the Judiciary Committee.
Mr. MURRRY (by leave) submitted the following:

Resolved,By this House, the Senate concurring, that the Door-keeper be and he is hereby authorized to instruct the publishers of the Brevier Legislative Sentinel to retain the copies ordered by this House for binding, as was done for the members thereof at the special session; one copy of which, when bound, shall be furnished to each member, and the balance distributed,one to each Township Library, for the use of the people; and that the members furnish said Door-keeper with the three copies of Brevier Legislative Reports already laid on their desks.
Mr. EARLY proposed to strike out that part of the resolution which assigns the Reports to the County Libraries.
Mr. MURRAY accepted.
Mr. HALL, of Rush. It would be impossible, to furnish the Door-keeper with the number the Reports received. Some of us have sent them off.

Mr. MELLETT wanted to know what additional expense this would induce - and spoke generally against the resolution, as leading to any expense already larger than many members intended, who voted for 500, when it turns out that the order was for 1,100 copies, costing $1,100. He also asserted that it was not a proper book for the township libraries, &c. It was money thrown away to place them there.

Mr. MURRAY'S object in this was to give to the people reliable information of the proceedings of the Legislature, which he acknowledged would be thrown away unless these Reports were preserved and bound. Every newspaper editor should have a copy. They would prove a valuable source of information through the press. He ventured to suggest to the gentleman that if he continued to be observant ot the future politics of the State he would know whether these Reports can be put to use or not. He would venture to say that the gentleman from Henry could not be able to come before the people for office without these Legislative Reports staring him in the face.

Mr. MELLETT. If the gentleman from Elkhart desired ever to come back here, he had better vote to burn these reports, than to preserve them. He [Mr. M.] wanted none of them, beyond the purpose of their daily publication here. He wanted them to become extinct as soon as possible, and he thought gentlemen would agree with him when they found out that the amount to be voted for papers in the appropriation bill would run up to $5,000. He alleged that these reports could not be quoted as authority. They had not been authorized by resolution, and he ventured to say, if they were quoted against the gentleman from Elkhart, he would deny the authority.
Mr, MURRAY, [in his seat ] No sir.
Mr. MELLETT. We have not bound ourselves by any resolution authorizing the reports: and suppose I deny the authority when they are referred to, how will the gentleman help himself?
A VOICE. Go to the Journal.
Mr. MELLETT. Yes, to the Journal. That s a much more readable document.

Mr. EDWARDS, interposing. If the gentleman objects to having the members of the House bound by the Legislative Reports, why is it that he should not be willing to have the Reports bound by the House? [Laughter.]
After further opposition by Mr. Mellett, and propositions to modify the resolution by Mr. Clements, requiring the Door-keeper to keep account of the copies returned to him, &c.

Mr. MURRAY withdrew the resolution, remarking upon the general understanding, that the publishers of the Reports would be subject to the order of individual members with reference to the disposition of their copies.
Mr Blythe'sbill (210) was considered on the second reading and referred to the Committee the Organization of Courts of Justice.

On motion by Mr. DOUGHERTY, (under a dispensation) the bill (S. 49) fixing the time of the Courts in the 5th Judicial Circuit, was considered and passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 70, nay 0.

Mr. PROSSER (under a dispensation) moved to reconsider the vote postponing Mr. Mellett's bill (186) to grant to the prosecuting attorney the closing speech in the argument in criminal causes. In most cases the prosecuting attorney was not able to cope with the opposite counsel.

The vote was reconsidered, and the question recurred on concurrence in the report of the Judiciary Committee, to indefinitely postpone the bill.

Resolved, That the Committee on the Judiciary inquire into the expediency of enacting a law to make penal the sale of any medicine, instrument or pill for the prevention of conception by women or the procurement of abortion; and a so to make penal the publication of any card or label for the prevention of conception or the procurement of abortion, or the publication of any advertisement of the same class with the following. [The resoluion rehearses one of the advertisements of M., the Doctor Duponceau, setting forth the properties of his Golden Pills, and the merits of his private practice.]

div.head: SHINPLASTER BILL.
div.p: A message from the Senate by Mr. Senator Heffren, announced the appointmeet of Messrs'. Heffren, Tarkington and Kinley, a committee of conference on the disagreeing votes between the two Houses upon the House amendment to Mr. Martin's shinplaster bill (12) and requesting the appointment of a similar committee on the part of the House of Representatives.
On the motion of Mr. STANFIELD, the order for this appointment was taken by consent, and the SPEAKER makes said committee on the part of the House, to consist of Messrs. Stanfield, Martin and Blythe.
The bill (S. 102) to amend the 3d sec. of the Common Pleas act, being considered on the second reading -
Mr. MARTIN moved that it be referred to a committee of one from each Congressional District.
Mr. THOMPSON, of Madison, stated that his constituents were dissatisfied with that provision of the bill which would disconnect Madison with Hancock.
Mr. GIFFORD was in favor of Mr. Martin's motion. The bill would not suit his people.

Mr. CLEMENTS proposed to amend the motion to refer, so as to refer to one member from each Judicial Circuit, with instructions to make 22 out of the 44 Common Pleas districts in the State. This would make the Court of Common Pleas respectable - enable competent lawyers to take its Judgeships, and it would save expense.

So the bill was referred to a select committee of one from each Judicial District, viz: Messrs.
Clements, Hamilton, of Boone, and others - not announced.

The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from the Auditor of State, responding to a resolution of the House of the 3d inst., embracing statements of the amounts of money audited in favor of the present Secretary of State and his predecessors; and the amounts audited and paid to all persons on account of selecting swamp lands. The total amount of these last sums paid is $9,052 50.

div.head: SCHOOL TOWNSHIP CORPORATIONS.
div.p: On motion of Mr. STANFIELD, his bill (5) to authorize school townships, &c., was considered on the third reading.

Mr. STANFIELD. By the present law there is no authority for taking titles to school house lots. The titles are generally in the trustees. I think it a matter of public policy that townships should be incorporated, not only as civil townships, but as school townships; that they should be corporate bodies for the purpose of taking titles of school house lots in their corporate name. That would obviate all difficulty about the death of township trustees, who now hold these titles as individuals. That is the principal purpose of the bill. Another purpose is, that, where a school house is not occupied for the public school, it may be occupied for a private school or any public meeting under the township authorities. As the law now is, there can be no legal occupancy of the school houses, but for the common schools.

Mr. DOBBINS suggested a constitutional difficulty. The school houses might be occupied for religious meetings and church purposes. There was a constitutional provision, that no person shall be taxed lor the support of the faith of any religious denomination.
Mr. STANFIELD had that question before him. The provision of the bill was, to authorize the use of the school house for any purpose that a majority of the township shall approve, &c.
The bill was passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 67, nays 11.
The House then, at 4:40, adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.

The PRESIDENT pro tempore laid before the Senate a communication from the Superintedent of the Insane Hospital in reply to a resolution tion of the Senate in relation to the amount of money drawn by the Board of Commissioners of said Institution from the treasury of Wabash county, which was referred to the Committee on Benevolent Institutions.

The PRESIDENT pro temporelaid before the Senate a communication from the Attorney General, in reply to a resolution of the Senate, asking the reasons why a suit in the Floyd Circuit Court in the case of State vs. Newland has been dismissed, stating that he had never been officially informed that any such suit had been commenced or was pending, nor did he know it from any other source, consequently, he did not attend to it, and can not say why it was dismissed
Mr. RICE, from the Finance Committee, returned Mr. Culver's bill (85) providing for ten per cent, interest, recommending indefinite postponement. The report was concurred in.

div.head: HORSE-THIEF DETECTIVES.
div.p: Mr. HILL, from the Committee on Rights and Privileges, to which was referred so much of the Governor's message as relates to an act, approved March 9, 1852, authorizing the formation of companies for the detection and apprehesion
of horse-thieves, reported a bill (187) to repeal that act.
Senator Wagner and Senator Rice expressed themselves as opposed to the repeal of the law referred to.

Mr. BOBBS opposed the repeal of the law authorizing the formation of associations for the detection and apprehension of horse-thieves. He was willing to hear from such Senators as had objections to the law, as to their reasons, and if there be abuses practiced under cover of the law, see if they cannot be provided for. The recommendations of the Governor are entitled to receive the consideration of the Senate, but many of his most respectable constituents are opposed to a repeal of the law, and he was here to represent their wishes. He said there were organizations in his county embracing among their members some of our best citizens, who believe they have been enabled to render great service to the community in the protection of their property, in the manner allowed by this law. Some of those have remonstrated against the repeal, and he did not know any of his constituents who are directly interested in the question, who desire the repeal; he, therefore, was opposed to the repeal, and hoped the Senate would not concur in the recommendation of the committee.

Senators Heffren and McLean were in favor of the repeal, and cited the cruelties, murders and unrelenting inhumanities perpetrated under this act by those regulators in Noble and Brown counties, as unanswerable arguments in favor of concurring in the report of the committee, and of the immediate passage of the bill recommended by it.
Mr. GOODING dissented from the report, holding that the law itself was good, but admitting that it was not properly carried out.

Mr. HAMILTON said the people of the region of Noble county for years were under the influence of the greatest set of rascals the country ever produced; but he did not justify the murder spoken of in that county, as committed by the regulators. He was opposed to the repeal of the law.

Mr. CONLEY was satisfied gross outrages had been committed under the law, but that was no the fault of the law. The perpetrators of the outrage alluded to as having occurred in Monroe county were composed of the rag-tag and bobtail of the country round about. He did not agree to a concurrence in the report of the committee, and expressed the hope that it would not be made a party test. [Laughter.]
Mr. HILL might not vote in favor of the report; he was directed by the committee to make it; had done so, and should not be dissatisfied if the Senate refused to concur.
Mr. TURNER was opposed to the repeal of this law.
Mr. STUDABAKER moved to indefinitely postpone the consideration of the report.
The motion was agreed to - yeas 34, nays 12.
Mr. MURRAY, by consent, offered the following resolution, which, under the rules, lies over one day.
Resolved,That the following additional rules be adapted for the government of the Senate:

RULE.-Any Senator desiring to give an explanation of the reasons for his vote upon any question before the Senate, may do so before the calling of ayes and nays is commenced, and not after, without the unanimous consent of the Senate.
RULE.Every Senator shall be limited in debate to not more than ten minutes at a time, and not more than twice on the same question.

Mr. KINLEY, from the Committee on Rights and Privileges, returned Mr. Garnahan's bill (86) to amend an act regulating marriage, approved March 22, 1852; and Mr. Hill's bill (22) to prevent the inter-marriage of first cousins, &c.; recommending that No. 22 lie on the table, and submitting a substitute for No. 86 providing that all marriages between first cousins or between persons of closer degrees of consanguinity which may hereafter take place in this State, shall be void: and to amend the title so that it shall read "An act to prevent the intermarriage of blood relations."
Mr. CONLEY moved to amend by inserting in the proper place the words "second cousins."
Mr. CARNAHAN was satisfied with the report of the committee.
Mr. GOODING concurred in the spirit of the bill - opposed the marriage of blood relations, but objected to that provision which makes the marriages of cousins void.
Mr. MURRAY moved to lay the amendment on the table.
Mr. WAGNER moved to amend the motion by laying the whole subject on the table.
Mr. BENNETT demanded a division of the question.
The amendment proposed by Mr. Conley was laid on the table by yeas 29, nays 16.
The motion to lay the bill and amendments on the table was rejected - yeas 9, nays 37.
Mr. CONNER was not in favor of the marriage of cousins, but proposed to amend as follows:
Provided, This act shall not affect marriage contracts now existing between cousins and which have not been consummated.
Considerable merriment sprung up upon a conversational debate on this amendment, when -
Mr. CARNAHAN said he was sorry to see sport made of such a grave matter.
Mr. CONNER said his amendment was offered in good faith.
Mr. CARNAHAN did not doubt that, but referred entirely to the mirth made out of it.
Mr. MARCH hoped the amendment would be adopted.
Mr. MURRAY was in favor of the provisions of the bill.
Mr. HEFFREN was opposed to the amendment.
Mr. CARNAHAN moved to lay the amendment on the table.
The motion was agreed to by yeas 25, nays 21, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson, Bennett, Blair, Bobbs, Brown, Carnahan, Conley, Culver, Hamilton, Hargrove, Heffren, Jennings, Jones, Kinley, Line, Lomax, McLean, Murray, O'Brien, Odell, Shoemaker, Studabaker, Williams and Wilson - 25.
NAYS - essrs. Cobb, Conner, Craven, Fisk, Gooding, Hendry, Hill, Johnston, McClure, March, Miller, Rice, Robinson, Slack, Steele, Stevens, Tarkington, Thompson, Turner, Wagner and Wallace - 21.
Mr. LOMAX proposed to amend by inserting in the proper place the following:
"Provided, This act shall not take effect till after the first of September, 1859."Mr, STEVENS proposed to recommit with the following instructions:

Amend by prohibiting Clerks of Courts from issuing marriage license to first cousins, and attach penalties there for by prohibiting any person from performing marriage ceremonies of parties they know to be first cousins, under penalties, and by subjecting all parties who may apply for or obtain license and marry, who are first cousins, to penalties.
Mr. LINE demanded a division of the question, first upon the proposition to re-commit, and then upon the instructions.

Mr. BOBBS said the principles of the bill are right, and the subject was a proper one for legislation, but he was not satisfied that the bill provided the best mode of preventing the evil. Beside this was not so general as seemed to be assumed by gentlemen. Where intermarriages occurred within the relationship of consanguiuity named by the bill, for successive generations, the evil results were manifest and very serious; but such marriages were not frequent in this State, and its evil results are overrated. In older communities, as in the slave States, or others where wealthy arristocracies existed, and class distinctions in society had become established, intermarriages among related families were more frequent, and entailed misfortune upon offspring. If Senators were governed by the statistics furnished by our asylums they were liable to be misled, as the statistics of other nations did not sustain the position.

The objections which present themselves to me are that the bill proposes to amend the marriage contract, instead of preventing these within certain degrees of consanguinity. All the parties need to do, is to cross the line into some adjacent State, and have the marriage solemnized there. The law would therefore fail to prevent the evil to be provided against. It seems to me the law ought to provide against the consumption of such marriages by opposing obstructions to them. Prohibit any person from solemnizing marriages within this State, and within the relationship of consanguinity proposed; and any clerk from issuing licenses for such purposes, to parties so related. He favored the suggestion of the amendments of the Senator from Decatur, and would prefer to have the bill go to the Committee of the Judiciary, to be modified and perfected in conformity with these suggestions, and therefore move such recommendation.
The report was then referred to the Judiciary Committee.
On motion by Mr. CONNER the instruction were also referred to the same committee.

On motion by Mr. WALLACE the committe were instructed to inquire into the expediency of amending so as to make it a part of the affidavit now required for a license, that the parties ar not cousins within the meaning of the statute.

Mr. McLEAN, from the Committee on Rights and Privileges, returned his bill (16) to amend the first section of a license act, approved June 15, 1852, and for the encouragement of Agriculture, &c., approved March 7, 1857, recommending its passage. The report was concurred in and the bill ordered to be engrossed.

held by him or in trust for him, designating such property that is exempt.
On motion by Mr. WAGNER, the rules being suspended, Senator Carnahan's bill (192) was read the second time by title.
Mr. MURRAY moved to amend the bill so that no person "shall knowingly suffer" the liquor to be drank on his premises.
This amendment was agreed to by yeas 23, 20, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson, Bennett, Blair, Carnahan, Conner, Cooper, Craven, Culver, Gooding, Green, Hargrove, Hendry, Hill, McLean, March, Murray, Rice, Robinson, Stevens, Thompson, Turner and Wagner -2 3.
NAYS - Messrs. Brown, Cobb, Conley, Fisk, Hamilton, Heffren, Jennings, Johnston, Line, Lomax, McClure, Miller, O'Brien, Odell, Shoemaker, Slack, Studabaker, Tarkington, Williams and Wilson - 20.
REFUSING - Mr. Bobbs.
On Mr. MURRAY'S motion the words "for every such offense" was added to the second section.
Mr. GOODING moved to amend the second section so that it will read "in person, or by agent to sell or barter away any spiritous or intoxicating liquors."
The motion was agreed to by yeas 31, nays 13.
Mr. GOODING moved to amend by adding a section providing that this law shall go into effect on the 1st day of May, 1859.
Mr. HEFFREN moved to amend by striking out "May," and inserting "July."
Mr. GOODING accepted.
The amendment was then agreed to - yeas 30, nays -
Mr. SLACK moved to amend by inserting in the proper place "except for medicinal purposes."
On motion by Mr. GREEN, this amendment was laid on the table by yeas 28, nays 16.
Mr. WAGNER moved that the bill be considered as engrossed and read the third time now, and upon this motion he demanded the previous question.
There being a second, under its operation the bill was considered as engrossed - yeas 28, nays 18 - read the third time, and finally passed the Senate by yeas 26, nays 20 - as follows:

YEAS - Mesrs.Beeson, Bennett, Blair, Brown, Carnahan, Conner, Cooper, Craven, Culver, Gooding, Green, Hargrove, Hendry, Hill, Jones, McLean, March, Murray, Rice, Robinson, Steele, Stevens, Tarkington, Thompson, Turner and Wagner - 26.
NAYS - Messrs. Anthony, Cobb, Conley, Fisk, Hamilton Heffren, Jennings, Johnston, Line, Lomax, McClure Miller, O'Brian, Odell, Shoemaker, Slack, Studabaker Wallace, Williams and Wilson - 20.
Mr. Bobbs refused to vote.

Mr. ANTHONY, when his name was called, said there was another bill pending which he believed would do more to promote the cause of temperance than the one before the Senate. He did not believe this one would amount to anything at all.
Mr. BOBBS, in explanation, did not know the wishes of his constituents on the subject, and would reserve his vote.
Mr. CONLEY, explaining, believed a large majority of his constituents was in favor of a license law. He would vote for a stringent license law, but not for this.
Mr. GOODING, in explanation, said he voted for this bill because he believed it was constitutional, and he should vote for all temperance bills that were constitutional.
Mr. HEFFREN, explaining, said he would vote for the bill if it contained a clause requiring all liquors to be pure and unadulterated.
Mr. LINE, explaining, had not read the bill and would not vote for it on that account.

Mr. MILLER, in explanation, said: I shall vote against this bill, and I desire to give some reasons for doing so. I will vote for any good temperance bill, and have been waiting patiently to get a chance to do so. Here, sir, we have been waiting on the Committee on Temperance during the whole of the extra session and over half the present. The bill that passed the House is here, and the bill recently reported by Senate committee, both ready to be taken up. Why, then, introduce a bill here and pass it through the Senate in less than one hour, and that under the gag or previous question? How can we vote understandingly on this bill which in the midst of the confusion could but very indistinctly be heard read, not even having a chance to examine it. I vote "no."
Mr. STUDABAKER, in explanation, said he had not examined the bill and could not vote for it till he had that opportunity.
So the bill passed.
By Mr. MARCH: (195) to enable married women to make a will.
Bv Mr. LINE: (196) to amend section 1 of article 8 of the State Constitutian.

By Mr. ROBINSON: (197) to amend the act establishing the Bank of the State of Indiana, approved March 3, 1855.
