div.head: THE TEMPERANCE BILL.
div.p: Mr. GOODING moved to suspend the regular order of business in order to take up the House temperance bill (29) and vote upon it.
The motion was agreed to - yeas 25, nays 23.

Mr. GOODING demanded the previous question, and, there being a second, the main question was ordered. A constitutional provision demanding the yeas and nays, they were ordered and being taken, resulted - yeas 26, nays 20 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson, Bennett, Carnahan Cobb, Cooper, Cravens, Culver, Gooding, Green, Hamilton, Hendry, Jones, McLean, Murray, Odell, Bice, Robinson, Steele, Stevens, Studabaker, Tarkington, Thompson, Wagner, Williams and Wilson - 26.
NAYS - Messrs. Blair, Brown, Conner, Craven, Fisk, Hargrove, Heffren, Hill, Jennings, Johnston, Kinley, Line, Lomax, McOlure, March, O'Brien, Shoemaker Slack, Turner and Wallace - 20.
Messrs. Bobbs and Miller refused to vote.
Mr. BENNETT makes the following explanation of his vote:

Mr. President - The peculiar position which I occupy as a Senator on this floor, in reference to the temperance question, makes it necessary for me to give an explanation for the vote I shall give on the bill now before the Senate. I represent a district of temperance men. No counties in the State are more anxious for a constitutional and effective temperance law, than Fayette and Union. And as their representative, I should prove recreant to my duty, were I to spire any exertion to secure the passage of such a law. I have said on this floor and elsewhere that I did not think I ever could vote for any law which recognizes the license system. I am utterly opposed to the principle of licensing an acknowledged evil. I have regarded drunkenness a great moral, social and political evil. I believe it the source of crime, and the enemy of all good government. I have believed as a lawyer, that the people through their legislatures, had a right to prevent these evils, by removing the cause thereof. I have never been able to arrive at that high degree of legal knowledge which affects to discover in the organic law of the State a principle which by any possible construction, would restrain this necessary power of the people. My law books teach me that the power of protecting society from evils, by removing the causes thereof, is as old as civilization itself, and never doubted save where whisky is in controversy. The power to protect rights and to prohibit wrongs, is the primary object of law. I have not thus far in my legal researches, been able to discover the nice technical distinctions which some courts and politicians seem to have discovered between the evils which flow from intemperance and those from any other source, the well written opinion of our own Supreme Court to the contrary notwithstanding. I have in all the preliminary votes taken on this question in the Senate, during this and the extra session, voted against the license system. But, sir, I am satified from the many test vote which have bee taken here, and in the other end of the Capitol that no other law can bo passed. I am also satisfied that such a law as my constituents would prefer, would be destroyed by the Supreme Court and at present constituted. I am very anxious to have some law on the subject, and believe that the bill now before the Senate, with the Senate amendments, will, in such counties as I represent have the effect of suppressing the evil. It hagf many provisions which will prove efficient and produce good results, and while it may not kill the "monster," it will do him great bodily harm. As legislators, we must compromise our differences, for the public good. Therefore, protesting against the license system, believing the bill a step in the right direction, and as a dernier resort, I vote "aye."

Mr. BOBBS makes the following explanation to-wit : He expressed himself against the bill for the following reasons. In the first place he was opposed to any license law, out particularly to this one, because it allowed a discrimination between the fashionable saloon, and the less pretentious places of drinking. The County Commissioners may not choose to exercise this power of discrimination, it is true, but if they should not, it is not because this bill does not allow them that privilege. Some Senators, I believe, support this bill expressly on the grounds that, it would allow the Commissioners, by the maximum license permitted, to suppress the sale of ardent spirits in their counties. And in my county, the largest saloons can afford to pay the highest license, if by that, they can shut out all competition in the traffic. Whether they so regard it, I do not pretend to know, but that they would find it to their interest to do so, can hardly be denied. Just in proportion to the amount of be paid for license required by this bill, will the smaller groceries be closed and those remaining lave a larger field for operations. And if the maximum, price of a license should be required, reduces the traffic to a monopoly in the hands of a few who can afford to advance the amount of license. If the sale of intoxicating liquors is to be restricted at all, that restriction should operate alike upon all, and not discriminate in favor of those who can afford to indulge in this luxury, and against those who can not afford this. My constituents are divided in opinion upon the subject of the principle upon which a temperance law should be based, and I am left without any instruction of their wishes upon the present bill. As I believe this bill does not reflect the wishes of a majority of my constituents, I decline to vote for it.
Mr. CULVER makes the following explanation of his vote:

No legislation can come before this body that will be of so much general importance to the people as the subject matter contained in this bill. It will affect for good or ill,directly or in directly, the welfare of every family in this State. The evil that this legislation proposes to remedy has often been the subject of legislation. We have had prohibition, that has been decidedly unconstitutional. Whether that decision was right or wrong, we have not the power, by legislation, to overturn its decrees. As we can not make a prohibitory law, the only practical question is, shall we have a pay license or simply a bond to keep an orderly house, &c. Between these two systems, I am for the former, believing that the ends to be gained will plead a justification ol the means used. I look upon the House bill as imperfect in many of its details. Yet at this late day of the session, unless we take that bill and pass it without loading it down with material amendments, we will get no law upon this subject. I do not like this bill; the latitude given in the amount of the license, and I vote for it without a change, believing that an amendment would be fatal to the bill in the other end of the capitol. This is so regarded by its friends there This kind of legislation, to be beneficial, ought to be kept clear of party. We ought to have a law that can not be charged as the exclusive act of any faction. This can only be done by mutual concession by the different elements that we have upon this floor in regard to this question. I hope that this law, if it passes, may be the means of suppressing intemperance. The few extreme temperance men ought to know, that oppose this bill, that this is the most stringent law that can pass. As a friend of a stringent law, I vote for this - not with my entire approval, but as a compromise.
Mr. HILL makes the following explanation of his vote:

It is, in my opinion, and in the opinion of many of the most intelligent of my constituents, wrong in principle for the State to license men to deal out to our people intoxicating liquors, the effects of which are too well known and felt to need enumeration here. The law, as I understand it, allows any person without license, and without giving bond and security, to sell as much intoxicating liquor as they choose in any quantity not less than one gallon. The law, therefore, in my opinion, will be absolutely worthless in protecting us against the evils of intemperance; and as it involves a principle that I do not wish to sanction, I vote no.
Mr. ODELL makes the following explanation of his vote:

Mr. President - I vote for this bill, not because I approve of all of its provisions, but because there is now no law on that subject; as it is a conceded fact that there will be no law passed this session, unless this bill shall pass, and as I prefer it to no law at all on that subject.
Mr. STEVENS makes the following explanation of his vote:

Mr. President - I shall vote for the bill now on its passage, not that I indorse the principle of license, but for the reason that I am convinced that if it fails, no other can be passed at the present session of the General Assembly. I feel,then, that I am compelled to take this or no law at all, and believing that if the provisions of this act are enforced, and the County Commissioners reflect, in their action, the sentiments of the people on the subject, that in the county I represent, and in more than half the counties in the State it will amount to a prohibitory law. I am aware that the temperance people of the State, are opposed to the license system; so am I, but the question now before me is, shall I vote I for the bill which authorizes license, or against it and have no law at all; in this dilemma I have no hesitancy.
Mr. WAGNER makes the following explanation for his vote:

Mr. President - I wish to say, sir, that this bill is not such a one as I would like; but, sir, my constituents wish some kind of a law, and the question is whether this law is the best one that might be passed. I admit that the principle of a license law is wrong - the State ought not to be a party to such a traffic - but, as under the Constitution, as decided by our courts, we can not prohibit the traffic altogether, we must do the best we can, and believing that if we do not pass a license law we will pass none this session, and believing further that my people desire some kind of a temperance law, I will vote for this bill. But while I do this let me say it is with great reluctance. So the bill passed.

div.head: WABASH AND ERIE CANAL.
div.p: Mr. MARCH, from the Judiciary Committee,returned Mr. Conner's bill (201) on the Wabash and Erie Canal, recommending its passage.
Mr. CARNAHAN moved to concur in the report, with an amendment striking out the 5th section: [releasing the trustees from maintaining bridges across the Canal.]
Mr. MURRAY objected to the amendment.
[A message from the Governor announced his approval and signature of the bill (S, 145) to provide for a more uniform mode of doing township business.]
Mr. McLEAN opposed the amendment. He thought the interests of the State demanded some legislation on the subject.

Mr. STEELE said this bill was the only plan that could be agreed upon by Senators along its line. He would not vote a dollar from the State Treasury, but was willing to release the trustees from keeping up the bridges, and allow them to be kept up by the townships in which they lie. He should vote for the bill.
Mr. HAMILTON feared the adoption of the amendment would be fatal to the Canal. He trusted the bill would pass.

Mr. WALLACE intended to oppose this bill; desired time for further consideration, but proceeded to discuss and explain his objections thereto He regarded this bill as the entering wedge to the taking back of this Canal.
On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the further consideration of the matter was postponed till Monday night at 7 o'clock.
On motion by Mr. STUDABAKER, his bill (23) fixing the time of holding the Courts of Common Pleas in Adams county, was read the third time, and passed the Senate by yeas 43, nays 0.

Mr. RICE, from the Judiciary Committee, re-
turned Mr Cooper's bill (189) recommending that it lie on the table. The report was concurred in.

div.head: BANK OF THE STATE OF INDIANA.
div.p: Mr. STEELE, from the Committee on Banks returned Mr. Odell's bill (122) taxing the Bank of the State of Indiana and its branches, and prohibiting said bank from issuing on deposits recommending its passage.
Mr. MARCH moved to amend by striking out section - and inserting in lieu thereof the following:

The capital stock of said bank, together with the amount of its circulation over and above the amount of its capital stock, ami its real estate and other property shall ba subject to the same rate of taxation for State, county and municipal purposes, as the property of individuals.

Mr. MARCH could not see why this bank should not be taxed for its capital stock and its circulation over and above the amount of capital stock paid in. Unless that bank is so taxed it has a decided advantage over individuals.
Mr. STEELE believed the bank ought to be taxed as individuals or other institutions are taxed.
Mr. MURRAY thought we had a right to make the bank law conform to the general law upon the subject of taxation.
Mr. WALLACE and Mr. TARINGTON each were heard in a few remarks.
[On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, Mr. Stevens' bill 192, was taken irom the table and placed on the file of the Senate.]
The amendment was then adopted - yeas 31, nays 7.
Mr. SLACK moved to strike out the preamble.
[Mr. GOODING obtained leave of absence till Monday, 2 o'clock p. m.]
The motion was adopted - yeas 27, nays 9.
The bill was ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. MURRAY made an ineffectual attempt to refer the bill to a select committee of five.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Mr. STEELE, from the Committee on Banks returned Mr. Hargrove's bill (93), recommending indefinite postponement.
Mr. WILLIAMS moved to reconsider the vote by which Mr. Odell's bill (122) was ordered to be engrossed.
The motion was agreed to.
On motion by Mr. BOBBS, the bill was referred to Messrs. Bobbs, Williams and Steele.

div.head: BANK OF THE STATE OF INDIANA.
div.p: Mr. WAGNER, from the Committee on Banks, returned his bill (187), creating six additional bank districts, recommending its passage[Senators March and Jennings dissenting.]
Mr. HENDRY moved to concur with the following amendment: "insert that the books shall be kept open for thirty days."

Mr. HEFFREN moved to amend the amendment by adding "that the stock shall be divided in proportion to the amount of stock subscribed; and that the books shall be kept open from 9 o'clock to 12 o'clock."
Mr. HENDRY accepted.
The report and amendment were concurred in.
Mr. MARCH moved to amend the 15th section of the charter by adding his amendment to the bill (122) as printed above; and the 9lst section, as follows:

The Legislature may at any time alter or repeal this act, but said bank, or any of its branches, shall not be authorized by any amendment to suspend or refuse the payment of specie, for its notes, bills or obligation, or for a money received on deposite, and the faith of the State is hereby pledged that no such amendment shall ever be made.

SEC. The power given by this act to establish additional branches of said Bank of the State, is made upon the express condition precedent, that said bank accept the amendments to its charter in the manner prescribed in the said 91st section of its original charter.
Mr. MARCH could not consent to extend its branches, unless the bank should be placed under the control of the Legislature.
Mr. HAMILTON said it was not he desire of the bank that, this increase should be made.

Mr. HEFFREN was in favor of taxing this bank the same as individuals are taxed; but thought the amendment was asking more than the bank was willing to concede, and we would consequently get nothing. He was willing to compromise, but was forninst giving the bank any more previleges than it has.

Mr. WAGNER thought the State should do justice to the portions of the State which have not had branches located in them; and to accommodate these people this bill was intended. He moved to make this subject the special order for Monday at 3 o'clock.
The motion was agreed to

div.head: LIABILITY OF RAILROADS.
div.p: Mr. CRAVEN; from the select committee, thereon, returned his bill [?]45, with amendments recommending passage. The report was concurred in.

Mr. MURRAY moved to recommit with instructions to amend, so that when the company come forward and tenders two-thirds of the value of the property killed or injured, and the party refuse to take it, and institute suit to recover the full value on account ofnegligence, that he shall not recover the cost of action.
Mr. MARCH contended there was no necessity for the adoption of the amendment.
The motion to recommit was rejected.
On motion by Mr. BOBBS, the bill was laid on the table.
On motion by Mr. GREEN, a resolution from the House, requesting the return of the bill H. R. 147, was considered and concurred in.

Mr. KINLEY, by leave, offered a resolution which was adopted, directing the Committee on Finance to incorporate in the specific appropriation bill some compensation to Professer Mills for his suggestions on the Common School system.
On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, Mr. Stevens' bill 192, about the public printing, was taken up, amended, and ordered to be engrossed for a third reading.

div.head: THE CALENDAR.
div.p: The following Senate bills were read the second time and appropriately referred:
Mr. Wier's 225 and Mr. Wier's 235, to the Committee on Banks.
Mr. March's 227, Mr. Slack's 228, and Mr.Wagner's 237, to the Committee on Finance.
Mr. Carnahan's 226, to the Committee on Corporations.
Mr. Slack's 229, Mr- Shoemaker's 230, Mr. Tarkington's 232, Mr. Hill's 234 and Mr. Robinson's 239, to the Judiciary Committee.
Mr. March's 236, ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. Craven's 238, to the Committee on Agriculture.
The following House bills were read the second time and appropriately referred:
No 142, referred to the Judiciary Committee.
No's. 143, 201, 249, were ordered to be engrossed.

Mr. STUDABAKER, by leave, introduced a bill (240) to authorize Justices of the Peace, within their respective counties, to administer oaths generally, and to legalize such as have been made in good faith and without fraud since the 6th day of May, 1853; which was passed the first reading.
And then the Senate adjourned.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
div.p: Messrs. Hartley, Treadway, Shields and Sullivan had leave of absence till Monday.

The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from James S. Athon, Superintendent for the Hospital for the Insane, responding to an inquiry of the House of Representatives respecting the cost of patients. &c.
Also a communication from the Governor responding to a resolution of the House of the 16th instant.
On motion of Mr. COLLIER, Mr. Boyd's ten minutes speech resolution was taken up and adopted.
Mr. SCOTT asked and obtained leave to submit a resolution for night session every alternate session.
Mr. DOUGHERTY proposed to add:

p.hi: "For the purpose of introduction and consideration of bills on the first and second reading."

div.p: Mr. CAVIN submitted an amendment byway of substitute, viz:

p.hi: "That during the remainder of the session, the House of Representatives will hold evening sessions each Monday, Wednesday and Friday - commencing at 7 o'clock.

Mr. REEFER made an ineffectual motion to take up the bill No. 200.

div.head: WABASH AND ERIE CANAL.
div.p: Mr. COLGROVE, from the Committee on the Judiciary, returned his bill (246), surrendering to the trustees of the Wabash and Erie Canal all the right the State has to redeem the Wabash and Erie Canal, &c., with amendments, [as heretofore proposed by Mr. C., with one exception striking out the provision in the 4th section which releases the trustees from keeping up the canal bridges,]
Mr. AUSTIN moved to lay the subject on the table.
Mr. COLGROVE, by leave, expressed a desire for engrossment and printing.
Mr. EDWARDS, by leave, desired opportunity to consider and hear from parties interested.
Mr. BLYTHE, by leave, desired to amend the motion by laying on the table, and ordering the printing of 100 copies, but made no motion.

div.head: ACTIONS WHERE THE NOTE-MAKER RESIDES.
div.p: On the motion of Mr. BOYD, the order of business was suspended for the consideration of bills on the third reading.

Mr. Prosser's bill (37) to amend the 33d section of the practice act of June 18, 1852, so as to provide that no suit against, the maker of any note or written contract shall be commenced without the county of the maker's residence, coming up -
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, objected to the bill. It gave preference to a class of defendants, and you must drag yourself and the other defendants to sue where the preferred defendants reside.

Mr. PROSSER. It will not change the law, but only prevent fraudulent assignments for jurisdiction. The jurisdiction is not removed, except in cases where the note or contract has been assigned in writing for the purpose of obtaining jurisdiction.
The bill was lost-yeas 31, nays 39as follows:

YEAS. - Messrs. Bowman, Boyd, Brotherton, Carr, Cavins, Clayton, Colgrove, Davis, Dougherty, Early, Fordyce, Gifford, Harrison, Jones, Jordan, Knowlton, Lawhead, Major, Mansfield, Mellett, Murray, Parks, Prosser, Row, Shockley, Shull, Thompson of Madison, Turpie, Waterman, Wildman and Mr. Speaker - 31.

NAYS - Messrs. Austin, Clark, Collier, Comstock, Davidson, Dobbins, Durham, Eastham, Griffin, Pall of Grant, Hall of Rush, Hamilton of Poone, Hancock, Hartley, Hunter, Johnston, Kelly, Lewis, McLain, Merrifield, Miller, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Nelson, Ritter, Robinson, Rynerson, Scott, Sherman, Shields, Smith of Miami, Stanley, Summers, Tebbs, Usrey, Wheeler, Whetzel, Whiteman and Wood - 39.
On motion by Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, (upon a reconsideration,) the regular order was resumed.

Mr. SHIELDS, by leave, from the Committee on Ways and Means, to which was referred that portion of the Governor's message recommending the erection of a building for the Supreme Court, reported a bill (297) authorizing the Governor, Secretary of State and Treasurer, to receive bids for the construction of such a fire-proof building, for the accommodation of the Supreme Court and the several State officers, on the corner of Tennessee and Washington streets, south of the State House Square - the cost not to exceed $25,000, which was passed the first reading.

Mr. HARRISON, by leave, presented the memorials of citizens and lawyers of Logansport, Peru and Fulton, concerning an impeachment of the Common Pleas Judge of Cass and Miami, which were referred without reading to Messrs. Knowlton, Smith, of Miami, Harrison, &c.

div.head: HORSE THIEF DETECTORS.
div.p: Mr. WILDMAN, from the Committee on Claims, reported favorably on the claims of Leonard Bowers and others, claiming indemnity for expenses incurred under the requisition of the Governor, in detecting and recovering fugitive horse thieves, to the amount of $2,000.
Mr. CAVINS submitted a minority report.
On motion by Mr. COLLIER the report was laid on the table.
Mr. WILDMAN moved to reconsider this vote.
Mr. MURRAY, by leave, explained the majority report. It was not for a reimbursement of money for detecting horse thieves, but for reclaiming fugitives under the requisition of the Governor.
Mr. DAVIS. Were these petitioners concerned in the murderous hanging of McDougal, in Noble county ?

Mr. MURRAY. No That was before this organization took place. These horse thieves and black legs, in the North-west counties, became so bold and formidable, that, it was almost incredible to tell of their acts, and the terror they inspired. He gave examples under his knowledge in Lagrange county. This organization had procured the detection and imprisonment of twenty-five thieves, and there were five others awaiting trial.

Mr. CAVINS, by leave, explained and defended the minority report. It was made some time ago, and intended to apply to all this class of claims, including those awarded by the House to certain claimants of Marion county. They were all claims for voluntary service, &c.

Mr. WILDMAN gave examples of the character of the organization of the regulators in question - the oath required by it - the necessity for itthe extent of the organization of desperadoes in Noble county and elsewhere, and the success of the regulators in breaking them up. Mr. McDougal was lynched before the regulators' associations were organized. He regarded this as an extreme and extraordinary case.
Mr. HUNTER opposed the allowance of these claims. He regarded these regulators as a curse to any people.
Mr. DOBBINS made an ineffectual motion to lay the motion to reconsider on the table.
The House then refused to reconsider - yeas 28, nays 44.
Mr. MURRAY hoped the House would now do themselves and all parties the justice to Strike out all such allowances from the specific appropriation bill.

Mr. GRIFFIN, from the Committee on Roads, reported upon petition, a bill (298) to provide for laying out and repairing highways on the line between the State of Indiana and adjoining States; which was passed the first reading.

Mr. RYNERSON, from the Committee on Agriculture, returned the committee's bill (244) to amend the 73d section of the assessment act of June 21, 1852, (with reference to agricultural statistics), recommending passage.
Mr. RYNERSON explained its provisions requiring copies of township tables to be filed with County Auditor, State Auditor, and to be submitted for publication in the local newspapers.
Mr. MILLER and Mr. PROSSER regarded the whole thing a as a humbug.

Mr. MURRAY. It adds this to the law: It requires the assessor to tell the number of acres cultivated, the amount of yield per acre, and a copy of each township statement to be tendered to the local papers for publication - to be printed without charge.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, would vote for the bill if he could get out that part requiring report to the Auditor of State.
Mr. JORDAN proposed to recommit with instructions

p.hi: "To change the present law so as to provide for the taking of such statistics but once in three years."

div.p: Mr. MURRAY was in favor of that.

Mr. HARNEY was for this favorable legislation to agriculture. This was the way to favor any great interest. The manufacturing and mercantile interests were amply reported in this way and its importance was understood. Strange that agriculturists were so willing to go it blind in their business. He suggested that the present imperfect statistical information gave a pretty certain indication that our Indiana lands were falling off in their productive value, and hence the importance to this great interest of encourageing the collection of statistical information.
Mr. NEBEKER, of Vermillion, desired to wake up the farmers to some appreciation of their interests in this direction, &c. He hoped this information would be given yearly.
Mr. JOHNSTON moved to amend the instructions by striking out "three," and inserting "five" years.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, moved to lay the motion and instruction on the table - which was decided in the affirmative - yeas 44, nays 42:
And then the bill was ordered to be engrossed.

On motion of Mr. SHIELDS, the orders being suspended for the purpose, it was ordered that the Clerk request the Senate to return his bill, No. 147, for further consideration and amendment in the House of Representatives.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
NEW BILLS
div.p: Mr. MERRIFIELD said he desired leave to a bill to reduce the salaries of public officers - not that he himself desired the success of the proposition. On the contrary there was probably no man on this floor who would vote to give our public officers more competent salaries than he would. But because a bill had been to-day introduced into the House,(the bill No.302) of which he understood the history, and which he denounced as a base and cowardly attempt to strike down as true a democrat as ever breathed the vital air; he intended, by the introduction of this bill, that it should share the same fate with that. If the State Printer was to be striken down, he was determined that the friends of those aiding and abetting in the act should share a similar fate.

Mr. CAVINS, (by leave.) In the early part of the session, before the election of printer, the question arose among Republicans whether or not the compensation of the Public Printer should be reduced, and though nothing definite was done he distinctly remembered telling his friends, Republicans and Democrats, that it mattered naught to him whether Mr. Sulgrove were elected or anybody else, he was determined to vote for reducing this compensation. He cared not particularly about abolishing the office, but he was for reducing the compensation. It was not a proposition to strike down a political enemy, because it was known, he presumed, that those in favor of it had been so from the first. It was supposed by some that Colonel Walker's time would be out next August. He did not know as to that; but if that were so,of course the proposed act should be amended so as not to apply till his time shall be out. He hoped those Democrats who had said, when the election was about to be brought on, that they would vote for this reduction, would not now retrain from doing so, for the sake of sustaining a political partisan.
Mr. MERRIFIELD. He had referred to the bill to abolish the office of State Printer.
The leave was accorded by consent, and Mr. Merrifield's bill (305) providing for the salaries of public officers and the manner of paying the game, was read and passed the first reading.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: By Mr. COLGROVE - Judiciary - returning the bill (S. 112) amendatory of the City Corporation law, with amendments:
The ninth section is amended so as to make the terms of office two years of all the officers elect.
The original section made the term one year, except the Mayor and City Judge, who held two years.
Section 17 is amended - requiring a special election to fill vacancies, to be conducted in the same manner as biennial elections are, instead of annual elections.
An additional section, after section 11, requiring Railroad Companies to keep a light at the crossings, and provide a guard to prevent accidents.
The 84th section is so amended as to prevent the city from annexing contiguous territory of 5 acres or upward, used for gardening or agricultural purposes, without the consent of the owner.
Which amendments were ordered to be engrossed, and the biil as amended, to the third reading.
By Mr. DOUGHERTY, from the Committee on Fees and Salaries, returning Mr. Devol's fee bill (211) amendatory of sections 2, 3, 4,7, 8 and 9 of the act of March 2, 1855, with an amendment by substitute.
The substitute was read.

Mr. DOUGHERTY explained the bill. It makes but few radical changes. The changes affect only Clerks, Sheriffs and Auditors. The object is not so much a reduction of the fees, as to prevent abuses which have grown up under the present, law. It makes reduction of the Clerk's fees in business that relates to e[?]ettlement of estates and guardianships. Issuing letters testamentary, are reduced from $1 to 75 cents - proving will, to 75 cents - qualification of administrator, to 75 cents - recording claim, 25 cents examining each administrator's settlement, 50 cents - examining report, nothing - the Clerk to receive 25 cents for affidavit only when he writes it; with other slight reductions.

The fees of Sheriff are not reduced. It cuts off extra allowance of 75 cents for summoning jury - the County Commissiner's allowance to be in full. The bill corrects the abuse of Sheriffs charging 15 cents per mile for each convict sentenced to the State Prison at the same term, instead of 15 cents for one, and 10 cents for each additional convict - prescribing that all the convicts sentenced at one term shall be taken at the

same time. It prevents also the Sheriffs' fees for services performed by his bailiffs and paid out of the County Treasury. It prevents duplications of allowance for extra services. The bill does not reduce the specific fees of the County Auditor, but aims to correct abuses under the present law. It allows 5 cents for each county order, for each allowance - nothing for any additional order under the same allowance. It allows ten cents per 100 words for copying duplicates and land descriptions - for words and figures actually written in the proper column, &c. It requires the Auditor to make out his quarterly itemized statement of fees, under oath - to be recorded in the County Commissioner's books, and published as required by law.
Mr. BAIRD and Mr. MELLETT moved and pleaded ineffectually for its reference to the Judiciary Committee.
Mr. HARNEY proposed to amend the bill, by adding the following:

The county treasurer shall not receive more than a thousand dollars when the duplicate is less than $50,000, and for each $25,000 additional upon the duplicates, they shall be allowed $500 for clerk hire; and he shall account for all money received except his fees now allowed by law. which shall not exceed in the aggregate the amount specified above.
The amendment was adopted.
Mr. DOUGHERTY (under a motion to reconsider) stated that it was against the constitution to amend a statute, without setting forth the section amended.
Mr. PROSSER opposed the amendment.
Mr. HARNEY was willing to withdraw it, with notice of his intention to bring it forward in a separate bill.
The SPEAKER. It cannot be withdrawn.
The vote was reconsidered, and the amendment laid on the table.

Baird, Boyd, Branham, Cavins, Claypool, Clements, Colgrove, Collier, Davidson, Dobbins Devol, Early, Edwards, Fordyce, Gregory, Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hamilton of Boone, Hunter, Lawhead, McLain, Mellett, Miller, Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Prosser, Row, Sherman, Shull, Smith of Perry, Snyder, Stanley, Thompson of Madison, Turpie, Waterman, Wheeler, Whiteman, Wildman and Mr. Speaker - 40.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Mr. Mellett's instructions were adopted, by yeas 47, nays 22.
Mr. DEVOL moved additional instructions:

p.hi: "Amend the bill so as to reduce one-fourth the fees of all clerks of the Circuit and Common Pleas Courts, and all county treasurers and auditors"

div.p: Mr. SCOTT moved, ineffectually, that it lie on the table - yeas 36, nays 36.
Mr. MURRAY moved, ineffectually, to make the instructions an "inquiry into expediency," &c.
Mr. DOUGHERTY. The only effect of the instructions would be to defeat the bill.
Mr. DOBBINS (out of order) proposed to add instructions to reduce the pay of members of the Legislature one-fourth.
Mr. HALL, of Rush, moved, ineffectually, to add to the instructions:
Provided, That no reduction shall be made where the fees do not exceed $1,000.
Mr. Devol's instructions were rejected by yeas 36, nays 42.
Mr. MERRIFIELD, from the select committee thereon, returned his bill (273) legalizing the change of highways by railroad companies, and recommending passage.
The bill was ordered to engrossment.

Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, from the Swamp Lands Committee, returned the petition from Vigo county, for a ditching law, with an adverse re commendation; and the petition of John O. Dibble, of Lake county, recommending indefinite postponement.
The reports were concurred in.

div.head: LICENSE LIQUOR LAW.
div.p: On the motion of Mr. MURRAY, the House took up the Senate's amendments to Mr. Mansfield's liquor bill, No. 29.
On motion of Mr. DOUGHERTY, the Senate's amendments were considered separately.
The amendments to the third section were read.

Mr. MANSFIELD saw now a change in the opinion of temperance men - they being now willing to take conservative ground. Place the license and the bond too high, and honest men would be slow to run the risk. One thousand dollars for license, and two thousand dollars for the bond was too high; and the securities of bad men we e generally worthless. This and the four instead of two free-hold sureties was unfavorable to the general objects and beneficent aims of the bill.
The four sureties amendment and the maximum of license extended to $1,000 was then concurred in.
The Senate's change of the maximum of the bond from $500 to $2,000 in the 3d section, was concurred in, by yeas 41, nays 39 - as follows:

YEAS. - Messrs. Austin, Blythe, Boyd, Brotherton,Carr, Cavins, Clark, Collier, Cotton, Davidson, Devol, Fordyce, Gregory, Hall of Grant, Hall of Hush, Hamilton of Boone, Hamilton of Wayne, Harrison, Hunter, Jeffries, Johnston, Jones, Knowlton, Lawhead, Mellett, Murray, Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Parks, Power, Ritter, Robinson, Scott, Shull, Thompson of Elkhart, Treadway, Whetzel, Whiteman, Wildman and Wood - 41.

NAYS. - Messrs Baird, Bowman, Branham, Clements, Comstock, Davis, Dobbins, Dougherty, Early, Gifford, Hancock, Harney, Jordan. Kelly, Kempf, Lewis, McLain, Major, Mansfield, Massey, Merrifield, Nelson, Newton, Prosser, Row, Sherman, Shields, Shockley, Smith of Miami, Smith of Perry, Stanfield, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of Madison, Turpie, Usrey, Waterman, Wheeler and Mr. Speaker. - 39.

The further amendments affixed by the Senate were severally concurred in, without a division, excepting the amendment striking out from section 15 the clause admitting druggists to sell for medicinal purposes; and this was also concurred in by yeas 53, nays 82; and excepting also the question of concurrence in the Senate's amendment allowing the manufacturer of wine and cider from fruits grown in the State, or any other person to sell such wine and cider in any quantity, whereupon the vote stood - yeas 41, nays 44, as follows:

YEAS. - Messrs. Baird, Blythe, Bowman, Boyd, Carr, Cavins, Clements, Davis, Dobbins, Early, Gifford, Hamilton of Boone, Hancock, Jones, Jordan, Keefer, Kelly, Kempf, Knowlton, Lewis, Major, Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Nelson, prosser, Row, Shields, Shockley, Shull, Stanfield, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of Elkhart, Thompson of Madison, Treadway, Turpie, Usrey, Waterman, Whetzel and Wood. - 41.

NAYS. - Messrs. Austin, Branham, Brotherton, Clark, Claypool, Colgrove, Collier,Comstock,Cotton, Dougherty, Devol, Fordyce, Gregory, Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hall of Rush, Hamilton of Wayne, Harney, Harrison, Hunter, Jeffries, Johnston, Lawhead, McLain, Mansfield, Massey, Mellett, Merrifield, Miller, Murray, Newton, Parks, Power, Ritter, Robinson, Scott, Sherman, Smith of Miami, Smith of Perry, Snyder, Stanley, Whiteman Wildman and Mr. Speaker. - 44.

Mr. MANSFIELD voting under a protestation that this would open innumerable places to sell all sorts of intoxicating drinks under the name of blackberry wine, and cider without license, and so defeat the objects of the bill. He laid this to the charge of the temperance men.
So the House refused to concur in this amendment.
The Senate's additional section 18, revoking the license after conviction of a violation of this act, was also non concurred in, by yeas 34 nays 48.
Mr. DOBBINS moved to reconsider the vote concurring in the Senate's amendment striking-out from section 15 the clause permitting druggists to sell for medicinal purposes.
Which motion, on the motion of Mr. RITTER, was laid on the table, by yeas 54, nays 34.
Mr. KNOWLTON moved to reconsider the vote concurring in the Senate's amendment raising the bond from $500 to $2,000.
Which motion, on the motion of Mr. RITTER, was also laid on the table, by yeas 43, nays 38.

div.head: THE CALENDAR.
div.p: Mr. Davis' bill (1) to provide for referring to the people at the next annual election the question of a Constitutional Convention, &c., coming up in order on the final reading, it failed for want of a constitutional majority - yeas 47, nays 39, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. NAYS - Messrs. Mr. Colgrove's bill (47) reorganizing the Circuit Courts of the State, was rejected on the final reading - yeas 36, nays 47.

Mr. Martin's bill (58) authorizing the Governor to make requisition of Governors of other States for the recovery of fugitives from justice, was passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 81, nays 2, with an amendment of title, so as to read: An act relative to the making requisition for and the delivering up of fugitives from justice.

div.head: GAME LAW.
div.p: Mr. Hamilton, of Boone's bill (64) to prevent the killing of wild game, &c., coming up -

Mr. DOUGHERTY said this was no game law - it allowed of any killing at any time, if the object was to preserve growing crops. He was willing to vote for a compromise on the question, but not for this.

Mr. CAVINS. I believe that all game laws are wrong - they are relicts of English aristocracy, promotive only of indolence, thrittlessness and dissipation. They are restrictions on the personal property of our citizens, that are incompatible with the spirit of Republican institutions. The amendment proposed by the bill under consideration is odious, as granting exclusive privileges to owners of lands, but not so bad as the law proposed to be amended. Therefore inasmuch as the Legislative has refused to repeal the game law, I will vote for the amendment.
Mr. DOUGHERTY moved, ineffectually, to lay the bill on the table - yeas 32, nays 47.
The vote on the final reading was then reported yeas 45, nays 34 - as follows:

AYES - Messrs. Bowman, Boyd, Brotherton, Carr, Cavins, Clark, Clements, Collier, Devol, Early, Edwards, Griffin, Hall of Rush, Hamiltom of Boone, Hunter, Jeffries, Johnston, Jones, Kelley, McLean, Massey, Miller, Martin, Nebeker of Warren, Parks, Prosser, Ritter, Robinson, Row, Scott, Shields, Shockley, Shull, Smith of Miami, Smith of Perry, Snyder, Stanley, Tebbs, Turpie, Usrey, Waterman, Wheeler, Whetzel, Whiteman and Mr. Speaker - 44.

Mr. Early's bill (72) to amend sections one and two of the act of March 1, 1853, allowing compensation to the owner or owners of animals killed by railroad cars, and to provide for the manner of service of process, was passed the third and last reading in the House of Representatives, by yeas 60, nays 14.
Mr, CLEMENTS, by leave, entered his motion to rescind the order of Saturday for night sessions.

Mr. Brotherton's bill (91) to provide for the transfer of certain cases from the Common Pitas and Justices of the Peace, of certain cases therein named, was passed the final reading in the House of Representatives, by yeas 67, nays 4 [This bill takes up cases in attachment where any claim filed therein exceeds the jurisdiction of the Justice of the Peace, &c.]

div.head: NIGHT SESSION.
div.p: Pursuant to he order adopted last Saturday, the House met at 7 o'clock p. m. - Mr. Edwards in the chair.

div.p: By Mr. COLLIER: a bill (310) to regulate the practice of medicine and surgery:
By Mr. AUSTIN: (311) to amend the 15th section of the felony act - [of seduction:]

div.head: IN SENATE
div.p: Mr. WILLIAMS presented a letter from one of his constituents on the subject of milk sickness, claiming to have found the cause thereof that it originates from the exhalation of metalic substances in the earth, and that the same effects can be produced by the feeding of a cow upon bran boiled in a copper kettle.
On motion by Mr. BROWN, the bill (H. R. 149) fixing the time of holding the Common Pleas Courts in St. Joseph, Marshall and Starke, was taken up, read the third time and passed by yeas 38, nays 0.

On motion by Mr. STEELE, his bill (69) to prevent the circulation of the withdrawn currency of the old State Bank, and to punish persons violating the provisions of this act, was taken up and passed - yeas 32, nays 6.
On motion by Mr. KINLEY, his bill (134) providing for the assessment of taxes for township library purposes, was read the third time.
Senators Turner, Line, Hill, Murray anc Bobbs, favored the bill, and Senator Carnahan opposed it.
The bill was then passed - yeas 29, nays 9.

On motion by Mr. JOHNSTON, his bill (101) to authorize county treasurers to assess property which may be omitted by assessors, and to legalize assessments heretofore made by treasurers was read the third time and passed - yeas 37 nays 0.

Mr. MARCH, from the Judiciary Committee returned Mr. Studabaker's bill (240) to authorize Justices of the Peace, within their respective counties, to administer oaths generally, and to legalize such as have been made in good faith: and without fraud since the 6th day of May 1853, recommending its passage. The report was concurred in.
On motion by Mr. STUDABAKER, the bill was read the third time and passed by yeas 37, nays 0.

Mr. BENNETT, from the same committee returned Mr. Conley's bill (176) to amend sec tions 8 and 10 of the Justices' Act, approved June 9, 1852; [proposing to give Justices concurrent jurisdiction to the amount of $300;] recommending its indefinite postponement.
Mr. CONLEY urged the necessity of the passage of the bill and the rejection of the report.
Senators Bennett, Slack, Stevens and Green favored concurrence in the report
Senators Williams, March, Line and Johnston opposed concurrence.
The report of the committee was rejected - yeas 16, nays 24.
[A message from the Governor announced his approval and signature of the bill (H. R. 210) to create the 10th Judicial Circuit.]
Mr. JOHNSTON moved to recommit to the Judiciary Committee - to so amend as to give Justices of the Peace jurisdiction on all notes or written agreements for the payment of money not exceeding $200.
Mr. SLACK made a motion to instruct the committee to amend so as to allow an appeal from the Justice to the Township Trustee.
On motion by Mr. CONLEY this proposition was laid on the table.
Mr. WILLIAMS moved to instruct the committee to give Justices of the Peace exclusive jurisdiction in sums of $200.
A division of the question was demanded.
Mr. Johnston's motion was agreed to.
Mr. Williams' motion was rejected>
The special order for this hour - Mr. Wagner's bill 187 - was made the order for 2 o'clock today.
Mr. COOPER, from the Committee on the Benevolent Institutions of the State, returned Mr. Turner's bill 67, recommending its passage. The report was concurred in and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. HARGROVE. from the same committee, returned Mr. Bobbs' bill 52, recommending that lie on the table. The report was concurred in.
Mr. O'BRIEN, from the same committee, returned Mr. Turner's bill 58, with an amendment recommending its passage. The report was con curred in and the bill ordered to be engrossed.

Mr. CRAVENS, from the same committee returned a Senate resolution of inquiry as to the expediency of erecting an additional wing to the Insane Hospital recommending that it is inexpedient at this time, inasmuch as the finances of the State are embarrassed. The report was concurred in.
Mr. SHOEMAKER, from the Committee on County and Township Business, returned Mr Conley's bill 214, recommending that it lie on the table. The report was concurred in.

Mr. STEVENS, from the Committee on Printing, returned Mr. Hamilton's resolution,and Mr. Anthony's preamble and resolution of inquiry on the subject of printing; also, various petitions on the same; recommending that they lie on the table. The reports were concurred in.
Mr. STUDABAKER, from the select committee thereon, returned the bill (25) for the distribution of the Sinking Fund, recommending its passage with the following amendments:
Amend 5th section as follows: insert after the word '"cancelled" the words "the amount thereof, and the amount paid for the same," and add to the bill the following section:

SEC. 15. All laws not inconsistent with this act, in regard to the Sinking Fund, or giving powers to or prescribing the duties of the Sinking Fund Commissioners, their officers, clerks, agents and servants, or prescribing punishments again't them for malfeasance in office, that were in force on the day preceding the 1st of January,1859, are hereby declared to be in full force, and to apply to the present Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners, and its officers clerks, agents and servants, but all such laws as are inconsistent with this act are hereby repealed.
The report was concurred in.
Mr. STUDABAKER moved that the bill be considered as engrossed, and read the third time now.
Mr. BOBBS proposed to amend so us to provide as follows:

That the Auditor of each county shall report to the Board of Commissioners of such county, at their annual meeting in March, any losses the Sinking Fund distributed to such county may have sustained, and which have not been secured or refunded at the time of making such report; and it shall be the duty of such Commissioners to assess a tax upon the taxables of such county, to reimburse said fund to the full amount of such loss; and the Auditor shall place such assessment upon his duplicate, and the Treasurer of the county shall collect the same as the other taxes are collected for county purposes
Mr. STUDABAKER thought the proposition in itself may be right, but would rather not see it placed in the bill at his present time.
Mr HAMILTON favored the amendment.

Mr. MURRAY, notwithstanding he was in favor of the original proposition, should vote for the bill as it now is, whether this amendment be adopted or not; but he insisted upon the adoption of the amendment.

Mr. WILLIAMS proposed as a substitute for the amendment, that when it is ascertained there has been a loss, it shall be the duty of the County Commissioners to pass an order upon the County Treasury for the amount of such loss, unless it has occurred through the negligence or misconduct of the county officers; and then they are to be held responsible for such loss.
Mr. LINE could see no objection to the amendment.

Mr. STUDABAKER proposed to raise no
[se]rious objection to either of the amendments, but would prefer the one submitted by Mr. Williams.
Mr. BOBBS accepted of the substitute, with the accountability of officers stricken out - to which Mr, Williams agreed.
The amendment was then adopted.
The bill was read the third time and passed - yeas 33, nays 10, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson, Blair, Brown, Carnahan, Cobb, Conley, Conner, Cooper, Culver, Fisk, Green, Hamilton, Hargrove, Hendry, Hill, Johnston, Line, Lomax, McClure, McLean, March, Murray, Odell, Robinson, Shoemaker, Slack, Studabaker, Tarkington, Thompson, Turner, Williams and Wilson - 23.
NAYS - Messrs. Bennett, Bobbs, Cravens, Jones, Kinley, O'Brien, Rice, Steele, Stevens and Wagner - 10.

The special order for 11 o'clock, being Mr. Conner's bill (212), releasing the right of the State of Indiana, to redeem the Wabash and Erie Canal, and granting permission to the trustees thereof to rent or lease the same, was then considered.
Mr. CONNER occupied the floor in favor of his bill until the hour of 12, when he gave way for the recess till 2.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Mr. McLEAN presented a remonstrance from certain lawyers of Terre Haute, against the abolishment of the Court of Common Pleas, which was referred to the Judiciary Committee.
Mr. CONNER resumed and concluded his remarks on his bill 212.

[A message from the House announced its adherence to its refusal to concur in the Senate amendments to the temperance bill (H. R. 29) and that Messrs. Murray, Mansfield and Dougherty, were the House conferees thereon.

The PRESIDENT, pro tem., announced the special order - Mr. Wagner's bill (178), creating six additional bank districts; the question being on the amendment proposed by Mr. March, as printed on page 218 of these reports.
Mr. ANTHONY thought it would give additional security to the bill holder to increase these branches, and that it would be beneficial to the interests of the State.

Mr. MARCH thought the increase of these branches would be an increase of the powers of the Institution, whether they be for good or for evil. He would not vote to give the bank additional powers, unless it would consent to come under the control of the Legislature.

Mr. HAMILTON desired gentlemen to know that the bank does not ask for this increase of its branches; and insisted that an increase of the branches did not give it additional powers, but simply increased its responsibilities.
Mr. GOODING was opposed to the bill, and thought the creation of the additional branches proposed would increase the power and influence ot this bank monster.
Mr. MURRAY objected to the amendment proposed, and contended that we have no right to impose the restrictions upon the bank that are contemplated in the amendment.
Mr. STEELE expressed himself as decidedly opposed to the amendment, and if it was adopted there could be no chance of creating additional brauches.
Mr. BENNETT moved to lay the amendments on the table.
Mr. STUDABAKER demanded a division of the question.
The first amendment - the one to section 15 - was not laid on the table by yeas 17, nays 27.
The next amendment - the one to section 19 - was laid on the table - yeas 24, nays 21.
The last amendment proposed by Mr. March Demanding an additional section - was also laid on the table - yeas 24, nays 21.
The question then recurred on the adoption ot the amendment to the 15 th section - the one taxing banks the same as individuals.
Mr. STUDABAKER was willing to tax the banks for the amount of stock paid in.
Mr. BENNETT proposed to amend by striking out the words "together with the amount of their capital stock."
Mr. ANTHONY opposed the passage of the amendment, but would vote for the bill as it is.
Mr. HEFFREN was opposed to the amendment, but would favor the amendment to the amendment. The increase of branches would decrease the profits of those already in operation.
Mr. MARCH objected to the amendment to the amendment, speaking at length.

Mr. WAGNER. I like to see Senators debate a matter fairly and honestly,and resort to the kind of arguments used by the Senator from Delaware, who upon all occasions reports for the benefit of the Senate, that same old buncombe sheech which we have all heard ever since my earliest recollection. It is the same old speech against banks, corporations and monopolies, and other associations to whom we are indebted for all our improvements. He then gave way for a motion to adjourn.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
div.p: Mr. Speaker GORDON (Mr. Davis in the Chair) moved to reconsider the vote of Saturday, refusing to concur in the report of the Committee on Claims adverse to the claims of certain persons in Lagrange and Noble counties, to the extent of $2,000, on account of the arrest of horse thieves, &c.
The vote was reconsidered.
Mr. Speaker GORDON then moved to amend the report so far as to admit of the allowance of $1,000.
Mr. HUNTER. These claims, if paid at all, should be paid out of the treasuries of the counties where the service has been performed. How could this House investigate these remote cases?
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, concurred with Mr. Hunter. If this game of claims was to be played upon the State Treasury, his county would come in for a large share.
Mr. COMSTOCK. This claim was meritorious as any, but he had determined to vote against the whole of them here, and leave them to their respective counties.

Mr. Speaker GORDON replied to Mr. Hunter. That the claim was fairly preferred, he argued the constitution of the Committee on Claims. The gentleman's argument was striking at the very first principles of justice. It was urged in forgetfulness of what is right between man and
man, and the citizen and the State. He spoke at length, giving examples.

Mr. COLGROVE considered the equity of the case. Upon what principle of justice could the State be required to pay the counties for catching and punishing their criminals? Why not pay all the costs - the witnesses and clerks - in criminal cases?

Mr. MURRAY. Claims of this character had been allowed, and now when those citizens of Lagrange and other northern counties come here by their representatives, and ask for $1,000 of $6,000 which they have expended under the Governor's requisition, where was the injustice? Such allowances had been made heretofore without question.
Mr. MELLETT had been voting under the impression that claims of this class ought not to be allowed, and he expected to continue to so vote.

Mr. HUNTER spoke again. The allowance of claims arising out of costs in criminal cases would break down the treasury of the State, &c. To were wiser to have a law paying the prosecuting Attorneys and Sheriffs. But such a law would be ruinous of the State finances.

Mr. DAVIS considered the importance of the principle of executing the laws. You authorize your Governor to make requisition of fugitives from other States, and then, by refusing this class of claims, yon paralyze the arm of the Governor in this very thing. He would confine allowances to cases oi services rendered under the Governor's requisition, &c. There ought to be a remedy for the fact, that, because the State pays nothing for criminal prosecutions, nearly all the talent of the bar was commonly enlisted on the side of the defense.

Mr. THOMPSON, of Elkhart, alleged that the County Commissioners, and others, in Noble, Lagrange and Steuben counties, had paid their full share of the expense in these arrests of thieves and black legs. More than $25,000 had been so paid. There was a man, now in this Hall, who paid for this purpose a hundred dollars out of his own pocket. &c.

Mr. SCOTT. The General Assembly might refuse to be generous, but, they could not shirk the demands of Justice. He was surprised to hear gentlemen declare they would not vote for any of these claims, no matter how just the claim might be. Such was not the feeling that would actuate him. He read names of several gentlemen whose claims, similar to these, had been allowed during the present, session. It was very questionable whether the County Commissioners have the right to make these allowances.
Mr. AUSTIN moved to lay the report and amendment on the table.

Mr. DAVIS gave notice that, if this motion should not prevail, he would move to recommit the report, &c., with instructions to inquire how much had been actually expended in the case under the requisition of the Governor.
The Clerk reported the vote - yeas 38, nays 47. So the House refused to lay on the table and then -
Mr. DAVIS submitted his motion to recommit with instructions.
It was recommitted without a division.

div.head: THE FINANCES OF THE STATE.
div.p: Mr. HARNEY, (under a dispensation) from the Committee on Ways and Means, returned the said committee's finance bill (195) with amendments, as directed by instructions heretofore adopted by the House, recommending the adoption of all the amendments except that requiring the Treasurer to convert into specie all revenue received by him in bank notes as fast as the same shall amount to $1,000.

Mr. HARNEY. The report provides for striking out from the bill all that relates to County Treasurers and State Comptroller, and for amending the fourth section, prescribing what moneys shall be paid into the treasury, adding these words: "Eleventh. All moneys arising from the sale of bank bonds or stocks deposited under the provisions of the general banking law, and all moneys belonging to or accruing to the State, or to any fund of the State:" together with the amendment directed by the House, that whenever payments shall be made into the State Treasury, in the notes of solvent, specie-paying banks, to the amount of $1,000, it shall be the duty of the Treasurer to convert the same into coin, by presenting and demanding the specie thereon. The report recommends the adoption of all but the last, which is recommended to be laid on the table.
Mr. MURRAY moved a call of the House, and it was ordered that the names of the following absentees be entered on the journal, viz:
Messrs. Black, Boxley, Durham, Eastham, Firestone, Hartley, Kempf, Parrett, Stiles, Stinson and Sullivan.
Mr. DOUGHERTY said the report did not embrace the instructions of Mr. Robinson.
The SPEAKER. The instructions fall.
Mr. AUSTIN. The House adjourned when his instructions were pending.
The SPEAKER. The adjournment cut them off.
Mr. MELLETT. The gentleman's instructions were incorporated in the report amending the 13th section.

Mr. HARNEY demanded the previous question, and under its force, the several amendments reported were adopted, and upon the recommendation to lay on the table the clause requiring the bank notes in the Treasury to be converted into coin, the vote stood - yeas 46, nays 42.
So the report was concurred in, and the bill was ordered to be engrossed, by yeas 51, nays 37.
Mr. HUNTER moved that the bill be considered as engrossed, and read the third time now.

The motion was agreed to under the pressure of the previous question, and the bill, being again read through by the Clerk, was passed the final reading in the House of Representatives, by the following vote:

On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the House took up the Senate's last message on the disagreeing voles on the Mansfield bill, (No. 29,) and moved that the House insist on its nonconcurrence in the Senate's amendment to Mr. Mansfield bill, (No. 29,) admitting the manufacturer of wine or cider, from fruits grown in this State, or any other person, to sell such wine or cider without license.

Mr. MANSFIELD. The Senate had returned the bill with a number of amendments. The House accepted them all except two; of which one was, that the license shall be forfeited in case of any breach of any of the provisions contained in the bill. The Senate has since conceded that point and set it aside. The other amendment attached by the Senate, and rejected by the House, was this: That not merely the manufactured of wine and cider from fruits grown in this State shall be permitted to sell the same in any quantity without license, but "any other person." These words "any other person," were objected to by the House. I understand that this amendment of the Senate was adopted in a great hurry, and the gentleman who made it, told me that it was not, his design to enable the manufacturers ot wine and cider to keep tippling houses, but merely to encourage the farmer in making these things, which are less harmfulth an whisky or brandy. But now this additional clause in the bill, That it shall not be drank on the premises where sold, will give us the advantage in the free conference, and there is no doubt but the Senate will immediately accede this mistake. I hope the House will insist, and that we shall yet, be able to succeed in making this bill not merely a good license law, but also a good temperance law.
Mr.BAIRD and Mr. AUSTIN. The Senate's amendment went only to allow the manufacturer to sell.
Mr. HUNTER. The effect of the Senate's amendment would be to make every grocery-keeper in the State a manufacturer.
Mr. MURRAY preferred the Committee on Free Conference.
Mr. DOUGHERTY had submitted this clause originally, and he construed it, and hoped the House would insist.
Mr. PROSSER concurred with Mr, Baird.
Mr. HALL, of Rush. There was obscurity, and laws should be so framed as to avoid misconstruction.
The House then adhered to its amendment,and ordered the appointment of a committee of free conference, which the SPEAKER makes to consist of Messrs. Murray, Mansfield and Dougherty.

div.head: THE SINKING FUND - SCHOOL LAW.
div.p: Mr. BOWMAN asked and obtained a dispensation to present the following memorial from a citizen of Washington county, which was referred to the Committee on Education. It is as follows:

p.hi: To the Honorable, the Senate and House of Representatives of the State of Indiana:

div.p: Every man is, or ought to be, interested in whatever relates to the cause of education and science. There appears to be great diversity of opinion as to the best and safest plan of investing the Sinking Fund - the main reliance, in future, for the support of Common Schools. Your memorialist would venture, with your permission, to make one or two suggestions to your honorable body.

If a public debt is a public blessing and to be perpetuated for all coming time, there might be a seeming propriety in converting the Sinking Fund into State or United States bonds, but in view of the growing sentiment in favor of the speedy liquidation of all public indebtedness, and the constitutional barrier in the way of contracting new debts, except in a few specified cases of great emergency and for limited periods - it follows most conclusively, that public stocks can not furnish a reliable investment for that purpose.

It is not necessary to stop to consider whether the Sinking Fund might not be invested profitably and safely in bank stock, because as banks are at present organized, the people will never consent to confide a trust so sacred to their keeping.

What, then, shall be done with the Sinking Fund? It ought, as your memorialist believes, to be apportioned and distributed amongst the several counties of the State, on the basis of population, as may be ascertained by the next census, and loaned on mortgage of real estate, under the laws now regulating the loaning of other trust funds, when amended as follows:
Amend section 60, revised school law, so as to require the township trustees, alone, to appraise any land offered in mortgage.
Amend section 67, so as to require that the sum loaned shall not excel one-third o the appraised value of the premises proposed to be mortgaged, clear of all perishable improvements.

Or, let the value of all real estate offered in mortgage he determined by the County Auditor from the returns of the County Appraisers on file in his office, and allow mortgage to be executed without the signature of the wife, if surviving.

This plan submitted creates no new officers, involves no additional expense, places the security of the fund on a basis not to be questioned, and whatever advantages accrue from the use of the money, the people of the whole State share equally among thousands. J. I. MORRISON.
Salem, February 12,1859.

div.head: THE PUBLIC PRINTING.
div.p: On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, the printing bill 192 was considered.

Mr. CONLEY thought the bill was to legislate the present State printer out of office. He was willing to reduce the prices paid for printing but would not vote for the bill because it turns the present State Printer out of office.
Mr. HEFFREN stated that the present State Printer goes out of office the first day of August, anyhow, for his commission only extended to that time.
Mr. HAMILTON said he would not vote to abolish the office, but would vote to reduce the prices.

Mr.STUDABAKER moved to recommit the bill to a select committee, with instructions to so amend the bill as to continue the office of State printer, but to reduce the prices now paid for the public printing.
Mr, HEFFREN moved to lay the motion to recommit on the table.
The motion was agreed to-yeas 28, nays 16.
Mr. STUDABAKER moved to recommit with instructions to strike out section 10.
Mr. SLACK moved, as additional instructions, to amend so that the superintendence of the pubic printing, the binding and distributing of the laws be let to the lowest bidder.
Mr. MURRAY demanded the previous question.
There being a second, under its operation, the motion to recommit was lost - yeas 16, nays 29; and the bill passed by yeas 31, nays 14 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Beeson, Bennett, Blair, Bobbs, Brown. Conner, Cooper Cravens, Craven, Culver, Green, Heffren, Hendry, Hill, Johnston,Kinley, Lomax, McClure, March, Murray, Odell, Rice, Robinson, Shoemaker, Steele, Stevens, Tarkington, Thompson, Turner, Wanner and Williams - 31.
NAYS - Messrs. Carnahan, Cobb, Conley, Fisk, Gooding, Hamilton, Hargrove, Jones, Line, McLean. Miller, Slack, Studabaker and Wilson - 14.

Mr. GOODING makes the following explanation of his vote: Mr. President, it is well known to this Senate that I favor a great, reduction of the prices paid the State Printer, and would so vote, but I can not now consent to abolish the office, believing as I do that personal reasons and political considerations have prompted this attempt to abolish the office after the election of Colonel John C. Walker, a Democrat. Again, I say that I am anxious to reduce the costs of State printing at least thirty three per cent., and would have voted to abolish the office before the election, but, neither party seemed willing at that time. I say now let us reduce the prices, but not abolish the office. Another objection to this bill is, that I fear the object is to establish at the Capital an office-holders' organ to take charge of the Democratic party, the State Sentinel having lost its character and power as a Democratic paper.

Mr. McLEAN makes the following explanation of his vote: He opposed the bill from the belief that under its provisions there would be more abuses than under the present law - that under its provisions it would cost the State as much to do the public printing as under the existing laws. This has been the experience of other States which have let out the printing to the lowest bidders. If the present law is defective, and the cost of printing under its provisions is too high, let the law be amended or modified and the cost of printing reduced. Under the law proposed the letting out of the printing would be a matter of personal or partisan favoritism with foe Secretary of State, who has charge of it, and as such he should oppose the bill under consideration.
So the bill passed the Senate.

div.head: WABASH AND ERIE CANAL.
div.p: On motion by Mr. HAMILTON, the bill (212) releasing the right of the State to redeem the Wabash and Erie Canal, was considered.

On motion by Mr. CONNER a communication from the Attorney General, giving as his legal opinion on the bill under consideration that there was nothing in it which could be construed to make the State liable, was read by the Secretary.
On motion by Mr. STEELE it was ordered to be spread upon the journal.

Mr. LINE moved to amend Mr. Carnahan's motion on page 217 of these reports by inserting a provision that if any person or persons shall take the canal and fail to keep up the bridges, the State shall not be bound to pay for the bulling or repairing of said bridges.

Mr. CRAVENS [Mr. Wagner in the Chair] spoke against the bill, not that he opposed it in principle, but because he apprehended the provisions of the bill were such as would bring upon the State many and complicated difficulties.

[ A message from the Governor announced his approval and signature of the bills (H. R 16) defining misdemeanors; (H. R. 20) prohibiting the carrying of concealed weapons; (H. R. 259) changing the time of holding the Courts of Common Pleas in the counties of St. Joseph, Marshall and Stark, and (H. R. 27) authorizing road companies to consolidate their stock with similar companies]

Mr. RICE wished to be heard briefly upon the bill under consideration - as no subject of legislation affected his constituents more vitally than the question of maintaining the Wabash and Erie Canal, and while he was opposed here and elsewhere to appropriating one cent out of the State Treasury for such purposes - and while he was also opposed to the passage of any law, which would in the slightes degree involve the State in any liability to the the Bondholders for that portion of our public debt which was discharged by the transfer of the Wabash and Erie Canal - yet he was in favor of and his constituents asked of this Legislature such legislation as would prevent that great work traversing the the State diagonally from north-east to south west, a distance of some three hundred and eighty miles, and that, too, through the richest and fairest portion of the State, from abandonment and general ruin. And while the bill under consideration vigilantly guarded the interests of the State, it provided the needful legislation for the mantainance of the Canal. He could not see the force or pertinence of the objections to the bill the idea that the State, by relinquishing the right of redemption of the Canal, thereby incurred or revived the original debt liquidated by its transfer, seemed to him preposterous and absurd. He did not so understand the law. or common sense, as applied to the business transactions of life. He discussed the bill by sections, and was in favor of its general provisions. He further proceeded to show how his constituents would be effected by the abandonment of the Canal. This work passed through the entire length of his county - a distance of more than thirty five miles-and at least one million of bushels grain were shipped annually from his county upon the Canal. During the suspension of navigation last
summer, when his constituents had to de end upon the railroad for the transportation of their grain, they had to pay three cents additional to Canal transportation - this item of three cents per bushel, would lose to his constituents some thirty thousand dollars - then the additional expense of hauling one half millions of bushels of grain to the railroad, would be at least five cents per bushel, which-would make some twenty-five thousand dollars more- These two items would make some fifty-five thousand dollars, which his constituents would lose annually by the abandonment of the Canal. The Canal traversed some fourteen counties, and he supposed his to be an average - then multiply the above sum by fourteen, and you have the enormous sum of more than three quarters of a million o dollars that these counties would lose annually by the abandonment of the Canal. These considerations he urged upon the consideration of the Senate, and particularly upon those Senators who were not immediately interested.

Mr. GOODING makes the following explanation of his vote: Mr. President, I shall now vote for this bill, regarding it as the only chance of obtaining any law at this session. Rather than go home and leave the State and the people without any law to protect them from the evils of intemperance, I will vote for any constitutional bill on this subject, however objectionable some of its unimportant i may be.

One objection I have to the bill is prohibiting the sale of cider or native wine by another person than the manufacturer, in less quantity than one gallon. I do not indorse or approve the bill, but only support it between the unrestricted sale of liquor consequent evils, and this bill with its imperfections.
Mr. TURNER makes the following explanation of his vote:

Mr. President - It is well known that I have uncompromisingly opposed this bill from the first, but there are some provisions in the bill that I heartily approve of, while the main portions of it I as heartily oppose. Believing, as I do, that traffic in intoxicating liquors is a great moral as well as political evil, fostering pauperism, misery and crime, and producing more evil than any or all other crimes known in this or perhaps any other country, I could not, under any circumstances, lend my influence to legalize so great a wrong; and believing that this provision is not wrong in itself, but calculated to make the bill more acceptable to the temperance people of Indiana. Believing that if it fails now, it willbe impossible to pass any Temperance Law this session; I, therefore, solemnly protesting against the right of any Legislature to license a moral evil, reluctantly vote "aye."
The PRESIDENT pro tempore decided that the bill should be yet read through and passed by yeas and nays.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. STANFIELD submitted the following:

Mr. Speaker - The Committee on the Judiciary, to whom House bill 261, to amend section 77 of an act to revise, simplify and abridge the rules of practice and pleadings, &c., so as to prevent sham pleadings, have had the same under consideration, and directed me to report the same hack and recommend its passage. Cases arise in the Common Pleas Court where great injustice is done by reason of the merest sham and trickery in pleading, that ought not to be tolerated in any court, yet as the law is now held, the court is powerless over such pleading. Take a case like this, an action is brought in that court to recover a judgment on a promissory note; the defendant appears and answers that the note was given to the plaintiff for a tract of land and that he had no title to it, whereby the consideration of the note had failed. The answer, if true, would be good, but it is wholly false. The note was given for personal property, yet the plaintiff must reply and deny the defendant's answer. That bringing into question the title to real estate, the court is ousted of jurisdiction. The plaintiff must dismiss his action, pay the costs and suffer the delay, and all this because that court has no power over false and knavish pleading.

div.head: RIGHT OF REDEMPTION.
div.p: On the motion of Mr. GRIFFIN, the vote of this morning, laying his bill No. 32 on the table, was reconsidered, to enable him to submit a minority report thereon from the Judiciary Committee, which he read, reasoning at length against the adverse report of the majority, and in favor of the bill:

This bill proposes that when real estate is sold on execution, or order of sale, the judgment debtor may have one year to redeem it by paying to the purchaser six per cent, interest and six per cent, penalty, and if the debtor fails to redeem in that time any other judgment creditor may redeem it in three months thereafter - and the officer or person selling the same is to give a certificate of purchase to the purchaser, which is assignable by indorsement in writing, in the same way that a note or bill of exchange is assignable. It also gives the purchase the possession of real estate, and makes him accountable for waste. It thus affords an easy and legal means whereby money may he invested at 12 per cent., and at the same time gives the debtor an opportunity to save himself from ruin should the land not be redeemed at the end of 15 months from the day of sale Upon the presentation of the certificate the officer who sold the same or his representative, is to make a deed, which is final. This is a provision that has been on the statutes of Illinois for twenty years, and Ohio nearly as long. This bill will serve as a temporary relief to the debtor under our present financial crisis.
Messrs. Baird, Merrifield and Colgrove opposed the bill; and Messrs. Nebeker, of Warren and Griffin defended the provisions of the bill.

Mr. STANFIELD trusted the House would not strike out. If the provision were just, it should apply to all public officers alike.
Mr. COLGROVE concurred with Mr. S.

Mr. TURPIE hoped a felony would not be created for such causes, and especially in such terms as embodied in this bill. It made it a felony for a public officer to deposit the public moneys with his wife, as it might be, &c.

Mr. SMITH, of Perry. The committee were satisfied with the bill as it is, &c. The object of the amendment was not to disturb the right of the County Treasurers to use or loan the county funds, leaving him to his local responsibility, and to confine the felony to officers of State. We want to stop this system of loaning the funds of the State, whether with fraudulent intention or not. These moneys belong to the State, and should be kept in the hands of their legal custodians.

Mr. AUSTIN, from the select committee on the Senate assessment bill (S. 142), returned the same with the amendments embraced in the instructions adopted yesterday, and so amended, he recommended the passage of the bill.
