Mr. STANFIELD proposed to amend by striking out from the first section all after the word "situation" in the 43d line, and inserting:

That the appraiser, in estimating the value of such railroads, plank roads, &c., shall take into consideration the location of the same for business, the amount of its gross and net earnings, and the condition of such roads for present and future business, so as to enable him to arrive at the true value of such roads, without reference to their cost or indebtedness.

Mr. STANFIELD. The assessment act of the extra session treats this property as real estate. This bill repeals that act so far as the road beds and iron on the track are concerned, and hence the necessity for this amendment. The difficulty was to equalize appraisements, and there was not now time to perfect a system, and in the mean time he considered the amendment the best that could be done.

Mr. BRANHAM submitted that a fair value could not be attained where the roads are not entirely within our own State. His plan would be to compel the valuation of the road as a whole, and distribute it among the counties in proportion to the distance run, subject to the revision of the Board of Equalization. div.head: IN SENATE
Wednesday Night - in continuation.
div.p: Mr. SLACK had no objection to Mr. Line's amendment, but objected to Mr. Carnahan's.
Mr. CARNAHAN moved to lay Mr. Line's amendment to his amendment on the table.
The motion was rejected - yeas 14, nays 25.
The amendment to the amendment was adopted.
Senators Murray, Slack and Steele favored, and Senators Johnston, Carnahan and March opposed.
Mr. COBB moved to indefinitely postpone the report and pending amendments.

Mr. HEFFREN said he should vote for the postponement, believing that we would not get a vote on the subject to-night nor to-morrow, and knowing that more important legislation was suffering for action.
The motion was rejected - yeas 18, nays 21, as follows:
YEAS - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson, Bennett, Blair, Brown, Cobb, Cooper, Gooding, Heffren, Hendry, Johnston, Jones, Lomax, McClure, O'Brien, Robinson, Thompson and Wilson - 18.
NAYS - Messrs. Bobbs, Carnahan, Conner,Cravens, Culver, Hamilton, Hargrove, Hill, Kinley, Line, March, Miller, Murray, Odell, Rice, Slack, Steele, Stevens, Studabaker, Turner and Wagner - 21.
Mr. BLAIR makes the following explanation of his vote:

Mr. President: I acknowledge the force of the arguments of those who live on the line of the canal for some legislation for their relief, and I would be unwilling from any mere imaginary fear to withhold my vote for any measure that would give them actual and substantial relief. Neither do I believe that any Senators, who are
asking the passage of this bill, would be willing to compromise the interests of the State, or willingly do any act that would compel us to assume the payment of any portion of the debt, which was liquidated by the arrangements made with the bond holders. But I must be allowed to say, that in my opinion they are unnecessarily alarmed By the act of 1846, the State of Indiana conveyed by deed to the Trustees, the Wabash and Erie Canal, "and alt the property, right, title and interest of the State in and to the same, with all its appurtenances," &c., "to have, hold, possess and enjoy the same as fully and absolutely as the State can, or could do."

We can not conceive of language more positive, and, to my mind, it placed the canal, its tolls and revenues completely in the power and control of the Trustees, subject only to the right of the State to compel the faithful execution of the trust, and after twenty years to redeem the certificates. Serious charges have been made by the bond holders, that we have by legislation impaired the obligations of the compact then made, and although I will not for a moment admit the charges to be true, yet I am unwilling by any further legislation - unasked for by them, open up this subject, and give them even an additional argument, whereby they may obtain admission to the Halls of legislation. This bill will be received by them as an acknowledgment, clothed with the sanctity of law, that the revenues of the canal are totally insufficient to fulfill the purposes of the trust. l am, therefore, compelled to vote for its postponement.
Mr. HENDRY makes the following explanation of his vote:

Mr. President: My reasons for voting against this bill are simply these: We have arranged a portion of the State debt with the transfer of this canal to the Trustees, the rights of the bond holders, the State and the Trustees, in whose hands the canal is placed, are closely defined by the act constituting the State debt arrangement. It is by no means clear to me, but what this very act is intended to disconnect the bond holders with the contract. If A, in failing circumstances, agree with B, his creditor, that he will place in the hands of a trustee certain property, the rents of which the trustee shall faithfully apply to the discharge of the indebtedness A, finding the trust property does not pay largely, proposes to the trustee that in case B will give his consent A will divert the rents and profits arising from the trust property to purposes that in the opinion of A will be more advantageous to the trust. B can have no interest in looking to the trust property longer when it does not pay. I am unwilling the State shall take the position that she desires the trust in its original form to cease, and thereby e ther leave the bond holders without any prospect of getting pay at all, or compel them to resuscitate the old debt against the State. When the bond holders demand a change of the trust property they will ask us, and that will be in time to act.
Mr. Carnahan's amendment - striking out the 5th section - was then rejected by yeas 18, nays 18, as follows:
YEAS - Messrs. Beeson, Brown, Carnahan, Cooper,Gooding, Hargrove. Heffren, Hendry, Johnston, Jones, Kinley, Lomax, McClure, March, Robinson, Thompson, Turner and Wilson-18.
NAYS - Messrs. Blair, Cobb, Conner, Cravens, Culver, Hamilton, Hill, Line, Miller, Murray, O'Brien, Odell, Rice, Slack, Steele Stevens, Studabaker and Wagner - 18.
Mr. MARCH moved to concur in the report of the committee, with the following amendment to the sixth section:

p.hi: "The release and all other provisions of this act a made upon the express condition that they are accepted by the bond-holders and others interested or connected, with out enlarging or extending the liabilities of the State."

div.p: The amendment was adopted by consent.
Mr. LINE moved to amend the first section by adding after the word "reserved" the words:

Provided, Nothing in this act shall be so construed as preventing the State of Indiana, by her Legislature, from fully and to its full entent enforcing the contract, as made with the bond-holders by the acts of 1856-7, and the supplementary act of 1857-8."

Mr HEFFREN moved to amend by striking out and inserting a substitute for section 1, renouncing the reserved right of the State to redeem, and agreeing never to exercise it, and recognizing the right of the bond-holders to rent, or lease, or sell said canal and all lands, &c., belonging thereto.

Mr. STEELE said he would never surrender the right to bond holders to do as they please with the canal, and if this amendment is adopted he would vote against the bill. He urged the passage of the original bill, in an earnest and argumentative speech of nearly half an hour.
Mr. GOODING moved to lay the motion to amend on the table.
A division of the question being demanded -
The motion to strike out was not laid on the table - yeas 4, nays 32.That portion of the amendment which proposes to insert was laid on the table - yeas 33, nays 4.
The motion to strike out was not agreed to.
Mr. LOMAX moved to strike out all after the date "1857" in section 6.
On motion by Mr. CONNER the amendment was laid on the table, and the bill was ordered to the third reading to-morrow.
And then the Senate, at 10:23 o'clock, adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: On motion, by Mr. GREEN, the reading of the journal was dispensed with.
Mr. CARNAHAN, from the Finance Committee, returned his bill 53, with an amendment, recommending its passage.
Mr. CARNAHAN opposed the amendment, and hoped the Senate would not concur in the report.
The bill and report were laid on the table.

Mr. SLACK, from the Judiciary Committee, returned the bill (H. R. 142), authorizing the payment, by County Commissioners, of damages sustained by ministerial officers in enforcing the Maine Law, recommending its passage.
Mr. HEFFREN gave notice that be should vote against it from beginning to the ending.
The report was not concurred in.
Mr. ANTHONY offered a substitute for the bill, and spoke in explanation thereof as follows :

Mr. President: - The amendment which I have just offered, to the bill as reported from the committee, makes provision for an indemnity to those who have innocently become victims to the liquor law of 1855, declared by the Supreme Court to be unconstitutional. But the bill as reported, leaves it discretionary with the "Board of County Commissioners" to allow and direct the payment of any losses out of the County Treasury. The amendment proposes to make the payment out of the State Treasury, when the matter has been adjudicated upon, and determined by the judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction. The amendment is introduced because I believe it to be grossly unjust to impose upon the counties the payment of losses caused by the negligent act ot the State in passing, through the instrumentality of the Legislature, an unconstitutional act; the resulting losses were caused by the State, and the State ought to pay them.

Again, it is right and just that those who suffered while executing the process of the court, issued under a law supposed to be constitutional, should be paid. The reported bill leaves it discretionary with the County Commissioners to pay them out of the County Treasury. Now, it is hardly possible that the people of any county would submit to having this discretion exercised by the County Board, or that the Board would exercise it, if they did. Hence I am clearly satisfied the original bill would contribute nothing at all in affording the relief designed.
Mr. BENNETT was opposed to the resolution, but should vote for the bill as reported from the committee.
Mr. HEFFREN was opposed to the report of the committee.
Mr. McLEAN hoped the bill would pass.

On motion by Mr. RICE, Mr. Wagner's bill (187) creating six additional branches of the Bank of the State of Indiana; was passed by yeas 29, nays 19 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson, Bennett, Blair, Brown, Conner. Cooper, Cravens, Craven, Culver, Green, Hamilton, Heffren, Hill, Johnston, Jones, McLcan, Miller, Murray, Odell, Rice, Shoemaker, Steele, Stevens, Studabaker, Tarkington, Thompson, Turner and Wagner - 29.
NAYS - Messrs. Bobbs, Carnahan, Cobb, Conley, Gooding, Hargrove, Hendry, Jennings, Kinley, Line Lomax, McClure, March, O'Brien, Robinson, Slack, Williams and Wilson - 19.
Mr. SHOEMAKER makes the following explanation of his vote:

Sir: Availing myself of the permission of the Senate to give some of the reasons for the vote which I shall give upon this question, I will say that while I would, under no consideration, have voted for the creation of a bank of issue, yet I am satisfied, after mature and careful consideration, that the bill in question ought to pass, and that I should lose sight of the true interest o the people of the State it I should cast my vote against the measure.

The Bank of the State was created by act of the General Assembly of 1855. Subsequently the validity of the charter was tested in the judicial tribunals of the State, and by both the Inferior and Superior Courts the act of incorporation has been pronounced valid. At the present Session an attempt was made to repeal the charter - I voting for the repeal, but the proposition failed, and the bans has now, by both legislative and judicial recognition become an established institution, to continue in existence for the next nineteen years. It would, therefore, be useless: to make, for the present, any additional war upon it, and in that view I take it to be the duty of good legislators to procure such practicable advantages and guards from the bank as may better protect the interests of the people.
The bill in question contains two propositions:
1. An increase of branches.
2. The right of municipal taxation.

It will be observed that it gives no authority for an increase of capital, or an increase of issues, but simply provides that the capital already authorized and judicially recognized shall be better distributed throughout the State.

Unlike the free banks, the security of the holders of the notes of the Bank of the State is in the mutual responsibility of the several branches. If one branch becomes unable to meet its liabilities, then each and all are bound for every deficit. Each additional branch gives to the note holders an additional indorsement or renewed security. The extension of the branches is our only safety against fraud and against insolvency. It is said by the friends of the bank that the people will derive advantage by an increase of places for a secure money deposit, and where money can be obtained by discounts; but of this I will say nothing, because upon this branch of the bill the reason of my vote is that the branches might be extended to other reliable business localities, so as to extend the security of the note holder.

The act of incorporation exempted the bank from municipal taxation, and that exemption has been pronounced by the courts to be constitutional. I believe the exemption to be an out rage upon, and violation of the rights of the people, but it h now too late to contend against that provision. I he exemption is res adjudicata. Our only remedy is by an amendment, and it is that which I voted for.

The Branch at New Albany has a capital of $200,000, and the municipal taxes are about one and a half per centum per annum, making the bank tax for that city, under the bill in question, about $3,000 per annum, or $57,000 for the nineteen years; and the taxes for the other cities and towns where the branches are located are in a similar proportion. The whole bank municipal taxation under the bill can not be much less than $25,000 per annum, or nearly one-half million of dollars for the term of the charter, in addition to the ordinary assessments for grading and paving. And when the question is put, as it has been put by the present measure, as a legislator I can not, on account of my personal hostility to banks, overlook the palpable interests of the people of the several cities and towns of the State, but am constrained by reason of these considerations to vote for the bill.
Mr. STUDABAKER made the following explanation of his vote:

Mr. President - I desire to say in relation to this bill that I shall vote for it, believing it will be as amended, for the best interests of the State. It will have the effect to compel the bank to pay tax on her capital and real estate as individuals pay on their capital and real estate. As the law now stands they pay no corporation tax, and some of the branches so construe the law as to require the individual stock-holders to pay the tax; and many of them being non-residents pay no tax at all. The amendment will compel the bank to pay the tax, and will largely increase the taxable property of the State. And inasmuch as the bill does not increase the capital stock, but permits the removal of a part of the capital of the bank as now constituted, to a more favorable location, in my opinion, the advantages to the people from a fair taxation, will more than compensate for any additional advantages given. I vote for the bill.

Mr. ODELL makes the following explanation of his vote: Mr. President, I vote for this bill for the reason that, if accepted by the Bank Directors, the charter will be so amended that the stock of the bank will be taxable for all purposes the same as other property. The establishment of the additional branches will in no wise increase its capital, but merely permit a change of capital to other localities.

On motion by Mr. SLACK, the Wabash and Erie Canal bill (212), described on page 179 of these Reports, was taken up.
On motion by Mr. WILLIAMS, the 5th section was struck out by consent.
Mr. MILLER demanded the previous question.
There being a second, under its operation the bill was passed by yeas 26, nays 20, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Bobbs, Carnahan, Conley, Conner, Cravens, Culver, Green, Hamilton, Hargrove, Heffren, Hill, Line, McLean, March, Miller, Murray, Odell, Rice, Slack, Steele, Stevens, Studabaker, Tarkington, Turner, Wagner and Williams - 26.
NAYS - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson, Bennett, Blair, Brown, Cobb, Craven, Fisk, Gooding, Bendry, Jennings. Johnston, Jones. Kinley, Lomax, McClure, O'Brien, Robinson, Thompson and Wilson - 20.

Mr. CRAVENS makes the following explanation of his vote: I vote for this bill in its present-shape, for the reason that I regard the bill now
as powerless for harm, and as the representatives of those counties immediately interested in the preservation of the canal are satisfied that it will benefit them without involving the State or trespassing upon the treasury. The bill now only empowers the Trustees to lease out the canal, in whole or in part, upon the express condition that the stockholders in said canal give their consent that it may he so used.

Mr. CULVER makes the following explanation of his vote: This, to the people that I represent, is a very important bill. Every grain producer in the valley would be affected materially by any legislation that would assist to sustain the canal. It is, and if properly maintained will ever be, the cheapest thoroughfare to transmit our grain to the great markets of the country. I have two objects in view in giving the vote that I will upon this question. The first is to avoid any legislation that will make liable the State for any amount of the debt that the bondholders canceled in favor of the State when they agreed to take the work and complete it. If the bond holders made a bad bargain, and find that the consideration they voluntarily agreed to take has not proved a profitable investment, it is a misfortune to them, in which the State of Indiana is not responsible. I will favor no legislation, directly or indirectly, that will obligate the tax payers of this State to pay anything to the owners of the canal. They have received what the Butler bill gave them in a contract of their own creating. Let them reap the rewards or punishments of their own voluntary acts. The other object I have in view is to favor legislation that, 'in the event the bondholders abandon the canal -which I can hardly believe they will-that it can be leased out to parties that will sustain it - allowing the same power that regulates the tariff or tolls that now exist with State and bondholders to remain unimpaired. This will guard any extortionate rate of tolls or retsts from being made by any company or corporation that might lease the canal or any part of it. This is one of the features of this bill now under consideration. This bill merely proposes to the bondholders to lease out the canal, or giving them the power so to do, without, changing any other relation of importance. With this explanation, I vote for the bill.
Mr. LINE makes the following explanation of his vote:

Mr. President: I feel bound, as a Senator, to cast my vote on any and all occasions for any measure that will afford relief to any portion of the citizens of the State, if I can do so without compromising my convictions of right, or without violating my avowals on the subject. Every Senator on this floor will bear me witness with what freedom and frankness I have stated that I would in no way cast a single vote that in its remotest result would involve the State in any liabilities to the canal. I have given the bill as scrutinizing examination as I was capable of doing, and I conclude that by no possible implication or construction, however arbitrary or forced, that any liability can possibly accrue to the State, and in this opinion l am backed by that of the Attorney General on that subject, whose opinion is published at length in to-day's Sentinel. The proposition is a plain, simple one, and it proposes to give the Trustees of the canal, by and with the consent of the bond-holders power to lease the canal to any person or persons,or corporation, that will keep the same in repair or in navigable order, and a forfeiture works to the person or persons, or corporation, if they fail to keep up the same If the bond-holders do not assent to the propositon, the law is wholly inoperative, and the Senators from the counties through which the canal runs say that under the rights given to the Trustees under this law, that the canal can be kept, up; and hoping their anticipations may be fully realized under the law, I shall vote for the bill. I vote aye.
Mr. TARKINGTON makes the following explanation of his vote:

I cannot at any time consent to give a vote that will in any way make the State liable for the debt of the canal. It is not, however, believed that this bill does create any liability in any manner whatever on the part of the State, but will be of immense value to a large portion of the taxpayers in the Valley of the Wabash, and on the line of the canal; and without such an act as this, the canal must be abandoned to the great injury of many citizens of this State. All the provisions of the bill are made upon the express condition that they are asserted to by the bond holders and other persons interested in the trust, without changing the liability of the State to them in any respect whatever.

div.head: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
REPORTED BY ARIEL DRAPIER/
div.p: The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from the Trustees of the Wabash and Erie Canal, responding to a resolution of the House of Representatives, submitted by Mr. Wheeler on the 22d inst., which was referred to the Committee on Canals.

ment, not exceeding one year,] was passed the final reading - yeas 77, nays 0.

Mr. Stanfield's bill (208) to provide for the case of the removal from office by death, resignation, or inability to serve, of both the Governor and Lieutenant Governor - declaring that the Secretary of State shall act as Governor - was passed the final reading - yeas 78, nays 2.

Mr. Mellett's bill (209) to amend the 38th section of the act defining felonies, &c., [with reference to professional gamblers - making the said section consistent with section 74 - taking away the felonious character of keeping a billiard table-] failed for want of a constitutional majority - yeas 46, nays 42.

Mr. Harney's bill (227) to amend the act of May 20, 1852, authorizing the locating, laying out and vacating of lanes, alleys, streets, and squares, making out and recording plats of towns, providing for change of name of towns, &c., [making the act applicable to towns not incorporated,] was passed the final reading - yeas 79, nays 0.

Mr. Waterman's bill (228) to provide for the collection of the surplus revenue fund belonging to the counties of Dekalb, Lake and Wells, on loan to the State Treasury, and for the payment of said fund over to the treasuries of said counties - was passed the final reading - yeas 83, nays 0.

Mr. Waterman's bill (212) prescribing part of the duties of County Auditors and Treasurers, and Township Trustees and Supervisors of Roads, in relation to road tax, and providing penalties for any failure on the part of said officers to discharge any of their duties as prescribed in this act[to save the expense of collecting road tax receipts,] failed for lack of a constitutional majority - yeas 45, nays 36

div.head: ASSESSMENTS.
div.p: Mr. Hartley's bill (213) to amend the 33d section of the Assessment Act of June 21,1852, [so that persons subject to taxation may deduct their indebtedness from solvent claims, moneys on hand and personal property, instead of as now from solvent claims,] coming up -
Mr. STANFIELD proposed to recommit to a select committee with instructions to amend so as to make banks pay the taxes on their stock.
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren. There will be a bill to meet that case.
Mr. STANFIELD would reach non-resident stockholders.

Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone. The instructions could not be incorporated without a repeal of the 15th section of the charter of the Bank of the State. The provisions of the bill referred to were more salutary than the gentleman's instructions.
Mr. STANFIELD withdrew the proposition.
Mr. HARNEY proposed to recommit, with instructions to add:
Provided, That when a County Treasurer shall fail to make a settlement at the proper time, he shall forfeit two per cent, on the amount due to the State Treasury.
The motion and instructions were agreed to.
Mr. PROSSER proposed to add to the instructions:
Amend by striking out from the bill all that relates to deducting indebtedness out of moneys on hand or at interest, or out of personal property. [Leaving the law as it now is in this respect.]
Mr. MARTIN proposed:
Strike out all that relates to deducting indebtness from money on hand, personal property and money loaned.
Mr. HUN1ER supported Mr. Prosser's instructions. Without such a provision, the bill would reduce the amount of taxables in the State to the amount of $150 000,000.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Wayne, and Mr. RITTER could not appreciate the wisdom of double taxing.
Mr. MURRAY. Under such a provision the agriculturists would have to pay the revenue.
Mr. PROSSER supported the instructions and replied to objections.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, opposed the instructions, giving examples.
Mr. CLEMENTS, when in order, desired to instruct the committee to the following effect:

Inquire whether the railroads of the State, and other corporations, that are indebted in an amount equal to the value of such railroads or the assets of such corporations, would not be exempt from taxation under the operation of the bill.

Instruct the committee to add an additional specification requiring each tax-payer to state under oath what amount of profits he has realized during the preceding year, from property for which he may be taxed.
Mr. BOYD had prepared instructions, allowing us to take our indebtedness which we owe within the State, from our solvent claims, and which he would offer at the proper time.
On motion by Mr. MURRAY, Mr. Martin's amendment was laid on the table.
Mr. HARTLEY made an ineffectual motion to lay the instructions on the table.
Mr. BOYD now submitted his instructions.
On motion by Mr. PROSSER, they were laid on the table.

On motion by Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, the vote on Mr Harney's motion for reference, was reconsidered, and then, on further motion, the bill and proposed amendments were laid on the table without a division.

div.head: THE CANADA THISTLE.
div.p: Mr. Wildman's bill (224), to prevent the spread of the Canada thistle, prescribing penalty for permitting the same to mature on the public highways, and for selling the seed then of mingled with other seeds,- was passed the final reading - yeas 59, nays 15.
Mr. STANFIELD, (for Mr. Branham), moved to reconsider this vote.
Mr. COMSTOCK hoped it would not be reconsidered.
Mr. BRANHAM. It would work a hardship on the Supervisors.
Mr. SCOTT. It was bad policy to accumulate criminal offences.
Mr. ROW. A similar law was well thought of in Ohio.
Mr. KNOWLTON. This thistle almost destroyed the farming land. On his motion, the motion to reconsider was laid on the table.

Mr. Durham's bill (214), to amend the 441st section of the practice act of June 18, 1852, so as not to compel sheriffs to levy on real and personal estate as designated by the judgment debtor, [when the amount is less than $100,] - was passed the final reading - yeas 60, nays 17.
Mr. CLEMENTS moved to reconsider this vote. The bill would oppress the poor. All the land and personal property of the poor man, was subject to be taken without the right of designation, &c.
Mr. MELLETT supported the provisions of the bill, and gave examples.
The vote was reconsidered - yeas 56, nays 28: and then
On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the bill was laid on the table without a division.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Mr. RYNEARSON, asked, but was refused leave, to report from the Committe on Agriculture, bills in relation to the acceptance of public lands for a State Agricultural College; and the Speaker pursued -

div.head: THE CALENDAR.
div.p: Mr. Stanfield's bill (272), defining the statutory meaning of the word "fence," [it includes hedges and ditches,] was passed the third and last reading in the House of Repesentatives - yeas 71, nays 1.
Mr. Clements' bill (268), prescribing the times of Common Pleas in the counties of Gibson, Posey, Vanderburg, Warrick, Knox, Daviess, Pike and Martin, coming up -

On motion by Mr. BLYTHE, (by unanimous consent,) it was amended, verbally, by transposing "Pike" and "Daviess," and so the bill passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 83, nays 0.
Mr Clements' bill (267), prescribing the time, and the length of term, of holding the Circuit Court in the third Judicial Circuit, coming up -
Mr. BLYTHE, (by unanimous consent), proposed, and the House adopted, an amendment similar to that above taken, and so this bill was passed the final reading - yeas 84, nays 0.

Mr. Brotherton's bill (266), to provide for the transfer from the Court of Common Pleas certain business, wherein the Common Pleas have no jurisdiction, was passed the final reading - yeas 84, nays 0.
Mr. Snyder's bill (257), to provide for the formation of new counties; the representation thereof, and the administration of justice therein, coming up -
On motion by Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, it was ordered to be committed to the Committee on the Judiciary, with instructions
To amend, so that no new county shall be formed without the consent of a majority of the voters of the county or counties, out of which said new county is proposed to be formed.
Mr. Davis' bill (262), to repeal the act to prevent railroad companies from changing their depots, except on conditions, &c., approved March 4,1853, was passed the final reading - yeas 90, nays 1.

Mr. Speaker Gordon's bill (276) to amend section five of the act to organize a Supreme Court, and prescribing certain duties of the judges thereof, approved May 13, 1852, was passed the final reading - yeas 83, nays 5.

Mr. Baird's bill (158) to provide for the management and disposition of estates of persons who have mysteriously disappeared and deserted their families, without having made provision for the settlement of their estates or the support of their families, was passed the final reading-yeas 60, nays 22.
Mr. Turpie's bill (177) to amend section two of the act to authorize the relocation of county seats, coming up -
Mr. STANFIELD. It requires making proof of the number of inhabitants asking for removal by affidavit.
On motion by Mr. STANLEY, it was recommitted with instructions, viz:

Amend by striking out all after the word "county," in the second line, and insert: ''Shall be ascertained only by reports verified by affidavits of the Trustee of each township, who shall make out a correct list of the legal voters of their several townships, to which shall be attached the affidavits of said Trustees, showing the correctness of such list.
Mr. Davis' bill (255), to abolish the complete record of cases in the Supreme Court, was rejected on the final reading - yeas 37, nays 50.

Mr. Colgrove's bill (256), to amend the 71st section of the justice's act of June 9,1852, was passed the final reading - yeas 66, nays 13 [The execution defendant may replevy his $300 worth of exemptions upon affidavit.]

Mr. Nelson's bill (253), to provide for the transfer of real estate for taxes on the books ot the County Auditor, and preserving the chain of title in the Recorder's office, was passed the final reading - yeas 81, nays 4.

On the "motion of Mr. Speaker GORDON, (Mr. Davis in the Chair,) the vote above rejecting Mr. Davis' bill (255), was reconsidered, and the same being again submitted to vote, it was passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 68, nays 17.
Mr. Stanfield's bill (217), in relation to the levy of execution or attachment on partnership property, for the individual debt of one of the partners, was parsed the final reading - yeas 78, nays 5.

Mr. Hamilton, of Boone's, bill (233) to amend the third section of the act providing for the election, and prescribing certain duties of county surveyors, approved June 17, 1852, was passed the final reading - yeas 54, nays 26. [It requires service of notice, 10 days, and notice by publication 30 days.]

Mr. Hamilton, of Boone's, bill (229) to amend the 76th section of the misdemeanor act of June 14, 1852, (corrects the law against stealing pumpkins, melons and standing corn, inserting the words, "the property of another person,") failed for want of a constitutional majority - yeas 49, nays 33.
Mr. Harrison's bill (155) to authorize appeals from the Circuit to the Supreme Court in contested election cases, was passed the final reading - yeas 71, nays 13.

Mr. Snyder'sbill (221) to fix the time of holding the Circuit Court in the 12th Judicial Circuit, regulating the terms thereof, and repealing all acts conflicting therewith, was passed the final reading - yeas 87, nays 0.

Mr. Knowlton's bill (225), to amend the 94th section of the assessment act of June 21 1852, [leaves it in the discretion of the County Courts to say whether the County Treasurer shall visit the election precincts for the collection of taxes,] was passed the final reading - yeas 66, nays 20.

Mr. Davis' bill (258), to repeal the 5th section of the act of February 23, 1853, to authorize railroad companies to consolidate their stock with companies in this and adjoining States, &c., [to permit railroad companies terminating their roads on the Ohio river, to change the location of their depots,] was passed the final reading - yeas 88, nays 1.

Mr. Early's bill (300), providing that certain notices of sale, and other legal notices therein named, shall be published in a newspaper at the county seat, in all cases where there is a newspaper published at the county seat - was passed the final reading - yeas 81, nays 3.

On motion by Mr. DAVIS, the bill (S. 112) to amend the city corporation law, of March 9, 1857, and to provide for a penalty on the collection of taxes remaining deliquent in such cities on the third Monday in March, 1857, with the engrossed House amendments thereto, was taken up.

Mr. EDWARDS asked unanimous consent to amend, by striking out that section of the amendments which requires railroad companies to light and guard the street crossings of their tracks, and it was so ordered.

Mr. Speaker GORDON (Mr. Blythe in the Chair) said, that, under the present law the percentage for delinquent taxes could not be collected till the time of sale, in January. This bill makes it collectable on the first Monday in March previous.
Mr. EDWARDS. Does the bill affect cities incorporated under special charters?
Mr. Speaker GORDON. Only those organized under the general law.
The bill, as amended, passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas 68, nays 6.
The House then, at 5:15 o'clock, adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: On motion by Mr. ANTHONY, the reading of the journal was dispensed with.

div.head: THE TREASURY BILL.
div.p: On motion by Mr. ANTHONY, the bill (H. R. 195) to provide for a Treasury system for the State of Indiana, was read through, and under a dispensation read by title the second time.
Mr. HEFFREN moved to refer the bill to the Committee on Finance.
The motion was rejected - yeas 21, nays 23.
Mr. CARNAHAN moved to strike out so much as authorizes the taking of paper money.
Mr. HEFFREN moved to amend the amendment by striking all that part of the bill which allows the notes of any bank to be received for taxes.
Mr. WAGNER wanted neither an exclusive gold and silver currency for taxes, nor a shin-plaster currency. He would be satisfied with gold and silver and the issues of legal banks.
Mr. ANTHONY said the proposition was impracticable.
Mr. CARNAHAN accepted the amendment to the amendment.
Mr. CRAVENS [Mr. Rice in the chair] thought it radically wrong for the Legislature to furnish the people with a currency and then refuse to take it in payment for taxes.

Mr. MARCH was in favor of a sub-treasury system and of having the taxes paid in specie, after a time: but if he could not get that, he was in favor of striking out all in the bill which refers to this subject.
Mr. COBB was also in favor of a sub-treasury system, and of having the taxes paid in gold and silver.
Mr. TARKINGTON said, to apply the sub-treasury system in a community like ours is but to oppress it with additional taxation.
Mr. HENDRY opposed the provision which requires taxes to be paid in the specie paying banks of the State.
Mr. SLACK was in favor of a sub-treasury system: and hoped the amendment would be adopted.
Mr. ANTHONY opposed the specie system of a sub-treasury, was in favor of the bill as reported from the House, and addressed the Senate in support of his position.
Mr. BOBBS was opposed to the specie paying system.
Mr. BENNETT moved to lay the amendment on the table.
The motion was agreed to - yeas 27, nays 19 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Anthony, Beeson, Bennett, Blair, Bobbb, Brown, Conner, Cooper, Cravens, Craven, Culver, Green, Hamilton, Johnston, Jones, Lomax, McLean, Murray, Odell, Rice, Robinson, Steele, Stevens, Tarkington, Thompson, Turner and Wagner - 27.
NAYS - Messrs. Carnahan, Cobb, Conley, Fisk, Gooding, Hargrove, Heffren, Hendry, Jennings, Kinley, Line, McClure, March, Miller, O'Brien, Shoemaker, Slack, Studabaker and Wilson - 19.
Mr. JONES explains his vote as follows:

Mr. President - I shall vote against the amendment proposed by the gentleman from Posey, notwithstanding I regard it as right. I would prefer a specie sub-treasury system, and would most cheerfully support it had I a hope that it could pass, but the action of this and the other branch of this Legislature has convinced me that an effort to secure the passage of a specie sub-treasury here would be wasting time for no good purpose. Regarding the present treasury system as highly objectionable and insecure, I shall vote for the bill as it comes from the House - yielding my own preferences, and taking what I regard as the next best proposition.
Mr. MILLER explains his vote as follows:
I am opposed to the provisions of sec. 3 of this bill, and I must, therefore vote for the pending amendments, so, if possible, to get the bill in a shape that I can vote for it.

Section 3 discriminates in favor of the banks of Indiana for the payment of taxes. I have no objections to the taking of good Indiana bank paper in payment for revenues, but I can not see why if the revenue is to be paid in paper currency the notes of solvent specie paying banks of other States can not as well be taken in payment for taxes. In my part of the State a great deal of eastern as well as Kentucky money is in circulation, which is just as good as Indiana, and I do not wish to have a person pay a premium in order to get money with which to pay his tax.
[A message from the Governor announced his approval and signature of the bill (H. R. 131) to secure dues from corporations.]

Mr. HEFFREN moved to amend so as to require the State Treasurer to send home for redemption the notes of all the banks which he is permitted to receive, immediately after receiving the State revenue from the county Treasurers.
Senators Anthony and Miller opposed.
Mr. BEESON moved to lay the amendment on the table.
The motion was agreed to, by yeas 25, nays 21 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Anthony. Beeson, Bennett. Blair, Bobbs, Brown. Conner, Cravens, Craven, Culver, Green, Hamilton, Hendry, Johnston, Jones, McLean, Murray, Rice, Steele, Stevens, Studabaker, Tarkington, Thompson, Turner and Wagner - 25.
NAYS - Messrs. Carnahan, Cobb, Conley, Fisk, Gooding, Hargrove, Heffren, Jennings, Kinley, Line, Lomax, McClure, March, Miller, O'Brien, Odell, Robinson, Shoemaker, Slack, Williams and Wilson - 21.
Mr. JONES moved to read the bill the third time now, and upon that motion demanded the previous question.
The demand was not seconded - yeas 20, nays 25.
Mr. SLACK moved to amend so as to require all payments for taxes after the 1st of September, 1860, to be paid in specie.
Mr. BOBBS moved to amend the amendment by striking out so much of the bill as relates to the kind of currency the Treasurer is to receive.
The amendment to the amendment was laid on the table by yeas 25, nays 21.
The amendment was also laid on the table by yeas 26, nays 20, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs Anthony, Beeson, Bennett, Blair, Bobbs, Brown, Conner, Cravens, Craven, Culver, Green, Hamilton, Johnston, Jones, Lomax, McLean, Murray, Odell, Rice, Robinson, Steele, Stevens, Tarkington, Thompson, Turner and Wagner - 26.
NAYS - Messrs. Carnahan, Cobb, Conley, Fisk, Gooding, Hargrove, Heffren, Hendry, Jennings, Kinley, Line, McClure, March, Miller, O'Brien, Shoemaker, Slack, Studabaker, Williams and Wilson - 20.
Mr. COBB moved as a substitute for the bill, Mr. Shoemaker's bill No. 90.
Mr. GREEN moved to lay the substitute on the table.
The motion was agreed to by yeas 28, nays 18.The question then recurred on Mr. Jones' motion to read the bill the third time.
Mr. CRAVENS demanded the previous question.
The demand was seconded by yeas 27, nays 18
The bill was then read the third time - yeas 27 nays 19 and passed by yeas 28, nays 18 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Anthony. Beeson, Bennett, Blair, Brown, Conner, Cooper, Cravens, Craven, Culver. Goading, Green, Hamilton, Johnston, Jones, Kinley, Line, McLean, Murray, Odell, Rice, Robinson, Steele, Stevens, Studabaker, Turner, Wagner and Williams - 28.
NAYS - Messrs. Bobbs, Carnahan, Cobb, Conley, Fisk, Hargrove, Heffren, Hendry, Jennings, Lomax, McClure, March, Miller, O'Brien, Slack, Tarkington, Thompson and Wilson - 18.
Mr. CONLEY explains his vote as follows:

Mr. President - Sir: Not having had an opportunity of making any remarks on the bill under consideration - from the fact that the gag has been applied to Senators by the friends of the bill, thereby precluding myself, as well as other Senators who desired to be heard, from giving reasons in opposition to the bill, I therefore claim the right to be heard in defence of the vote I am called upon to give. Sir, I am as much in favor of curtailing the expenses of the State government as any Senator on this floor. But sir, I can never give my consent, so long aa I hold a seat in this body as a Senator, to the passage of any law which has for its object the putting of power into the hands of the monied sharks of the Stale of Indiana. The bill provides that the taxes may be collected in the notes of the banks of this State. I have repeatedly stated on this floor, and it has not been denied, that there is no security whatever to the bill holder under the provisions of the charter for the Bank of the State of Indiana, except the individual liability of the stockholders. I can not therefore give my consent to the passage of this, or any other bill similar in its provisions. I can not give my consent to the passage of any law which collects the taxes in the notes of that or any other bank where there is no security to the bill holder. This bill provides that the Treasurer of State shall receive said notes for taxes, and that he shall not have power to exchange it, notwithstanding fears may be entertained of the failure of such bank. I can never give my consent to the passage of any law requiring the Treasurer of State to keep revenues in the vaults of the State, unless the revenues are collected in gold and silver.

Mr. GOODING makes the following explanation of his vote: He should vote for the bill because under its provisions the paper of the bank of the State of Indiana could not be received - that institution never having been regularly organized; and as he regarded the bill the best that could be passed under the circumstances.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Mr. CONNER, by leave, introduced a bill (252), to provide for the maintenance of plank roads, where they have been sold by the judgment of any court; which, under a dispensation, was read by title the second time, and referred to the Committee on Corporations.

Mr. BOBBS introduced bill (253), to amend section 3 of an act to prevent the distruction, or the injury of animals, or the distruction of human life by railroads, approved May 11, 1852; which was read by title the second time and referred to the Judiciary Committee

Mr. SHOEMAKER introduced a bill (254>, supplemental to an act to provide for a more uniform mode of doing township business, approved February 18, 1859; which was read the first, second, and third times, and passed by yeas 40, nays 3.

Mr. SLACK presented a petition from 200 citizens of Huntington county on the subject of the Wabash and Erie Canal; which was referred to the Committee on Canals and Internal Improvements, without reading.
On motion by Mr. WILSON, Mr. Tarkington 's bill (166) the special order for this hour, was laid on the table.
Mr. Hill's 61, was laid on the table.

Mr. Wallace's (119) to amend section 5 of an act concerning the partition of land, was passed by yeas 41, nays 0.

Mr. Line's 121 was recommitted.

Mr. Blair's (127), to amend sections 18, 25, and 26, of an act regulating the apportionment of real estate, approved May 14, 1852, was passed by yeas 40, nays 4.

Mr. LINE, from a select committee thereon , returned his bill (121), to protect exhibitors of articles or animals at agricultural fairs, and to punish offenders against certain rules of agricultural societies, recommending passage with an amendment

Mr, WAGNER, from a select committee, thereon, returned Mr. Conley's (99) to provide for the protection of wild game, with amendment, recommending passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill failed under the operation of the previous question - yeas 18, nays 27.
Mr. SLACK, from the select committee thereon, returned his bill 255, recommending passage.
The report was concurred in and the bill passed by yeas 34, nays 10.
Mr. Green's 128 failed - yeas 8, nays 36.
Mr. Bennett's (129) declaring the having carnal knowledge of insane women a felony: was passed by yeas 43, nays 1.
Mr. Cooper's 130, was laid on table.
Mr. Green's (132) for the protection of the Sabbath, and repealing an act of the same title approved February 28, 1855; was passed by yeas 33, nays 9.
Mr. Craven's (136) for the recovery of damages from any officer of the State who shall illegally charge, demand or collect more than is legally due him as fees: was passed by yeas 43, nays 0.
Mr. Gooding's (138), fixing the salary of State Librarian, and dispensing with the assistant and a clerk, was passed by yeas 37, nays 3.
Mr. Cobb's (139), for the protection of side walks in unincorporated towns or villages, and prescribing punishment of persons injuring or obstructing the same, failed to pass by yeas 24, nays 13.

Mr. Green's 243 and 244, referred to Senators Green, March, Studabaker, Cobb and Anthony.

div.head: PETITIONS.
div.p: By Mr. KNOWLTON: memorial of the city of Logansport, for legislation in regard to the power of such city to change, alter, amend or terminate such city government, which was referred to Messrs. Knowlton, BIythe and Davis.
By Mr. SNYDER: of E. M. Chord, and others, of Jasper county, for a certain State road, in Jasper county, south of Renssellaer, &c., which was referred to the Committee on Roads.

Mr. COMSTOCK, from the Committee on Agriculture, reported (upon petitions referred,) in favor of the passage of an act, authorizing commutation money for working the roads, &c., and in connection therewith -

Mr. HARTLEY had leave to introduce a bill (No. 332) to amend the 10th section of the act to provide for the election of Supervisors of highways, and prescribing the duties of county and township officers in relation thereto, which was passed the first reading. [It authorizes commutation for working the roads; when judgement is obtained for neglecting to work, no exemption or appraisement laws shall prevent collection, &c.]
Mr. NEBEKER, of Warren, submitted the following, which was adopted.

WHEREAS, It is believed that large sums of money are, and have been due the State Treasury for different lengths of time, from different persons, who have heretofore held State and County offices, and from banks and individuals as drawers and indorsee of bills of exchange or otherwise; which seems are in danger of being lost by the statute of limitation or otherwise. Therefore, be it

Resolved, By the Senate and and House of Representatives of the State of Indiana, That the Auditor of State be instructed to ascertain without delay, and as near as possible the exact amount legally due the State Treasury from every person who has heretofore been an officer, agent or trustee, of any funds rightfully belonging to State, from every source, and in like manner the amount that may be due the state from any bank corporation or company, or from any individual for money had or received, or as drawer or indorser of any note, debt or bill of exchange in favor of the State that has been protested for non-payment, and to make an immediate demand from such ex-officer, agents, trustees, or companies for the amounts respectively found due from each; and in case of failure or refusal to pay the same, to make out a certified copy of the amount due from such ex-officers, agents trustees, person or persons, banks or corporations, or companies, so failing or refusing to pay, and to place the same in the hands of the Attorney General, who is hereby instructed to bring suit for the recovery of the same without delay.

Mr. STANLEY, from the Committee on County and Township Business, returned Mr. Turpie's bill (177), to amend the second section of the act for the relocation of county seats, with amendments in obedience to the instructions proposed by him, and adopted by the House yesterday, and, so amended, they recommended the passage thereof.
The amendment wart adopted.
Mr. DOUGHERTY moved to refer to the Judiciary Committee.

Mr. STANFIELD. If the object of reference is to prevent this act from being taken as a repeal of the act of the last session, for the relocation ot the county seat of Perry, that might be obviated by an additional section.
He submitted a section for this purpose: to prevent the repeal by construction of the said act, which was adopted; and the amendments were ordered to be engrossed.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL COLLEGES.
div.p: Mr. RYNEARSON, from the Committe on Agriculture, returned sundry papers on the subject of accepting the Congressional donation of public lands [20,000 acres to each Representative and Senator in Congess, and 20,000 acres to each Representative to which the State shall be entitled under the next census and apportionment to each of the land States, and the same proportionate amount in land scrip to the States in which there is no public land,] to be applied to the erection of colleges for the encouragement of agriculture and the mechanic arts - and reported two bills founded thereon, entitled:

A bill (No. 333), accepting on the part of the State of Indiana, certain public lands, donated to such States of the Union as shall accept and provide for the erection of colleges for the support of agriculture and the mechanic arts, and providing for notice of the same to be given by the Governor of the State to the Secretary of the Interior:

A bill (334), defining the duties of the Auditor and Treasurer of State in the management and security of the trusts arising from the donation of certain public lands for the erection of colleges for the encouragement of Agriculture and the mechanic arts, and providing for the election of a Board of Regents for the government of
such institution , and defining their powers and duties, &c.
Which were passed the first reading.

Mr. MANSFIELD, from the Committee on Education, reported on the petition from Sullivan county, with reference to the return of the $188,000 of the School Fund in the State's hands, and the distribution of the Sinking Fund among the counties, with information that the Committee on Ways and Means were engaged on a bill for the return of said fund.
Mr. BLACK, from the select committee thereon, returned Mr. Knowlton's bill (278), fixing court time in the 11th Judicial Circuit, recommending indefinite postponement.
The report was concurred in.
Mr. SHERMAN, from the select, committee on Mr. Collier's bill (310), to regulate the practice of Medicine and Surgery, returned the same with verbal amendments, recommending passage.
The amended bill was ordered to be engrossed.

Mr. RITTER, from the same committee, returned Mr. Kempf's bill (312), prohibiting unqualified persons from practicing the science of Medicine and Surgery, and the Pharmaceutical Art, recommending that it be laid on the table.
The report was concurred in.
Mr. DOBBINS, from the select committee thereon, returned his bill (304), with an amendment by substitute.
The amendment was adopted, and the bill, as amended was ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. CARR, from the select committee thereon, returned his bill (314), to repeal the 73d section of the assessment act of 1852, with a favorable recommendation.
It was ordered to engrossment.
Mr. CAVINS, from the select committee thereon, returned Mr. Hunter's bill (125) for protection of railroad tracks, &c., with amendments comformable to instructions reported yesterday.
The amendments were adopted and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. STILES, from the Committee on Corporations, returned Mr. Edward's bill (269), concerning enclosures, trespassing animals, fence enclosing railroads, &c , with an amendment, adding these words:
Provided, That whenever any fence shall be destroyed by fire communicated by any locomotive, the same shall be rebuilt by the railroad company owning such locomotive.
The amendment was adopted and the bill ordered to be engrossed.
On motion by Mr. STANFIELD, the bill was considered as engrossed and put upon its final reading.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, objected to the farmer being compelled to keep up half the fence. It was a scheme to avoid railroad responsibility, &c.
Mr. PARKS concurred with Mr. H.

Mr. BRANHAM'S experience and knowledge in the case, was that more stock was killed where the railroad was fenced. Assuredly railroad men would not kill stock if they could help it. It was the jeopardy of lives, and the loss in costs and damages on their part. There was the best, guarantee in the world that engineers would not run over stock if they can help it. This bill allowed the farmer to enclose up to the track itself. It gave no immunity for killing stock. It was directly for the advantage of the farmer adjoining the track. Stock killed generally belongs, not to those adjoining the track, but to trespassers beyond. Why not give the company the same right accorded to individuals, &c.?

Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone. We do treat railroads as individuals. We tell them to keep a good and sufficient fence around their unruly engine. The bill, makes the owner of the field or enclosure a partner in the fence, and so relieves the road from the responsibility for killing stock, because the fence is not kept up.

Mr. MANSFIELD considered the development of the resources of the country by railroads, and the duty of the Legislature to assume the effort or the company to avoid running over stock. He claimed that the provision of the bill requiring the farmer to keep up one-half the fence, was simply what is right between man and man, &c.
Mr. KEEFER. The bill would compel the farmer to join in keeping up a fence for the track through his field, whether he desired to do so or not.
Mr. BRANHAM. Such was not the intention.
Mr. MURRAY. By the present, law the railroad is compelled to fence.
He could not vote for a bill that would compel the farmer to keep up half the fence.
Mr. POWER. If the gentleman was right, he could not vote for such a bill.
Mr. EDWARDS asked unanimous consent to enable him to amend the bill as follows:

p.hi: "Provided, That where any railroad runs through an enclosure, the company owning it shall build the fence thereof through such enclosure, and maintain the same at its own proper expense."

div.p: He said the sole object of the bill was to have the fence kept in repair, for the security of life and property. That was the object of the bill, without this proposed amendment.
Mr. HALL, of Rush, was willing to extend even handed justice to the roads. The amendment, of the gentleman from Vigo obviated all the difficulty in his mind.
Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, moved to recommit, with instructions to amend as proposed by the gentleman from Vigo, which he subsequently withdrew.
Mr. SULLIVAN moved to lay on the table; but withdrew the motion for the final vote on the bill without the Amendment, which resulted yeas 50, nays 42.
So the bill failed for lack of a constitutional majority: and then -
On motion by Mr. EDWARDS, the bill was recommitted to Messrs. Edwards, Branham, Parrett, Jeffries and Gregory, with the above instructions submitted by him
Mr. DOUGHERTY, from the select committee thereon, returned his bill (321) declaring it usury for banks to charge for exchange, recommending passage.
It was ordered to be engrossed.

Mr. CLEMENTS, from the select committee thereon, returned his bill (313) fixing the salaries of the Trustees of the Wabash and Erie
Canal, without amendment, recommending passage.
It was ordered to be engrossed.

Mr. MARTIN, from the select committee thereon, returned the bill (S. 102) redistricting the State for Common Pleas purposes, with an amendment by substitute (21 districts, judge's salary $1,000 - repealing sections 29 and 38 of the Common Pleas act.)
The amendment was ordered to be engrossed, and the bill passed to the third reading.
On motion by Mr. MARTIN, the amendments were considered as engrossed
Mr. SHULL proposed to recommit with instructions to strike out "1,000" and insert "500."
Mr. DAVIS. It was impossible to make all the districts acceptable. The bill would save $15,000 a year. Against his habit, he was almost ready to move the previous question.

Mr. AUSTIN proposed to amend the instructions by striking out "$500" and insert "$1,200-" He said: The argument against the present Common Pleas system has been that the present, salary is insufficient to secure men of competent ability to discharge the duties. I submit then whether, when we increase the labors, to double the present, and only increase the salary two hundred dollars, will it not bring the system into disrepute. I desire that the amendment be made, that I may be able to vote for the bill; without it, I will be compelled to vote against it.

Mr. MURRAY demanded the previous question, and under its force, the amendments to the instructions were rejected, the House refused to recommit, and the bill, as amended, passed the House o Representatives - yeas 69, nays 25 - as follows:

YEAS. - Messrs Blythe, Bowman, Boyd, Boxley, Brotherton, Carr, Cavins, Clark, Clements, Collier, Comstock, Cotton, Davidson, Davis, Dobbins, Dougherty, Durham, Devol, Early, Eastham, Fordyce, Gregory, Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hall of Rush, Hamilton of Boone, Hamilton of Wayne, Harrison, Hunter, Jeffries, Johnston, Jordan, Keefer, Kelly, Kempf, McLain, Massey, Merrifield, Miller, Murray, Martin, Nelson, Parks, Parrett, Prosser, Ritter, Robinson, Row, Rynerson, Scott, Sherrmn, Shields, Smith of Miami, Smith of Perry, Stanfield, Stiles, Sullivan, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of Elkhart, Treadway, Usrey, Waterman, Wheeler, Whetzel, Whiteman, Wildman, Wood and Mr. Speaker. - 69.

NAYS. - Messrs Austin, Black, Clayton, Colgrove, Edwards, Gifford, Harney, Hartley, Jones, Knowlton, Lawhead, Lewis, Major, Mansfield, Mellett, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Newton, Power, Shockley, Shull, Snyder, Stanley, Thompson of Madison and Turpie - 25.
So the bill passed with an amendment of title "repealing all acts conflicting therewith."

Mr. EDWARDS, from the select committee thereon, returned the bill No. 269, amended in accordance with his instructions above. The bill, he said, requires the person using the rail road fence to pay one-half the expense of repairs of so much of the fence as he uses. But where it runs through an enclosure the railroad pays all the expense of construction and repairs.
The amendment was adopted and ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. GRIFFIN would not compel a man who had donated a hundred feet strip of his grounds to keep up one-half of the fence also.
The bill was lost on its final reading, by yeas 42, nays 50, as follows:

YEAS - Messrs Baird, Blythe, Bovd, Branham, Cavins, Clayton, Clements, Collier, Cotton, Davidson, Davis, Eastham, Edwards. Fordyce, Gifford, Gregory, Hall of Grant, Hamilton of Wayne, Harney, Harrison , Jeffries, Johnston, Kempf, Lawhead, McLain, Mansfield, Mellett, Miller, Martin, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Nelson, Prosser, Ritter, Rynearson, Sherman, Smith of Miami, Stanfield, Stiles, Treadway, Whetzel and Mr. Speaker - 42.

NAYS - Messrs. Austin, Black, Bowman, Boxley, Brotherton, Carr, Clark, Comstock, Dobbins, Dougherty, Durham, Early, Griffin, Hall of Rush, Hamilton of Boone, Hancock, Hartley, Hunter, Jones, Jordan, Keefer, Kelly, Lewis, Major, Massey, Merrifield, Murray, Newton, Parks, Power, robinson, Row, Scott, Shields, Shockley, Shull, Snyder, Stanley, Sullivan, Summers, Tebbs, Thompson of Elkhart, Thompson of Madison, Turpie, Usrey, Waterman, Wheeler, Whiteman. Wildman and Wood - 50.
Mr. STANFIELD, by leave, submitted the following, which was adopted:

Resolved, That a select committee of one from each of the districts named in the bill, reducing the number of the Common Pleas districts, be appointed for the purpose of preparing and presenting to this House a bill fixing the time of holding courts in said districts.

The SPEAKER announced the committee, viz.: Messrs. Stanfield, Blythe, Eastham, Jones, Davis, Gregory, Austin, Collier. Hunter, Martin, Baird, Mellett, Hamilton of Boone, Harney, Harrison, Turpie, Merrifield, Colgrove, Wildman, McLain and Knowlton.

Mr. Hunter's bill (122) to authorize the holders of unauthorized paper currency to sue for and recover if the issuers of such unauthorized paper currency "for money had and received," making the paper evidence of the act,of deb - so as not to make previous holders parties liable - was considered in order and passed tho House of Representatives on the third and last reading - yeas 78, nays 5.
Mr. Power's bill (30) to repeal the Court of Conciliation act, was laid on the table - Mr. Hamilton of Boone's bill for the same object having been rejected.
Mr. Clement's bill (182) was also laid on the table, as superceded matter.
Mr. Hunter's' bill (182) authorizing county Auditors to collect moneys belonging to the common school fund, and providing punishment for his failure of duty therein, coming up -
Mr. CLEMENTS could not vote for a bill increasing the criminal code, multiplying, inconsiderately, the number of offences for which a man may be fined and imprisoned.
Mr. BOYD would vote for the bill if that part relating to imprisoning the negligent auditor were not retained.
It was stricken out, by unanimous consent, and so the bill passed the House of Representatives, yeas 81, nays 4.

div.head: AFTERNOON SESSION.
div.p: Mr. SULLIVAN asked and obtained leave to submit the following:
Resolved, That the Door-keeper be instructed to remove immediately the palings placed around the lobbies of the House of Representatives.
Mr. CAVINS moved to lay the resolution on the table
The motion was agreed to - yeas 37, nays 30.
Mr. SHIELD, by consent, submitted an order, which was adopted, to send back to the Senate Mr. Mansfield's bill, N . 147.
Pending this order - Mr. EDWARDS and Mr. CLEMENTS inquired if the object of this bill as to favor certain subscribers to stock in the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad, and who have not yet paid in?
Mr. SHIELDS denied.

div.head: THE CALENDAR.
div.p: The SPEAKER then pursued the calendar of bills on the third and last reading in the House of Representatives, and he asked and obtained leave of absence till to-morrow morning - calling Mr. Edward's to the Chair.
Mr. Stanfield's bill (176) to amend section 19 of the first chapter of the practice act, was passed the final reading - yeas 56, nays 15.
Mr. Snyder's bill (165) to amend section 18 of the misdemeanor act of June 14, 1852, repealing disfranchisement for fraudulent indictment, was passed the final reading - yeas 81, nays 8.
Mr. Black's bill (149), to amend the 11th and 18th sections of the act concerning the partition of land, approved May 20, 1852, was passed the final reading - yeas 77, nays 2.
Mr. Mellett's bill (186), to amend section 103 of the criminal practice act of June 17 1852, to give the State the closing argument; in ie criminal cases, coming up -
Mr. STILES resisted it.
Messrs. MELLETT and PROSSER supported it
Mr. DAVIS proposed to recommit to the Judiciary Committee, with instructions -
To amend so as to give the Prosecuting Attorney himself the right to close the argument.
On motion by Mr. COLLIER, this motion and instructions were laid on the table.
The bill was then passed the final reading yeas 53, nays 37.

Mr. Edward's bill (174) to authorize the constitutional enumeration of the white male inhabitants of this State, over the age of 21 years for the year 1859, was rejected on the third reading yeas 35, nays 53.

div.head: SUPERVISOR'S ACT
div.p: Mr. Massey's bill (77), to revise the Supervisor's act, coming up -

Mr. MASSEY asked unanimous consent to amend the bill so as to make it conform to the one township trustee system; but Mr. Comstock and Mr. Prosser objected - asking if the only object was to make the bill conform to the one trustee system.
Mr. MASSEY. That is the only object.
Mr. COMSTOCK withdrew his objections.
Mr. HALL, of Rush, moved ineffectually, to refer with instructions.
Mr. RYNERSON moved to recommit with instructions to inquire into the expediency of amending as proposed by Mr. Massey.
Mr. CLEMENTS feared there was not time to refer again. He desired the passage of the bill.
Mr. BOYD proposed to amend the instructions to strike out all that relates to taxation to keep up the roads.
Mr. COMSTOCK. The bill proposes an imperative tax of five cents on the $100. This was a discrimination in favor of the poor.
Mr. BOYD. Still it was a double tax upon labor and upon property.
Mr. DOBBINS defended the imperative tax.
Mr. PROSSER withdrew his objections.
Mr. MURRAY. This bill had been matured with care, and he hoped that it would be allowed to pass, with conformity to the change to the trustee system.

Mr. HALL, of Rush, considered the powers of the supervisors for assessment should be limited to 10 or 12 cents on the $100, and that some limit should be fixed as to the number of days a man may be called out
Mr. PARKS wished to have the tax apportioned to the real estate of the districts.
On motion by Mr. MURRAY, the motion to recommit, &c., was laid on the table.
Mr. KNOWLTON demanded the previous question, and there was a second, but -
On motion by Mr. CLEMENTS, it was reconsidered, and the amendment was withdrawn.
Mr. CLEMENTS now hoped the amendments of Mr. Massey would be adopted by unanimous consent. ["No consent."]
On motion by Mr. ROBINSON, the vote on engrossment was reconsidered.
Mr. ROBINSON moved to recommit the bill.
On motion by Mr. SHULL, that motion was laid on the table.
On motion by Mr. HAMILTON, of Boone, Mr. Massey's amendments were taken from the table, and adopted, and then -
The bill was again considered as engrossed, (as now amended , and passed the final reading in the House of Representatives - yeas is 56, nays 34 - as follows:

YEAS - Messrs. Blythe, Carr, Clark, Claypool, Clayton, Clements, Comstock, Dobbins, Dougherty, Devol, Early, Eastham, Fordyce, Gregory, Griffin, Hall of Grant, Hamilton of Boone, Hamilton of Wayne, Hancock, Harney, Harrison, Hunter, Johnston, Jones, Keefer, Kempf, Knowlton, Lawhead, Lewis, Major, Mansfield, Massey, Merrifield, Miller, Murray, Nebeker of Vermillion, Nebeker of Warren, Nelson, Newton, Prosser, Ritter, Rynearson, Scott, Sherman, Shockley, Shull, Smith of Perry, Stanfield, Stiles, Sullivan, Summers, Thompson of Madison, Treadway, Wheeler, Whetzel and Wood. - 56.

NAYS - Messrs Austin, Bowman, Boyd, Boxley, Brotherton, Cavins, Colgrove, Collier, Cotton, Davidson, Davis, Durham, Edwards, Gifford, Hall of Rush, Hartley, Jeffres, Jordan, Kelly, McLain, Martin, Parks, Robinson, Row, Shields, Smith of Miami, Snyder, Stanley, Tebbs, Thompson of Elkhart, Usrey, Waterman, Whiteman and Wildman - 34.

div.head: WORK FOR COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. Gregory's bill (324) was referred to Messrs. Gregory, Durham and Hartley.
Mr. Knowlton's (325) was ordered to be engrossed.
On motion bv Mr. BRANHAM, the bills Nos. S. 81, 78, 77, 58, 41, 79, 103, 38, fi8. 62, 46, 55, 64, 67, 73, 187, 101, 134, 45, 251, 255. 212, and 282, were passed the first reading.
Mr. Black, by leave, presented the petition of Speer, Case & Co , asking compensation for arresting a fugitive from justice, which was referred to the Committee on Claims.
Mr. Tebbs' bill (320), Mr. Edwards' (324), and Mr. Major's bill (329), were referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. Branham's (331), and Mr. Dougherty's (318), and Mr. Stanfield's (319), were ordered to be engrossed.
Mr. Miller's bill (293) was referred to the Committee on Fees and Salaries
Mr. Treadway's (322) was referred to Messrs. Rynearson, Smith of Perry, and Smith of Miami.
Mr. Waterman's (326) was referred to the Committee on Public Expenditures.
Mr. Carr's bill (327) was referred to Mesrs. Carr, Nebeker or Warren, Davis, Hanfield and Devol.
Mr. Knowlton's (330), was referred to the Judiciary Committee.

Mr. RITTER, by leave, from the Committee on Buildings, returned the committee's hill (297) for the erection of a building for State offices, with verbal amendments, which was adopted, and the bill was ordered to be engrossed.
The bill (S. 2[9?]3), providing for Boards of Trustees and Commissioners of the Benevolent Institutions, was referred to the Committee on Benevolent Institutions.
The bill (S. 207), in relation to the salaries of the Judges of the Supreme and Circuit Courts and Prosecuting Attorneys, was ordered to the third reading; also the bill S. No. 240.
The bill S. No. 51, was referred to the Committee on Rights and Privileges.
The bill from the Senate, No. 50, was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary
The SPEAKER laid before the House a communication from the Auditor of State, suggesting the sale of lots south of the canal, in the town of Indianapolis, by authority of law.

Mr. SMITH, of Perry, by unanimous consent, introduced a bill (335), to authorize the sale of certain lots in the town of Indianapolis, which was passed the first reading, [It provides for the sale of the out lot south of the cross-cut canal, and the south-west corner of lot No. 50].
The House then, at 9 o'clock, adjourned.

div.head: IN SENATE.
div.p: On motion by Mr. HEFFREN, the reading of the journal was dispensed with.

div.head: REPORTS FROM COMMITTEES.
div.p: Mr. MARCH, from the Judiciary Committee, returned Mr. Heffren's bill 106, recommending passage. Also, the petition of John Zount, recommending that it lie on the table.
Mr. ANTHONY, from the same committee, returned Mr. Robinson's bill 239, recommending passage. Also, Mr. Tarkington's, 232, recommending indefinite postponement.
Mr. CONNER, from the Committee on Corporations, returned his bill 252, recommending passage.

Mr. BLAIR, from the same committee, returned his bill 14, Mr. Carnahan's bill 9, and a memorial from Posey and Vanderburg counties praying for a more uniform mode of doing township business, recommending that they lie on the table.
Mr. LOMAX, from the Committee on Rights and privileges, returned his bill 190,recommending passage.
Mr. GREEN, from a select committee thereon, returned bis bills 243 and 244, recommending passage.
These reports were severally concurred in.

Mr. SHOEMAKER, from the Committee on Roads, returned Mr. Turner's bill (221) empowering supervisors of highways to keep in repair roads which have been changed by the construction or running of railroads, recommending passage.
The bill, on motion, was read the third time and passed, by yeas 28, nays 11.
Mr. BOBBS, from a select committee thereon, returnee. Mr. Odell's bill 222, with amendments, recommending passage.
Mr. RICE, from a select committee thereon, returned Mr. Wagner's bill, 249, recommending passage.
Which reports were concurred in.
Mr. MARCH, by leave, introduced a bill (259) to prohibit persons from preventing, hindering or delaying specie payments by the banks of thia State.

div.head: THE PUBLICATION OF LAWS.
div.p: Mr. JONES moved to reconsider the vote taken last night on the passage of Mr. Conner's bill (166) providing for the publication of laws, [described on page 138 of these reports.]
Mr. JOHNSTON was in favor of reconsidering the vote. He thought it would be a great expense with no comparative benefit resulting therefrom.
Mr. GREEN opposed reconsideration.

Mr. CONNER explained the provisions of his bill. He was willing to publish the laws in more than one paper in each county, if the Senate would consent; but if we cannot have that, let us have the act passed by the Senate last night.
Mr. MILLER voted against the law last, might, but he has since become satisfied it is right,and should vote against reconsideration.
Mr. HEFFREN moved to lay the motion on the table.
The motion was agreed to, by yeas 22, nays 18 - as follows:
YEAS - Messrs. Beeson, Bermett, Blair, Carnahan, Conley. Conner, Craven, Culver, Fisk, Green, Heffren, Hendry, Kinley, McClure, McLean, Miller, Murray, Odell, Rice, Slack, Steele and Stevens - 22
NAYS - Messrs. Anthony, Bobbs, Brown, Cobb, Gooding, Hamilton, Hargrove, Johnston, Jones, Line, Lomax, Robinson. Shoemaker, Thompson, Turner, Wagner, Williams and Wilson - 18.

The select committee thereon, returned the petition of the Cumberland Presbyterian and Plymouth Congregational Church, praying for the use of the Senate Chamber on Sundays, during the recess of the Legislature; recommending the adoption of a resolution granting the prayer of said petitioners.
The resolution was adopted, by yeas 29, nays 15.

A message from the Governor announced his approval and signature of Mr. Slack's bill (255), to provide for the application of any surplus that may remain in the hands of the Auditor of State after the redemption of the circulation of any bank, or banking association where such bank or banking association has received on deposit money belonging to the State, and has failed to pay the same.
